Gorgeous gardens with Rodin's famous sculptures throughout. Unbelievable number of studies and sculptures in museum. He was quite prolific. Also a few Van Goghs!I highly recommend. A highlight of our trip to Paris.

amazing!!. to see the masterpieces of Auguste Rodin it's an important for all judge of art. We can see how piece of stone or marble can be transform into masterpiece of art in hands of unique master. I had sometimes a feeling that some figures could come to life. Besides there is a beautiful garden to enjoy walking.

Expected more. Quite frankly, I knew that this couldn't quite beat our experience in the galleria borghese in Rome, but I didn't think I wouldn't like this museum. I wasn't really attracted to any of the pieces, and the thinker was under renovation process. Regarding The gates of hell, it was a great piece of art but the inside of the mansion really did disappoint me. A good stop if you're going to the invalides next.

Great Gardens. A spur of the moment decision to visit but well worth the €4 admission to the gardens. Well kept and relaxed grounds and a really wide range of sculptures with detailed information in 3 languages. The cafe is expensive so bring your own food! We didn't pay to go in the house but we're very happy with what we saw!

Calm, elegant and great value . This was not a stop we had planned to make, but we decided to buy a €4 ticket to visit the gardens and see the sculptures outside. Well worth it for a close up of The Penseur alone. Beautiful grounds, interesting artworks - didn't realise Rodin was so obsessed with Hell and the destruction of man! - and a lovely little cafe to enjoy a cold drink and ice cream on a sunny summer afternoon. Wholly recommend.
Quite small. The museum is quite small and can be quite crowded if there are a lot of people. The gardens have nothing special (except the sculptures of course).

A tranquil oasis. This is one of the best attractions in Paris. The sculptures are, of course fantastic, but the house and gardens are lovely in their simplicity. You can spend a couple of hours just quietly enjoying the world go by, with the Eiffel tower and Les Invalides in the background. The restaurant serves excellent food at a reasonable price for Paris. It is not to be missed

Incredible Volume of Work. A French friend of ours suggested we go to the Musée Rodin, as she thought that we’d enjoy it. She was right. The Musée Rodin is comprised of two parts – a two-story mansion housing the museum and 7.4 acres of gardens. It was raining very lightly as my wife and I meandered through the gardens of Musée Rodin, but the rain couldn’t dampen our appreciation or admiration of the unbelievable number of sensational large bronze sculptures scattered throughout the entire garden. Every one of them is breathtaking. Being close enough to touch Rodin’s creations of the large bronze sculptures known as “The Thinker,” “The Three Shades,” “The Gates of Hell,” and “The Monument to the Burghers of Calais” (just past the entrance in the front part of the garden) alone were worth the price of admission; everything else was a bonus. Near the back of the garden is a large pond in the middle of which is the famous large bronze sculpture of “Ugolino and His Children.”There are more amazing exhibits in the two-story mansion that houses the museum holding much of Rodin’s work, including many Rodin’s smaller bronze sculptures, marble sculptures, ceramics, drawings, prints, paintings, and photographs. Being able to admire Rodin’s famous creations, including “The Kiss,” “Fall of Illusion,” “The Call of Arms,” and the “Pedestal of the Titans,” to name only a few, was a real treat. The museum also displays many ancient works of art that Rodin collected from Egypt, Greece, and Rome, and then later from the Far East.Auguste Rodin was an extremely prolific artist over his 77 years; the gardens and the museum beautifully display much of his work. A truly awe-inspiring experience.

Comprehensive Rodin. We really enjoyed our morning immersed in Rodin.The gardens are beautifully kept with a wonderful range of exhibits. The gardens are easy to walk. The cafe offers a good range of food and beverages.The house has been beautifully restored. The exhibits were set out throughout the building over all levels.It was easy to move through and there were not large numbers of people so it was very comfortable.

Amazing Experience. Beautiful museum and sculptures in outdoor gardens. Very peaceful place to stroll and enjoy art outdoors. We had lunch in outdoor cafeteria, excellent, a must do. Give yourself time, not a place to rush through.
some of the best stuff. I was quite surprised and pleased at the wide variety of art work. The sculptures are especially pleasing.

You can TOUCH and stroke and love these statues.... This is a wonderfully laid out museum... hardly a museum more of a statue'd delight. Admire Rodin's obsession with FEET... his people all had lovely feet, and gasp at the size of The Kiss, and giggle at the Thinker in the garden on his toilet. A superb day off here, and they will let you back in after lunch in a nearby brasserie. Grand value. Adam and Eve.. just admire their glorious bodies.

Lovely garden. With all art Paris is offering, Musee Rodin may be a secondary choice on a Sunday afternoon to enjoy the garden. The collection is quite good but if in hurry just a visit to the garden would be sufficient.
if you love Rodin, this is a must. Sadly, we were here while the house was being worked on. so I saw nothing inside. But the gardens and the works...beautiful
love this place. The Rodin Museum is a lovely place to visit on a regular basis. Lots of his works on display and the garden is just as wonderful.
Magnificent collection. Very well-presented, comprehensive collection of Rodin's work. Terrific gardens with sculptures in various places. Decent food available in the garden.
Great museum. Love the sculptures, and that so many are in such a small space without crowding each other. Rodin was a genius, and this place is a treasure.

Peaceful artistic journey with Rodin. What a beautiful peaceful place in the heart of Paris, near the eiffel tower. The "penseur" was unfortunately being pampered, refreshing shower. The building is magic, the pieces of art heartbreaking. Sometimes you get the feeling the sculptures will come to life around the corner. Walk in the parc was relaxing.

Gardens are sufficient. With so many museums and galleries in Paris, we decided to skip the Rodin museum and just pay for entry to the Sculpture Garden. We bought an audio guide and thoroughly enjoyed the peace and beauty of the gardens and sculptures and the information provided through the audio guide. If you are time limited yet still want to see Rodin's Thinker and other significant sculptures (e.g. Gates of Hell), then just visiting the Gardens is a fabulous option.

Beautiful grounds and statues. Nice quiet gardens with lots of statues. Would give 5 stars but unfortunately when we were there Le Penseur (The Thinker) was covered up as it was being cleaned and restored. Would have been nice if they mentioned this when we paid for entry as it was the main purpose of us deciding to go here. In any case the gardens and statues were nice.

Smaller more intimate Museum. Certainly a highlight for us, like vex the sculptures, paintings and gardens. Loved the history of the lost art of casting.This is easier to maneuver through than most. Gardens are beautiful

Fascinating and compact with lovely garden. Anyone with an interest in sculpture would love this museum. Great explanations of the creative process and the lost wax method of casting bronze. Rodin donated the home and gardens and many of the works thus creating his own museum. There are also paintings from his collection by Monet and Van Gogh. The room about Camille Claudel, his protegee, is full of her beautiful work! Gardens have a small cafe -- you might be able to bring a picnic -- lots of shade and trees with benches. It is compact and not overwhelming.
Not a highlight. With so much to see in Paris Musee Rodin doesn't really take a priority but yes if you are staying in the city for a while it's worth a visit.

Unforgettable, Outstanding Exhibits Reflecting the Life and Times of Rodin. Over 18 individual galleries taking you through the timeline and trajectory of Rodin's personal and artistic career, elements well intertwined. Themes from Dante's Divine Comedy run throughout Rodin's works, therefore I suggest a brief review (think Cliff Notes) of the stories and characters to better appreciate these remarkable works and what inspired them.Definitely buy the additional tickets for the Gardens which amplify some of the works within and provide a shady respite and additional photo opps during your visit to this treasure of a collection.

Lovely stroll in the Jardin Des Scultpures for only €4!. In the interest of time and budget, we decided to only visit the gardens of the Musee Rodin and it was definitely worth the price of the ticket. You get your share of Rodin sculpture and the gardens are beautiful and peaceful, with benches and a nice café to spend as much time as you want there.

Great museum.. Smaller, compared to Louvre and Orsay, but beautiful, intimate, and charming. Wonderful garden with his sculptures. His works are arranged in separate rooms, so you can enjoy and avoid the crowd. Worth it.

Master Sculptor's Exhibit. When I was a kid few of the artworks were sent to Kolkata for an exhibition. I saw them in that exhibition but was too young to appreciate them and apprehended them to be ghosts. Now after my visit I can say I have done justice to them. It is a must visit place while in Paris if you love sculptures. It does not have mad rush like the Louvre. You can enjoy the artwork peacefully.You can also buy little memorabilia from the shop outside. However the new fad of taking selfie with the sculptures was quite irritating. But you cannot always help !!

Fantastic collection and beautiful gardens. I highly recommend this museum. You will need plenty of time to look through the house and all of the sculptures and artwork inside. The museum organized the artwork and sculptures in a lovely way based chronologically. There are not really any English explanations next to the artwork and sculptures so either get an audio guide or do research before arriving. You also need a lot of additional time to go through all of the gardens. Definitely arrive with an appetite because the café is lovely. There are tables and chairs or bring a blanket and have a picnic. There is a very convenient metro stop right by the museum.

A gem :). Loved walking around the garden filled with roses and 'le penseur'! Too bad i'm not that much into sculptures.. Yet still I was so happy to see the masterpiece of Van Gogh in this museum. Felt so blessed to look at 'le pere tanguy' which I had been longing to see!

Much expanded museum experience. I hadn't been here since 1985. The lay out and the depth of the museum has expanded dramatically. This is no longer a "one hour-see "The Thinker" visit. Great effort has been put into areas that demonstrate how Rodin evolved and how other artists, but ancient and his contemporaries, influenced him. It is still a small museum, but if you are interested in Rodin, it will now leave you even more appreciative than before.

The outdoor area is beautiful to enjoy on a sunny day. My daughter and I visited in March and the weather was perfect the day we were there. We sat on a bench at looked at the Gates of Hell for a long time -- so much to see! It's beautiful! There are so many beautiful pieces to see here -- don't miss it!

What a pleasant surprise!. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed Paris, but this by far was my favorite museum. It is not mobbed like the Louvre and you can really enjoy these wonderful pieces of art and sculpture without hundreds of people trying to take selfies with them. We also ate at the eatery in the museum which was lovely as well. I couldn't believe how close you could get to my favorite sculpture "the kiss"

A calm island in Paris to relax and enjoy art and the scenery.. Accidentally walked into this Museum like areal and were not disappointed. Suggest to go for the less expensive ticket which still allows full access into the mail building including many of Rodin's work and the parks. At a sunny day a must see!

Wonderful museum exhibiting Rodin's famous works. If you are fond of Rodin works, this is a place you should not miss. The museum is very well organized including indoor and outdoor exhibits of Rodin's sculptures. The indoor exhibition includes a number of rooms that you can tour consecutively to admire Rodin's art. The outdoor also includes scattered pieces that would attract your mind. The museum also caters a shop were you can find books, and small imitations of Rodin's work for sale.

Put it on your places to visit. Wonderful museum with sculptures scattered throughout the rear gardens. Also, numerous works in the house. It was not crowded when we visited, which was a pleasant change after visiting the Louvre.

"Le penseur ". The great sculpture of the "le penseur " was under renovation that was bit of disappointment otherwise All the sculpture are magnificent and with lot of details and with that you can see paintings and sculptures of other artists too .A must visit

Often overlooked, less crowded, and amazing grounds.. Make this a must see! There is so much more to experience here than The Thinker, impressive in it's own right, but not even the highlight of our visit.

Thinker Covered in Plastic. Be aware that as if Tuesday July 12,2016 The Thinker was covered due to restoration. Otherwise museum great as always but disappointed. Staff said the had no idea when it would be uncovered.

Beautiful Gardens. In the summer time when the weather is hot, you can come and have a great time watching amazing rodin's statues. sincerely a great place to have picnic as well. As we did of course :)
A treasure. This is my favorite museum in Paris. After five visits here, I'm still in awe of the magnificence of Rodin's work.

Small but interesting. There is a nice garden with sculptures, in addition to the main building. Can get up close to everything.Not a busy spot so it is fast to get in.Enjoyed seeing the various versions of some of his work.

Beautiful Sculptures and Gardens. Magnificent museum spanning the years of Rodin's sculptures. What makes this museum so special are the beautifully sculpted gardens in which many of Rodin's sculptures are displayed. An absolute must see when in Paris! The museum not only displays Rodin but houses major works of Van Gogh, Monet and Cezanne. Go on a nice weather day to truly appreciate the beauty of the gardens.

Beautiful, quick, next to war museum.. If you go to the war museum you should definitely go to the Musee Rodin. It is right next door. It has many sculptures outside and it is small. It is a perfect way to spend a half hour absorbing a bit of culture and seeing 'the thinker'. The kids even liked it

Favorite Museum in Paris. This museum is two separate spaces, the gardens and the mansion, and either would be an excellent museum in their own regard. I would advise that you pay attention to the weather to decide whether to start inside or outside. I started outside, and just as I was going inside it started to rain. The gardens are beautiful and some of the pieces are placed within them. Make sure you get the audio guide and follow it around the garden, then go inside and continue the tour.

Amazing building, beautiful building. The Musee Rodin is a small and beautiful museum to visit while in Paris. It is less packed than the bigger ones and thus easier to get a good view of the statues spread in the beautiful gardens.

Absolutely lovely!. Towards the end of a recent visit to Paris, a friend and I ducked into the Musée Rodin gardens for a moment of shady tranquility. We sat under the trees and enjoyed a most delicious little salad (with caper berries - I LOVE caper berries!), then strolled the gardens and enjoyed the magnificent sculptures and surrounding flowers - roses! Hydrangeas! Wow! It was so nice to just slow down, relax, and soak in one of the most beautiful museums in Paris ... it was relatively uncrowded, peaceful, cool and breezy (on a very warm day) ... perfect!

Perfect museum experience. Spent two hours at this amazing collection of Rodin works - really well-curated, easy to navigate, very enjoyable time. Both the inside and outside exhibits are worth exploring. Highly recommend it!

The Garden is Great!. While the building section of this museum isn't as large as something like the Musee d'Orsay, the garden is what truly sets this place apart. You can spend a lot of time lazily strolling through the sculpture garden and admiring the works that are spread throughout. The building is well-organized and still pleasant to walk through, but there are other museums where you could do that sort of thing. There is also a cafe here if you'd like to spend some extra time just taking in the scenery.

Cool Museum. The better stuff is out in the gardens, and The Thinker was being restored while were there. The stuff inside the building is interesting too but isn't air-conditioned so we ended up going through it fairly quickly.

Under visited. My son and I had a wonderful visit at the Rodin Museum. The gardens were lovely and not crowded. There is s lovely cafe and places to sit outside. The sculptures are just beautiful and you can get close enough to really experience it. Each piece has an English written description. Highly recommended

Peace and quiet within Paris hustle-bustle. While doing the museums of Paris we came upon the Rodin. It's in a building the sculptor had a studio in, and has many sculptures on display. Most significant is the garden where many sculptures are also, but it's a beautiful and quiet place to to take a break from the noise of the street. The house and garden is a postcard setting, so be sure to take you camera. Note this is an independent museum, privately funded which is very unusual. A great refreshing break not to be missed.

One of my favorites . I've visited Paris many times. I almost always stop in to the Musée Rodin on my trips. I love to stroll through the museum then spend a leisurely time in the gardens relaxing with a coffee or just reading a book.
Beautiful museum with an outstanding garden. The museum itself is excellent, but the garden is outstanding, big, pleasant and very relaxing, in a luxurious way. Nice for a romantic outing.

Loved this museum!. Many of the sculptures are on display in the gardens; we did those first and enjoyed that part of the visit most. It was a pleasant walk among trees to see everything, and we enjoyed time at the cafe while we visited. The house was much busier, yet still worth the time. I wouldn't hesitate to visit this museum again - the outdoor part was a favorite for me on our Paris visit.

Perfect spot for a sculpture enthusiasts!. One can easily spend half a day in Musee Rodin. It is named after one of the best French sculptors and houses the majority of his works, along with a few other which fall into Rodin's way of sculpting. Apart from the fantastic works of art here, the location can be of an interest. There is a large pool with green areas all around it and you can enjoy a relaxing atmosphere after your visit. The statue of the thinking man is the ultimate piece on the outside.

Do not miss out on this if Art is your thing!. Rodins sculptures are just exquisite. Truly a highlight.... it's not extensible and the house they are kept in is spectacular anyway if you are into architecture. The sculptures themselves are breathtaking. Very moving indeed to see them in the flesh. A must see in Paris!

Wonderful museum, splurge to get the audio guide. This place is a gem. It completely follows the life of Rodin. The audio guides were wonderful and easy to use. The museum is small enough where you can listen to it all. I think the inside part is about 1 1/2 hours and the gardens are another 1/2 hour. But you can easily get lost in the history and the sculptures and the time whizzes by. What I learned from this tour will stay with me forever!

Gorgeous house and gardens in addition to Rodin works of art. The audio tour was a bit long-winded and hard to follow but overall an enjoyable museum to visit. The garden was a pretty setting but underutilized.

Peaceful oasis. We went on a recommendation and were happy we did. The museum is the mansion Rodin lived in until he died. We found the exhibits were informative but not compelling, and it can be very crowded inside too.The real treat and for us, the only reason for visiting, was strolling through the extensive walled sculpture gardens and enjoying the 25 works all beautifully presented. The gardens themselves are a welcome oasis in an otherwise non-stop city - and the bronze castings each capture so much depth it is hard to say anything other than "awesome!". I think even non-fans of Rodin would be impressed.Best to plan a couple hours or so and take your time. There's a garden side cafe to rest and have drinks or bites. The first Sunday of each month is free - and the combination ticket to the Musee d'Orsay (a must see) and the Musee Rodin is 18 euros. See the Musee d'Orsay web site. The Musee Rodin web site shows admission to the sculpture garden alone at just 5.30 euros.

Varieties of Rodin's Sculptures, Numbers of Marble, Bronze, Plaster, Ceramics, Paintings, Drawings. Auguste Rodin (羅丹, Full Name: Francois Auguste Rene Rodin, 1840 - 1917) was a famous French sculptor. In 1916, Rodin donated his collections to the France Government, including sculptures and drawings, along with the reproduction rights. The Musee Rodin (羅丹美術館) in Paris, France is a museum that opened 2 years after his death in 1919 and was dedicated to his works. We thought there was only one Musee Rodin in France at the Hotel Biron and its surrounding grounds in Paris. Later we learned there is another museum of Rodin just outside Paris at Rodin's old home, the Villa des Brillants at Meudon which Auguste Rodin bought on December 19, 1895. It was reopened on March 4, 2016. Rodin is considered as one of the most remarkable sculptors of his time. The collections include 6,600 sculptures, 8,000 drawings, 8,000 old photographs and 7,000 objet d'art (art object or work of art).We visited Rodin Museum in Philadelphia, PA, USA in 2012 and saw some of his famous sculptures. This time we had the chance to visit Musee Rodin in Paris. We took the metro line 12 to the Solferino station and walked to the museum. The walk took us 20+ minutes although it looked like only a short distance on the map. When we finally arrived at the gate, there was a security check and then we went to the building of museum (Hotel Biron). The major difference compared with the one we visited in Philadelphia was the quantities and varieties of the collections. Its displays include not only sculptures, but also numbers of marble, bronze, plaster, ceramics, paintings, drawings, and works by other artists (Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh) from his personal collections. You are allowed to take as many photos as you like without using flash. The major problem was the strong sunlight and the glass cabinets make it almost impossible to take a clear shot. Once we went through the indoor exhibitions, we went outside to the garden and found those famous sculptures like The Thinker, The Three Shades and The Gates of Hell. The pool in front of the museum is another lovely location to enjoy the museum (Hotel Biron).The closest metro station is Saint-Francois-Xavier (not the Varenne), and it takes you about 7 minutes to reach the museum. We found a wonderful feature of the museum - the open-air restaurant in the garden. You do not need to rush out for a meal but can sit on either side of the path with trees along the path. It was a lovely and unforgettable experience in addition to visiting the museum. Try to go there before noon so you can pick the table you like and enjoy it.

Beautiful Grounds. The grounds were so nice on a sunny, spring day. The collection is quite interesting and the museum has never been overly crowded on any of my visits. This is a nice break from the huge museums.
A must see. Ornate trappings, fabulous gardens, an art historian's dream. Take your time. Enjoy. The sensuality in the pieces is palpable. Stroll. Great cinema almost next door, La Pagode.

Rodin was a different kind of Sculptor. His work is very unique and often shows his subjects in contorted positions. The pieces speak volumns about the statue. Each one has a story but we all see them from a different perspective. Very Cool!
Enjoyable. A small, but interesting museum displaying some of Rodin's incredible pieces of work. The grounds are gorgeous and so very peaceful.

My new favorite museum in Paris!. The Musee Rodin is a nice break from all the large and overwhelming museums in Paris. I love that you start in the beautiful garden looking over the sculptures. What a lovely place to take photos and walk around on a nice day! The museum is the perfect size and has a nice collection of Rodin sculptures as well as art from other artists that worked with and inspired Rodin. The museum has recently been refurbished and is just beautiful! This is a great spot to spend a few hours or even an afternoon. If I lived in Paris I'd visit here on a regular basis just to spend time in the garden!
Wonderful. If you like art and want to see something really special, go there..you will love it..there is also a picture of Edvard Munch..nice
don't miss it. this is a great museum, very interesting exhibits and beautiful grounds to explore. I would highly recommend it
Amazingly Beautiful Museum. We loved visiting the rose-garden and sculpture heaven of the Musee Rodin! It is a must see in Paris!

This museum has been underrated. This museum didn't get enough attention that it deserved. Maybe because I am also into sculptures, Ordin provided a decent volume of respectable collection here. Of course Louvre has more but Louvre is also X-th times bigger that tires you out. This museum is way smaller but also makes the whole visit very enjoyable
Nice Treat. This museum and gardens were such a nice surprise. Of course you'll see the Thinker, but you'll also see countless other beautiful bronzes and works collected by Rodin.

Rodin's Museum nee studio. There is animation in the museum that explains the lost-wax technique for bronze casting. All placards, as in most museums of Paris, are in French only. I have been told that there is another Rodin Museum in his former home.

Awesome sculptures, neat paintings, bad lighting. Searching for ever more famous art, we stopped into Musee Rodin to see "The Thinker." With poor weather and overcast skies the sculpture was not at its best because of a lack of lighting. In fact poor lighting in all aspects is why this museum is so disappointing it should get a 5, but cannot because if what you miss due to horrible lighting throughout. The artwork is second to none. The location is fine. The presentation of sculptures with poor direct lighting, and some encased in glass, as well as pictures behind glass require delicate, but appropriate lighting. Compared to L'Orangerie museum this place's lighting is an injustice to the art work. The garden is beautiful and the totality of Rodin's work (as The Thinker is contemplating his work of Hell/Hades/Underworld) is magnificent - just all needs better lighting. Enjoy.

Wondderful little museum with beautiful grounds in the heart of Paris.. This is near the office in which I was working, so when we finished early one day I walked over. Try to go when the weather is nice, because there are lovely grounds and gardens and some of the most famous works you probably expect to see (The Thinker, Three Shades, Gates of Hell) are of course outside.
Luv this museum!. This museum is awesome. The garden is beautiful. This was my second time visiting the site and it is even better with the renovations.

Glad we made time for the Rodin this trip. The Rodin was closed for renovations last year, so we were very glad to get to visit this time. It was absolutely terrific, both the sculpture and paintings, but also the gardens themselves and the home. I was particularly smitten with the interior decoration -- the plaster cornices, wall color, chandeliers, etc. I also very much enjoyed seeing Rodin's paintings, which I was fairly ignorant of, previously. We had a simple lunch in the cafe in the garden and enjoyed it also.

Might be my favorite spot in Paris. The fiancé and I love the place. The view of the tower acting as a background for the Thinker is worth seeing all by itself. Great picture moments to be had along with a lot of history.
A Must visit. This museum is must in your to do list while visitng Paris . The gardens is bery nice ,i let the photos speaks for themselves.

Highlights only. We visited the Rodin on the way to a reservation at the Eiffel Tower, so we only hit the highlights. As with most Paris museums, the children's admission was free. We spent the most time at the Gates of Hell, but also enjoyed seeing the Burghers of Calais and the outdoor Thinker. The interior is spacious and light, with the sculptures well displayed, but the gardens with the sculptures are the best.

A Paris Oasis. This is a great place to lose yourself in history. The villa is outstanding but the stroll through the garden is absolutely breathtaking. A great place to sit and watch people against the backdrop of the beautiful works of PA Rodin, The only drawback is it becomes quite crowded on weekends. Best to visit during the week.

A great collection of Rodin's works. The jewel of this site is not the museum, but the sculpture gardens in the rear. An exquisite place to rest, enjoy a gelato, and take in the art, including the, "Thinker" and a casting of the door fore the Gates of Hell.

Beautiful gardens and artwork. Rodin's artwork - sculptures, statues, gardens - all gorgeous and immaculately maintained. Very large house. Beautiful architecture style. Very ornate. Detailed craftsmanship.

If I could .... I'd live there!. Simply stunning! Perfect manicured gardens, sculptures, park benches to sit and just enjoy the surrounds and a small cafe in the gardens where you can grab a drink and a snack!
good visit. good visit during raining day. I am surprised even the weather is bad the museum can still attract so many people.
Cool. I had high expectations about this museum but it's not as good as it seems. The garden it's the best thing about this museum.

Wonderful gardens. What a surprise to discover such beautiful gardens behind the huge stone walls and gate in the middle of Paris. Some of Rodin's most famous works - the Thinker and the Gates of Hell are located in the gardens. The museum also houses another of his famous works - the Kiss. A gem of a museum - not too big and overwhelming.

Will have to go back. We got to this museum late in the day and didn't really know what to expect. There is a lot here from "The Thinker" to some various pieces that were done as trial and error practices. Many sculptures to see but we didn't have a lot of time to do it. The one nice this was the shadows that fell on the busts while we were there at the end of the day made for some photographic eye candy. We didn't meet a lot of crowds here but it may have been because we were later in the day.

Please note my rating is because of the display. The ART is incredible. Rodin was a genius. Those running this place not so much.Much of Rodin's work was designed to be shown together to produce a certain emotional response, like the elements of a fine meal. What these barbarians have done is separate them so that each item is seen in isolation.Would you eat a salad with the lettuce on one plate, the tomatoes on another and the chives hidden behind the salt?It's bad enough with Les Bourgeois de Calais, but to separate the components of The Gates of Hell is like dissecting a beautiful woman and asking us to appreciate her with her organs in glass jars.The final insult is that they took one of the elements of this masterpiece, Fallen Caryatid Carrying her Stone, was surrounded by plastic and unpainted plywood evidently in preparation where the directing tasteless could entertain other tasteless barbarians with bad wine and putrefying fingerfood while those who appreciate art could look on with horror.
Fabulous bronze sculptures . Rodin's "The Thinker" and all other major works are here. Recently reopened after renovation this museum is another "Must see" in Paris. Beautiful chateau and gardens.

Great setting. The big house is a neat place to exhibit Rodan's sculptures, but the garden is the best. Such a great setting and worth the money. Get the Paris Museum Pass for the best values at many museums in Paris.

I love sculpture!. OK, we decided that we are sculpture junkies and this was a great way to see how these sculptures were created. Very interesting and had some Van Gogh's and other paintings that I had never seen before. Unfortunately, while we were touring the home museum, it started pouring outside and we weren't able to go through the gardens.

Wonderful ground, hidden treasures. Enjoyed this visit very much. The gardens are really very nice with hidden treasures around every corner of the walk ways. The main house itself is almost as interesting from an architectural aspect as the art within.

Wonderful Visit. Very nice museum, my wife enjoyed it a lot.This museum (as with all the others) are covered by the Paris Museum Pass which can be purchased at any of the museums. If you are planning on visiting few or several museums then buy the pass, it will pay for itself and you would NOT have to wait in long lines.

A Great Museum. We have been to Paris before, but opted not to go to this museum at our prior visit (because we could see Rodin's Thinker from the street. Big mistake! This museum is fabulous! We had the Paris Museum pass (a great investment), which allowed us to visit this museum as well as countless others on our five day return visit to Paris.
Magical!!!. A wonderful house and garden filled with Rodin's Sculptors and working models. The house is elegant and the gardens make a wonderful backdrops for a lot of his works.

Such a great place. We went there on a Saturday morning and expected it completely crowded. But we just cued 10 minutes. For us: Must have for a stay in Paris! Extraordinary garden, really nice museum! Museum shop you can skip :-)

Highly recommended. Over the course of visits to Paris over the years, we've been been to many of the city's museums, and would rank this one near the top. It's a beautiful place, and a nice combination of indoor and outdoor. But it's Rodin's sculptures that you go for, and they are beautiful, vibrant, and emotional. We'd highly recommend it to anyone visiting Paris.
Beaultiful. I have been there on summer, so, the garden was amazing!!!You can know a lot about Rodin, all his fases and, of course, enjoy his art.
Beautiful sculptures. In the heart of Paris you will enjoy this visit like I did. The sculptureso are outside so better go on a sunny day

Worth a visit. Compact museum (formally a mansion) with an amazing garden. The garden alone is worth the admission. The place has all of his greatest "hits". There's also 2 wonderful Van Goghs that was in Rodin's personal collection. Theres a neat video that explains how his bronzes and marble sculptures were made.

Terrific Transformation!. Has been a number of years since my last visit ..but WOW what a difference !! The museum is certainly a beautiful display case for all the wonderful artwork..however the gardens to me were such a wonderful site for enjoying all the wonderful sculpture!! Even had to stop to enjoy my lunch ther as well!!!! Highly recommend!!!

Going back to an old friend. It seems that overtime that we come to Paris, we visit the Rodin Museum. We did so again. The only house offers a generous selection of Rodin's work along with many of his contemporaries. There is a great deal to enjoy in the house. And the view of the gardens from the house is spectacular. But the gardens themselves and to enjoy along with the numerous sculptures. Additionally, the Gates of Hell are very dense with various forms which the work that one has seen in the garden and the house form the base.

Amazing!!. This is a museum not to be missed! Rodin's many sculptures (and several paintings) are displayed in a beautifully renovated, centuries old, hotel and gardens. His work is astounding, and everyone will appreciate the scope and magnitude. The gardens are a joy to stroll through, full of gorgeous roses and greenery. There is a nice cafe on site if you need to take a break and grab a bite.

Renovated recently and stunnjng. I've been here 4 times and still come back every visit to Paris to enjoy the gardens. The gardens in summer are lively with the roses in full bloom. The house has been restored recently and the changes have made the collection more accessible. Gorgeous house, stunning grounds, incredible sculptures and art.

Sculpture Oasis. The museum was near our hotel, and we took advantage of a Wednesday special offer. Admission is reduced starting at 6:00pm, and they are open until 9:00. Starting outdoors to view the larger than life sculptures in the sylvan setting was perfect on a fair summer's evening with light until quite late. The Kiss; Burghers of Calais; and of course, The Thinker. The small café was still open so that was a good stop for refreshment before turning to the interior of the mansion.

Best unknown museum in Paris. For some reason this museum is nort in the "must see" list of museums of Paris, but undoubtely is the most beautiful, calm museum in town. I went there with my 15 year-old kid and you cant imagine how much he enjoyed the Hells Door or the thinker. Don´t miss it by any chance!!

A serene place in a busy city. This museum combines both indoor and outdoor exhibits in the heart of Paris. It also features some of the finest sculptures and works of art in the world, but is not as overwhelming as the Lourve or D'Orsay. Highly recommended.

beautiful sculptures, beautiful gardens. if you have any control over it, do try to visit this museum in late May-early June. the roses in the garden are fantastic in their variety and their beauty. but even without their glory, this is a beautiful small museum, with old and new things to appreciate in it. Rodin's sculpture (and his little-seen drawings, etc.) are always wonderful to see. when i was visiting, they also had a 6 person exhibit of photographers, some of whose work i very much appreciated, others, less so. but i am always interested in seeing what is out there and the exhibit was well curated and well mounted.

Must visit. This museum/garden has three components: the former Rodin residence which is not very large houses mainly his sculptures and models, some of his paintings and a few Masters paintings that he owned. The gardens are very relaxing and feature a number of Rodin's sculpures including The Thinker and The Burghurs of Callais as well as an outdoor restaurant. The entrance building houses special exhibits.

Surpised by how fantastic it was!. We stopped by the Rodin museum because it was close to our hotel, but I am so glad we did. I do wish we had purchased tickets at the Orsay, or had the museum pass because those ticket holders breezed right in, while we did wait in line for a bit (20 minutes) and it was a rainy day so I would expect lines to be longer on sunny days. A good portion of the museum is in the garden which was a truly wonderful experience. And there was much more inside the mansion than I had expected to see, so definitely buy tickets to see both. The audio guide was also quite good. And I was surprised to see that they had a short file of Rodin himself that was very interesting. There is a cafe in the garden, but we did not check that out.

I head to the garden first!. This is one of my "must sees" every trip to Paris. I love the sculpture garden behind the museum. I start my visit there. I wander through the roses, the sculptures, the marbles, and then head inside for beautifully displayed pieces in extremely well lit spaces. It is a very welcoming museum that you can pace as you wish-20 minutes if you like or 3 hours if you so choose. I definitely spend more time outside than in each visit. (Great views of the Eiffel Tower through the roses.)
Gem in Paris. Really lovely place to visit in the summer, very interesting and really nice gardens and lots of great work to see

Unique, quaint, and out of the world. Do go to Museé Rodin. I always go back again and again and never get tired of it. The statues and sculptures seem to be able to speak when you look at them. Hemingway is right - Paris is a movable feast. Yet Rodin Museum is an absolutely hidden gem that does not want to be discovered by everyone, just a few that really appreciate it.
That's a whole lotta pretty..... I absolutely loved this place!! This is a museum that is gorgeous inside and out that features some pretty special statues.
Nice place. . Nice museum and grounds. Enjoyed walking around the property also enjoyed the food in the outdoor cafe. Did not however care for Rodin's work. It all appears incomplete.

A quiet haven. This lovely garden setting is such a peaceful place in the midst of hectic Paris. Not too many people, and beautiful sculptures to find within the pretty gardens that are well maintained.
fascinating. Rodin visited florence and was inspired by Michael angelo's work. You can see the changes he brought about in his work after this trip.

Truly a gem . I stumbled upon this lovely oasis a few years ago and just visited again last month. It's a magical place right in the heart of Paris. The grounds with quiet paths and lush green areas are inspiring and the statues are incredible. One can easily see how this place inspired such beautiful works of art. The interior of the home is beautiful as well with many other examples of Rodin's vast interests. It is also very easy to get to from the metro. I could spend a good portion of an afternoon just walking and sitting here, enjoying the tranquility that abounds here. Don't miss this gem!

Great collection of Rodin sculptures. This museum is located very near the Army Museum in Paris. It is a great collection of sculptures by Rodin. Several of his major works are housed in the beautiful gardens -- including The Thinker and The Gates of Hell.We thoroughly enjoyed the museum, especially the outdoor displays.

Rodin's city palace. The garden was at its best and what a joy to be in such beautiful surroundings in the heart of the city. The exhibition is a bit too full to my taste but the video gives useful info on how this magnificent sculptor worked. Worth your while.

Explore Rodin's work in a pleasant setting. Musée Rodin, Paris is a 18th century private mansion surrounded by an large garden, extensively landscaped. You will find a dozen or so of Rodin's sculptures in the garden, including The Thinker, The Burghers of Calais, The Gate of Hell. There is also a café on the grounds of the sculpture garden. The mansion itself house the museum's collection of Rodin's drawings, paintings as well as sculptures through out his carrier. One can get a glimpse of his development as an artist. I found the exhibits informative and the garden relaxing. The museum is located in the 7th district close to the Invalides and the Eiffel tower, Musée Rodin is included in the Paris Museum Pass. As an individual venue, the full ticket (including the sculpture garden and the permanent exhibition) costs 11.50 euros. You can buy ticket also only for the garden.
Nice setup. Very well maintained and beautiful building. Many Rodin sculptures in the museum as well as in the garden. Peaceful ad quiet. Very interesting museum.

Self guided tour. Well worth the visit. His works are so amazing and the manner in which they are displayed also helps to show the struggles he had to even be recognized as the great artist he was. The art works by contemporaries help to contextual I've his life. Wonderful.
Love this!. Wonderful museum with many Rodin's sculpture and paintings. If you are interested in art, then could not miss this for Paris!

Rodin, Rodin...much more than just The Thinker. This reopened museum displays the best of Rodin and shows enough more to get a feel for the development of his skills and breadth. A delightful outside stroll plus extensive inside galleries. Be sure to catch a glimpse of the Eiffel Tower to the west of the sitting Thinker.

Incredible place!. OMG, this place is incredible. So nice and so big; and Rodin was living there. You can see many of his sculptures, pairings and draws. The house has two floors and the garden. I recommend you to go there with time. But once being in Paris - and if you like museum and history - visit this place.

Gardens alone are great. Real fans should see the Museum. The Museum is filled with hundreds of sculptures, studies, paintings and Rodin's own collection, etc. Very extensive. Alternatively, for 4 euros, just tour the gardens. Grounds are beautiful and there are a number of his most famous works in full size and glory.

Beautiful! Amazing!. Until we visited Versailles, this was one of our favorite places. The inside museum was really neat to see all of Rodin's (and others') works, but the outdoor garden and sculptures is beautiful! We relaxed on a parkbench after walking around and it is just an amazing peaceful setting tucked inside the city. To think that he did all of this work and all these sculptures is awe-inspiring. The Thinker and the Gates of Hell were our favorites. Nice place to eat there in the gardens too.

Excellent. Spectacular statues but you will arso have the chance to see Rodin's paintings! The garden is a beautiful spot and includes a nice little cafe that also serves some dishes in case you got hungry. There might be a temporary exhibition of another artist at the museum aswell.

The gardens are pleasant and it's all about Rodin. You get to see allot of Rodin's work sculpture and painting. His paintings are worth the visit. So much has been attached to his bronze work that the painter get forgotten.
Relaxing Gardens at Rodin's historical residence!. My wife and I really enjoyed strolling the garden sculpture displays as well as the Rodin residence.....a fine small museum!
My favorite museum in Paris. Small intimate with the best garden and statues in the world. I love Rodin and his works and the building and garden is really perfectly managed.

Beautiful Small House Museum. Great works of Rodin, where he lived. The gardens are great, don't miss those in the rear as well as up front. It has a very nice outdoor lunch place to the right rear that is great for snack and full lunch.

My favourite museum in Paris . Lovely place to spend an afternoon, the museum gives you an insight into the brilliance of Rodin. Very easy to navigate, wasn't packed with tourists like the louvre or musee d'orsay. The garden is beautiful and is a fabulous location for Rodin 's masterpieces. You can buy tickets for musee d'orsay here, which will help you beat the queues there, it's pretty close to Rodin

Smaller Venue But Don't Pass It By. Rodin was one prolific fellow! This is an excellent outdoor and indoor collection of his works and depicts the very intricate work of transferring his product from one media to another. Only familiar with his later works, it was fascinating to be able to observe the evolution of his art. Definitely worth the visit.

Go early, I'd hate to see this place packed. This is an easy place to get in; they have the gate and ticket operation working well at least early in the day when we showed up.The gardens were nice it was a great day only issue is they were setting up for an event for that night and a big tent was blocking the view of some parts of the house. The house was a bit crowded even early in the day so it was a bit like herding cows to get around exhibits. Some of the items were a little odd and some were fantastic.

For sculpture lovers and anatomists. Rodin's as a master sculpturer was unquestioned. But his understanding of anatomy was excellent and if you like movement in form and function this is your place. Both indoor and outdoor art are in this special place.

Great Thinker. How many times have you seen the great thinker in your life on TV or books. Well if in Paris go here and you will see this magnificent sculpture as well as other pieces of art such as "The Kiss" and the frightening gates of hell.

Best part: the garden. Access to the garden is just a couple of euros and it contains most of his impressive larger pieces in a lush and calm setting. A very good and often not very crowded refuge and one of my favorite Paris spots.

Musee Rodin. Great experience, even if you are not an art enthusiast. Set in a couple of hectares of beautiful gardens in the 7the, with magnificent bronze sculptures scattered around the garden. Beautiful house with great examples of Rodin's work over his life. We went early Sunday morning to avoid the crowds....it opens at 10.00. There is a cafe in the gardens......adequate but not fabulous.

Well worth a visit. The gardens alone are extremely pleasant. Rodin was certainly a gifted artist and the sculpturs around the well kept gardens are impressive.In the museum ... worth going in but, outside is better!

Rodin's Home - Perfect Place To See His Art. The home has undergone a complete renovation. You get an inside view on how his bronzes were created. The garden is lovely, containing many of Rodin's sculptures and a delightful cafe. Vista this museum in conjunction with the Hotel De Invidales, right across the street and see Napoleon's tomb. Metro stop is right outside the Rodin Museum.

Spectacular!. The sculptures in the museum & on the garden grounds are absolutely spectacular. My favorite sculpture was " the thinker", which is found on the garden grounds & it's surrounded by beautiful roses & small green pine trees.
Beautiful gardens. Large museum.. Need a pretty day to slowly walk through the gardens. Takes at least half a day to see both the gardens and house. Well worth a visit.

beautiful villa with a large collection of Rodin work. The villa and grounds are beautiful. Nice collection of Rodin work that was nice although he is not my favorite. I like his paintings more. ParisPass allowed us to skip a long line. Very restful to sit in garden

Meh. So yeah we were in Paris during the worst flooding in 100 years and most of the other museums were closed. We may not have had the best attitude. But still. Just not all that interesting, especially given the price. Garden was nice enough, small, and it was wet there too.

Loved it. Especially the gardens.. Loved all the sculptures and works of art from other famous and prominent artists. The Paris museum pass got us entry to the main exhibit building and gardens but you have to pay extra for the special exhibit if interested. Didn't bother with that as we were pleased with all the other work we saw. Some stunning pieces and worth a visit. One of the better museums in Paris in my opinion and it's small enough that it's not a daunting task to see it all. In and out within a hour or much longer if you take the guided audio tour and stop at every piece.

Don't Miss This Great Exerience!. Tired as we were (having walked from the far side of the Eiffel Tower and after hours of enthralled standing at Musee Marmottan), it was exhillarating to delve into the world of 3-dimensional art! Fascinating to see the progressions and the perspectives of this artist. Would have loved more time in the garden, despite the drizzle, but we'd arrived a bit late, and spent over an hour inside, even though we tried to hurry.

Picnic in the garden w/The Thinker!. Grab some patisseries in one of the shops nearby, and enjoy them in the beautiful garden. Strolling through the gardens was the highlight, but we also enjoyed perusing the art inside. Definitely worth our time -- we had a great time here!

Awesome Museum. Ok, you have to go just to see The Thinker but the museum itself and the garden are beautiful. The view of the museum from the end of the garden is postcard perfect. The entrance brings you to a building with the gift shop, bathrooms and some special exhibit (we didn't bother) but then you go outside to get into the museum proper. The Thinker is outside to right if facing the building and the Burgers of Calais and the Gates of Hell are on the left. These statutes are all outside and then you can go in the museum itself to wonder around the two floors and see Rodin's other lesser known work and see some other works by famous contemporaries that Rodin had acquired. Then wonder around the garden on the side and front/back of the museum and see even more statutes in a beautiful garden setting. There is a little cafe there outside along the right side serving the ubiquitous baguette sandwiches.

Great little musee . Lovely and easily digestible art museum, perfect for a Sunday morning visit. Indoor two floor museum displaying sculptures by Rodin and some others. Also heavenly little cafe and sculpture garden to wander in. Top tip: if it's been raining bring substantial shoes as the garden is a little muddy (don't go in ballet pumps like I did.)

A MUST SEE IN PARIS. This museum is a must see if you are in Paris. The line was long when we got there (10:00 a.m.), but there was no line at all by the time we left. Get the Paris Museum pass and then you won't need to stand in line. The museum has a fantastic collection and has lovely grounds. You should plan to spend at least three hours. Don't miss it even if you are not a fan of Rodin. There are some wonderful painting on the top floor. It is a great place to just "chill" for a little while in the garden area.

For art lovers only.. We squeezed this in after visiting the Army Museum across the street. I was delighted by the grounds and the pieces scattered around the lovely property. The pieces inside are nice but the real attractions are outside. It's fantastic to see them up close. Mu hubby, however, was not so enthralled and quickly became board. My overall assessment is that I would not go out of your way unless this is something specific you wanted to see while in Paris. I was certainly glad we stopped but then again I'm a bit "art-snob", unlike my hubby. Helpful hint: It's a feasible plan to split-up your party between Rodin and the Army Museum since they are literally right next to each other. This would have saved us a few euro on one entry fee into Rodin.

Nice if you like sculptures.. My wife had this on her list of places to see. She wanted to see the Thinker in person. One hint, if that's all you want to see, you can go in to the waiting area where you buy tickets and get a good glimpse of it without paying.

Rewarding Inside and Out. We visited after seeing Invalides just around the block. What an approachable studio/museum. The different media Rodin worked in and the plaster castings which gave insight into the process of castings was unexpected and the building itself with furnishings, made it feel like the studio it was. The sculpture garden (The Thinker, The Kiss, et al) was beautifully laid out and lush in the springtime. After the huge museums visited, this was a gem. Highly recommend.

Gorgeous Gardens!. We were surprised by the beautiful garden setting containing many of Rodin's sculptures. The Mansion containing many more works is also stunning, and has an intriguing history. Amazing!

Beautiful gardens and impressive sculptures. Even though it was raining, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. The gardens are impeccable and every sculpture is so impressively crafted. The museum inside is not to be missed, as is a stroll through the flowers outside.
If you are a Roudin sculpture fan,you'll love this. Great museum,akin to the Roudin in Philadelphia. With only 3 days it would not be tops on my "must see" list but I liked it

Go outside and play.. I don't know what the Rodin exhibits inside, but outside in its sculpture garden (I mean, they ARE after all Rodin sculptures) the serenity is beautiful in its own right. And then there are the Rodins themselves. Are you kidding me?! This is the place to go when you need a break, and still be awestuck.

Been visiting these thoughtful sculptures for 50 years!. Just a long block or two from the Eiffel Tower is a home turned museum of the great sculptor Rodin. Go there! I first stumbled upon it on my first trip to Paris, 50 years ago. Every time I return to Paris, I must go back and pay homage to the work of this great artist. One can spend all day or just a cursory hour. The gardens are peaceful--a welcome break from the hectic pace of the city. The emotion of the sculptures in the house are beyond description. Do not miss this one!

Great museum . Well conceived museum to the master sculptor featuring his works and some of his own collection of artists he admired, including a couple of works of Van Gogh . Organized so that you follow Rodin's career works from start to finish.The gardens are also great. There is a good cafe in the garden to relax after touring.

Quick bucket list stop ( my apologies to art connoisseurs). Here's what we did: We wanted to see the Thinker and the Gates of Hell. Both are in the garden, so we bought garden only tickets (I think 2 euros). Both the Thinker & Gates of Hell are in the front garden, plus we got to see other interesting works as well, though we didn't make it to the back garden. We skipped the museum. Travel demands tough calls. I would rather see something quickly, sometimes, then never get the chance again. The Musee Rodin is very convenient to Napoleon's Tomb and army museum, so just allow a bit more time. The Gates of Hell are truly grotesque. Great photo ops with the Gates and Thinker.

Gardens worth a visit. I can only comment on visiting the sculpture garden but we enjoyed a wander around these well kept gardens. The sculptures are very interesting and look great in these surroundings.

Superb Museum. My wife and I love Rodin and have had an opportunity to view many of his works in nearby San Francisco. Alma Speckles was a friend and collector who put many of his works on display at the amazing Legion of Honor in SF - a 3/4 replica of the Palais de la Légion d’Honneur in Paris.We arrived at the Rodin shortly after it opened at 10AM, waited through a brief line and entered a few minutes later. We were immediately impressed by both the collection and facility. The works are well laid-out, the facility beautiful and there is a wide-variety of Rodin's styles available on view.And don't miss the gardens - beautiful and serene with many works hidden away visible only to those who take time to explore the many paths.A great stop for those who love Rodin!

A masterpiece of art and tranquility. The Rodin Museum provides an escape from the crowds of the Louvre with many areas for "thinking " .....the garden is filled with wonderful sculptures as is the museum inside . The security checks on entry allow you to amble with no worries . A must for art lovers and for gaining some peace in a hectic city

Wonderfully quiet and haunting in winter . . .. The museum has an austere beauty during winter, in late December, when both the crowds and the flowers are scarce. The surrounding gardens are quiet and gray, and the sculptures seem to dominate your thoughts during the cold weather and allow you the opportunity to truly enjoy their presence.

Beautiful gardens. Only visited the gardens but they are well worth the visit. The sculptures are beautifully set in lovely gardens and there is a very quiet atmosphere which is a break from the bustle of the Paris streets. The museum cafe serves great food and coffee too. The museum is easily accessible from the open top bus, bus stop.

Very enjoyable outing. I visited the Musee Rodin and enjoyed strolling around the grounds looking at the incredible sculptures and reading about each one. The house holds many more sculptures and is also very enjoyable. Lunch at the cafe was eaten outside, as it was a lovely day, and was very good.

Beautiful museum . We went to this beautiful museum on a rainy day so couldn't see the garden. We took at taxi here so we didn't have any problems finding the museum.The museum has great sculptures to see especially The kiss and the Thinker were astounding.I would definitely recommend visiting this museum in Paris
My favourite spot. To be able to combine the beautiful sculptures with the fabulous gardens was delightful. The outside restaurant was a delight - great food in a lovely ambience.
Interesting. Popped in to the museum to avoid a rain shower. Opted for the head set to assist, was useful to get some additional background on Rodin. Good set-up. The gardens were lovely.

Good stuff. A very good museum with beautiful and interesting sculptures and art. It's also a very peaceful place where you can just stroll around and enjoy some time trying to interpret the people in the sculptures.

Rodin's signature. It was not only wonderful to be in his home and the presence of his sculptures, but I enjoyed searching them for his signature carved into each piece. You'll find it first on The Thinker in the gardens. Make sure to visit The Gates of Hell. Get close and notice the extensive details. Incredible and eerie.

Beutiful setting, spectacular work.. Seeing Rodin's work in a beautiful garden setting is a wonderful treat. Sculptures appear within a wooded setting, around a small pond, surrounded by bushes, etc. The inside is just as good in its own way, a museum set in a beautiful home. The range of work, from the representative to the abstract, is spectacular; one never tires of the work of one artist. That being said, the few contributions from Camille Claudel were a lovely addition. Put this one among your top choices to visit in Paris.

Not to be missed. one of my favorite museums in all of Paris. Not just because seeing The Kiss or The Thinker that close up is awe inspiring - but because walking through the house and gardens, and getting a sense of the breadth of what Rodin created over the course of his life time is truly inspiring.

A Sculpture heaven . Amazing Sculptures set in beautiful gardens in a tranquil setting. The volume of the works is unbelievable. Indoor displays are gorgeous and the whole experience is a complete contrast to the chaos and crowds at the Louvre (but don't miss that either) I loved it
very nice choice to visit. Got to visit the Rodin museum and it did not disappoint. wonderful pieces, laid out on beautiful property. Of course the highlight is seeing his work "The thinker".

Overrated. The museum and the gardens are really overrated in my opinion. The sculptures and art are not as beautiful as the sculptures at the Louvre. Plus the gardens were not that impressive. I think it is free to see the gardens - so if you want to just see the garden and skip the museum that should be enough. The famous thinker statue is in the garden. A lot of movies were filmed here by the thinker statue (The scene from Midnight in Paris). I found Rodin's work a little on the perverse side.

Wonderful. I arrived about 15 minutes after opening and went straight to the gardens. It wasnt crowded at all--only a few others and it was splendid. I stopped at the cafe for breakfast and then took my time viewing the sculptures. Remarkable. I really enjoyed the peace and quiet of the gardens. Once inside the museum it was a bit crowded. A private tour with a large number of people took up a lot of space so I was unable to view The Kiss as I would have liked. The museum shop leaves much to be desired. Overall I really liked this museum.

Nothing like it. The collection of Rodin statuary is unbelievable, and most of it is displayed outside in the garden where it is most powerful. Inside is wonderful as well.While the museum pass works here, they did not provide much of an advantage in time saved as everyone had to stand in line to get a ticket, we just didn't have to pay for it.Perhaps this is because it's newly reopened after years of renovation, and they may be feeling their way, bur it's still a must see.

Do NOT miss this Museum!. If you visit Paris and you have time for only one museum, make it the Rodin Museum - one of the very few outdoor museums and with the most impressive collection of his sculptures, in an amazing setting

very nice garden, average museum. A must-go if you like sculptures and sculpted gardens. If you have only a little time, skip the museum and visit the gardens for statues like the Thinker. The museum shop is expensive. Museum is included in Paris Museum Pass, though we didn't see much queue when we visited during mid day.

The Real Thing. Up close and personal with some of the worlds finest sculpture is what is found at this world class Paris Museum.Found in a magnificent old mansion surrounded with wonderful gardens the pieces are everywhere A must see for those visiting Paris. Each trip to France we make it's must see to review and relive these beautiful pieces.

Relaxing garden setting and scuplture. The inside museum is great but it is the garden filled with sculpture which sets this museum apart. A perfect place to visit on a hot summer day.On a late May day arriving mid to late morning we experienced no queue and at no time were the number of people an issue. Fortunately no organised tour groups interfered with our visit.
Best Museum in Paris. This is the best curated space in all of Paris. The gardens and sculpure are magnificent. Visit this space.

Gardens over the museum. All has been said already, so here are our tips:The museum itself contains a lot of models of bigger sized sculptures on display in the garden... so don't worry about not having good shots of them inside.The gardens are the real highlight of this museum. make sure to visit them thoroughly.Expect to spend about 1:30 altogether (museum and gardens).No photo restrictions.
A gem.. Really peaceful, pleasant place to view lovely statues and learn about this talented man. Has a nice cafe as well.

A Masterpiece!!. It was heaven. I love sculpture and, in particular, Rodin's sculpture. The museum was wonderful. It contains not only many of his finished pieces but also hundreds of studies so you can view his developing thought processes, but also contains some of his personal art collection, including Picasso's. And then, there's the Garden!Scattered with many of Rodin's most famous pieces, it's a quiet sanctuary and the perfect place to rest your feet and gather your thoughts. I enjoyed this incredible museum far more than the Louvre. Go early. The museum pass covers admission. Enjoy!
Excellent museum, a little crowded. The amount of people in the main house made it a bit difficult to maneuver (especially with the group tours), but a spectacular collection.

Beautiful display, indoors and outdoors. The display of statues both inside the mansion and on the grounds is fantastic. Outdoors, walk through various paths and get different angles and views of the various statues (don't miss the ones on the side in the back). Inside, you are lead through a number of rooms which contain statues, paintings, and collections of various interesting art pieces. The outdoor cafe is also nice and the ice cream was excellent there. The closest metro station is Varenne. While visiting this museum, also consider visiting the nearby Army Museum and Napolean's Tomb.

My favourite place to spend a day in Paris. Tranquility and Rodin. Walking around the Rodin gardens is a good way to spend a beautiful day. The gardens have all the important works - the Thinker, the Kiss, the Gates of Hell. Worth visiting each time in Paris.
A must for historical view of great sculpture?. Rodin is iconic artist is well displayed in this historical setting. Have lunch in the garden. The sequence of sculptures is well presented.

Early morning experience/outside musee. I loved this place. It was a cold week in Paris and the first sunny day was the day we planned Musee Rodin. We arrived early and thought the placed was closed, so always check the front door sign and the website for opening. We went just across the street and had ouefs and cafe at the corner bar. Good! The Thinker is great to pose in front of, especially if you have a daughter who doesn't know what to do in life. :) The outside cafe was very inexpensive and delicious, so we coffee and then later lunch before we left for the next musee. The gardens contain Rodin's work along with information of when he sculpted them. Some writings of Rodin state that he made his students do most of the work and he took the credit for it; either way it was a piece of the French history transformed into art. If you have a Museum Pass the entrance is covered and the additional museum also. It was a great surprise inside to see a few Van Gogh's including the The Harvesters . Lots of sculptures from Rodin's early years. We both enjoyed it and was one of our favorite mornings.

QUINTESSENTIAL HEAVEN!. I am not a big sculpture aficionado, but my husband is and we visited yesterday in the golden sunshine of Paris. This Museum is my favorite! I LOVED the gardens with Rodin's sculptures throughout the beautiful settings; I thought the Museum itself is a beautiful Mansion full of fabulous works of Rodin which I found amazing!!! The view from the top floor of the Museum down to the water pool is magnificent! Don't miss this hidden treasure on your visit to Paris!!!

4 hours needed for this one. once you have conquered the metro system everything is easy to get to and within easy walking distance including this underrated attraction the details on his sculpture the gates of hell which incorporates so many different sculptures including the thinker is unbelievable

Nice Gardens. Opted to visit the gardens (which are filled with statues) rather than the museum due to time restraints. Beautiful setting and good value at only 2 Euro to get in. The gates of hell and the thinker are the obvious highlights. A bit out of the way so unless you are visiting for more than 2 days its not necessarily a "must see".

A lovely garden to visit. We really enjoyed the Rodin sculpture garden. It was the perfect setting to display the beautiful sculptures. We also had a nice lunch at the cafe on the grounds. Definitely fit this in your schedule for Paris.

Wonderful. By far, my favorite museum in Paris. The gardens and statuary were exceptional, So many beautiful, Iconic statues displayed in the gardens here. We were enchanted, and enthralled. What a beautiful display. We also enjoyed the interior of this lovely villa. I was surprised and delighted to see my old friends, Van Gogh, Renoir and Monet inside a well as Rodin. It was a treat and well worth the price of admission. There is also a lovely cafe, just inside of the garden, Wonderful soups and sandwiches

Lovely stroll in Sculpture garden. Went later in the day to avoid crowdWas successfulNice cafe on grounds for a snack or simple lunch.Amazing to be in the city and so walled off from the bustle of Paris!Enjoy ! Stay several hours .
Wonderful museum . What a genius Rodin was. In bequeathing his house and work to the nation we can enjoy stunning artworks in a fabulous setting.

Must see museum!. I truly love this outdoor/indoor museum. The outdoor garden contains many wonderful Rodin sculptures, various places to sit and enjoy the outdoors and a wonderful cafe. The indoor museum features more Rodin sculptures, paintings and carvings. I was pleasantly surprised to see the small Van Gogh section in the museum. I highly recommend this museum.
New Favourite. The gardens are beautifully landscaped and filled with wonderful statues. The interior is equally beautiful with so many wonderful things to look at. Our new favourite museum.

Beautiful Small Museum with Great Gardens. We enjoyed the garden and café even though it was raining, it was beautiful. A little bit of quiet and peace right in the city. A must for anyone who loves Rodin. Got a great kids guide afterwards which would have been fun to pick up in the gift shop before going to the museum.
Lovely Gardens. This was my third visit to the Rodin Gardens and they still enchant. To be greeted by The Thinker, enjoy a delicious lunch, and then continue through the gardens is a Paris treat!

What an improved gem. The museum has been renovated and it is excellent. You can see how Rodin worked and the level of skill he had and how hard it was to acquire. The gardens are lovely and provided an opportunity to relax and mediate in. There are sculptures every where. The cafe in the garden is excellent with a lot of choices. This is an unique experience.

Beautiful museum with well laid out exhibits. The museum has been re designed and is now very welcoming. The garden is lovely with major pieces set out in the garden. The inside of the museum has always been nicely laid out. It remains popular so be aware of possible wait times
Great way to spend an afternoon. The museum and gardens are lovely and peaceful. And don't miss the cafe. It is a great place to grab a nice lunch.

Wow. We have been to Rodin once before. We had great memories of it being really special.It still is. We debated whether we are more entranced by the sculpture...or the place itself. It is so beautiful, you just want to sit in a sunny window and look out at the spectacular garden views!

Very enjoyable. A very well priced and enjoyable museum. We had a lovely few hours at the Rodin Museum. The grounds are beautiful and relaxing and the museum packed with the work of Rodin and others. For 10€ per person I thought this was very reasonable and an excellent way to spend an afternoon come rain or shine.

Breathtaking building, Amazing Sculptures. The building is so quintessentially french its unreal, an amazing photo op. And the sculptures showed a great range in style and material. We arrived 15 minuets before open and go in within 30 minuets, so very fast by Paris terms.
A must see for Rodin fans. Charming museum with great gardens for showcasing his work. Be sure to walk all the way through. Nice cafe for lunch or a glass of wine.
A must see. If you like sculptures you really must visit this museum, Rodin's artwork is brilliant. The museum itself is beautiful, very peaceful in its gardens.

Fabulous sculptures. When we were in Paris a few years ago, we were only able to see the gardens as the building was being renovated. We wanted to get back to see the inside and we were not disappointed. Savor the "walk" through this building, there are plenty of sculptures to see and not just Rodin sculptures. You can spend 3-4 hrs here easily if you include the gardens which contain some of Rodin's most famous works.

Romantic Gardens with a Museum. The Museum has been closed for three years but the best bit of the reopening is that it seems to have hardly changed. The building has been renovated to be able to withstand the weight of the sculptures but the wonderful antiqueness of the interior - including the mirrors - has been maintained. This is probably the most romantic garden in Paris and even in the rain was just heavenly. There is an excellent cafe to retreat to -it blends into the gardens and serves wine!

Musee Rodin. Passport to two Paris museums is a great deal to see some other works by Van Gogh (D'Orsay) that are not found elsewhere. If our like sculpture then this is a must see. Get the "passport" deal at Musee D'Orsay for a discounted double header of a museum deal. Limited Picasso also at Rodin.

best group of Rodin sculptures. I've seen the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia and the sculptures in LA and at Stanford U, but they pale in comparison to the wealth of beauty, condensed in one place. Never very crowded. And the entire sculpture of the Burghers of Calais and of the Gates of Hell. If you like Rodin, you will love this museum.

Peaceful Gardens. What a beautiful place. When we went the museum itself was undergoing renovations, so we only went into the gardens, but that was enough. You can have a picnic amongst the trees or have ice-cream and light meals at the café. Rodin's most famous artwork "The Thinker" takes pride of place and is a lot bigger than you will expect. A must-visit place when you visit Paris.

Excellent museum and gardens!. Beautiful spot to wander or rest in the gardens. Very interesting museum of Rodin's life and art. The sculptures are well placed and worth a look. The museum was crowded, the garden was not.
A classic favorite that never disappoints. The Rodin Museum and Gardens are a must visit if you have an appreciation for art. Spend a few hours and take in all the details, you won't regret it.
Delightful!. Do the garden first! It's really magical. Also, the museum has an outstanding collection of Camille Claudel's work, which was a nice surprise! HIGHLY recommend!
My favourite Paris Musee. Outdoor gardens + indoor collection make this a unique experience. Fabulous work on display in both areas. A must see.
Great sculptures. Quiet neighborhood and a beautiful museum. Beautiful sculptures/art--a nice way to spend an afternoon. Close to Invalides. Definitely worth it.

The place for the "thinker" among us. Rodin's beautiful home has been converted to a museum for the public. The house does a great job of showcasing the history of Rodin's art. The real jewels here however are the spacious grounds and amazing statuary display. Works by Rodin are placed though out the well maintained gardens and make for a very nice "art walk" with nice photo ops around every corner. We were there in early spring and missed some of the display of roses that will showcase as the weather warms. A small cafe is located on the grounds and is a surprisingly good place for a quick lunch.

Certainly one of my favorite place in Paris!. This place is just charming! the size of the museum, the fact that is is niched in a superbe monument, the magnificence of the sculptures inside and outside of the building, the quite garden, everything play for joy and fascination. I am not a painter nor a specialist of Rodin, just an admirer of this plain and fully understandable beauty. If you like taking picture this is the place!! and cherry on the pie: everyone in the family with 3 teenagers liked it!

My favourite museum in Paris. As far as museums go, I found this one special. Its super cool that his works are on display throughout his stunning home and grounds. The property is just as beautiful as his work.

A must see. Many of Rodin's pieces are made for outdoor gardens and they are beautifully displayed here. Take a stroll around the grounds, stop at the cafeteria for a nice lunch, champagne optional, then go inside the house to see the more delicate works. I will definitely go back.

A quiet corner to discover Rodin. You can visit the house or gardens or both. If time is short, the gardens are excellent on their own even if other people's bronzes of Rodin's work. The house more if you want to see some originals and some background.
We expected better gardens. We didn't visit the Museum but instead visited the gardens. They were nice but not so large. You can find much better in Paris, such as Luxembourg and Tuileries gardens.
