The first statue we found after entering the garden was "The Thinker", one of the most celebrated sculptures ever known. Then, passing by the Museum Cafe we admired the "Ugolino and his children" statuary ensemble within the fountain opposite the museum building. After sit on a bench near the fountain to relax and enjoy the scenery we turned right and walked through the wooded area filled with statues until we reached "The Gates of Hell" and "The Three Shades". To tell you the truth I am not very fond of Rodin`s works but all in all we had a wonderful time there including the lunch at the Museum Cafe which was a great value for money.

a must visit. I love the work of Rodin and walking around this beautiful museum was amazing. Once you have visited inside, walk around the gardens and see his other works such as the Thinker and Hells gate. The gardens themselves are beautiful and worth just sitting and taking it all in. A must see place.

A must for Sculpture or garden lovers. After seeing Napoleon's Tomb we walked across the road to Muess Rodin. It was a hot day and the nice garden was a cool change. It is behind the large wall that runs along the road near the Tomb building. The entry building houses some sketches and other exhibits. The gardens have a large amount of sculptures dotted around it. Including the "Thinker", "Gates of Hell", "Rabbit" and other sculptures. As with all major Paris attractions watch out for the pick pockets. But inside you are fairly safe.The Musee Rodin is in the Paris Museum Pass which I highly recommend for anyone going to 2 or more of any of the museums, attractions and city highlights.Nice clean toilets down the stairsSome nude and Graphic not for children eyes art work when we were there., But it was behind a door. I cant recall if there is food to purchase. I think there is a cafe inside the gardens.

COMPLETELY RENEWED, THE MUSEUM IS SIMPLY MUCH GREATER !. In visiting the museum Rodin just a few days after it reopened, the visit proved well worth the many months it was closed !The Rodin pieces are shown at their best advantage, and the house where rodin passed his last years is now in a jewel state ! The only negative aspect is that there is so much to see and enjoy, that I think you should do the visit in two separate occasions, and choose what to see ! Apart from that, it is an extraordinary display of the even more extraordinarely talented Rodin ! Don't miss it !

Amazing collection. The museum is set in the home of Rodin. It is a beautiful structure with wonderful gardens surrounding it. Inside are many of his most famous works, plus a large collection of his plaster castings, studies for larger pieces and some of his paintings. There is, also on the second floor a room with several stunning Van Gogh's a Renoir and a Monet just to give the museum some more color. The gardens that surround are filled with some of his works, but on the day that we were there there were pretty voilent storms and the gardens had to be closed. We did however get to get a glimpse of the works from the windows of the mansion. All in all a very enjoyable and enlightening visit.

Magnificent. This is one of my favorite small museums. Easy to see in an hour or maybe two, with some very fine work I had never seen before. Plus some art by other people, friends and lovers of Rodin's. Make sure you see the house where he worked and the garden as well. Some of the finest pieces are out-of-doors.

Need to go. Beautiful Museum. If you love sculpture that is surely one of the places to go in Paris. Between the museum and the gardens you will have a marvelous half-day. Of course you can stay longer and profit of nice luncjph or tea at the gardens cafeteria.

Worth it!. This was Rodin's studio where he created and exhibited his works. It is absolutely gorgeous and doesn't feel overcrowded. The sheer scale, variety of mediums, and the number of Rodin's works is mind boggling. He was a prolific genius, and this is a temple dedicated to him. Get a museum pass to skip the lines.

Very interesting to see Rodins works displayed together. A well laid out and informative Museum. Rodin is not my favourite artist but the displays showed the strengths and weaknesses of his work. My favourite pieces were the uncast clay heads that were elaborate and expressive. recommend a visit

My number 1 museum in Paris. Been itching to revisit following its recent refurbishment and we were not disappointed. Floors, ceilings and much else have been refurbished in keeping with the original design. The refurbished space is well lit and the many Rodin sculptures are intelligently displayed. As an added bonus there is also a small collection of art by other French artists that Rodin acquired in his lifetime. I suggest that you too make it your no. 1 place to visit when in Paris.
A magnificent setting for magnificent art!. You come away totally inspired but if an artist yourself, totally humiliated as you will never be able to create anything as beautiful.

Musee has been refurbished . We have visited the Musee Rodin a number of times. It was definitely getting somewhat shabby The refurbishment has been well done. Rodin's work is astonishingly well crafted. The display's are good. However, after all the time and money it took to renovate the museum, we were somewhat surprised at the lack of innovation. If you have never been there, you must visit. If you are looking for a modern version of the museum, you may be disappointed.

Rodin live !. Mecca for Rodin fans and art lovers, you must plan and spend an entire day for Musee Rodin. Starting from The Thinker and the Gateway to Hell this place is filled with most of the unforgettable art creations of the great artist Rodin. The museum is hosted in the erstwhile hotel where Rodin spent a major part of his life. This place has many exibitoins themed on Rodin with his works, lot of detail histories about his life, his work and his personal life, about his inspirations. It also has a restaurant and a nice souvenir shop. You may buy your piece of Rodin's art from here.
Gardens are Gorgeous. The gardens here are gorgeous, with "The Thinker" and other great pieces to see. Unfortunately the museum was closed for renovations when we went.

Surprisingly moving and elegant art!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Discover the full range of Rodin's work, much of it quite sensual. "The Thinker" is wonderful, but there is much more. And, on a warm day, enjoy the outdoor garden cafe.

Fabulous. Wonderful museum in a beautiful building with stunning and peaceful gardens. It was really interesting to see how Rodin worked and to see various maquettes as well as his very famous works. In January it was wonderfully quiet but we will go back to see the gardens in Spring/Summer when they will be more interesting. A lovely way to spend a morning.
Picnic & wine in the yard. After taking in the great sculptures & walking around the building, it's nice to enjoy the courtyard & all that is offered here. Have lunch & enjoy the quiet atmosphere.
The Thinker!. No lines! Near the Eiffel Tower. Very pleasant grounds to stroll through. "The Kiss" and "The Thinker" are highlights for me. Great place to plan to visit on the free museum days!!

Exceptional and Affordable Entry Ticket. A must see in Paris. This museum recently open to the public after major work completed is an absolute marvel, from the building to the art, and display, it is stunning. This museum is auto funded from sales from the artist copyrights and part state funding which makes it among the most affordable in Paris about 10 euros.Congratulations.

One for Rodin fans. Lovely building and gardens with a fine collection of Rodin's work. Also his own art collection on the upper floor. Lots of studies and maquettes for final pieces which are interesting.

Rodin's talent is overwhelming. Thorough representation of the artists work across multiple art forms. Very impressive displays. Palatial setting with beautiful gardens even in winter. Lovely cafe with excellent food adjacent to the gardens.
Magnificent!. What a thrill to visit Rodin's last studio, seeing his art in rooms where he once lived and worked. Such a thrill.
heads and bodies!!!. A great sculptor and fabulous masterpieces whether inside or in the lovely garden. One room for Camille Claudel!!!

Very nice afternoon close to Eiffel Tower. Been here few times, and absolutely love museum, and gardens. I'd recommend it for everyone who loves Rodin, art or something different to discover in Paris.

One of the best museums in Paris. This museum is great! It is for sure one of the best in paris, with an amazing collection of Rodin works. The museum by itself (witch in the past used to be a hotel) and its gardens are beautiful!

Beautiful musee with fabulous range of Rodin's work.. My husband and I loved walking through this mansion - the building itself is beautiful. Even in winter the gardens were lovely highlighted with Rodin's sculptures. The mansion was lightfilled and Rodin's sculptures filled all rooms and spaces. The musee had been recently renovated and it was crowded with extremely tight security. The inside bathroom only has one toilette so a tip is to use the outside ones if one needs to use a bathroom.

Much more than an art museum. Where else in the world can you experience an iconic artist in the homes and gardens where he worked? The experience is so much richer when you have a sense of the world in which Rodin lived and created his art. It is worth a visit even if you little of Rodin beyond 'The Thinker', he was so much more than that.

Very good museum with tons of Rodin's inside and in their gardens. Very beautiful former mansion now a museum! Lots and lots of Rodin's. The gates of hell is here as it is in Philly! If u like Rodin, do come to this museum.

Magic. We enjoyed walking in the gardens, among the roses, in December! The manor house is beautiful and the sculpture work is exquisite. There was not rush to visit and the added security to enter the museum made us feel very safe
Dreamlike. A wonderful, enchanting collection of Rodin's work, exhibited both in the museum itself and in the extensive grounds, which are beautiful. Not to be missed.

Rodin produced a huge number of works which are housed in the museum and the gardens.. This is well worth a visit, there's so much to see! There are all Rodin's well known works as well as all the models and prototypes he made before the final version. There are also paintings both by him and of him. It's a huge collection so,a lot of time is needed to see everything.

Breathtaking!. It is really easy to miss, but it is one of the best art museums of Paris! Even if you know only The Thinker, go and enjoy! Rodin was an amazing artist and you are going to see the shining of his talent at its best!

Hotel Biron is still great. Closed for renovation when I last visited, this estate was the original home to the Order of the Sacred Heart who have schools all over the world. Napoleon had all religious orders removed from Paris and the house fell into ruin. The Rodin and other artists moved in, with Rodin finally buying it from the government The gardens are amazing. Worth a visit.

Don't Miss!. The Musee Rodin has always been a wonderful place to visit, with its rich selection of sculpture. But since the building has re-opened from its renovation, it is absolutely spectacular. The building itself is just wonderful, and there is a short video available to see what has been done to bring it back to its full beauty. The artwork is arranged well with plenty of space to enjoy it. There is also a variety of artwork that Rodin himself collected, as well as pieces from friends and contemporaries to help put his work in context. The grounds look better than they ever did, and there is a delightful coffee shop in the garden which is a wonderful place to stop. Les Invalides is just across the street, and with a metro stop around the corner visiting couldn't be any easier.
Beeindruckend. I knew Rodin of course, but I never realized the extent of his art. This is a must see for all those visiting Paris

so much to see in a small space. Wonderful house - size of Edward Heath's in Salisbury England - easy to get around and see everything without sore feet. The Kiss, The Thinker, Gates of Hell. He was an artist too. Hundreds of statues. And a tranquil garden, with small coffee shop. A 12 franc taxi fare from Notre Dame.

Really worth the visit !. This museum was closed for a long time and it has been lovingly restored. Rodin is famous for his Thinker sculpture and it's right there as you enter the gate ! So many of his works are in the gardens, so after you visit inside take a walk to see even more work outside.. works such as the Burgers (?), and the Gates, and a large version of the 3 men embracing each other .. the Shadows, I think it's called ? Inside .. so many wonderful sculptures.. famous ones.. like "The Kiss", or the clasped hands (Cathedral).. all right there in front of you. There are hundreds of sculptures. He donated everything to the state.There are also some of his own things that he collected privately, like a Van Gogh, or a Monet that he swapped with the artist for a sculpture. There are also videos at the entrance which explain how he made the sculptures. A very enjoyable couple of hours. The museum itself is really beautiful, with a lovely garden. Obviously, as it was January, there weren't many flowers in bloom but there was a gardener there who was very busy pruning the roses ... hundreds of rose bushes ! We wanted to have a coffee in the café in the garden, but as it was 12.00 noon, the manager said that we had to eat there, and we only wanted coffee/snack ! He lost out on about €60 there !
Great museum for passionates of sculptures and paintures. The garden and the interior hold masterpieces of Auguste Rodin, but also paintures of Van Gogh, Monet.

Glad I went!. I walked from my hotel in the opera district to the museum. There was a bit of a wait to get in but it was well worth it. Inside you can lunch at an outside cafe on the lawns of the museum in a very beautiful, lush and green setting. The grounds and museum are child friendly. I was in a bit of a hurry to see other sights so I didn't get a chance to see everything. I think it would take at least a day to see Rodin's own works, his art collection and the many works of his students. His statue, The Thinker, was the highlight of my experience there in light of it being something I've seen photos of ever since I was a little boy. I understand Rodin made many Thinkers which are placed at various museums around the world. I'm not sure if the statue I saw is the one owned by the City of Paris that was moved from the Pantheon to Hotel Biron in 1922. The Hotel Biron had transformed into Rodin museum.

just visit the wonderful garden. even if you don't have the time or you're not into art - you can still visit to Jardin . its one of the prettiest in Paris , and for 4 euros only you can enjoy is. some of the major works of Rodin are presented in the garden, so its a double winner.

nice garden with his dinamic sculptures. There was a construction still going on when we went there and they didn't have much to see(there are many of his art works we saw in Orsay) but of course the famous ones are there. And we didn't see much tourists either so it has a better atmosphere compared to other big ones.

Must See Musee. With many Attractions and Museums to choose from in and around Paris and Europe, the Musee Rodin in Paris is a "must see". The interior architecture,collections and exhibits will take a day to explore and appreciate. It's well worth the time to schedule in a tour of the Museum and Gardens.

Rodin Museum. If you have the chance to visit this newly renovated museum, do. A wonderful way to see the brilliant works of Rodin, as well as to see his own art collection, the things that inspired him, and many works by his students including Camille Claudel. The grounds are brilliant and perfect to find some solace in a busy city. There is a restaurant for light meals and coffee and dessert. Well worth the walk from the centre of Paris, about 20 minutes. Rue de Varenne.

Garden was worth the price even though museum was closed. When my friend and I visited in September 2015, the museum was undergoing renovation, and they had a makeshift gift shop and workshop type area that displayed Rodin's smaller works and plaster casts. I would love to return to see the actual museum, but the garden alone is worth the visit. It is peaceful and lovely and the sculptures are placed all around the premises. We sat at a table and had gelato and just enjoyed the surroundings. The Burghers of Calais was probably my favorite, next to the Thinker, and if you are not familiar with the story, check it out. The final bronzes are in Calais, but the workmanship is quite evident on the sculptures here. I hope to return one day to see the real museum.

Love the Musee Rodin and the gardens. Other than the Louvre and d'Orsay, this is the museum I tell people to visit in Paris. You don't have to be a Rodin aficionado to enjoy (although I'm sure it couldn't hurt). Housing the most impressive collection of art by both Rodin and Camille Claudel, my favorite part of the museum is the outdoor sculpture gardens which are a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city, especially at the height of tourist season. Bring a sandwich or a drink and just sit for awhile and let the beauty soak in. You won't regret it!

For sculpture fans. This museum contains mostly Rodin's sculptures. The "gate of hell" was the most impressive among them. If you like sculptures type of art, you might find this museum to be attractive. I won't go again...

A quaint treasure.. As much as I enjoyed the many Rodin sculptures and the associated history, I enjoyed the grounds just as much. The rose garden is stunning and not to be missed in the summer months.
My favorite place in Paris.. This museum had the most beautiful rose garden , I could have gotten lost in there !! Absolutely stunning roses !!!

Newly refurbed and better than ever. They have finally finished restoring the Hotel Biron to its form when Rodin lived and worked there. The new arrangement of works and art is superb; the inclusion of films and videos enhance the overall experience; and the jardins are marvelous -- a wonderful way to top off your tour.

Much more than the Thinker. A nice small museum to spend an hour or two. Come for the Thinker and The Kiss but don't miss out on all the other wonderful art and the beautiful gardens. This museum was Rodin's residence during the later years of his life. One of my favorites was actually a Van Gogh portrait that was surrounded by Japanese motifs. The painting is called "Portrait of Père Tanguy"

Visit With an Old Master. These larger than life sculptures reflect the larger than life person Rodin was. In these beautiful settings, see many of this Masters works displayed in the surrounding gardens.None more spectacular than Rodin's 'Thinker', awesome. The museum not far from central Paris, an easy walk from the Eiffel Tower. Free entry if you have the Paris Museum Pass. Powerful
great updating. this musee was recently remodeled do not miss this collection and exhibits are much better presented

Overrated. This place was the most crowded of all the sites we attended in Paris over 6 days. It was nuts to butts in there and we could not appreciate it at all. I think Rodin's work is crap quite honestly and stopped here mainly due to proximity to Napoleon's tomb and since it was free with our Museum Pass. I'd "Pass" on this museum for other stuff.

best garden to visit, great museum. have visted this musen many times and i still love it,stunning gardens, cute coffee shop and grwat muesum of ridin's and camille's work.a must see in paris and a place to return to often for the serenity of the garden, although its sometimes used as a venue for Fashion week, when marquees sometimes taken part of the garden from use.

Gorgeous gardens. Great place for lunch. The Museum building was under renovation when we visited, so we took advantage of the gardens. For a 2euro entry fee, this is the best value in Paris! Le Penseur/ The Thinker is obviously centrally featured but as you walk through the grounds you get to really appreciate the art of sculpting. There is an indoor/outdoor restaurant and lots of people were lounging around on the grass, sipping their wine. It was quite charming. Worth a visit.

Take a sketch pad, a book and chill out. Beautiful gardens containing some of Rodin's best know works. Also there is a mansion house containing further works of Rodin and his friends. The gardens are the best bit. Sit, relax, get away from the hubbub. Draw a little, think a little, chill out a lot.

Wonderful sculpture venue. This museum is located in the villa where Rodin spent the last years of his life. It is surrounded by lovely gardens and definitely worth a visit. A huge display of his work is there with lots of information on its history and even a short movie on its refurbishment upon the death of Rodin. I must say however that there are other artists who I believe are better than Rodin and can be seen in various museums around Paris. He was brilliant at the human form but did not tend to "finish" his sculpture but left the areas around the forms in their natural state. There are also a few wonderful impressionist paintings from his own personal collection on display. He was also a very astute business man as this is the only completely self funded museum in Paris.You can purchase the Paris Museum Pass here as well which is worth every cent if you plan on going to many. The Paris Pass which is different is very pricey and in my opinion not worth the expense.
Beautiful Grounds. This is a beautiful Museum full of Rodins (obviously) Some places say they have a good deal of the works but this one does a great job or spanning his long career.

No THINKING required, just visit it!. Loved this Musee. It was truly a wonderful exhibition of beautiful Sculpture, paintings and artifacts.What an incredible Master of sculpture? The gardens were beautiful and if you manage to take photos in the garden, the Eiffel Tower makes an imposing back drop. A must to see when other Galleries are closed!

Quiet and beautiful. I, first of all, had the luck to go there on a sunny day. It is very easy to go there by public transportations. The museum is really quiet, not too crowded and the staff is really nice. The expositions are amazing and it's close to the Invalides and other very nice places to visit.

Wonderful Sculptures. This was our first visit to the Rodin Museum. We started in the large gardenwhich contained about 2 dozen large sculptures including The Thinker. Then we went inside a beautiful building that was like a small palace. The rooms were filled with small and medium sized sculptures. There were even some paintings done by Rodin. The rooms were fairly crowded so it was sometimes difficult to see everything. We still found it to be a very interesting museum and would recommend to others who enjoy seeing sculptures in a beautiful setting.

Continues to improve . This is my second full day visit to Musée Rodin and it was pleasing to see the development of the curation since last time. Despite being winter the sculptures outside were still on display unlike the gardens at Versailles Palace. Importantly they have added lifts for less mobile patrons.

Perfect for a rainy day. The Rodin Museum and garden blew me away! Because it's a smaller museum featuring the work of only one artist, it's a very intimate experience. I'll be honest, I didn't know much about Rodin's work or other pieces than the Lovers and the Thinker. I was so pleasantly surprised at his other work. Each piece is moving in a different way. The house on site has several exhibits which are very good, but what I think the real highlight is are the gardens and large sculptures outside. The garden is beautiful on its own. I'm sure it looks glorious on a sunny, summer day, but I was there on a cold and rainy winter day and it was still an experience I'd never trade. What a good place to come enjoy some incredible art and clear your mind of its troubles. The admission is incredibly affordable. Of the museums I've visited in Paris, this one has been my favorite. Light crowds, affordable admission, intimate setting, amazing art - I have only good things to say! Don't skip the "special exhibit" either - it's worth a walk through!

Wonderful. Quite unexpected! Huge garden area quite beautifully set out. Fascinating. Wonderful house also. A lot of exhibits. Needs at least 2 hours. Get there early and have breakfast in the cafe between the metro and the museum!

Even a better visit on a sunny day. Rodin's sculptures are majestic and moving. Besides the aesthetics of the numerous gorgeous piece, the emotions pouring out of the stones and bronze are palpable. And, yes, do take ke time to visit the gardens on that sunny day. PS: you will enjoy the visit even more if you first watch the movie "Camille Claudel"

Garden Remains My Favorite Part. I visited the Musee Rodin a few weeks after it reopened, following a 3-year renovation. Work enhanced the parquet floors and woodwork and included a redesign of the layout.The 18th-century mansion, which houses the museum, looks much improved since I last saw it just before the closure. Rodin's works remain as impressive as ever. But I prefer his finished creations to the myriad plaster works that have been added to rooms. And though one of the renovation goals was to focus on lighting, I found that the light play on some display cases prevents a clear view of the contents.The garden beckons to me more than the museum itself, which was also true in the past. Rodin's sculptures here, such as The Thinker, The Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell are simply stunning. I find it pleasant to walk around the beautifully landscaped grounds and come across one sculpture after another. In warm weather, many chairs beckon to come and sit for a while. On future visits, I plan to buy a reduced admission ticket for the garden only, as this is one of my favorite spots to stroll in Paris.
Rodin in a Garden. The setting of this museum is incredible. Some of Rodin's most iconic pieces are in a beautiful garden setting.

Lovely. A beautiful sculpture garden featuring the amazing works of Rodin. The new space is under construction, but the temporary space was set up nicely and gave a great overview of Rodin's artistic life and processes. A really lovely place to visit and have a drink in the garden surrounded by beautiful works of art.

Nice garden, lesser known sculptures besides 'The Thinker' worth a look. This is a nice garden to meander your way through on a pleasant day. It is not very big but there are quite a good number of sculptures in and around the garden to look at. Although many visitors mainly come here to see the famous 'The Thinker' statue set grandly in the centre of a maze in the garden as the epitome of Rodin's work plus 'The Kiss' marble sculpture displayed inside one of the buildings, there are many other sculptures which are quite interesting too. In fact, apart from tourists you can also find locals or art students spending the time drawing the lesser known sculptures hidden in the shades.There is also a little cafe where you can buy snacks and ice cream and was a welcome respite for me as my legs were aching from walking from the louvre museum and getting a bit lost in the side streets before I finally found this museum. (Nonetheless, I serendipitously found two other delightful neighbourhood gardens in the side streets so it wasn't a total loss.) I'm not sure what was in another building as I didn't venture there because of some renovation works in the area around it. I think you pay less if you just want to walk around the garden and not go inside the buildings to see his exhibition work but for first time visitors - his exhibition is worth a visit as there are many sculptures made from marble. Also if you want to see 'The Kiss' sculpture, its inside.

Don't just think about going, go. I loved the museum when I was there a decade ago. Now after a long renovation, it is even better. Take your time and marvel at the sculptures, they are truly amazing. It was raining and we were without umbrellas or we would have spent more time in the gardens as well. Having the museum pass saved us so much time not standing in line to get in, it is so worth it.

Very peaceful. I had about an hour and a half to kill so I came here and loved it! Very cheap entrance (I only chose to do the garden). It was beautiful and very peaceful. Exciting to see "The Thinker" statue which is probably the main attraction. the cafe was good too.
Stunning. Wonderful! Such artistic genius and beauty. ! Loved the beautiful and peaceful gardens to stroll through artistic history.

Beautiful . If you appreciate sculptures and Rodin this museum is a must. We went in the first days of 2016 and it was raining and it was very difficult to see the art work inside the museum because of the overcrowding. Outside you were able to appreciate everything because no one was outside because of the rain. The house where the museum is located is very beautiful. If you are not a Rodin admirer this is not the museum for you Not a must for first time travelers to Paris but definitely worth seeing if you have time in your itinerary

Majic in metal. Rodin's works are displayed in the gardens surrounding his home. The gates of hell are impressive. As well as the Thinker. Also the house contains many of his artworks. Very worthwhile.

Renovated museum now restored. The line (queue) to get into this museum was not long, but the entrance procedure was disappointingly slow that the rain and cold may have over shadowed my enjoyment of the day. Very popular on a Friday (holiday) with many wishing to visit. Those with Carte Musee (pre-purchased tickets) were allowed in swiftly, but for the rest we waited as a few were let into security at a time. The museum is wonderful with full understanding of Rodin's life and studio life. I was disappointed that the sculptures that were now under glass were under reflective glass and photographing them difficult with the reflections. The gardens were delightful - Rodin's The Gates of Hell, The Thinker and The Burgers of Calais always a crowd pleaser. Over all the museum was a "do not miss".

Lack of efficiency at the start almost ruined our visit. I'll qualify this by saying that the Musee Rodin is my favourite in the world. For that reason alone, there's really no way I can give it less than 4/5, though in realty the artwork, layout and information is worth 5/5 while management of the queues, security and tills is worth a 1-2/5.We arrived on Dec 29 (Tuesday) around noon to find the queue almost 2 blocks long. It seemed to be moving so we guesstimated a 30-40min wait. The first problem was that of the two large gates you pass to enter the property, one was shut. Since most people were in groups of 3-4 people they took up most of the space at this gate. So when people with Paris Museum passes or pre-purchased tickets arrived they had to squeeze through all the people since there was no dedicated line for them. Not only that but many people with pre-purchased tickets didn't know that they could jump the queue since their dedicated entrance is only marked once past security. Only once in our hour long wait did someone go out onto the street and shout out "Museum pass?" Lots of confusion on that front.Because there is no dedicated line to funnel pass holders toward the security check, you could make it all the way to the front of the line (for security checks, we of course understand their importance) and find yourself with 10 people clamouring to get in front of you. One more security guard, or a dedicated queue wherein the one guard could check 5 from one line and then 5 from the other would not go amiss. Like a Disney World Fast Pass - you've jumped *most* of the queue already, you can wait for 5-10 people to have their security check, you'll get to pass them once past security anyway!Then there's two dedicated lines once past security except the pre-purchase line (to the right) involves those people walking directly in front of the registers and those waiting to buy tickets even though they don't need a ticket so you think you're at the front, they think they're at front and the reality is that they can walk on by but there's virtually no direction. Why the queues are the other way around makes no sense.All of this really put a damper on our visit. A lot of people around us looked frustrated and annoyed as well; while those with pre-purchased tickets looked sheepish and embarrassed as they "queue jumped" even though it's entirely their right! All that was needed was another formed queue and the second gate door opened. My step-mom commented several times on the Musee Rodin being an efficiency experts nightmare.Only two registers keeps the queue moving super slow as well. Unless that's the point? Washrooms in the main entrance have multiple stalls; inside the mansion the men's was out of service and the women's had one stall.Once finally inside we found ourselves in an amazing re-worked exhibit. Rodin sculptures are nothing short of spectacular and his personal donations has created such a wonderful museum. Seeing all of his practice pieces just goes to show that brilliant artists still need to work on their craft, something generally omitted. The gardens are lovely and laid out beautifully. I will certainly come back, but either with a pre-purchased ticket and my head kept down or as early in the day as possible.

Beautiful garden . Loved the gardens and despite some renovation and peaceful and relaxing outdoor activity recommended for a sunny day. The indoor museum was a bit disappointing and tickets are sold separately for the garden and museum so I strongly recommend you just skip the museum and enjoy the lovely garden and beautiful statues which includes some of his most famous work anyway
A real gem. This museum just recently reopened after an extensive renovation. The mansion and grounds has been lovingly restored to its original glory. If you love Rodin, you will love this museum.

A delight - especially in winter. We have just visited the Musee Rodin, having heard great things about its recent refurbishment. We were not disappointed. The exhibits in the house are arranged very thoughtfully, allowing one to see the progression of Rodin's work. The audio guide provides short, informative narrations on the key objects, without overwhelming one with detail.Visiting in December meant that we avoided the crowds. Most of the other visitors seemed to be Parisians, with a number of young families taking advantage of the Christmas holidays. The day of our visit was unusually warm, so walking round the lovely gardens was even more of a delight. We were even able to enjoy a good lunch at the cafe sitting outside.It is worth combining a visit here with a trip to Les Invalides, which is clearly visible from the museum and less than 10 minutes' walk away.

beautful garden in summer!. When we visited in May - the house was still being furnished We still had the opportunity to examine Rodin's The Gates of Hell, The Thinker and The Burgers of Calais within the beautiful garden.

Wonderful hidden jem of Paris. There's no shortage of world class museums and galleries in Paris, but the Rodin Museum is unmissble. Set in a converted hotel the house and grounds are in themselves a wonderful few hours, but added to that the amazing collection of the work of one of the greatest scupters in the history of art is fantastic. There is all of his greatest achievements "the kiss" etc and a good number of lesser known sculptures and sketches. I've visited this museum many times and it never lets me down. On one occasion I watched the famous "gates of hell" sculpture (a giant bronze door covered in naked writhing sinners burning in hell) being cleaned. They were using blow torches on the metal to remove a layer of corrosion. Utterly amazing.

Disappointing. I love Rodin but the pilgrimage to see where he lived and worked were disappointing. Building works disrupted the entrance and main house so a second rate exhibition and the gardens were only available. The fountains were empty so the whole place had an under-construction feel. There were a few good sculptures dotted around but nothing as good as The Met in New York. The cafe was grossly overpriced with surly service. Bad day at the Brion.
Sculpture lovers must see. Reopened and fabulous. Sculpture garden and vast Rodin collection in the renovated museum. Easy to see after D'Orsay or venture from the Eiffel. Make time as it is amazing.

Hotel Biron, the residence of Rodin, now a museum dedicated to the master sculptor. The Rodin Museum is located in the Hotel Biron, an elegant mansion built in 1730, where the artist lived and worked. A new visitors' entrance (just a two minute walk from the Varenne Metro stop), gift shop, library and temporary exposition room are part of the major restoration of the museum. When we visited in August the house was not yet open, so we have another good excuse to return to the City of Lights. The beautiful garden was in full bloom however, and Rodin's The Gates of Hell, The Thinker and The Burgers of Calais were magnificently displayed in the summer sun.Open from Tuesday - Sunday, with hours varying by season.

More than just the thinker . Anyone familiar with Rodin's work knows what he is beat known for, but this collection shows the many sides of this artists abilities. From paintings, to the casts in the garden areas you can spend a good couple of hours admiring it all. Admission is €8 or is covered under your Paris Pass

Exceptional !!!. Our last visit to Paris was tarnished because we found the Musée Rodin closed still for refurbishing. Now re-opened and looking so polished, this is a must for any fine arts wish list of Paris. Give yourself 3 hours -- go in the morning with a picnic in the gardens; go at lunchtime, picnic in the gardens and then tour the art in the Hôtel Biron [the museum]. Four hours at the Musée d'Orsay and you have seen maybe half of the salons; four full days in the Louvre and you may have visited a quarter of their offerings. Rodin's life is art in many forms and this small museum is dedicated to exposing his life and his art. Though bursting with great works, two hours will give full pleasure.The directrice and staff have done an excellent job with the catalog and presentation, both interior and exterior [in the gardens]. I was amazed to find that Rodin had amassed such a fine collection of art from other artist. His gallery of paintings is an extra bonus.Take the time to watch the videos in the little space under the staircase and the videos cycling on two screens in the first salon. Also use the audio guide. They are chalked full of information and have additional information segments you can access by just hitting the PLAY button a second time.

Wow - beautiful museum. This museum was recently renovated. The sculpture garden was amazing, even on a gray winter afternoon. The museum was toasty warm, and the guides were very helpful.The only challenge we had? There's a glassed-in area in the garden with assorted works. No matter how we tried we couldn't make out the descriptions. They are in white type, which against white art, and white/gray sky -- illegible. Minor issue. We will return!

A beautiful space in Paris.. Great museum especially the garden with the works of Rodin. The hotel des Invalides, and the lovely French house serves as great backdrop to his art.Come about sunset for some amazing light in the garden.
Do not miss the gardens. The newly re-opened Musée Rodin is a splendor, but the true beauty lies in its gardens. Try to go there mid of the afternoon and enjoy the sunset there.

Nice grounds!. Since we had our Museum Pass we only had to wait in a short line to go through security. Once inside the grounds we immediately saw the Thinker. The grounds are very nice. The museum held a few surprises in such as works by Van Gogh. The exhibits seemed to be arranged chronologically by the periods of Rodin's life and stages of his growth as an artist. Would have liked to understand more about the process of creation, but film was in French.

The Thinker and Balzac are incredible!!'. I have been to Paris 15 times and I've been to the Rodin Museum at least eight. This is an incredible experience where you will want to do some research on Rodin before you go. Walking through the garden and seeing the Thinker and Balzac are my two absolute favorites! There are several incredible sculptures and paintings to be, but spend some time just looking at the thinker and then spent some time looking at Balzac will truly move you. Read Balzac's history before you go and it'll make you feel like you're standing there right in front of him.

One of our Favorite. If you are touring alone or with family with children, this museum is great not only for the wonderful sculpture but the peace & tranquillity if offers. We visited with our 3 grandchildren who were 11, 13, 15 & was perfect for their exploring as well as playing & running off energy in the gardens. I loved the little tea house there for us all to rest & have refreshments. Of course, the genious of Rodin was not lost in this exposure as evidenced in their daily journals that the children kept. One granddaughter,13 years, gave a presentation to her class this fall of all the wonderful exposure to various artists & museums that she had visited while in Paris. Hopefully a trip that will have lifetime memories. KathyB, NC, USA

Not to be missed!. The Musee Rodin offers and insight into Rodin that can not be gained elsewhere. The display of his sculptures and other artwork in his former home brings him back to life in a manner hard to capture otherwise....the volume of work and process to the final art piece is laid out for all to see. However, beware of the crowds. Although the museum tries to limit the numbers of viewers, it is still very crowded and sometimes difficult to view larger sculptures because of people crowding around. Nevertheless, it is an experience you will remember.

Fantastic sculptures and garden. Great would be to visit the first sunday of the month when this museum is free, thus making the visit even more appealing; there is a fantastic garden with many works of Rodin, his most famous ones. An absolute must when in Paris.

Fascinating Window into the Great Sculpter Auguste Rodin. You know his work - "The Thinker," "The Kiss," "The Gates of Hell." This interesting and manageable museum devoted to the work of Auguste Rodin is a perfect morning or afternoon visit. Located in the 7th Arondissment near the Eiffel Tower and the Musee d'Orsay, you can add this to a broader itinerary. The grounds and gardens are lovely and offer an ideal setting for some of Rodin's larger works. Pay extra to get the audio for interesting details on Rodin and his work.

A great museum with marvelous gardens. My wife and I consider this a “must do” in Paris. In fact we go there every time we visit Paris. Begin your visit to the museum in the gardens going to the left of the museum. The gardens are a delight in any season. Before you leave visit the Café du Musée Rodin in the gardens for lunch or snacks. I use the Varenne station, line 13 (métro de Paris) to get there.To create a prefect morning in Paris include a visit to the Dôme des Invalides (the tomb of Napoleon) before your visit to the musée Rodin. The Dôme des Invalides opens at 10:00 and is closed on Mondays.

Mujsee Rodin - 20151211. Bit of a walk here from Notre Dame but well worth it. Be sure to buy both a ticket and audio-guide. Amazing collection! Rodin must have spent every day working. Not to be missed.
Reopened and Superb. Just reopened (although some work is still being completed) the Musee Rodin is superb. Beautifully presented timeline showing the progress of his work through his life.

Rodin, Rodin, Rodin!!!!!. All the Rodin pieces were excellant and the museum itself was one of the best we went to. Although some construction was going on, it didn't distract us from enjoying ourselves.

Stunning Renovation and a Beautiful Museum. Amazing comprehensive collection of Rodin's works. The garden is beautifully laid out, with many statues and informative notices I 3 languages by each. The many benches and chairs must make a beautiful slot to linger in the good weather. The mansion itself is stunning, and Rodin's works laid out in chronological order. This man was prolific, and the museum shows his works beautifully.

Long line but worth it. Get a museum pass to avoid waiting. Totally skipped the line with our passes. It was really cold outside and really hot inside but....zip through the inside portion to get a perspective on what you will see outside. Don't skip that step. Then enjoy all of the statutes and the Gates of Hell.

Must go for all Rodin fans!. You may know about Rodin's famous artwork, the Thinker, but how much do you know about Rodin himself? That's what Musee Rodin is there to tell you! Set in the mansion where Rodin used to live, Musee Rodin organizes his artwork in chronological order to describe his progression. This is definitely a must-go destination for all Rodin fans or generally people who are enthusiastic about sculptures!Musee Rodin has two main parts: a two-story interior exhibit and a garden exhibit, both has a sizable collection of his or his students' sculptures. Unlike most museums, Musee Rodin is actually better as a sunny day activity so you can walk through the beautiful garden and admire the interior exhibit in natural lighting. If you do not intend to hear the details, you can easily finish in an hour, but I highly recommend buying an audio guide to get the most out of this museum! Unless you are already knowledgeable on the matter, the audio guide truly helps in understanding the significance of each Rodin piece and its role in building up his famous style. I was a Rodin fan before I came in, and after spending two hours in there, I have even greater respect for this remarkable artist!Take an hour or two under a good weather to admire this beautiful museum! It's a shame that Paris doesn't advertise this as much as the Louvre or d'Orsay, but that simply means that the crowd is much smaller. Especially if you intend to get an audio guide, Musee Rodin is definitely an excellent museum to visit!---tl;dr version:1) Set in a mansion where Rodin used to live2) Good for a sunny day activity because of the garden3) Get an audio guide to get the most out of this museum!

Excellent smaller museum. My wife and I enjoyed this smaller museum. We are not big museum fans generally but we enjoyed this museum along with Espace Dali (near Montmartre) and l'Orangerie too, as they are all pretty easy to navigate. We also enjoyed Orsay but Louvre was too much for us, albeit very grand. This museum has both an indoor and outdoor component with the outdoor component being the more interesting of the two. if the weather is bad, I think you are better off waiting for the weather to improve so you can see the outside portion as well. I would probably rate this museum as less essential to your Paris adventure than Orsay or Louvre but probably the best museum to go to after those two larger ones and definitely any 5-6 trip or longer you should strongly consider going to Rodin museum.

A Masterpiece. I visited the day after the attacks on Paris. It was very somber and few people were visiting. Although the museum closed early since many other museums were closed, they were kind enough to let us complete our visit. When you walk out of the entrance facility you have 'The Thinker' on your right and the 'Gates of Heaven and Hell' and 'The Burgers' on your left. These masterpieces alone are worth the visit, and you get to see them both on entering and leaving. The chateau contains many of his plaster models and presents how he performed his art. The art is in the gardens, and visitors should stroll the entire estate since scuptures are dispersed throughout. My only disappointment was to find that 'La Defense' had been moved to the Rodin House in Meudon. Plan a leisurely couple of hours and take your time to enjoy the grounds.

Rodin's garden the best place to spend a day. The museum was closed for renovations, but for a reduced admission of 2 euros, we were able to spend a few hours in the garden, having a leisurely stroll and long lunch at the café. Believe it or not, this was the highlight of our time in Paris, it was a gorgeous sunny day, and away from the hustle and bustle. We've been to Paris a few times, but this would rate as the place I'd return to again and again

Hotel Biron and Rodin's Masterwork. After what seemed decades the Hotel Biron, residence of Rodin and now home to his priceless sculptures opened this November. Completely restored the Hotel Biron houses his personal painting collection, plaster models, bronze sculptures and marble statues. On opening day 1000 people, I was in line, waited for the gates to the Hotel, Musee and gardens to open. Whilst in Paris, all I can say is take time to see the life work of Rodin, his paintings (Monet, VanGogh and Renoirs) along with gardens and a hopeful sunny day to do so.
A wonderful sculpture garden. For any admirer of Rodin - a visit to the museum is a must. The statues and sculptures are excellently sited within a very beautiful garden.

Romantic, artistic, inspiring garden!. Really beautiful garden hidden in the city center! If you like art, this place is a must! Rodin's "Laboratory of creation" is a small museum exhibition placed inside the building, where you can find a lot of interesting details about Rodin's life and work. Expect to see many unfinished pieces of art: Victor Hugo, Thinker, Gates of hell statues, and many more.Garden is full of trees and flowers (roses mainly), with small pretty lake on one side and a lot of benches to sit and to enjoy the magnificent view to the old museum house and to the many famous statues placed all around the garden.
Boring Place. If you want to take a look around some gardens with a few naked statues on display then this is definitely the place for you. I found it extremely boring!

Beautiful mueseum - audioguide was worth it!. Make sure to show ID if you're under 26 because you get a discounted rate! Its a beautiful mueseum; the gardens are picturesque even in December. The audioguide helped me understand a lot, so that was helpful.

Beautiful sculpture garden. It is a small but beautiful museum with an excelent variety of Rodin famous sculpture works.Try to visit this when Paris has good weather because is important and nice to visit its garden

Great museum. I find Rodin fascinating... the museum is perfect, takes about 2 hours or so to walk through the 3 story house and his gardens. I learned a lot about his life and work, recommend the audio guide!

Don't miss the garden!. Of course, it's worth to go there to see Rodin's sculptures, especially the Calais-group. But the best is to go there on a sunny spring or summer day, walking through the garden, finding a quiet place apart from the house and enjoying a peaceful hour with a book or just looking around. Parisian students like to go there for learning.

Amazing Sculpture Garden. I've been to Musee Rodin twice, and was as enchanted on my second visit (despite extensive renovations in progress) as I was on the first. The outdoor sculpture garden is magnificant. If standing inches away from The Thinker doesn't give you a thrill, I don't know what will!

A Pleasant Experience. Not knowing anything at all about Monsieur Rodin and just going a long with a fellow traveller that wished to view it I was pleased to say it was a very pleasant experience. Unfortunately when we visited, the house was closed for renovations (I suspect this will not be a quick thing so might be worth checking first) but the gardens and statues where on view. We also stopped and had lunch at the cafe which offered some lovely fresh selections in the garden setting. Definitely worth a visit if you enjoy art or gardens and a bonus if you like both.

My fave. One of my favorite museums in all of Paris. It's less overwhelming, more manageable, than its larger and more famous brethren. Also, the works are predominately three dimensional (i.e. sculptures), and they seem to speak to me more than two dimensional works.

Just wonderful. We arrived early as it was free Sunday at the museums ( first Sunday in the month, not every museum is included) and were near the front of the queue. After security checks by friendly staff we entered this wonderful museum. The sculptures and paintings were stunning. My husband enjoys the novels of Honore dr Balzac so he enjoyed seeing all the sculptures of the writer. i really liked his dressing gown.The Museum has recently reopened after refurbishment and is really beautiful setting for the art works.The garden, even in December, was lovely .I would return and pay to visit this museum.

Lovely small museum. Stunning Rodin sculptures in an outdoor garden setting. Other priceless works in a lovely mansion (being updated this year). After you've been to the Louvre and Muse D'Orsay, this is not to be missed.
A Quiet Museum Day. This is a must see while in Paris. The museum maintains the feel of an elegant home in the city. Walking through the gardens to view the sculptures is a magical experience.

A favorite visit. Don't miss the Rodin Museum when visiting this great city. It is small, intimate and has a great garden. I love the small dedicated museums such as this one after a visit to one of the more famous Paris museums like the Louvre.

A wonderful setting!. One of our highlights of out family trip. The statues, the gardens, the chateau, even a cute wild rabbit, all combined for a wonderful afternoon. So many great pieces both inside the house and in the garden. Favourite include "The Thinker" and "Hells' Gates". I think my wife wants to buy the house!
Worth the visit. Stroll through the grounds, enjoy the gardens. The house is amazing andcthe art os engaging. Not too big, not too small.

Excellent re-design. We hadn't been here for a few years but had read good things about the recent changes at the Rodin Museum. The place has always been lovely, but we were thrilled with the new 'hanging' of the sculptures and the accompanying information. We had a sunny late autumn day, and it was great to stroll around the garden. Cafe is good food and good value, if rather thronged with the pointy-elbowed middle classes.

Reopened - what a gem!. If you like sculpture then this is a must. All his famous pieces - the thinker etc - laid out wonderfully in the gardens of a small mansion - the house where he lived at the end of his life. The house further works - such as the Kidd - and those of others and an exhibition - which I should warn is for the aficionado only. All for €10. And a nice little cafe. But go on a nice day so you can enjoy the garden!

An oasis in the city. For a very small charge you can enjoy a beautiful garden with outstanding art and a lot of history too. Be prepared for a little chaos in the ticket office and make sure you carry your ticket then at all times. You can be asked to show it. It's worth it though. Rodin was also an art collector, so his Van Gogh's are worth seeing what a shame he didn't purchase them in Vincent's lifetime!
Love this museum. This statues are amazing to see. A great museum with not only Rodin statues. You can also find Camlle Claudel and others.
Went for the thinker, loved other sculptures way more. gates of helleveadamthe shadowsthe kissall more impressive than the thinker, which in itself is very impressive.

Tears in my eyes. This is the most moving experience in France. Slow down, open your eyes and take it all in. The expression on these pieces is heartbreaking. Amazing. Life changing. What a great outdoor experience.

I love this museum. It is little but beautiful! I'd visited on a previous trip to France and had to return with my husband. The Thinker and Gates of Hell are worth the price of admission alone. Add in the grounds and you've got quite a nice museum. Would recommend!

Great break from inside tours. Very impressive to see Rodin's works broken down like this eg the Thinker both in and out of the Gates of Hell, or the burghers of Calais one by one and in different raiments. Each piece has a good description near by. I would like to see it again in summer when the surroundings would appear completely different although it was nice in November without a crowd.

Greatly overrated museum. Decent gardens. While the museum is highly overrated, the courtyard is actually a very interesting collection of sculptures, ensembles, landscaping and decorations which seem to offer the visitor a compelling impression of Rodin's art, tastes and personality. It is also conveniently located few minutes away from the Dome des Invoices.

Must see museum in Paris. This fantastic "hotel" housing the Rodin museum has just reopened to the public after a wonderful restoration. What is there not to like? The garden with all its wonderful bronzes is simply fantastic, its a great place to spend some time with a good book. One could spend hours just looking at "the Thinker" with the Eiffel Tower in the background. The house itself is is beautiful in its own right and it contains wonderful objects from Rodin's collect. I would recommend taking the audio guide

Just renovated. We returned to the Musee Rodin last month, for the first time in almost 20 years. The museum has just undergone its first major renovation.All of Rodin's great works are on display, either inside the museum, or in the surrounding gardens. There is also a room with the works of his much younger mistress and muse, Camille Claudel. How sad that her own family had her forcibly committed to an insane asylum, after Rodin dumped her.I highly recommend a morning, or afternoon at the museum, as it is small enough to be visited in a couple of hours. There is a small café in the garden, which is a nice place for a break.

Wonderful. After three years of renovation, the museum jsut opend in Mid November of thsi year. The museum and the gardens are wonderful. Not to be missed the walk in the garden (la porte de l'efer, les Bourgois de Calais, les ombres). Inside the museum is not cluttered ( contrary to the Picasso museum) and the Hotel de Maitre has been very well restaured. You can really appreciate the architecture in each room and the views onto the garden are beautiful. If you have time for only one museum in Paris, I would highly recommend the Rodin one. You will need at least 2 hours to be able to appreciate.
OK. Seeing "The Thinker" is the highlight for this museum. It has several sculptures that are outside vs. inside paintings that you see at many of the other museums.

Newly renovated. If you can, buy tickets ahead of time to avoid the long lines. Also, I would suggest going early and, if possible, on a sunny day because the natural light truly enhances the experience both indoors and in the gardens. Overall this museum is encyclopedic---and at times less would have been more. The audio guide in English was excellent and allowed us to learn a lot of information!

Sculptures everywhere and not only. This superb museum, located near venerable institutions such as The Invalides, the US Embassy, the French Ministry of Agriculture, etc. is hosted in the former Biron Palace. Rodin spent years as a tenant and created dozens of major works there. Completely renovated it has re-opened this year. The grounds and gardens are magnificent with many Rodin Statues displayed among beautiful trees, with constant views towards the golden Dome of the Invalides.

Peaceful. This Museum was partly being reconstructed when we visited. However, it felt like most of the pieces were still accessible in the garden so not sure how much we really missed. The sculptures are laid out in this gorgeous garden setting and it was tranquil and peaceful to stroll around.

Wonderful artwork. We only went to the sculpture garden, but that is where Rodin's finished works are and the Thinker and gates of Hell are spectacular. The Garden is also a pleasant place for a stroll and has a nice cafe where you can grab lunch.

A Must if you visit Paris. We got here by Taxi, as the bus routes to get here were not understood by us tourists. It was worth the taxi ride, lots of great exhibits, lots of history, Highly recommended

Spectacular Sculpture...Open Late on Wednesdays. This is a wonderful museum and the plan and presentation of all the works are beautifully situated throughout the mansion. The info on how the statues are made from plaster casts to the brilliant bronze was very interesting. Still the favorite spot is the gardens with the large Thinker statue as a highlight. The museum is open late on Wednesdays, so work that into your plans. The gardens were dark at night when we visited late in December, but during the day are gorgeous. Also covered on the museum pass.

A wonderful place to show off his work.. We could not go into the hotel where he lived and died as it was having construction done. However, the grounds and the placement of his pieces is what make this tour great. there is plenty of time and space to reflect on what you see. You are not subject to having to decide what among hundreds of paintings and sculptures you have just seen.We left with our thoughts still centered on what we had just experienced.
Spectacular. The audio guide was extremely helpful. The exhibit carefully arranged.mwe had not been here in over 25 years. The renovation is wonderful.
Spectacular Museum. We enjoyed strolling the gardens even on a chilly November day. This museum is not to be missed. There is a lovely cafe just off the main garden behind the palace.

Reopened. This was one of the places that did not close up after the terrorist attacks but security has been increased.The complete site has now reopened so we could not see what we had missed on our previous visit. And it was worth coming back.The museum is well run with numbers controlled through the two main buildings so it does not become too much of a scrum. There are many notable pieces and a lot of source material displayed. Information is in both french and english adjacent to the exhibits. Only slight negative is that there is occasionally no natural flow so there is a bit of doubling back to see things.Nice cafe on site as well set in the delightful gardens which gives a pleasant break.

It is now even better than it was before the renovation. The organization is original and wonderful. The setting in the garden is unique - you really sense Rodin !!!The additions to the Rodin works really enrich the exhibition !
Musee Rodin (Camille claudel). do not ever forget that Rodin Used women the number one is his lover Camille Claudel.many people believe that his work was done by her he just signed the work

Construction took away. This was my 2nd visit here, last time it got 5 stars because it was just beautiful and relaxing to stroll around. This time unfortunately the garden area around his most famous works were under construction making for limited viewing and difficulty walking around because of the narrow spaces and numbers of people. The works are still magnificent, but the construction barrier which were just giant boards take away from the experience. Hopefully they are gone now.
Lacking organisation . A beautiful place with some great pieces but the organisation of the staff and the entrance esp leaves a lot to be desired
Wow - so much Rodin in such a fine spot. Well worth a good visit - Do this... The works beautiiully presented. Rodin would surely have been pleased. Worth a quiet visit and just gaze and adore

Up close with Rodin. This museum provides an incredibly intimate experience of Rodin's work. As you go through the museum you become familiar with his methods of developing his pieces and have access to a wide variety of his pieces, large and small.

Very Disappointing. I visited on a rainy and cold Saturday. The line wasn't too long, but they still made us wait outside for over thirty minutes since there is no space inside for more than a few people to stand in line to get tickets. Most of the Rodin pieces inside the building are plaster planning models and sketches. Everything looks like it is half finished. There are a few bronzes inside, but most of the major works are outside, in the freezing cold rain, which I did not get too see since it was getting dark so early. The only good thing is that it is inexpensive at only 10 EUR.

Great way to spend a day. This collection of Rodin's work is presented in a lovely old chateau, where he apparently lived for some time. In addition to plaster casts and bronzes, his paintings are here as well as paintings he owned by other artists, including Van Gogh. Rodin's paintings were quite beautiful -- he did landscapes in addition to the studies I expected to see. He sometimes did several castings of sculptures, including The Thinker, presented in an outdoor garden setting. There were two walls that featured studies he'd done: one wall of hands, another wall of feet, ankles, and legs. In addition to Rodin's work, there are works by his student Camille Claudel. In fact, one of her works was actually my favorite of the exhibit; specifically The Waltz, which had remarkable fluidity and movement. There is a little cafe on the property that serves above-average fare for this type of setting (at least in the US it's above-average. In France, it's just about what you'd expect.) Highly recommended if you enjoy art, particularly sculpture.

Garden and sculptures make it a wonderful trip. The museum was under construction, but the main thing we wanted to see were the sculptures in the gardens that were clearly still open to the public. From the Thinker to the Gates of Hell and many other famous works, we had a great time. You can stay there as long as you would like - there were some people there having lunch and drinks there as if they were in a regular city park. It was not very crowded as compared to other landmarks in the area and an easy walk and place to find. It is in the same general area as the Musee de Orsay and Louvre for those who might be visiting the other landmarks.
Beautiful Museum and Sculptures. A museum devoted to one of the greatest artists is essential to visit. The bronze sculptures are exquisite.

Good Museum, But Still Under Construction. The grounds are beautiful and fully available. One museum building is open, but does not offer a large amount of art. The main building is being renovated and not currently (as of October 2015) open. Your Paris museum pass is good here and will save you some money. Signs along the way make it easy to find from the metro exit. Not recommended until it is all open, unless you just want another art museum to visit.

Great museum.. Loved visiting the Rodin Museum! We went on a Saturday late morning, it wasn't too busy yet. We spent some time inside enjoying the pieces before walking around the gardens. Its so quiet and peaceful, we enjoyed lunch there! I liked that this museum was focused and not overwhelming in size. Would recommend!

Worth a stop. I had always heard that the Musee Rodin was wonderful, but had been to Paris five times and never got around to it. This time, I am very glad we took the two hours to check out the museum. It is a wonderful illustration of Rodin's best work.

The Thinker was nice to see. The museum was still undergoing renovations when we visited so perhaps we did not experience this museum as we should have, that is why my review is lower than most. We really only got to see some sculptures that honestly did not really interest us inside the museum. The gardens were pretty but even a lot of those sculptures were monotonous and nothing that really excited us. We did enjoy seeing the Thinker though and outside of that we did not think much of the rest of what we saw. We did visit the cafe and found it to be very nice.

Wonderful! But wait for the re-opening of the house in early 2016.. My 4th visit. In spite of the house being closed, this is a wonderful place to visit though street signage (if you do not know the area) is poor. Queues are normal. Internationally infamous works of art by Rodin are numerous in the gardens and (normally) in the house too. The historical development of his subjects is interesting with different media, scale of representation and single aspects on display. Some of the heads and hands are the finest bronzes ever made by anyone, ever. Look out also (in the house) for the life-size terracotta head 'woman in a straw hat' believed to be his lover, then in the last days of his life, his wife, Rose Beuret.

Great Visit. We enjoyed this museum and the $10 euros was a reasonable entry fee. The museum is actually in 2 buildings and a lovely garden in between. We were there when it opened (at 10:00am) and the lines were not long. One of the buildings is a former hotel and it is lovely inside and a great structure to display the masterpieces of Rodin. If you are a Rodin fan, it is a must see.

Excellent overview of Rodin's life and works. Rodin's sculpture is the highlight of the museum, though it also contains three Van Gogh, one Renoir, and one Monet painting. Everyone is probably quite familiar with Rodin's public works, especially The Thinker, The Kiss, and Hands. Most of the items on exhibit are not the bronze works that can be found in the world's great museums, but plaster works that were models for those great works. The museum is in an old two story villa with a large garden in back. I was fascinated by the story of how Rodin decided to bequeath all of his works to the State, and also how he chose the Hotel Biron as his home away from home, where he would meet people during the last decade of his life.The Musée Rodin just reopened on 12 November 2015, so it's very popular. Even if you book your ticket online, you may have a wait to enter the museum.

Wonderful. I went to the reopening of the museum - and it is better than the last time I visited (2010). There was only a five-minute queue (unlike the 1 hour plus queue in 2010), so I was pleased - this also included time for the extra security. Exhibits are better displayed - especially the lighting. Much much better with no shadows. There was an extra room and lots of new exhibits that I had not seen before.It had rained the day before so parts of the garden were muddy, and it was approaching winter so it wasn't as green as last time, but I was there to see the sculptures (not the flowers). And of course they were magnificent. Fortunately there was blue sky so it was lovely to stroll around looking at Rodin's garden.
Fabulous . A truly enjoyable experience. The gardens are beautiful with iconic Rodin pieces and the museum is not only fascinating but well laid out.

Gardens. If you are a Rodin fan, this should be on your list. If you aren't, you may truly enjoy a visit here. ADVICE: no great need to pay extra for the museum. A stroll through the garden is perfect--lots of works to enjoy

Iconic sculptures in a relaxing park. The main museum was still closed when we arrived, but in the entrance building they had a very interesting and informative display of Rodin's workshop and of his works while in progress that provided very informative background on what we saw out in the park. There were many selected sculptures scattered around a large and relaxing park. We grabbed a sandwich in the cafe out in the park and enjoyed the beautiful day we had. We wound up spending much more time here than we thought and it was some of our most pleasant time in Paris.

Well worth an afternoon visit.. I went on 12th November, the day the museum opened after refurbishment. Long queues to get in and about an hours wait but well worth it. Great museum, lots to see inside the building and in the grounds and a nice cafe to use in the rear garden area.
Tres tres beau. I love going to Paris museum in the zero that was an incredible experience that that would definitely suggest to everyone that is in love with our culture

Lovely gallery. it was a little disappointing to find that the gallery was undergoing renovations when we were there, BUT every cloud has a silver lining! We were "forced" outside and thus saw more of the statues in the garden than I saw when I was last there (and the gallery was open). While we were enjoying the gardens, we saw a group of blind patrons experiencing the statues which was fascinating, and also saw the fashion week stands being set up.

Not to be missed - a special place. Come see Rodin's best work in an incredibly beautiful and intimate setting. The museum is housed in a building known as the Hôtel Biron. The gardens that also display a number of his works are lovely at any time of year. You can see, in a natural setting, The Thinker, the Gates of Hell and The Kiss. Rodin really understood depth and passion, which shows in his sculptures that really embody different human emotions and experiences like love, conflict and dispair. His understanding of the human body is shown clearly in the poses and defined musculature of his sculptures. It's a serene experience. Peaceful if your alone, romantic with a partner. This museum outshines the Louvre experience with regards to connecting with work and the artist. It's really not to be missed, and is a pleasant walk from the Eiffel tower if you're in the area. There are also works by his lover, Camille Claudel and other pieces of art from his personal collection. You can also see his drawings. Enjoy!

My favorite spot in Paris!. This Museum is my favorite part of visiting Paris. The sculpture gardens are breathtaking and always very relaxing to walk around in. The extensive collection of Rodin works are unmatched anywhere. This is a great place to enjoy a relaxing afternoon. A must see!

A highlight. We visited the Museum basically to fill in a little spare time but it turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip to Paris. Aside from the Thinker, there were a number of other fascinating works on display. The gardens themselves are a beautiful tranquil spot.

Better now than ever!. We were excited to hear that the museum was reopening on the day of arrival from visiting Oslo and we saw the museum on Friday, just before the attacks. We love the new arrangement whereas you enter the museum through what is designed to be the workshop of Rodin with studies, prototypes and models of his famous works. The main house is beautifully arranged and very informative in showing how the casting process is done and sculptures are created. Please note that toilet breaks need to be thought out carefully since there is more to see and not many toilets available. Thanks so much for a wonderful job in restoration.

Lovely museum and gardens. Such a peaceful place amongst the masterpieces and the well laid out gardens. Great place to walk around, take a seat and admire the master's works. Well worth the reasonable charge. Easily accessed by the metro network.

Enjoyed enjoyed enjoyed . What a peaceful and lovely place to visit. Although he inside was closed for refurbishment, but he garden had plenty of statues to see. Especially the Thinker? The place to mimic his post. Lovely and peaceful place. Delighted to have included as part of our trip. Enjoy.

never disappoints. We have been to the Musee Rodin on multiple other occasions, but decided to go back after some years away. We were not disappointed, even though the main museum was closed for renovations. They had set up a nice (but somewhat limited) alternative display inside, but the gardens were open and the weather cooperated so we spent more time outside this trip and still enjoyed the amazing art.
The Kiss! Make time for this.. Interesting journey through Rodin's career showing work product from inception to finish. Garden is a gem.

Come on a sunny day. The Musee Rodin has just undergone renovation and reopened to the public. Who would imagine I would be writing this a day after the barbaric attack on this wonderful city. But yes, life will go on. Come and spend a day in this inpiring museum, and if you come on a sunny day, you will not miss all the art in the garden. I myself have not been there since the renovation I have seen advertisid in metro stations, but it is one of my favorite haunts in Paris.

superb setting enhannces masterpieces. Though the main building was being renovated at the time of our visit, the gardens around this display the Rodin masterpieces we were not fazed at all.The fact that he lived in this building and the history one learns just adds to the experience.an absolute must for art lovers.

I would fly back to paris just to visit once again!. Rodin! Stroll along the manicured alles and visit with the sculptures personally. Sit on a bench and observe the visitors. Stop by the gelato cart in the garden and try violet gelato. Inside the building you can visit with Rodin's smaller works and studies set amid beautiful Parisian appointments. My last visit the house was closed for renovations. When it reopens, it will he more lovely than I remember. The rose garden in front is worth the price admission alone!!

Charming. Luckily my trip coincided with the re-opening of the museum. The gardens are joyful to wander around with the Gates of Hell particularly breath-taking. Enjoyed inside as well although more crowded. Marvellous surprise to see three gorgeous Van Goghs there too. Only downside was that the general organisation was a bit chaotic so leave a little extra time to get in.

Greatest Rodin collection re-opened !. Better and expanded after 3 years of renovation, the Musée Rodin offers lots to see and enjoy, including some 200 works not shown before. Beyond his world-famous masterpieces, you can discover his art collection of contemporary artists, Greek and Roman pieces, his astonishing 'collages' of Greek pottery with his own plaster studies, splendid works by his mistress Camille Claudel. The expansive garden (7 acres in the heart of Paris!) hasn't changed much -beautiful as before and strewn with his great bronzes. An art lover's must!! My only regret: not enough background info; labels placed at knee-level...!
Amazing masterpiece sculptures. I do not think a trip to Paris could be complete without going to the Rodin museum and gardens. The gardens features a large collection of many of Rodin's sculptures.

Stunning. We were somewhat disappointed walking around the museum until we came to the end of the display to be confronted by a notice informing us that the display of art continued out in the gardens.We exited the building and I was literally astonished at the extent of the gardens and the numerous sculptures it contained.Well worth a visit when in Paris and it is just round the corner from the Hotel des Invalides another museum worth a look.

Our favorite museum in Paris. There are two parts of this experience as renovation goes on. Inside, the exhibition includes photographs and plaster casts from Rodin's studio, illustrating the process involved in the creation of the finished pieces. It traces his work from early days to the conclusion of his career.
