Very interesting and informative, with good English text.Finished pieces, in bronze and marble are outside, in an absolutely beautiful garden setting. Such a pleasurable way to really appreciate this magnificent work!
Worth the visit. The main exhibit was closed while we were there in early November. The gardens were still open as was a temporary exhibit. Well worth the trip.

A huge garden full of sculpture. This is where Rodin lived in exchange for donating his work to the State of France. His actual home is under renovation so it can't be toured but the museum has an interesting display illustrating how he worked (i.e plaster models). The garden itself has work after work that we have come to know and love and is well worth your time.
After Rodin's rewanmping. Big Works in the Museum( for the safety of the very old wooden floors)New presentation,in the different floors, and more works to admire, in the garden aswell
Know need to THINK on this One!. A trip to Paris would not be complete without seeing Rodin's work! Walking around the gardens and viewing the statues was inspiring.
Rodin. was closed for renovations on the day so cant review it,look great from the outside maybe next time .

THINKER'S PLACE. In September the museum was closed for renovations and should open soon. The only interior space accessible to the public was his studio. It is not worth the price of admission. One should wait until the entire museum is open to the public.On the other hand, for the minimal price of admission, the visit to the garden is a must. On a sunny worm day it is a delightful experience.Auguste Rodin, considered to be one of the greatest 19th century French sculptors moved in on the first floor of Hotel Biron, now a museum. He made it his studio in 1908. Eventually he occupied the whole building until his death in 1917. In lieu of rent he donated his entire collection and possessions to the nation, in which manner he saved the building from being demolished.The well kept the park displays many if his well known sculptures including the famous Thinker, set in the portion of formal garden. The leisurely walk will take one by many of his sculptures. The Gates Of Hell Door on the left, the Burgers of Calais,, Balzac and many more.The garden has natural ares and thousands of roses. Eiffel twerp and skyline of Paris can be seen from the garden

The Musée Rodin reopens to-morrow. The musée Rodin is one of the most attractive museums in Paris. It is situated near the superb Invalid church, in a beautiful garden whre we can admire some of Rodin's sculptures (The Thinker, Les Bourgeois de Calais..The museum was closed for several months for refurbishment. It will reopen tomorrow, November 12th. The museum used to be Rodin's home and studio, where he lived with his lover the famous lady Sculptor, Camille Claudel who became mad and spent the rest of her life in a psychiatic asylum. The house and garden are wonderful with many sculptors of Rodin and Camille Claudel, the greatest French sculptors. The Rdin museum is a must in Paris.
Fantastic. Lovely garden,, amazing place to spend an afternoon ,,,couldn't ask for more,,,be sorrounding by priceless pieces of art ,,, what an amazing feeling .
If you like Rodin you can't miss the place.... In a good weather its worth to go and touch the history. Go slow, read and watch, enjoy. Better to spend an hour here than in Eiffel Tower.
Undergoing refurb. Half price entry with full access to the garden and its collection. Indoors there's a good collection of plasters. The cafe is good for lunch.

One of my favorite places in Paris. Rodin's work is truly magnificent and we spent hours studying it. The interior was still under renovation but the garden was superior with statues carefully placed in great settings. Again I could visit this many more times. I need to live in Paris.

What stands out is the facial expression on each his works. A space dedicated to the works of Auguste Rodin, this Museum is a must-visit. While this exhibition requires fairly lesser time to tour around (and why of course, for it houses the works of Rodin exclusively), the attention to detail to each of his works is enough to capture one's eye and root them to the spot, lest they miss any of the finer details. Audioguides are available at the front counter for those who wish to understand the pieces' details. These are made available in English, French, Italian, Spanish and Korean at 5 Euros per piece.The inner part of the Museum consists of only parts of his works; the life-sized sets are displayed for consideration in the gardens. This allows one to walk around the sculptures freely in open air. His famous works, 'The Thinker' and 'The Gates of Hell' are also found here. For a novice (as me) who barely understands arts, one of the interesting features of Rodin's works is the expression he has captured on each of his faces. They vary from displaying shock, depression, sadness to awe, inspiration and admiration. Some even showcase indifference.Although sadly, The hôtel Biron was closed for refurbishment while we visited, we would certainly want to go back for a second look.

Great Outdoor Activity. A stroll through the gardens was a great outdoor activity for us on a sunny day. The entrance was included in our Paris Pass/Art Pass and it was very nice to be able to stroll around and sit on the benches to admire the works and read about their history. A beautiful place for a relaxing few hours or a nice quick stroll I'm sure if you were in a hurry to get through but still wanted to be outside in the sun.
Stunning works of art. A lovely museum and some amazing pieces of sculpture. It was a shame the main part of the museum was closed for refurbishment at the time I visited.

Always a must. Anyone at all interested in Rodin would of course enjoy the Rodin Museum. Although we visited during the renovations and the interior of the building was closed, the major works are still visible outside. Although there are a number of castings of all of these works scattered around the world, seeing them on the grounds of the Hotel Biron where Rodin spent much of his time is still special. Of course, soon the full Museum will reopen and it again will become a major attraction because of the wealth of history related to Rodin and the full display of exhibits not available anywhere else.
Wow!!!. Rodin...enormous amount of talent. His work is mesmerizing. It depicts an earlier era, but was created in the late 19the and early 20the century. The 'Thinker' is his centerpiece.

Good art, rude staff. When I visited the museum was partially under renovation, but a temporary exhibit was set up and the garden was open. The garden is very lovely and it is not too busy, the works were gorgeous. However the staff was extremely rude and snobbish. Aside from general demeanor I was yelled at multiple times to keep my backpack in front of me, even though I did so the first time I was told. I noticed that many others were walking the gallery with backpacks on their backs, some bigger than mine. The museum curators paid no attention whatsoever to the visitors and were much more interested in their phones, and the reception was rude and brusque. So, come for the art if you are interested in it, but overall not as pleasant an experience as it could be.
Best For Fans. If you're a fan of Rodin, then you can't miss this. Even if you don't love the sculptor, it has a serene little garden.
Beautiful Gardens. Beautiful small museum with lovely gardens and a great café serving pastries that must have been sourced from a Rue Cler bakery.

Small, no long line for entry. The home of Le Penseur, the Thinker. I happened to pass by on my walk to the Louvre. No long line for entry. The Thinker statue is in the garden. Beautiful grounds. If short for time, not worth time to go see...

AWESOME!. It was a life long dream come true to visit there and it did not disappoint my wife made me go because she knew I wanted it so bad and I am glad she did even with the renovations going on it was still the best
beautiful. Enjoyed the layout of the gardens, and, obviously, the sculptures. Only €2 for just the gardens. Very relaxing and good for all ages.

Peaceful garden. Truthfully, I was most interested in going right outside to see the statues and the beautiful garden.We had fun, it was a beautiful sunny day. There were some interesting works of art in the museum too.
Beautiful building. A beautiful museum we appreciated visiting. The art exposed is beautiful and felt privileged to visit it on a non-crowded day.
Have to see if in Paris. Lovely art and excellent commentary. Line up long but worth the wait. If you can buy tickets in advance.

Once Museum Re-Opens It Will Likely Be An Excellent Attraction. On our recent trip to Paris my wife and I visited the Rodin Museum. As one of our favourite sculptors we were very much looking forward to the visit. We were disappointed to learn (only after having entered) that the main building was closed for renovations. The garden and the works of art on display there are impressive and amongst Rodin's most famous. That said the museum itself appears to give greater insight into the life and labours of this man and would have been a capper. We still got to view The Thinker, The Burghers of Calais, The Gates of Hell and more. This is well worth the time and is covered on the Museum Pass.
The Thinker is here. Beautiful grounds, lots of amazing sculptures. There is an outside garden with several of Rodin's sculptures including The Thinker. It was an amazing place.
Great insight into the sculptor's work. When we visited much of the museum was under renovation but there was an interesting exhibition. Outside, in the lovely gardens, there were more sculptures.
Good take. I liked this museum. Small and manageable, mostly sulptures. Good break from the large scale museums.

Beautiful garden full of Rodin sculptures. The indoor museum was under renovations when we visited but we enjoyed the outdoor sculpture garden. Though "The Thinker" is the highlight there are so many other Rodin sculptures to enjoy.

The thinker and the Kiss in a beautiful garden. It was nice to see the Thinker and the Kiss statues for which Rodin is so famous. The gardens were also nice but not much else to see. It is a nice place to relax and less busy than other museums. We had the Paris Pass so it was worth going to as it was included but i don't think I would have paid the entrance fee to go in otherwise.

Main museum reopening soon. The main house/ museum was closed due to renovations when I was there mid October 2015 so it was disappointing and the gardens were muddy. It was not worth the time. BUT I'm giving it an "excellent" because I was there once before when it was uncrowded and informative and charming. I'm sure it will be even better after the renovations. Check and make sure everything is open before you go.

INCREDIBLE MUSEUM. This museum has the grace and history of being in a home in the heart of Paris..........while exploring the grounds and the home you can get a feel and a sense of what it must have been like and to read about the sculptures and the biography of Rodin....makes it a special experience.

Don't think about it, go. My review is based on previous visits. This October the museum is under major renovation. The bronzes in the garden are still there, but the house, and many of the sculptures are not available.When the renovation is done, I am sure it will be a worthwhile trip.
Mostly closed. . The museum was mostly closed. We could see the thinker from outside, the kiss was closed and there was only part of the museum open to the public. A wasted journey!
Construction. Unfortunately, the main museum was closed for renovations when we visited. However, the items on display were wonderful to see, and the garden, even though it was October, was lovely.

Well worth the visit.. The museum was closed for renovations when we were there but the beautiful gardens have many bronze statues including The Thinker. We spent over an hour and loved every minute. Too bad we couldn't see the marble statues inside but glad we went.

Wonderful museum. Small museum, but has a lot of wonderful sculptures, my favorite "the Thinker" you can find there, and I like their garden as well. Not crowded, you can take your time and soak in everything, read the inscrptions or get the audio guide. It is probably a better choice than the very big museum, you get more of a personal feel of it.

Wonderful wonderful . You can get really close to the sculptures here. It can get a little tight when it is crowded. The best part is the gardens- hang out with the Thinker- view the roses that are as big as your head! What a relaxed atmosphere to view such great works of art. Again I say - don't rush. Take it all in at a leisurely pace. You can grab a bite in the garden cafe! How cool to have a cup of coffee in Rodin's back yard!!
A Must See. Love the bronze of Balzac in the gardens, and the house where Rodin hosted guests and fans. Amazing sculpture of course and the collection is astounding. Must see if you love Rodin.

A favorite museum in Paris. One of our favorite museums in Paris. Get a headset so you can really appreciate the sculptures. It is a smaller museum and only takes an hour or so; has a nice garden to just sit and relax.

Intimate Museum Experience!. This little gem felt quite personal in its size and collection. The text accompanying the sculptures were informative and offered a sense of shared history in its intimacy. As i was caught in a downpour during my visit to the museum, i missed much of the gardens but can assure readers that the light within the museum mansion is spectacular and enhances every sculpture. While many of the pieces are well known, the lesser known sculptures are just as compelling and offer a glimpse into Rodin's life and creative process.
Fabulous if you love sculpture. Or just the Thinker.. Informative info in the muse on when and where and why and how Rodin created the sculptures. The real back story that makes it all come alive.

Loved the Garden. We spent very little time inside the museum (It is undergoing renovation), but we spent about an hour walking around the gardens, stopping at the cafe, and admiring the sculptures. We saw so many incredible sculptures including "The Thinker," "The Kiss," and "The Gates of Hell." The information plaques in front of the artwork increased our understanding of Rodin's life and works. The gardens were beautiful, quiet, and restful, a perfect place to linger while in Paris.

Among the best museums anywhere. This museum is small enough to be manageable, yet full of fantastic masterpieces. Outdoor sculpture garden is great even in rain or winter. Light within the mansion that houses the museum is stunning.

Surprising little gem. Loved the garden, it's beautifully maintained. Sadly some part of the garden and the hotel Biron was undergoing construction and was closed. The Thinker and gates of hell sculptures were in the garden. Good place for photo taking as the whole place was very picturesque. I think this place will be even more beautiful in spring next year.

Art Experience. Located in what was a private home, this is a must see museum for anyone who likes sculpture. It is fascinating to see finished work, studies, incomplete works. The garden is a great place to just sit and and admire the Thinker. You can take a replica of sculpture home as a memento of your visit. Best to go on a sunny or fair day so the gardens can be enjoyed properly.

Fascinating Garden. Lots of construction going on at the site. We didn't go into the house, but instead wondered around the gardens. If you can delay your visit until the construction is over, your visit will be more enjoyable. If you cannot postpone, go to see the garden statuary.

Loved it. This was an unexpected gem in Paris, we knew about it, but was not sure we could fit it in. We all thoroughly enjoyed the sculptures, they were absolutely amazing. A real surprise was how beautiful the grounds were after entering a fairly non descript building. If you go, you won't be disappointed.

Thinker. Coming from Philadelphia where the other Rodin museum is this is a must see on the list. At the time of the visit the museum is undergoing rennovations, but was able see plenty of works. The museum is located in an old hotel, Biron, which has beautiful gardens to compliment outdoor works of Rodin. I understand that it will be back in full swing November 2015.

Paris Museum Card. This is what you would expect-well maintained, fairly splendid, with a good recital of Rodin's life and some of his work. Unless you are a huge fan, don't bother. Some of Rodin's best work is in the Musee D'Orsay. Your Museum pass gets you in however.

Excellent Garden!. My wife and I toured the Rodin garden, just 2 Euros. You see the exterior of the house and museum, one of the casts of the Thinker, and casts of many other Rodins. Well laid out, easily walkable, with a nice tea room that has other snacks.

Excellent. Many of the sculptures are in the surrounding gardens and are more than life size. The Thinker is a wonderful example of his work. An excellent gift shop carries many books and studies of Rodin's work and life.

for Rodin fans. The Rodin Museum is undergoing a makeover, and is scheduled to re-open the villa this fall. The outside gardens are maintained beautifully and have a wealth of sculpture. Especially outstanding is The Gates of Hell, an amazing sculpture from which Rodin made many other statues. The rose garden was in full dazzling bloom when we visited in September 2015.

Peaceful delight. This exhibition is one of several set in grand old Paris buildings with beautiful gardens. The presentation of the artworks is understated but of course impressive, the gardens a delight.

A highlight. A beautiful museum, kept upon a gorgeous property.The Rodin sculptures are iconic and unforgettable, and the way the museum is curated ensures a great flow through his varied works. There are often exhibitions, I was lucky enough to enjoy a fantastic one during my visit.The gardens are also a highlight, beautifully maintained and showing off some of the most well known pieces from Rodin.This was a highlight of the museums I've visited in Paris, certainly one of my favourites & well worth a visit.
Rodins' statues in the gardens. We so enjoyed walking around the gardens and viewing Rodin's amazing work in stratgic positions around the gardens. A relaxing way to view artworks.
Garden is very nice. The museum was closed when we were there. however simply walking in the garden (for 2 EUR each) is worth a stop.

KInd of a disappointment. When we visited the Musee Rodin, I was expecting more by the description I had read online. When we arrived, we were told that the Museum was going through a renovation (which the woman behind us said when she had visited here a year and a half ago... it was the same story. We could only tour the garden area, which was nice... but the whole experience was not worth the 8 euros for the taxi to get there....

Lovely museum, not busy or noisy or crowded. We loved Musee Rodin. There is a much different atmosphere here than say the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay which are both great, but Musee Rodin is smaller and more intimate. The garden is beautiful and that's the really impressive part

Should Have Waited Till November. Apparently the construction will be completed in November and the entire museum would be accessible to visitors then. Currently, you can view only a handful pieces of art work in a space/ building next to the entrance. The garden was open with, of course, The Thinker greeting you as you walk in. However, The Thinker itself could not make it for me. I found the construction severely affecting my visit. It was a disappointing.
Impressed. It was the first museum we visited in Paris and loved it. Quite interesting, rounded off with a lovely garden which sets the scene for great photos.

Would have been nice, but..... Beware! As of this writing the Museum is closed for renovation. You can walk in the garden for 7 Euros (or you can confidently take the first exit door to the left as you enter as we did by mistake and wander through the garden for free). There are no indications that the place is closed until you wait in line to get inside. The garden is pleasant, with quite a few sculptures to see, but if your time is limited in Paris, give this a pass for now.

Beautiful gardens!. Enjoyed the statues - take time to read the history, see sketches etc. then make sure you stroll through the gardens . Not sure it would be worth it in the winter - but the first week of October the roses were spectacular.
Small Museum Dedicated to Rodin. This is a small museum with a beautiful garden with outdoor sculpture. Worth a visit if you love Rodin and a great place to sit quietly outdoors in busy Paris.
Fabulous. Rodin's sculptures, sketches etc are displayed in the house and around the beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit especially if you're a Rodin fan
Wonderful walk in the garden.. The main house is closed at the moment, but it is still worth going for the sculptures in the garden.
A gem. Although the main building is closed never skip this wonderful museum. The garden and the indoor exhibition will fill you with the energy of this remarkable artist.

"Thinking" about Rodin. Musee Rodin was interesting. Lots of good sculptures -- The Thinker, Hand of God, The Cathedral, The Gates of Hell and Man with the Broken Nose. Small museum so it doesn't take much time. Not as awe-inspiring as Musee d'Orsay or Musee de Louvre. If you really like sculpture this shows how he created a lot of his works.

Closed for renovation but gardens are fab. The gardens house some of the best sculpture (incl the thinker and the gates of hell) - for just 2 euro. Shame not to be able to see the kiss but still worth a visit.

Enjoy the Gardens!. A lovely garden amidst Rodin's statues at merely 2 euros/ person. Perfect for an afternoon tea.
During the summertime there is a sandbox in the far corner where children can play.

A pleasant afternoon in the garden. The exhibit was closed when we visited, however we spent a couple of the hours in the garden. The art was accessible in this setting and actually preferable than being in a building on a beautiful afternoon. We enjoyed lunch from the cafe. a nice respite from the hectic pace that is Paris.

Definitely worth a visit. Even though the inside was closed for renovation the gardens are really what this site is all about. IMO, all we missed inside was "The Kiss" and we had seen it before.The extensive gardens have so many sculptures to admire Rodin's work. We were there in fall so many of the flowers were finished but there were still some beautiful photo ops overlooking the pond. In spring & summer the floral displays will blow you away.Very annoying----inconsiderate people who gather with each other and chat for long periods of time right in front of something many are trying to photo. Ex: 4 people with a baby stroller who just stood right in the "view" while 10+ people stood about 10 ft. away waiting for their "shot." After about 10 min. someone finally said "EXCUSE ME!", they looked back & finally moved on.
Greatest Rodin collection. There is more Rodin here than anywhere else and it's presented in a fine old bulding with beautiful grounds

A jewel of a museum. If you have two hours, this is a wonderful place to spend them. Wander around the beautiful gardens of the Hotel Biron and delight in the exquisite sculptures of Rodin that you come upon.

Hits you with the biggee up front.... Before you even pay you can see The Thinker thru the windows in the back gardens. Couldn't believe such a treasure is outside. Gotta mimic the pose below the bust...

Go early. We went on the first Sunday and it was beautiful being there when it first opened with very few people. We loved wandering in the gardens. You will find the famous ' Thinker' there and it all has a wonderful feel to it. The cafe is great for morning coffee and something sweet although it is quite expensive. Worth it. We did go inside and have a look at the sculptures as well before walking to Hotel des Invalides. A lovely area of Paris.

Surprisingly great collection of works & lovely gardens. This Musee, although a little out of the way of the main Musee's (The Lourve etc), was a favourite. The collection of works was very good and the gardens lovely to stroll through. There is a great little café that serves a limited selection of goods & drinks. Worth a visit

Fantastic. This is just an awesome museum. We loved walking around the gardens viewing all of the statues. The inside home museum is also fantastic. We also ate at the garden cafe, which had terrific sandwiches and desserts! Just a wonderful experience to visit this extraordinary museum. I can't say enough good things about this attraction.

Small and lovely museum. This is one of my favorite museums in Paris, due mainly to the famous Rodin sculptures like the Kiss and the Thinker, but also because there is a beautiful peaceful garden in the back to explore. It is such a lovely oasis in downtown Paris.Our Paris Museum Pass really helped us out, because we saw a long lineup as we neared the entrance. I got the guard’s attention through the glass door by waving our passes, and he let us in. The exhibit was also included in our pass.

A serene retreat. We only went to the gardens at this museum as we were in desperate need a quiet space in Paris. It was absolutely beautiful. Unlike many parks, you can sit on the lawn without having someone blow a whistle in your face, and simply take in stunning surroundings. Many of the statues are also in the Musee d'Orsay in a different medium which is an interesting contrast. There is also a lovely little cafe with outside seating where you can have a glass of wine and relax before hitting the tourist trail again.

small museum, beautiful gardens. The museum itself is small, but interesting. There is a gift shop off the entrance. The real point of interest for me was the gardens with the various art pieces tucked here and there. The garden area feels so secluded and doesn't seem like it is just the other side of the hedge from a busy street (it is across a side street from the left side of Les Invalides as you face Les Invalides). There is a little snack shop inside the edge of the gardens (on the street side of the gardens) with various salads, sandwiches, beverages, and treats.Tips: there was a line up the sidewalk from the entrance, but if you have a Paris Museum Pass, go to the front of the line and they will let you right in! You can wander the museum and then go out the back door of the museum into the first part of the gardens. But continue down the hedge path and you'll find the much larger garden area beyond.To exit back to the street, you will have to re-enter through the back door of the museum and go out the front/main entrance.They were still doing construction on the large house when we were there, so I cannot comment on the house other than it looks beautiful from the outside!As with all museums in Paris, check their hours and days of closure before you head there, so you aren't disappointed to find it closed.
One of my favorite museums in Paris. A must see and very cute/charming museum and courtyard! Also small and manageable - so easy to fit into a busy day!

Rocking Rodin. Unfortunately when we visited the Musee Rodin, the Hotel Biron was closed for renovations so we could not visit the interior of the building. This did not diminish our visit whatsoever. The gardens are so beautiful and are filled with Rodin's famous sculptures. Such a memorable experience. The museum is very close to a lot of other attractions - Les Invalides, Tour Eiffel, Alexandre III bridge - so you can make a day of it in the area.

Beautiful gardens, many great works. Beautiful gardens and many lovely pieces on display. There is a fountain and food truck in the gardens. Changing exhibition and history or the man himself. Audio guide was great.

HOUSE UNDER CONSTRUCTION, but still a GREAT stop!. Our 2nd visit to the Rodin Museum and gardens. The house is under construction...so call to see when completed. The gardens are full of his works (including THE THINKER). There is also a delightful restaurant with indoor and outdoor seating.

The setting for art is amazing. Do visit Rodin's home when in Paris, not only is the home worth the trip but the gardens have some of the most amazing sculptures anywhere. Lovely setting and incredible place!

Marvellous . Lots off amazing statues and a magnificent garden area. Privately funded garden so make sure you visit. Smaller than a lot off the other museums but it makes for a lovely walk and a nice quite pace from off the street

Beautiful space, with interesting sculptures. The house was closed for renovation, but we really enjoyed the gardens. The sculptures are interesting, but some are a little 'dark'. We were impressed by the talent of this artist.
Family trip Paris, France. The museum was amazing. Walking through the old house, the gardens, all the statues....it was so peaceful and relaxing. Our children (17, 16 and 10) loved it as well.

Lacking a narrative. A theme with me for museums is that the best ones, like the Mémorial de Caen, tell a story rather than just being a collection of artifacts. The Rodin has lovely gardens and a large sampling of the sculptor's work, but doesn't tell a story.
À master of his art.. If you love sculpture with à passion ,do not miss this place.it is beauty and raw and human fragilité expressed most powerfully .

nice gardens - sculptures are worth a look - not breathtaking. tbh, i personally think there are better things to do in Paris. (i must admit here, I am not especially into art and if I have to visit a gallery then I find I am best suited at the Lourve or d'orsay - sculptures are not so much my thing!) When we went here the gardens were half shut due to renovation and the prices in my mind was not cheap enough to accommodate this so our visit was prompt. The walk back from Rodin towards the river is picturesque if you pick a some nice streets,

If you enjoy art, architecture and gardens, this place has it all. The is undergoing major restoration so not a. If you enjoy art, architecture and gardens, this place has it all. The building is undergoing major restoration so not aaccessible but there are bronze sculptures in the garden and displays of Rodin's work in the entry building.

Renovation Shrinks Visible Collection. As an FYI for visitors...I would have rated this all five stars, except that the museum is, again, under renovation. Only a smaller temporary collection is available (for a reduced entry) at this time. Disappointing as the same thing happened to me 3 years ago. The Gardens in the back are just beautiful, and are available for separate entry fee.

Surprisingly good. My husband and I visited the Rodin Museum today and, despite being extremely disappointed that the main museum was closed for renovation, and tickets didn't seem to be discounted despite this, we thoroughly enjoyed looking around the sculpture gardens and having a coffee in the coffee shop. It was a lovely relaxed afternoon of wandering and sitting outside in the sun.

Home of the "Thinker". This is a small museum with big bronze statues by Rodin. Of course you get to see the famous "Thinker" among other of his bronze works. The gardens are scattered with his bronze statues. Although the house is not open he did live and work in it and at some point it maybe open to the public. With the museum pass this was a great option.

Half a loaf. The museum was still closed when we visited, but the garden was open, also a small special exhibit next to the gift shop. The long flower beds are mainly flowering shrubs and looked wonderful even in late September. The special exhibit was nicely done and informative. The whole place should be open in November 2015.

Surprise Visit filled an Afternoon. Near to the Metro, so a short walk took you to the museum. Warned that a Revamp meant some exhibits were unavailable to view. Weather good so garden and cafe were good to use.

in my top selections. the most beautiful garden ever. since the museum is under redecoration, only a small part of it beeing available four tourist, the garden becomes the no 1 attraction of the musee rodin. i highly recommend you to come, even if you will not visit the museum itself, the garden has beautiful paths, sculptures, a view over the eiffel tower and a very nice shop where you cna buy tea, coffee, wine.

Thinker. If you like sculptures, this is a nice museum. the gardens are also very nice. Purchase a museum pass. this venue is included. It also allows you to skip the queue where guests are purchasing tickets.

One of our favorite things we did. Our whole family loved walking around the gardens of the Rodin museum. It is one of the most beautiful settings in Paris and the sculpture sre besutiful. One of the highlights from the trip.
Great Art in a wonderful garden setting.. We only got the ticket for the garden, but it was a nice exhibit and beautiful place. We learned a lot about the artist.

STILL under renovation. I have been here many times. It is the most romantic museum in all of Paris. On our last trip in 2012, it was undergoing renovations and the exhibits were on display but not so nicely organized. When we returned this time, it is STILL under construction and not all the items were available to be seen. Since they were still charging entry admission, my wife and I decided to pass. When it is NOT being renovated, it is very much worth spending several hours.

Time to Think. If you like sculptures, please make a point to visit Musee Rodin. The gardens and sculptures are truly amazing. Was very peaceful and serene in the gardens while the hustle and bustle of Paris is just outside the walls surrounding the gardens. Managed to visit at a time when only a few people were visiting so felt as it I was in a private garden.
Relaxing Musee. Inspite of renovation,the main pieces are outside,located in a beautiful garden.Relaxing place at the middle of Paris

Sculpture worth seeing. Much of the museum was closed for renovation, but is reopening soon. I love his sculpture, we recently visited his museum in Philadelphia where we saw much of what is on display in Paris. We will be back when they reopen.
Small but delightful. From the gate to the deeper understanding of the artist's life, we really enjoyed this little museum.
Under construction. While the museum itself is under construction/renovation, the outdoor sculpture garden is still open and lovely to see.

Second time and it's still awesome. It's under construction right now. So the exhibit inside is small. But the gardens are gorgeous. The gardens are a much cheaper visit. So at this time I would recommend just going to see them.
loved this small museum. Bummer that they are remodeling, but the grounds are worth it, great work, by a very talented guy. grab a coke and sandwich in the garden and just hang out

Really Really Rodin. NOTE: much of the exhibit is closed until mid November; however, the garden is a delightful venue for many wonderful examples of his sculpture in a lush & gorgeous setting. I HIGHLY recommend a visit to this wonderful museum in the the 7th!
It's a Rodin!. We got the ticket to look around the gardens and the museum. The museum was quite small however and getting a ticket just for the gardens may have been a good idea.

Sculpture Gardens & House of the Master ...... Check carefully thr days / times of opening to avoid any disappointments. Two distinct sections to visit - the multistoried house & the front & rear sculpture gardens. Allow time for them all, about 2-3+ hours. Wonderful pieces, history, maquette so & exhibition in house. But the gardens have "The Thinker" - "The Burghers of Calais" and many others. TIP: best way to see all is House first, the Right front garden, Rt. Side, then Rt. rear garden ( has refreshments, snacks also), Back gardens & pool, the come up Lt. back Garden, Lt. side & finish in Lt. front near the Exit - you'll see it all this way. Invalides is nearby, so tie in both depending upon open times. Enjoy....

Let me think .... Was pretty cool to see The Thinker and The Kiss "in person" after reading about them in my teacher, Holly Alexander, art history class back in high school decades ago ... Whenever you watch the movie "Midnight in Paris", you'll think to yourself, "I've been there!"

The best part of the Museum has been closed for 2 years!. I was here in 2011 and was thrilled with the museum it was so beautiful. The main room has tall beautiful windows with so much light. The sculptures of the women are exquisite. So we came back this September and the main room was closed and had been closed for 2 years for rennovations. - So if it is not currently open again, it's barely worth the visit. I'm sorry I love Rodin but there is not enough to see without the room that showcases his work.

ONE OF OUR FAVORITES. We visit this museum every time we are in Paris. It just never gets old. An amazing collection of Rodin work. I highly recommend paying for the audio tour. Its well produced and worth it.

Beautiful gardens. Currently under construction, the exhibit inside shows how the plaster casts were made for the bronze statues. Interesting but not worth a separate trip. The gardens and statues there, however, are lovely. The roses were in full bloom and the statues in the garden reveal the true genius of Rodin. Plan a picnic lunch or stop by the garden restaurant.

Worth the visit, although residence closed due to renovation. Wonderful insights into Rodin's incredible sculptures, including several classic examples on the premises. Unfortunately the residence was under renovation, so we were disappointed that we missed an important part of the visit. Guess timing is everything! Better luck next time.

Under Renovation.. Travelled to Paris to see the Thinker, sadly the Musse was on partially open as it was under renovations. Only the gardens were open, the Thinker sculpture was great to see. Tip Check before visiting.
The real views are outside. A nice small museum inside but the treat comes when entering the formal gardens. Rodin's sculptures are best viewed outside among beautifully maintained gardens.

Very good museum. This museum was under construction when we were in Paris. They had an exhibit in a separate building with the molds used to create the sculptures. Learning the process was interesting. There were many sculptures on the grounds to see. They were wonderful.
Disappointed!. Do not visit tll the repairs are complete. The Rodin is under reconstruction and is a mere shell of its ususal magnificent self. Wait till next trip to visit.

Lovely Museum . When we were here the main building was closed so the options were garden only or garden and temporary exhibits, two or seven euro respectively. We chose the garden tour and it was exceptional - in retrospect worth the full admission price. Come here, avoid the crowds of the supposed top museums and spend a few hours amidst some of Rodin's finest works.

Relaxing. Though the building was closed for renovations we thoroughly enjoyed the magnificently relaxing gardens with many famous Rodin sculptures. I did visit the interior last April and found it to be a beautiful experience. It is a relatively small collection but the setting is lovely with a good variety of art works.

Was not in my plan. It was not in my plan but I've visited it since it was on my way. For me it was not interesting but for others it would be great. It depend on your taste and with whom you are traveling.

Beautiful garden. As is mentioned previously on TA the museum is closed but the garden with it's spectacular statues is open. I am looking forward to once again (I have been here several times before) visit the museum when it opens again.

The garden is beautiful and the one exhibit inside that is currently open is very good. The garden behind the house is beautiful and contains a number of wonderful pieces. While the main building is under renovation, the entrance building has a very good exhibition giving the stories behind and more explanations of his works. For example, we learned that The Thinker represents Dante, part of a Gates of Hell piece that was intended for a museum that was never built. A relaxing, fun visit,

Nice museum, but mostly under renovation. My daughter and I spent some time in Paris recently. We stopped by the Rodin museum for a visit. Unfortunately, the majority of the museum is being renovated right now. We were able to see all the statues displayed outdoors, and they had a nice little collection of statues in the front building, but most of the galleries were closed to visitors. Uncertain when it will all be open again. I'm sure the rest of it is spectacular. Sadly, we didn't get to see it.

Museum closed but gardens delightful!. The gardens at the Musee de Rodin are beautiful and make one rather contemplative. The statutes are all set out in the gardens, in a thicket of shrubs, under a shade tree or by the fountains. As with all Paris parks/gardens there are ample benches, places to contemplate the artwork or to just soak up the sun. Entrance fee of 2 euro is a bargain! Restrooms and small food area in gardens.Enjoy a quiet afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of Paris.

Rodin musee is a great place for rest and to see beautiful sculptures. he really looks!. This is a nice museum in scale and has a nice flow moving around from one place to another. I enjoyed looking a the various sculpture and also other collection of work by Van Gogh. The gardens outside are very nice too.

Ponder the Thinker... and the other extraordinary works of art.. This is a beautiful museum in Paris. You'll not only get close up to The Thinker statue, but many of other Rodin's works. The gift shop is also very nice. Come on a sunny day and you won't regret this cultural experience. I bet you'll even learn something about art.

very good sculptures in a beautiful garden. You can visit the garden with the sculptures for 2 euros or for 7 you also can see a display about the history of the works and the models used by rodan. We went on a sunny day and were able to get in without a queue and it was lovely to walk around the gardens and see the sculptures. There are 16 on display with one missing currently and each has a sign in french and english describing the work. They are great sculptures and so well worth a visit. I dont always find scupltures the best art medium but found these to be well worth the visit plus the gardens are lovely and so you can have a rest or buy something from the cafe and just enjoy both the scupltures and gardens.

Quiet peaceful Setting. We toured the gardens early in the morning and almost were there alone. Such mighty work surrounded by voluptuous gardens. Such a show stopper to see Rodin's work all together in such an elegant space.

Great Collection and Peaceful Grounds. We were on a whirlwind sightseeing tour of Paris and managed to stop here and enjoy the gardens with many fine pieces of Rodin's work. The main museum was being renovated and we felt we would get a good perspective by touring the gardens which was only 2 euro for me and free for my 16 year old son.The grounds are extremely well kept and full of many of Rodin's pieces, including iconic "thinker". I noticed that some people were using the grounds purely as park, which is understandable considering that it is like an oasis of green set in the middle of bustling Paris.We enjoyed the collection and the grounds and recommend a visit as one of the "must-see" sights in Paris

Really Nice Place. We bought tickets only for the garden since there was a renovation inside. It cost 2 Euros. The garden was a nice surprise after a day full of activities. So calm and beautiful. I just regret that we didn't have much time until the museum closed. Plan to spend 1 hour to 1 hour and a half in the garden. Take some minutes to seat down and appreciate the view of the garden.

Spectacular and peaceful. This was quite a beautiful setting to see art. In Rodin's private garden. The scope of his work is simply breath taking. We all know "the thinker" but there is so much more. Escape the tourist. Yes tourist come here but not as many as most attractions, and because you re outside, you never feel cramped.

The nice place.. Очень приятное место. Много скульптур Родена и потрясающий розарий.
The nice place. There are many Roden's sculptures here. Amazing garden, rosarium.
Escape from the crowds--and still get culture!. Small but lovely! Rodin's work is most appreciated in the gardens, where his figures seem to have a secret life of their own amid the greenery.
Peaceful Gardens. I was a bit bummed because the large building on the property was closed for renovations. But the gardens were incredibly beautiful and peaceful. It includes Rodin's best works.

What a Wonderful Surprise!!!!!!!!!. The Musée Rodin is situated within the Hôtel Biron, an 18th century mansion. The museum houses a number of Rodin's sculptures. The garden is a MUST. Many of Rodin's greatest pieces have been placed in the garden.
Beautiful sculpture in garden setting. Enjoyed the sculptures even though it was under construction. Beautiful garden settings for many of the sculptures.

Gardens were lovely. Major construction is taking place at the Rodin now. The actual museum selection of sculptures was small, but we did enjoy the sculptures placed among the well-landscaped gardens outside.

Lovely gardens!. Has two options, you can either pay for full entry or you can pay a modest 2 Euro entrance to get to the gardens only.
Gardens are amazing, have many sculptures to see and on a sunny day are an incredible option. Restaurant is quite good and cheap!

Amazing Thinking Sulptures in a Beautiful Garden!. The sculptures in the Rodin Museum in Paris are just amazing. The details, artistry, and realism in these sculptures (large or small) are just beyond belief. Of course you have to go there to see the famous "Thinker" sculpture in the garden. Unfortunately, the museum was under renovation and remodeling when we were there in September 2015, so we spent less than two hours over there, but we still enjoyed it a lot. If you are a fan of sculptures, this is the place to visit in addition to Louvre. Go, think, and enjoy the place!
The Thinker -- think about it.. It is wonderful to see Rodin's work up close and in person. The statuary garden really gives you a complete experience.

Closed for remodeling in September 2015. We had hoped to view Rodin's house, but it was closed for remodeling during our visit. Still, the museum was interesting, and the gardens were lovely. We just wish we could have seen more.

Sadly the main museum was closed. I was most eager to show my wife this beautiful museum with its many Rodin works of art. But his home/studio was closes for repairs. The tour was of a tent and only The Kiss was available to see, but couldn't enjoy as the line needed to keep moving. The gardens are beautiful as is The Thinker. But I was very sad that we saw so little.
Rodin at his best. The Kiss and The Thinker were on our granddaughter's list of must sees and both were well displayed outside in a lovely garden. The main building was being renovated.

Wonderful Museum and Gardens. We visited this museum for the third time in May, the main building was closed for renovation so not all of the pieces could be viewed but it was still well worth visiting. We went early in the morning on a sunny day before it got busy and it was a wonderful experience walking around the gardens taking our time looking at the sculptures in the morning sunlight in peace and quiet - we felt very privileged and its an experience I won't forget. The Thinker, the Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell in particular are breathtaking.

Wonderful small museum. Lovely small museum. Definitely worth a visit. Approachable. Lovey grounds and outside statues. Being remodeled inside just now. Just off one of the hop-on-hop-off bus stops. Combine it with a visit to Napoleon's tomb.

Under renovation. The hotel is under renovation - Camille Claudel's works are not available. The ticket is even cheaper because of this. Maybe you can skip the museum and go directly to the garden - where you can check the famous works. The garden is stunning! There you can find the Thinker and the Gates of Hell. Go on a sunny day and enjoy!

Excellent despite a remodel in progress. Because they are making changes to the museum, they substituted a rewarding temporary exhibition detailing the origins of many of Rodin's works. The building and gardens blend perfectly as a showcase for Rodin's works.

Lovely garden. Part of the museum was closed for renovation but the gardens and one large gallery were still open. The gardens were very well kept and the many pieces of art were fascinating and beautifully incorporated into it.

New and improved Rodin Museum.. The first time I went to the Musee Rodin, the grounds were in a bit of a shambles, with a few of Rodin's fine sculptures teetering unevenly on their pedestals. Now, the grounds are beautiful, the sculpture is exquisite and well cared for. The museum itself it lovely, though the outdoor spaces are the real stars.

Very impressive museum. Although during our visit the museum was undergoing some works, we were able to see some works inside, and some great sculptures outside. The explanations were also very interesting, even if you are not a fan of sculpture art.
Enjoyed the garden. The main museum was closed for construction during our visit, but we were aware of that. We enjoyed the garden.

One of my favorites. The museum came highly recommended. It is well worth it. The grounds and sculptures were amazing, just beautiful. Rodin's home is under construction which was disappointing but his work is not.

Musee Rodin Gardens. When we were there, late Aug 2015, much of the interior was being renovated and inaccessible. However for 2 Euros you could still access the beautiful gardens. Two hours of walking about was not enough. Rodin's "The Thinker" is a classic. The marble gallery behind glass was fascinating and the multitude of other works of art had to be seen to be believed. Each piece had a brief but comprehensive description of the work and its sculptor. The day we were there it was drizzling but didn't deter us from keeping on exploring. I wouldn't hesitate to return

Nice sculpture exhibition. The Rodin is usually housed in a house that I am sure is lovely. However, when we visited, the house was under renovation and there was a temporary housing. This is a museum to go to if you like sculpture. I have always loved "the thinker" so it was great to see. The gardens were lovely.

Afternoon visit to museum. the afternoon we visited the museum was undergoing extensive renovations so some aspects were unavailable. Having said that, what was open was very interesting and well worth a visit. In particular the inclusion of explanations in both French and English was very helpful. Audio recordings are also available and the way the museum is laid out means that nothing is missed.Even though it was raining that day we still strolled outside in the extensive gardens which are beautifully laid out with statues in strategic areas. It is very well balanced and peaceful and, again, many explanations in both French and English. I thoroughly enjoyed this visit viewing the magnificent works of art of this fascinating sculptor. The tea rooms have a small but varied selection of drinks and snacks all amid the gardens. The finale was when two rabbits appeared in the middle of a huge stretch of lawn and began munching away completely unperturbed by visitors ! A lovely afternoon despite the rain and renovations.

A beautiful place on a beautiful day. It's the garden that's so special. Rodin's sculptures are placed in a landscaped setting that perfectly suits the master's works of art. Renovations are now going on (September 2015) and they detract a bit from perfection of the setting, but it's not too serious and we had a wonderful visit. Take as much time as you like; sit and look at the various pieces on display and in between masterpieces just stroll along the paths and enjoy the scenery. There's a little coffee shop on one side of the gardens that's also a great place to sit and enjoy the surroundings. We had a perfect early autumn day with lots of sunshine and it was simply magical to be there.

Absolute most favorite place in Paris. The thing I love about this museum is the fact that it is set on the grounds of Rodin's old estate. Not only are the grounds breathtaking, but the coziness of seeing the enormous amount of sculptures that he created over his lifetime in and around this home, leaves you feeling like you were truly close to the epicenter of his creations and his life. The grounds are peaceful and not too crowded. And the small cafe in the garden serves some wonderful food at an excellent price. I would recommend that everyone make time for this stop in your itinerary!

Don't miss the garden. The museum houses hundreds of works, many of them legendary, so don’t be surprised if after a while your vision starts to blur. That’ll be your cue to head outside and enjoy the beautiful garden. Note: Don’t be surprised if parts of the building are closed for renovation during your visit. They were during mine. The most famous pieces were still on display and the statues in the garden were present and accounted for.

Under construction. This is normally a wonderful museum but the whole house is closed for construction. As a result you can not view most of the pieces. They do allow you to walk through the garden in the back which is beautiful, while the garden on the left is closed so aren't able to see any of those statues. Wait until you are back in Paris again.

Worth the visit even during renovations. We were so happy we went even though we knew most of the museum was closed for renovations. They were nice enough to make sure you knew that when you entered the museum. We still got to see two of the most famous scupltures: The Thinker and The Kiss. The gardens are gorgeous with sculptures scattered throughout and make a very relaxing walk on a beautiful day. Highly recommended.
One of the Best Museums. Terrific Museum and definitely worth a stop. I have now visited the Musee Rodin every other time I am in Paris. That is how much I love it.

The most romantic museum of art!. Rodin's work is amazing and full of passion, so the museum housing his works of art is a must for all romantics with lovers or without! With many pieces to enjoy and information on his life as well, a very satisfying visit will be had.

Pleasant inviting museum. A small but beautiful museum to visit. I bought my Paris Museum Pass here, although it can be bought at any museum. This one had the shortest lines and is where I began my tour of Paris museums. Both the inside and garden presented many famous Rodin works of art. Very nice and pleasant museum visit. Do the audio tour if you can and make sure do not miss a single piece in the garden.

Do not GO!!!-Under construction--Peak over fence. The Rodin museum is under construction and the attempt to make it viable is sad. It is less than half on what it used to be. The gardens used to be the most fabulous setting and beautiful with roses in bloom. Forget it-construction leaves little to see. Wait for the completion of the new Musee-don't know when but is far off-from what I could tellMy tip:Look over the fence if you want to see the THINKER-the rest is a messThe park inside is a nice place for lunch and there are some great picture opportunities but is certainly not worth the price of admission
Worth visiting. Makes a good idle afternoon takung in the great sculpture. Definitely worth a visit and it was not too crowded whilst we were there.

The main exhibits are closed for renovations. None of the travel books or webpages that I had reviewed indicated that the major exhibits one normally would want to see at Musee Rodin could not be enjoyed as the main pavillion is undergoing a major renovation. The gardens are still very impressive but I do not think I would return again until the full exhibit is open

Rodain-Sculptures for All. When in Paris-visit Rodin's Museum and Garden-the white marble sculptures are exquisite! The Thinker and The Kiss are my favorites. All are originals. You don't have to be a sculpture connoisseur to appreciate Rodin's masterpieces!

Under Construction. Unfortunately I decided to finally visit this museum on my 4th trip to Paris - and it is being refitted. The main house is closed to the public, although a number of pieces are setup in a temporary area as you enter. The gardens however, are for the most part open, and contain a number of significant works in them.Not sure how long the work will be going on, but if you can put this off for a return visit in the future it may be worth waiting.

Rodin and Claudel. Of course, this is the place to see Rodin. Unfortunately we saw it during renovation. We had hoped to see more works by Camille Claudel, but they were not on view. A few fine works of hers were on vies.

Wow--One of our Better Museum Experiences. If there is one museum not to miss, then it is Musee Rodin. Totally devoted to the sculptor, his works are seen inside and outside in the gardens. I did not realize the extent that he went to in researching and modeling his works. For a wonderful afternoon--away from other crowded museums--head to see the works of Rodin(including The Thinker) .FYI, at the time of our visit the central building was open with renovations on another building to enlarge the capacity of the museum
Most excellent!. A sea of calm in a bustling city, the Rodin is a fitting showcase to an amazing artist who had to fight with the city to save a hotel and display his work...I'm glad he won!

Art in the Garden. Even if you have only a short time available go see the garden. At 2 Euro for the garden only, it is well worth the price of admission. If you are a Rodin fan and have the time then by all means go see the museum as well.

A lovely garden walk for Rodin fans.. The central building on the property was closed for construction, but it was still worth visiting. Probably a 5/5 with all buildings open, check before you visit.

Everyone loves The Thinker. We skipped the museum itself and just explored the gardens. One of the first sculptures you will see in the garden is The Thinker. It is magnificent! Arrive early in the day so you can snag a few pictures without tourists in the background.Expect to spend 1-2 hours in the garden - the more you walk, the more sculptures you will stumble upon. Definitely worth a stop.

An Outdoor Museum! Breath of fresh air!. We spent two weeks in Paris and were starting to get "museum'd out" but then visited this one and wow! Am I glad we did! It's beautiful sculptures in a magnificent garden. The description of each sculpture are the best we've read the whole trip - they provide such meaning and context that you can't help but gaze at the statue as it tells you its story. Very moving and beautiful experience. We grabbed lunch in the cafe on the grounds and it was amazing! The salads were fresh and delicious - not what we expected at all! What a wonderful outing.

Lovely garden. The museum was closed for renovation. So we skipped the exhibition and bought tickets for the garden, 2 euro per person. Kids are free. Nice sculptures in the garden. Money well spent !

Must see in Paris. Visited this attraction on recent trip to Paris. I did not get to see the house because of renovation but I feel like the gardens may have been my favorite part anyway. A great relaxed atmosphere where you can see several very famous sculpture pieces by Rodin. Highly recommended as one of your Museum stops in Paris.

Audio guided tour. Unfortunately the museum was under renovations so patrons had access to the garden only. If you are interested in Rodin, it is still worthwhile. Some might be disappointed if they spend 13€ but it was worth it to me. Beauty and quietude. There is a chance to appreciate the beautiful gardens as well.
The garden is the best.. The museum itself is small, but the garden at the back is spectacular! All of Rodin's work are back there. The grounds are immaculate and is a pleasant stroll.

Don't miss the gardens, larger than you think!. Lovely small indoor museum and large gardens with many works and Cafe. There was no wait when we went on first Sunday of the month when admission was free.

Amazing. The museum is closed for renovations. We skipped the exhibition and bought tickets just for the garden (2 euro per visitor).
It was really nice to eat our sandwiches outside, sitting on a bench and watching statues and nice trees and plants. The combination between the garden and Rodin's art is wonderful. Very good VFM.
Not very crowded when I went. Gardens are Spectacular. If you are a fan of Rodin you will love the museum and gardens. One of the top 5 on the left bank in Paris

Interesting for a short visit. The museum was undertaking some major renovation and lots of pieces were unavailable. There were still some nice pieces of art in the garden. It's also a nice place to escape from the busy streets of Paris and get some rest in the garden.
Under renovation . Under renovation so you can only see the garden which is where the thinker sculpture is. There are a few sculptures to see in the garden during the renovation.

Just the gardens. We had a day in Paris and made the gardens one of the priority stop-offs after a recommendation from a friend who knew the city well. We were running out of time and energy but glad we visited. €2 per adult, free for the 6yr old. It's only a small park but lovely and tranquil to sit a while and enjoy the sculptures and hidden fountains. Also chance to be a bit cultured without boring the kiddo. It's a nice 10-15min walk from Tour Eiffel to the museum.
Be sure what is open before you go.. We enjoyed it very much but the garden was the only thing that was open. We paid less but saw many great bronzes there. The grounds are very nice.

A different type of museum mostly outside.. Not much of an art buff but somehow like the sculpture. We visited on first Sunday of the month so entry was free. We paid €6 each for audio guide and proceeded to wander around the gardens. Unfortunately the main house/museum is being renovated so the indoor exhibition was in a newer building and was just okay. Really enjoyed the bronze sculptures outside though. Definitely recommend it.

A walk amongst giants in a garden. I only visited the garden but that was more than enough for me. Rodin is my favorite scultpor in the world and to see his pieces surrounded by the beauty of Mother Nature, it was magnificent.

Glorious!. I was here in October 2014 (museum was all open) and September 2014 (when main building was closed for renovations) and I can say with great confidence that it is worth a visit even if only for the gardens alone. There's a lot of sculpture outside and it's a beautiful and serene place to visit. I am not a major fan of sculpture, but this is one of my very favorite places to visit in Paris.
Avoid until they reopen. Museum under renovation. Not worth the money. Wait until they reopen. The current exhibits are nothing but photos and plaster casts of molds. The audio guide is very good.

Sorely disappointed September 2015. I have visited this museum for the five previous years. This year ws a profound disappointed. The website and the publicity significantly understates the effect of the renovation on the pleasurability of the visit. Stating the permanent exhibit at the door, is to little to late. The temporary exhibit was a hastily thrown together attempt to provide something more the a view of the roped of permanent exhibit. The store was a shell of it'd former self and utility It was not worth my trekking across the city to visit.

Wonderful museum for wonderful artist. The museum is divided to two parts: the museum itself and the park. This time we decided to visit the park only.Visited the museum in 2011 - it's fabulous, but we were afraid that kids will be bored.The gardens are very lovely for just walking also, with a lots of Roden statues and rabbits jumping on the grass.Had a wonderful time: kids and us.
A favourite museum. My favourite museum, the gardens and the sculptures are unparalleled...you will enjoy wandering them for hours.

More than The Thinker. We knew little about Rodin other than The Thinker before we went. We were amazed at the body of his work. The only downside is the current renovation being done with one whole building closed off!

Highlight of the trip. I really enjoyed this museum. The bronzes were well spaced allowing us to properly view each piece. The museum is rather small, but that was for the best. We felt we could appreciate each piece without feeling that we had to run to the next.
Under Construction. So disappointed that Rodin's home was closed for repair. The gardens were lovely but the construction was loud and very dusty. Lovely little cafe was a pleasant surprise.

A lovely hour . This was a very peaceful place to visit amid the masses of tourists elsewhere - would definitely recommend! We were a little tired so had a rest on one of the numerous benched dotted about - we felt recharged after a little chill!

LOVE this place. This was my 9th trip to Paris. I'm embarrassed to say that I saw it for the first time. it is a gem! So delightful and provides the best views of Hotel des Invalides' dome. I will return for sure next trip - don't let the construction keep you away.
Small is beautiful. Well located small pleasant museum not to be missed while in Paris. Beautiful collection of Rodin's sculptures and lovely gardens.

A great museum. Although the main museum was closed for renovations, the grounds and a temporary exhibition space still offered many sculptures to see and ponder. This is a very peaceful and at times provocative place that was a welcome break from the craziness of the Louvre and d'Orsay.

under construction. One of our favorite musea in Paris. having checked the website we did;t expect it but the main house was under construction and even though gardens are nice for a stroll- that was;t what we came for...
We liked the garden. An enjoyable time was spent wandering through the garden and viewing the statues there. The museum is under renovation, so our inside visit was limited.

Beautiful work.... ... if you are hoping to see the incredible original casts made by Rodin himself.. there isn't much here. Some small pieces inside, but the stuff in the gardens is all from the last century. Parts of the museum were closed for my visit... very disappointing.

The great Sculpturor Auguste Rodin. Auguste Rodin was born in 1840 and in his great artwork, you can concentrate on 4 lifeparts. Many great artist from his life are influencing and pulsing him to greater art sculptures. The museum offers a large view of it, even in the garden with some monumentals, but personnaly I found his work a little bit dark and depressive. Every body his own taste of course.

Truly inspiring. Very interesting visit despite main interior exhibition being closed for renovations. The gardens are lovely and peaceful, and a number of bronzes are displayed, and a gallery of Rodin's marbles. Looking forward to visiting again once the museum is fully reopened.

Awe inspiring. Unfortunately a great part of his wonderful museum was closed for renovations when we visited in April this year but there was still plenty to enchant us. To actually stand next to scuptures and works of art that one had only seen photos of in the past was very humbling. The fascinating story of Auguste Rodin is adequately chronicled elsewhere so I would just say - if you are in Paris, go there. The renovations will be completed in November but in any event go and enjoy the existing works and the peaceful gardens.

Currently Under Renovation. I'd love to review this higher, but the main gallery is under renovation. Essentially, you're now limited to the gardens and a temporary exhibit. In the garden, you can see the Gates of Hell which is a really cool work to see. You, of course, will see the Thinker scattered around.

Inspiring and beautiful museum and gardens. The main part of the museum, the Hotel Biron, was closed for renovations, but the gardens were absolutely lovely. Rodin's main sculptures were moved to his laboratory for viewing, so we still got to see what made him a master.

Miss this and you miss Paris. Robin was one of France's greatest sculptor s and perhaps the greatest of all time. This museum was his home and his studio. It started out as the "Hotel Boron", and before that a parochial school run by nuns. When the building then became the Hotel it was first populated by artists (some of note, including Rodin) and then it was taken over by Rodin and finally became the Musee Rodin around 1916 when the Assembly accepted his art works, permitted him to occupy the premises for his lifetime and proclaimed it as the museum. Go see masterpieces such as the thinker, the Burghers of Calais and The Gates of Hell (at least 10 years in the making). You will find this more than worthwhile.

Calm and beautiful. We love this place. It is a perfect mixture of art and peace in the middle of all the hustle of Paris. Rodin's sculptures are so expressive and "full of life" that you can contemplate them for hours and what a better place to do It than in a beautiful garden. A must-see in Paris.

Great gardens. I've visited this museum on a couple of occasions. It has a large display of sculptures and other art works and beautiful gardens. I was lucky that on both visits the weather was glorious to .
Good museum but being renovated. This museum is open but was still being renovated in September 2015. There is still much to see, but if one is not compelled to go now, wait until next year.
Al you need to know about Rodin. I love Rodin, in this museum you get the basics of how he worked, the examples and also the criticism which he got for his statue of Balzac.

Deserves 5 stars but under renovation. This is a museum that should not be missed. The sculpture garden including the Gates of Hell are a treasure. Unfortunately the museum is under renovation. The main collection is not accessible. The museum deserve your support at this time But it's just an abbreviated visit.
Ideal museum for a sunny day. Ideal for art-lovers and those with no knowledge whatsoever alike. The museum and gardens are perfect for a hot day - lovely cafe and bookshop too.

Not to be missed. Despite the current renovations which - we knew about in advance - we decided this was still well worth a visit and we were not disappointed. Whilst the main block is closed for renovations, the entrance/visitor centre contains a really well presented and fascinating exhibition relating to the background to some of Rodin's masterpieces, examples of which are then presented in the exquisite gardens. The narrative is excellent, and in both French and English. The mixture of photos (some annotated), sketches, early models etc really bring alive Rodin's creativity and way of working. Pieces which are now accepted as masterpieces are seen in their historical context, sometimes rejected by their commissioning bodies. The sheer effort in moving from idea to finished product is evident from the exhibits, as is the way in which Rodin sought to portray each subject. We will return in the hope that the same care is given to interpreting the contents following the renovation - opening in November 2015.

Excellent stop on the Paris museum tour. We were going on a multi-day museum pass - highly recommended - so we waltzed right in. Unfortunately, the main hall is under renovations right now, but we were greatly impressed with the "Rodin, the Laboratorie of Creation" exhibit showing early prototypes of the works, and the beautiful gardens with many other sculptures, including the most famous - The Thinker. It will be great to return here when the renovations are complete. Rodin works are stunning and special, so this is a must stop that can be completed in an just an hour or two, and it is near other landmarks such as the Eiffel Tower and Louvre.

Rodin Bronzes and Marble Figures: Sculptural Paradise. We had to detour a demonstration to get to the Museum and then discovered the building itself was closed for repairs. Do not be deterred if you will be in Paris in September. The gardens outside contain a cornucopia of Robin's work that you will enjoy more because you can examine each piece from multiple angles. Plus the gardens are a miniature Luxembourg or Tuilleries so if you love horticulture too, this is a must see! Don't forget to see the marble sculptures displayed behind glass in the building adjacent to Renoir's former residence too.

A delight for art lovers and non art lovers. The gardens are superb and Rodin's sculptures are a joy to behold. Great to visit on a pleasant day. Also, the interior exhibition of Rodin's work is well curated and terrifically informative. Great shame about the guy running the food outlet, though. His surliness almost spoiled the visit.
Surprise! What a gem. Best Museum in paris for me. Small, very special hidden gem. I was not big on sculpture but this museum is really a find.

Is that you?. Where do you begin? The Musee is perfect if you want to understand a little about August Rodin. It has countless great works, and photographs cannot give you the chance to appreciate the beautiful work he did.
Rodin gatdens. Under construction. So limited viewing. Gardens beautiful with the thinker as a main attraction. Visit early to avoid crowds
A must to do in Paris. Was very impressive. They are doing work in many of the areas. The outside garden is the best part. A very peaceful place to visit.
A real jewel. For all lovers of Rodin sculpture, you will enter in his temple in this wonderful hotel particulier in the heart of the 7th district. It is a marvellous experience.

Must See but Wait for Completion of Remodel. This is my second time here in ten years. The hotel is under complete renovation and so there is a temporary exhibit and of course the lovely gardens are open. The temporary exhibit is well done but there's nothing quite like being in the hotel where one can get a sense of the studio atmosphere. Someone told us of the violet ice cream sold in the cafe in the garden. When we got there for a try, it was closed for the day. Hope you have a better chance to sample this special ice cream!
Musee Rodin. Fantastic museum. Less crowded than most others. Outdoor sculptures not to be missed. Able to see The Thinker close up.

Another must see.. Did not plan to go here but had time after Les Invalides. Rodin was a genius and his art speaks to you in another dimension. Whilst his statues adorn various parts of the Tuilleries Gardens, by visiting this museum, you see so much more. We want to go again and spend more than 2 hours.

Moving. I really like Rodin's work, so I find this museum a great place to visit. I particularly like the little garden at the end. You can sit and try to imagine the artist at work. I've never seen it particularly busy, either, which is refreshing if you've recently been to the Louvre.

Lovely gardens, main museum closed when we visited. Check what is open before you visit. The main museum was closed for refurb when we visited. We paid the 2 euro though to go around the gardens which were very nice (helped being a sunny day). Quite a few statues to see in the grounds as well nice grounds and architecture

Don't Miss This Beautiful Experience!. We loved this museum very much. It is set in a beautiful grounds-park in which many of the artist's most beautiful works are displayed. The ambience is relaxed and friendly and well worth the trip there. And it is a good value as well.

Do not miss this treasure. No matter how many times I visit Paris, this museum never fails to enchant, not only is the museum full of masterpieces that enthrall, but the gardens are superb. Take time to discover more about this fascinating man who created some of the most well known sculptures in the world. If after this surfeit of art you need to gather your thoughts, nothing is better than the calm of the surrounding gardens, a true oasis of tranquility. Although you are in the midst of this beautiful, bustling city, here one can sit and dream undisturbed.

Very nice open museum. It is not a typical museum in the sense that most of its exhibits are in the garden so instead of walking through big halls with shiny chandeliers you just take a walk in the nicely decorated garden and every now and then you come across a wonderful masterpiece. Very nice experience that I recommend to anyone. You'd rather choose a sunny day to visit though!

Sit and Enjoy the garden...if you need a rest from the crowd!. Beautiful garden. Wish I can sit here long and contemplate but time is precious when you travel across the Atlantic for Paris. Didn't spent too much time inside the museum. Garden is the centerpiece with all the statues.
Rodin, the thinker.. Excellent exhibition of Rodin's work and life. All his uninished work was donated to the city and ismexhibited here

Arguably the most delightful spot in Paris. Of all the "must sees" in Paris, Rodin Museum (with its garden) is the most delightful. Period.Anyone would appreciate the charm and power of those great sculptures, even he/she has very little or no knowledge or capability of arts,

Must See for Rodin Fans. Four stars only because the museum is still under renovation, due to open Sep 15. However, well worth it to tour the gardens where various works are located - it's only 2 euro to visit the gardens at this time.

The Hidden Gem of Paris Museums. This is the hidden gem of all of the Paris sites. The walk through the gardens with the great works of art cannot be beat. So much to see. The Kiss, The Thinker, The Gate of Hell, Cathedral,.....and so many more. Go. You will not regret it!

Ideal for a romatic Rendez-vous. The museum is THE best place to impress your girlfriend - you will be considered as an intelectual, romantic and elegant guy (if this is what you want to look like of course:-). Both interior and exterior are nice - the gardens are full of sculptures and small benches to sit down and relax. I like the souvenir store too. Close to Invalides or Champs de Mars, it is a very central and beautiful location.

Well worth a visit - even under restoration. A fantastic oasis of calm in the centre of Paris within easy walking distance of many other more well known attractions. When we visited there was a temporary exhibition in place as the main house is undergoing a full restoration. However, to see the many elements that would make up just some of the great man's work was a humbling experience. The gardens are very well kept and contain many examples of his work, including 'The Thinker'. The café is in a wonderful position and offers a wide range of snacks and hot meals. Quite "the hidden gem"!
Interesting place. Lots to see in the gardens and sculptures everyone will recognise. The house is closed and under refurbishment at the moment but still lots to see in nice gardens
