Could not visit. I tried to visit twice during my visit on Paris. The first day was closed and next day there were some works for some months and only a temporary exhibition was available.I would suggest to the responsible to do the following next time:1. Better explain on their website both what can be visit during the works and which days the museum is closed (so that you don't have to go and check for that).2. Work on a room while the rest of the museum is open, then close another one and keep the others open and so on, so the visitor can still enjoy most of the exhibition.
Most of it closed for renovation. Most of museum is closed for renovations until Nov 2015. Some sculptures have been moved outside, but I think its best to miss this one until it re opens.

The Garden is worth the price of admission. The main indoor exhibits were closed during our trip, however the garden is the attraction. It really does have some great works. It is nice and peaceful to walk around outside. It is spread out enough that you can get some great pictures of the works.
A tranquil respite. Get a Paris Museum Pass to avoid the queues.Also, much of the museum is being refurbed at the moment to delay going if you are a real fan

Lovely museum. Lovely museum, lots to see indoors and out. Noticed that the "Gates of Hell" includes another sculpture Rodin did. Nice to see pictures of what he looked like, to put a face with the name.
Rodin. If you going to the museum don't stop for a drink or a snack they have a nice food and drink area in the garden area with the sculptures and nice break at a beautiful museum
Lovely. A wonderful collection of the work of Rodin in the house, as well as a charming garden with refreshment-stand and seating. Well worth a visit if you like Rodin's work.

The main exhibit was closed but the garden is beautiful!. Unfortunately, the main exhibit was closed today, August, 26, 2015, due to renovations so they offered us tickets to the Garden and we took them for a total of 2 Euros. We walked through to the back and saw the big one - The Thinker. One of the most famous sculptures in the world. We actually thought that was it for 2 Euros until we walked toward the toilettes and saw a HUGE garden in the back.There are lots of twists and turns where you'll find hidden sculptures. The flowers and landscaping are beautiful. There are plenty of places to sit and just look at these beautiful pieces. I only gave it a 4 because we couldn't get inside to see the rest of it.Really pretty garden, though.

Closed on Mondays and under renovation. I adore this museum, it is one of my favourites in Paris and I try to visit it each time I am there. I especially love the gardens. This time I was in Paris for just one day and it was, sadly a Monday and therefore the museum was closed but it did also seem to be undergoing a major renovation so perhaps check before you make the trek there if you plan to go anytime soon.

Maison is being renovated--museum open but unimpressive now. What a shame we planned our visit for Sunday afternoon thinking the house would be open, but it is closed for renovation. The museum was ok, but looks like it is in temporary quarters. Will go again next time in Paris.

Suprise experience!. When we first entered the display areas beyond the iticket office there was a sea of sculpture items and the area to me anyway looked a little bland!However the grounds and the history contained within was fascinating, there is alovely cafe within the grounds where you can take a breather from walking in the heat.The main building is currently being restored but I a stunning sight.There are many Rodin works contained throught the gardens.This place is an oassis ofcalm compared to most paris attractions.

Lovely sculptures and garden. Truly a beautiful place where the lovely art work is well placed through out the garden. Finally got to see the famous "kiss " and "the thinker". Great pieces of art indeed.

Gardens only until renovation is done. This is another great piece of Paris architecture -- an old hotel that Rodin made his home and art studio, along with some other artists, back when it was a fairly deserted hotel, overgrown outside, etc. While it's under renovation, only the gardens and a small exhibit inside are open, but a number of his works are in the garden so it's one of the deals in Paris, for sure -- only a few euros. Don't miss the walk around the fence where they have posted the history of the hotel and how Rodin and his friends got together there. That was almost more interesting than the exhibit inside!

Nice to walk around outside. We took the opportunity between rain showers to view Rodin's work, the pieces looked really great in an outdoor setting. We enjoyed outside more than the inside but appreciate there are works being completed. There is a good cafe and plenty of toilettes and great as it wasn't as crowded as some of the better known museums.

Beauitufl part of Paris. Really loved the visit, the sun was shinning, a little later in the season would be perfect, the outdoor exhibits are truly beautiful...we were luck enough to have a school excursion visiting at the same time (wouldn't recommend this if you could help it :) )
Peaceful and relaxing experience. The museum is in revonvation works at the moment but it's worth a visit anyway. Strolling around the garden while admiring the sculptures is a great experience.

An unexpected delight. After a jam packed visit to Louvre we decided to see a smaller Museum that next day and was pleasantly surprised and delighted with Musee Rodin. I especially liked the Gates of Hell and the garden was a beautiful place to slow down and enjoy the view of the garden and Eifel tower. Our whole family enjoyed the slower pace of this museum and we were able to enjoy each piece more. The audio guide was extremely helpful. Definitely worth a visit if you are in Paris.
Great style . Lovely building though not open in August which is odd as height of tourist season. Beautiful sculptures in the garden !

Could only visit the garden but well worth it. We were a little disappointed as the museum was shut for renovations (until Sept), but we paid €2 each for the garden which was an incredible bargain as it contained many of Rodin's famous pieces including 'The Thinker.' We found it extremely peaceful. There's a lovely little cafe in the middle which is worth a visit too

Didn't love it. The museum shows parts of his work, not much on his life. The gardens are nice, and you can see the Thinker, which is cool. The Gates of Hell are also a sight to see, but I didn't find myself drawn into his other works. Google some of them before you go and make sure this is worth the trip.

Rodin, It will only get better. Although the gardens area was the only part of the musuem actually open inMay, it was still nice to see and have explained all those Rodin sculptures you see around the city and elsewhere. A good afternoon couple of hours especially if the weather is warm..

Gem of a museum with little traffic. Located just to the east of the Musee de l'Armee, the Musee Rodin is a very charming outdoor/indoor display of Rodin's best work in large scale. Includes the original Le Penseur (Thinker) which is even more majestic up close. Rodin's version of Ugalino, the alleged cannibal count from Dante's Inferno, is at center of back fountain and a remarkable depiction of despair. One of the only two castings of Rodin's model for The Gates of Hell is here; at 6 meters tall with over 200 figures it is a technical masterpiece. Musee Rodin is a great way to spend a pleasant couple of hours especially in nice weather.
worth a look. Very interesting to read his history, and see the amazing artworks on display House was not open to public when we were there, which was a shame

relaxing visit. Having 2 young children, we decided to only visit the gardens. Free entry and the gardens were so peaceful and relaxing. The children found a sandpit to play in while we relaxed on lounge chairs.

Amazing Art, but under Construction?!. Very Interesting, incredible to actually see Rodin's sculptures in person. Unfortunately, our group had a rough start. Give anyone a uniform, badge, & a walking-talkie and they think they can be a bully. We had bought tickets just like everyone else but for some reason he kept insisting that we NOT come into "his" lobby which was large enough to accommodate all of us. We waited on the sidewalk outside. Other ticketed visitors were sent in ahead of us while we were forced to wait past our designated ticket time. Made us run late for our other tours that day. Once in the Garden, there was a lot of construction fencing, noises, & vehicles which covered a large area...So much for a "tranquil" experience... With all of that set aside, if you've studied and/or appreciate art, Rodin's works are still a must see!

Le Penseur It's My Favorite Piece Of Art!!. It's my favorite Museum, and it has my Favorite piece of Art!.... The Gardens are amazing and it also has Le Baiser another one of my favorites Piece of Art! The're doing some Renovations in the Museum.

Beautiful and worth a trip, even while it is undergoing renovations. The Musee Rodin is a fantastic collection spanning the life of Rodin and his famous assistant Camille. During my visit the main permanent collection was undergoing renovation, so a temporary exhibit had been set up. It was a fantastic collection, and the museum deserves a lot of recognition for being able to put together a temporary exhibit that was as captivating and interesting as the main permanent exhibit.DO NOT MISS the gardens. They are the most spectacular part of the museum, and wandering around looking at the sculpture and art outside is even better than the inside. The large bronze casting of The Thinker, the Gates of Hell, and his family casting of Balzac all reign in their areas of the garden.Do avoid using the rest rooms here, however, as even walking by them will cause your eyes to water with the terrible smell. Keep away, and your visit will be significantly less odoriferous.

my favourite museum in Paris. I have to go there every time I am in Paris, as it is such a beautiful museum. At the moment the building is under renovation, but there is a good exhibition in another building and the garden is as lovely as ever.
Don't go until the renovation is complete. Horrible to not see all the works in the home or even the outside of the home. I love this museum but right now it should be avoided
A great site to visit. For anyone who enjoys great sculpture, this is a not to be missed museum. The gardens are beautiful, tranquil and inspirational as are his sculptures

The garden is serene and beautiful. While there is extensive renovation of the Hotel currently being done in 2015 when I visited you can't help but be awed by the incredible creative output of one man in his lifetime. Rodin's works including drawings, plaster models and casts are displayed here as well as many of his iconic bronzes. The opportunity to stroll peacefully through the gardens is wonderful in such a busy city and if you stand quietly and savour this artist you can even get wonderful photos - with no people in them! Magnificent and a must see when in Paris.
Fantastic Museum. Go on a sunny day. The best sculptures are outside in the garden. And the garden is very nice. Rodin was a very talented sculpture.

Enjoy the garden!. The garden is the real deal of this museum. Walking around the fantastic sculptures with excellent tree formations kept in shape, fountains, benches, little retreats. Always worth a walk!
Lovely garden. One of my favorite place in Paris. Most of the garden make it. Beautiful and peaceful place, full of wonderful details.

A must-see for anyone interested in Rodin's work. The Musée Rodin opened in 1919, dedicated to the works of August Rodin. It has two sites – the Hotel Biron and gardens in Paris and at Rodin’s old home, the Villa Des Brillants at Meudon (Hauts-de-Seine), outside Paris. The collection is the largest of Rodin’s work with 6,600 sculptures, 8,000 drawings, 8,000 old photographs and 7,000 objets d’art including works by Van Gogh and Renoir that he had collected during his career. The Musée Rodin displays most of Rodin's most significant sculptures including The Thinker, The Kiss, the Gates of Hell and separate works forming the Burghers of Calais, many of which are in the extensive gardens. It is am extremely enjoyable setting in which to view Rodin's work.The Hotel Biron and parts of the gardens are currently undergoing refurbishment, but there is an excellent temporary display and many more sculptures have been temporarily housed in the gardens. The strength of the Collection is that it is possible to see the development of a sculpture through sketches, plaster models and photographs to the final bronze and thus see and begin to understand something of the thought process of Rodin himself..

Really lovely quiet setting and some great art.. Stopped here to kill some time before a tour of the Eiffel Tower. Main house/museum was closed for renovation but the grounds are lovely and filled with amazing Rodin sculptures (including The Thinker). Very quiet and uncrowded - a nice change from most of the attractions in Paris. Also, plenty of shade, a great cafe and nice clean bathrooms. I think this is a must see. Can't wait to go back when the museum is reopened.

Lovely strokl. Take a lovely stroll through the garden. It's simply magnificent, filled with stunning art, the garden is a must. Go on the earlier side. As it gets later, the line starts to wrap around the corner.

One of my favorite museums in Paris. Formerly Rodin's home, the house & grounds are lovely. The collection of Rodin's work within the building and on the grounds is extensive & magnificent. Even if you have seen Rodin's work in other settings, seeing this huge collection in this setting is definitely worth your time.

A truly lovely museum and gardens well worth the trip to Paris.. I am perhaps biased ,but this was an outstanding display (the gardens are magnificent.) There was renovation going on to the Hotel Biron while we were there,however that should not stop you from going Pick a nice day and see the gardens.In my view this is one of the best reasons to go to Paris.

Great place to visit, not great for kids.. Not for kids really, just not exciting enough unless you count the sniggering at the rude bits. An adult attraction really, well worth the visit. It was one of the more relaxing and peaceful places we visited in Paris.

Worthwhile for Lovers of Great Sculptors. If you appreciate the arts, particularly sculpture and the great Rodin, then you certainly should visit this museum dedicated to his works. There are inside and outside sections - the outside gardens displaying his works in a beautiful, peaceful setting. We would not recommend this place for children who might find it boring. Unfortunately, a part of the inside section was under renovation and therefore, some of his works were off limits.

Rodin created statues that make you think!. The main historic studio building is under renovation and is closed but many statues are scattered around the really lovely gardens and marble and plaster pieces are in a glassed in area so you don't miss much. I particularly was taken with was the statue with a stone on its shoulders picturing the burden we all carry that we will die at some time! It was very emotional and of course the masterpiece - The thinker! At only 1 Euro it was a cultural bargain
Under renovation.. Permanent displays closed until Nov 12. E2 for Jardin(Garden ) only, E7 for it and temp display. Many scultures in garden, includes Thinker, the kiss is in the temp. Display.

Most of Rodin's best sculptures on display here. This is a wonderful museum due to the nature and setting of Rodin's art. Some of it is on display inside the museum building while the rest is on display outside. All of Rodin's greatest works are on display here. From "The Thinker" to "The Kiss", this museum has Rodin's creations displayed all over the garden area. The museum building is the old Hotel Biron and is currently undergoing extensive renovation.Even though the building is currently being renovated, it is still open to the public for a small fee. Spend a couple of hours or a whole day roaming the gardens and marvel at some of the worlds most beautiful sculptures. Keep in mind that this is best visited on a day that is bright and sunshiny. A must see while visiting Paris.

Worth a visit!. Even though the house in undergoing renovations and was closed when we went in July, we used our Museum Pass to visit the gardens. The gardens are large and filled with Rodin's sculptures. It was a lovely visit and we thoroughly enjoyed it! We could see the top of the Pantheon and the Eiffel Tower over the gardens. So worth a visit!

TRANQUILITY. You HAVE to put this on your to do list - it is a beautiful Musee. currently under refurbishment, but nonetheless a great experience. I went 30 years ago and it was my first thing to do when I hit Paris. The gardens are so peaceful and breathtaking.
A nice walk around. . Museum under renovation, but most of the key sculptures are around the grounds. A nice walk around and not too busy even in August.

Best place in Paris. Musee Rodin is my favourite place in Paris. Every visit is a great experience. The collection is incredible and the gardens are good for a relaxing time between masterpieces. Take some time to enjoy some coffee and macaroons in the cute restaurant.
Waste of time. The inside was closed so we visited the gardens. They were ok but there are many things worth ones time oil Paris that come before this place.
Perfect day for a garden visit. The main museum was closed, but the garden was tranquil and lovely. It was very peaceful to stroll through the garden and see the statues. The roses were exceptional.

A superb excursion.. Nestled within the gray streets of Paris is an garden sanctuary of art. The house is lovely, the topiary is delightfully subdued, and the sculptures are everywhere. While it was crowded with other enthusiasts, the museum is well-organized with many options for viewing and enjoying Rodin's work. The docents are unobtrusive and there is plenty of information available for non-Francophones. I loved being able to have my lunch in the garden with the sculptures of my choice.

Gardens visit was perfect. The museum is under renovation so we opted to pay E2 each for access to the gardens. It was perfect. The Thinker is here which was what we were most interested in. Further sculptures are throughout the gardens. PARENTS there are 2 sandboxes at the back if the garden for kids to play in. Here also are chairs and lingers to relax, read a book.... It was relaxing and not too busy.

Lovely to spend the afternoon in the garden . We visited Musee Rodin during the renovations so the main museum was shut. We had a lovely afternoon in the garden, we had lunch at the cafe and enjoyed the shade on a hot day.It was very nice to get some respite from the heavy crowds around as this wonderful place must be just off the beaten track for most tourists and was not very busy.The temporary exhibit was a little disappointing but they do have the Kiss on display. Note to families- no strollers allowed in the temporary exhibit. They can be left outside the door. We had our 1 year old napping in the stroller so my husband and I went one at a time.

Under construction right now. If you're traveling to Paris before September 2015, I'd recommend saving the Musee Rodin for your next trip. We went in July 2015 and pretty much the entire museum was under construction. The gardens-- which are breathtaking-- are open though, and so we paid 7 euros and learned all we could do was walk through it. But again, because so much is under construction you are literally walking amongst orange tape. Don't get me wrong, this museum is amazing and absolutely worth seeing, but save your trip for when the work is done.

Disappointing that we couldn't see the main exhibit. We did not realize that the main exhibit was closed until we actually were on line to purchase our entrance tickets. We did enjoy the gardens and the small exhibit that was open.
One of the best museums. One of the best museums in Paris. Resembles one in Philadelphia US. Come here every year. Best to come on free days in August when city is empty
beautiful garden!. a beautiful garden and lots of sculpture works, the construction/renovation might be a little annoying recently, otherwise, would have the chance to visit all!

Lovely gardens and statues. We visited here after napoleons tomb across the street. We just visited the gardens for €2/3 and did not go inside. It was well worth the money. No lines and not crowded on a Friday afternoon. Saw "The Thinker" statue, though currently its surrounded by construction. Gardens are very large and there are many statues to look at. Seating areas are plentiful. We ate at the cafe in the gardens - good food but pricey. Perfect place to rest, relax and take photos. English speaking staff.

Wonderful Museum, calm and inviting.. Definitely visit this museum while in Paris. It is calm and just beautiful to see Rodin's art situated all over the garden. We are not major museum lovers and found this one to be one of our favorites. Get a nice lunch at the outdoor cafe, bring your book and relax in the very back of the garden while soaking in the gorgeous atmosphere.
The Thinker--of course, you must see this!. One of my favorite museums in Paris. Just sitting under the Thinker is amazing, and then to go through the charming museum is the icing.

An oasis of calm. How lovely to find this oasis of calm in the midst of busy city centre Paris. To be able to see some of the most famous works of art in their "natural" setting was fabulous. And free entry for our 15 year old - a real treat!

A good spot that you can't miss!. Its graden is suitable for an art lover to do his/her painting. I spent a nice summer afternoon portraying my water paintings. Besides, there is full of the lovely benches for visitors to take a rest. Some important scultures are displayed with the repeating recorded introduction and background music. This definitely attractive setting make those scultures more vividly.

One of my favorite places in Paris. We've been here many times and always enjoy the (relative) quiet and calm of this museum and gardens near Les Invalides. Currently the main house is being renovated. To compensate, there is an excellent exhibit showing, through plaster and clay models as well as beautiful photographs, how Rodin created many of his wonderful works. Start here, then go to the gardens and see the finished works cast in bronze or carved in marble. You can pay a separate admission to just enjoy the gardens, sit in the shade, contemplate "The Thinker" or "The Gates of Hell" then perhaps repair to the little café (prices okay for a museum eatery) for a small bit and a drink. Even on a first visit to Paris, I highly recommend squeezing in an hour or two to at least enjoy the gardens.

Auguste Rodin is our age's Michelangelo. His museum is astonishing.. Rodin gave life to his statues. You should visit this museum on a sunny day, as all statues are in a park and it's a joy to admire them in the sun. It's a very emotional display, like nothing else in Paris.

Under repair. Very disappointing as mentioned before with the renovations, but for me it truly detracts from the special ambiance we seen in past visits. You need to be a big Rodin fan to enjoy things other than the gardens.

Rodin, the master. An unbelievable close-up view of Rodin's very best sculptures! The location of the house in the gardens allows you to view indoors as well as outdoors, with a lovely cafe on site. Rodin is my favorite sculpture, so this was very special for me.

I Don't Want Anyone Else To Go.... This is my favorite "go to" museum in Paris. We have been twice now and will probably always come back. The museum and grounds have all of the classic Rodin pieces that you see in the books or classes and both times they had a different "special" exhibit. I love coming here because it is not overwhelming, it is surprisingly quiet and peaceful and it is a great place to relax and enjoy when everything else in Paris is such a hustle and bustle. I don't want anyone else to go because I want to keep enjoying it without the crowds ;)

renovation still ongoing. The grounds and the museum have been under renovation for a long time and we have to admit, we were sorry that is STILL was when we were there in June. It's just not the same obviously walking past staffolding and barricades. Yet, the art is fantastic and a must see and absorb. Close to metro so easy to reach and we walked from there to Eiffel Tour and wondered through lovely neighborhoods.

Pretty gardens and some interesting works and preparatory works.. The Gates of Hell bronze cast in the garden is to me the probably the most impressive work. Nice to come to if you are in the area. We stayed only a short time and that was enough to see everything.
Small, But worth it. I don't have much to say, it a very nice museum, and it doesnt require a lot of time to see it all ..

A fantastic museum. Rodin's sculptures, in this setting, will leave you awestruck. There are also pieces by his very talented mistress, Camille Claudel worth checking out, who did not get her due in life. As the Rodin is very near L'hôtel des Invalides where Napoleon's Tomb is, both can easily be visited on the same day.

Worthy of a Master. I enjoy this museum and the surrounding garden. The grounds are wonderful for a stroll. The museum inside is enjoyable, but to me, are an added bonus. Rodin is best viewed in nature, outside. Most of his greatest pieces are displayed by walkways and in alcoves, including 'The Gates'. The cafe is nice for a quick pick me up.
A good experience. The museum is in restauration but there is a wonderful garden, in which the statues are placed. The queue seems long at first but it rapidly moves ahead.

Must see in Paris. Disappointing that the old house is not available as it is being renovated. But the works of Rodin are well displayed including in the garden, make sure you take a stroll right around the garden to see his major works including the Gates of Hell around at the side.

Saved the best for last. On a dark, dreary, rainy day we visited Musee Rodin. The grounds were muddy, and there was a fair sized crowd. Inclement weather be damned. The Musee Rodin is exquisite - even in dank weather the grounds are lovely. Simply go and soak up the totality of the talent that stands, sits, lay before you. The only odd thing was The Kiss - shoved into a corner of the ground floor - placed before one wall that was painted a garish yellow, and another battleship gray. Such a strange choice, that I hope the curator has recovered his/her senses and moved it elsewhere.

Best Museum Experience. Possibly the best museum experience we had in Paris! The line was manageable, the number of people in the gardens were reasonable and I'm not sure why, but it only cost 1 Euro per person! Of course the Rodin sculptures were fantastic, the gardens were beautiful/peaceful and quiet....we brought croissants/cheese and ate them on a bench and just absorbed the beauty....the actual hotel/museum was not open but just as well - we enjoyed the gardens/sculptures there immensely. A 5-star for us.
Don't Skip This. Easy to go through this museum and gardens. Really cool to see The Thinker anf Gates of Hell in person.

Relaxing change from the other museums. It was very nice to get away from the big attractions and get to enjoy the garden in relative quiet. The sculptures are very impressive to see up close - incredible detail. Although there is a temporary exhibit while they are doing renovations, it was very interesting to learn about the stories for how some of the sculptures were created (different ideas, etc.)

The Thinking Man. You should visit the Musee Rodin to actually see the Thinking Man and the Gates of Hell. It was convenient for us to visit as it is next to Napoleon's Tomb and the Armees Musee. You can see all three fairly easily, without having to get back on the Metro. Recommended.

Great place but main museum under renovation. the museum is located near Varenne metro station. Gardens are worth the visit so you still get to see the thinker. there is a temporary exhibition where you can see the kiss as unfortunately the main museum is closed due to renovations until Oct this year

Nice quick visit. We breezed through the gardens to see The Thinker. It was nice to have a quick visit after lots of long museums. The gardens were all that was open. And we weren't able to skip the line with the Paris Museum Pass. We all went in the same line.
Must see. Very impressive building and tremendous array of sculptures. Take your time to view the grounds as well as the museum.

Excellent gardens but under rennovation. We have always delighted in Rodin, visiting the fine museum in Philadelphia and the traveling exhibit in the lower level of the Smithsonian's Art Museum, modern wing, years ago: with a Calder mobile sweeping across a Rodin statue of Balzac (sans tete) in the main lobby and a sign pointing down the broad staircase to the lower level gallery of the exhibit marked "Descend this way to the Gates of Hell".The Paris Musee Rodin is well worth a short visit but as we toured the continent in the summer of 2015 its exhibits were under massive renovation leaving us only with a pleasant stroll through the gardens. None the less this fun and relaxing.

Worth a visit. We visited here with children in July and found the gardens a welcome break from the heat. The gardens themselves are worth a visit! The main exhibition was closed for renovation, but we still saw the statue of The Thinker and The Kiss and quite enough to satisfy us and the teenagers. The story of how Rodin saved the building from demolition is a neat one, and it will satisfy any art lover and even those who aren't so into it.

Interesting art in a beautiful garden setting. Rodin's work is very nice, and the presentation here made it even more pleasant. The facility is a former hotel and it has a very stately appearance, as is fairly typical with most of the larger buildings here. His sculptures were placed throughout a large garden. While there was considerable construction, it was still a nice visit.
Great Museum. Excellent small museum well worth the visit to get away from the crowd and see great works of art by Rodin
Under construction. This museum is under construction. You can still see the sculptures outside. Go see the Thinker. Covered by the museum pass.

The best museum under the sky. This museum interesting not only because of an amazing works of one of the best skull for on earth , but also the way it's done. First of all because all the great sculptures are situated in a huge and wonderfully made park where you can walk and enjoy watching the great works of art while you are listening to a guide . . . Love it!

Different than the pictures taken. Such a beautiful medium-sized garden. Maybe I expected too much. I visited this place May 2015 and the actual museum was closed. Only the indoor temporary one was open. The garden was under a construction.

Saved the Best to Last. We went here on our last day in Paris and it really just was the icing on the cake. To see Rodin's works (inside the gallery and in the gardens), where he actually resided and how he left it is really something special. It was my favourite museum / gallery in Paris and I can't rave highly enough about it. A must see!

Definitely worth the time!. Didn't even know who Rodin was except for the "The Thinker", however, there is so so so much more of his works that had my husband & I speechless....the gardens weren't much as far as flowers go but the sculptures and bronzed ones were quite magnificent...pleasantly pleased with the cafe' (that can only be accessed with your museum pass, unfortunately) food and drink selections....enjoyed a bowl of a legume soup and a glass of prosecco...perfect break in the day! Enjoy!!

One oy my favorite in city of art and culture!. Make sure that you pay a visit there. If you have the pass museum, then you would enter with no problem. Just note that they are renovating it so some parts are not accessible to public, but still you get to see most of his works (and yes the famous thinker of all time and hell's gate!).Make sure you walk in the garden and find all the hidden sculptures, and fountains. They have a little cafe as well in case you want to take a break and have a gelato or coffee!

My Favorite Museum in Paris. This is our favorite museum in Paris because of the magnificent sculpture of the greatest sculptor since Michelangelo, the beautiful gardens, and its manageable size and accessibility. We go there every time I visit Paris.

Worth a Quick Visit. A lovely small museum with a nicely adorned garden. Houses "The Thinker" & "The Kiss". Reasonable fee or part of the museum pass. Focussed and not overwhelming. Stay for a peaceful drink or snack available in the garden.

beautiful garden. The place is awesome, it offers beautiful pieces of art form statues to paintings. a wonderful garden full of flowers in the summer and spring, but also beautiful in the winter. It has a good and reasonably priced restaurant, so take your time and spend teh day there.

Wait for the construction to be completed.. We've been to the Rodin Museum several times. It's wonderful. Our most recent visit, however, was confusing and abbreviated due to the construction. We were able to tour the gardens, which are wonderful, but the regular collection seems to have been put in storage and a small sampling placed on display in a temporary building.I'd recommend waiting on this one until the construction has been completed. Especially if you have limited time to see sights in Paris.

My Favorite Museum in Paris. First of all, this place is super cheap for Paris. It's about 3 Euros if you don't want to see the special exhibit and about 8 or so if you do. Since Paris will stretch your wallet in general this is definitely a bonus. The sculptures are also amazing and they include the classic Thinking Man as well as The Gates of Hell. I also like that it's outside and there are many places to sit. Usually I get bored after walking a few hours in a Museum and I find it nice that in Rodin you can just sit an relax and hang around outside if you want. Definitely my favorite Museum in Paris.

Rodin garden open; rest of museum currently closed. Only the garden was open- the inside museum is being renovated. A large fashion show was being erected in the garden, so the space was crowded. However, the sculptures were great- so wonderful to see them in person at last.

A great surprise. You would know about the great Rodin sculptures, but the surprise was having them spread among great gardens outside. It is a very relaxing place, you can bring a picnic and it has a decent cafe as well. Definitely worth going to.

Very Good; Will Likely Be Excellent in November. This is the largest collection of Rodin’s art in the world, but please note that it is currently under renovation, so you won’t get to see much of it until mid-November.The Rodin Museum is near the Museum L'Armee, and the two make an odd, but compatible couple. It is housed in a former convent structure that was closed by the government around 1900 and was used by artists as a place to stay afterward. It was basically adopted by Rodin as his home.The large house is under renovation, but there are many Rodin works in the garden, including the Gates of Hell and The Thinker. There is also a very good cafe and you can eat in the garden – where else can you have lunch surrounded by Rodin sculpture?The museum was free the day we visited, perhaps due to the renovation, but it is also included in the excellent museum pass you can buy at art museums all over the city.If you really need a Rodin fix, there is also a large Rodin museum in Philadelphia, about a 5 minute walk to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.Even with the closure, this is a good place to visit, and an ideal place for lunch if you are nearby. It should be great in 2016.

Good break from traditional indoor galleries. Musee Rodin is a fantastic gallery, especially if you take the time to enjoy the gardens and have a cup of coffee in the cafe. We visited on a sunny day, and having been to perhaps a dozen galleries in the space of a week, this was a wonderful change of pace. The collection featured some favourites of mine, including Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell. This is a great gallery to take kids to, as the outdoor space is more welcoming than indoor galleries.

Very interesting museum. Musee Rodin is accomodated in the house in which the sculptor was living and working.That´s why it is a very authentic place. His works are just amazing, he was a true genius.So if you like sculpture don´t miss this interesting museum which is not far from the Les Invalidés. I reccommend to hire an audioguide there as there is not that much information written about the single exhibits in the rooms.

Lovely oasis of calm. The reason we did not give 5 stars is just that the house is closed for renovation at the moment, so the size of the museum is reduced. We thoroughly enjoyed being close up to such amazing sculptures and the gardens were lovely. The Cafe was fairly expensive, but the food was definitely worth it - even the vegetable soup was wonderful. This place is definitely worth a visit, even in its reduced state!

Still worth seeing. The museum itself was being restored (and not open) when we arrived, and the visit was free. It was still well worth visiting the gardens, where you can wander and sit and contemplate The Thinker and The Gates of Hell among other classics. The Museum grounds are beautifully kept and well worth a stop.

Wait until Construction is Finished.. It is under construction, so you can't get into the hotel he lived at, and they are working on the fountain. There are still nice pieces to see, and I love the little cafe that you can sit out at in the shade and relax in the hustle and bustle of Paris.

Only go to garden and skip museum due to renovation. Only worth it if you go to the garden for 1 euro. Garden and cafe there nice. I would skip the museum inside due to the renovation and not worth 7 euros to see the temp exhibit.
Wait till renovation is over. The place is under renovation, for the time being is only worth to visit the gardens. They have a very small temporary exhibition which is not worth seeing.

Better before and hopefully after the renovation. My husband and I visited this museum on a trip 5 years ago and had fond memories of it. We returned this month and it wasn't as great an experience. The house portion was closed for renovations, and the few exhibits shown in the visitor center building were not as enjoyable to browse as the main collection in the house. The gardens are worth a visit, to see the Thinker as well as the unfinished gates and the Burghers of Calais. Hopefully once the renovations are done the experience will be even better, but as it is now we only stayed about half an hour and were sorry we couldn't see the house. Note that it is part of the Museum Pass, and fairly near the Army Museum, so it is worth a stop if you're nearby and have the pass to enable free entry.
Amazing. I was initially a little let down by not going into the mansion but the gardens is where most of the famous pieces are housed.

Garden is beautiful, and only €2!. The museum is closed for renovation until September. We paid to see the temporary exhibit for €5, but this was poor value - you get to see 'the kiss' but not much else. Most of our time was spent in the wonderful garden, two euros very well spent.

Avoid until building works are completed. Best avoid until the building works are completed. Additionally to these works, much of the garden was closed off the day we visited, following a function - a large marquee and scaffolding/stage were being taken down, so felt like wandering a building site. Of course the sculptures were fabulous, but the experience was marred by the works.

Must See. The Garden is worth the trip on its own...a great walk among dazzling sculptures. The inside galleries can be crowded but are quite spacious.nphotography allowed. Buy express tickets...LONG LINES
Charming. For me onde of te most interesting museums I've been. Beautiful garden and wonderful sculptures! If you have time enough in Paris, you must go!
Exquisite - and the gardens are too. What a brilliant man, and how special to see so many of his art and sculpture works in one place. The gardens are worth a visit all of their own.

Worth a visit. Very interesting museum. Beautiful building, well preserved like most things in Paris. It was good to see one of Rodins most famous works of art "The thinker"in the garden. The gardens are well worth the visit, and the restaurant which has an outside eating area in the garden serves varies types of food,I had a salad which I think was the best I ever eaten.

A Real Gem. The collection of sculpture, both in the house and in the gardens, is fabulous and not to be missed. There is a most considerable range of Rodin's work always on display here. Opt for a 'no rain' day to be certain you can enjoy the gardens.

The outdoor garden is the best part. Even if it's closed for renovation, this museum is worth a quick visit just to see the outdoor gardens. That's where most of Rodin's well-known works are displayed. At one euro, the price can't be beaten. It combines well with a visit to the Army Museum, and provides a pleasant place for a relaxing stroll.

Partially closed for renovation July 2015. Main museum closed for renovation, only garden open. You may be disappointed if you travelled here specially. Please check availability before.Only €1 entry to garden.However, on a perfect summer day the garden was absolutely amazing.The thinker and beautiful flowers.
The perfect Parisian outdoor museum stroll.. One of the most classic museums in Paris you actually need to see. The iconic Rodin thinker is a need to see.

A Destination Museum. After a lengthy trek from the Eiffel Tower to the Musee Rodin (due to my own miscalculations of distance), my wife and I were deeply impressed by the Rodin works and the elegant setting in which they are displayed, indoors and outdoors. Rodin's Gates of Hell and Thinker are reason enough to visit, but there are many other sculptures worth seeing, and the grounds themselves are well-maintained and attractive for quiet walks and contemplation. Even if you don't count yourself as a Rodin devotee, this is well worth a visit however limited your time in Paris may be.

Absolutely amazing. this "house" in the center of Paris has one of the finest collections of Rodin. He worked here many years. Many of his sculptures are in the lovely gardens. Very interesting museum to attend. Nice cafe inside the museum compound.

“Rodin being renovated.”. This visit the main house was closed in renovation. Only the garden was open. They also had special exhibit - nothing notable. As we had been prior with the main house open this was a bit disappointing. One sidebar is the rest rooms are located in the lower level of the main entry complex -- they are super cool from the AC flowing down there- on a hot day it felt pretty good to linger a bit,

A relaxing walk. A lovely garden to wander around and view Rodin's magnificent sculptures. Give yourself 1 to 2 hours to enjoy the whole experience. There is a cafe situated in the gardens for a break.

One of my favorite museums. First, be sure to get a multi day museum pass. The pass will allow you to have priority access and you won't have to stand in line. The museum is having some renovations, but the beauty of this place is all the sculptures in the rose garden. Just gorgeous! A must visit!

Lovely sculptures and gardens but currently under construction. The Rodin Museum is wonderful - fabulous sculptures and gardens, but the mansion and parts of the garden are currently under construction. You can't go into the mansion and there is alot of scaffolding that detracts from the beauty of the gardens.The ticket price has not been reduced to compensate for the inconvenience.It is still worth a visit (all of the sculptures are on view) but go on a nice day as almost everything is outside.

A lovely sculpture garden in the heart of Paris under renovation. Alas, under renovation! I am an avid fan of Rodin, and proud owner of a bronze reproduction of "Cathedral" (purchased before bronzes became unaffordable) so I had looked forward to visiting one of two French landmarks dedicated to Rodin: Musee Rodin and le Maison Rodin. The Musee Rodin is in Paris and therefore more accessible, so it was an easy choice.The Musee Rodin was formerly a hotel that Rodin stayed in whenever he was in Paris. It prides itself on being the only museum that is wholly privately funded. All the sculpture is in the garden. The hotel building itself is closed off. It was not clear to me whether it is open to the public under normal conditions.Perhaps bcause of its private finding and the renovation, the museum did not seem to be as organised as all the others we visited in Paris (Louvre, D'Orsay, Museum of Modern Art, Cluny, L'Orangerie, etc). Some areas were closed off. I did not see a replica of "The KissThe other Parisian museums do not have much of Rodin's work. The only other museum that displays a lot of Rodin's work which I have visited is Stanford University's Cantor Arts Center. I enjoyed my visit and think it was worth it.
A true mastermind. You have to make time to see Rodin. HIs work and attention to detail is parallel to none. He was truly brilliant.

The scupure garden very good. set in a garden the sculpures are in the envon they they would enjoy were it not a museum Robin well get all ages thinking, its art you an touch to feel the form. An oasis in a busy city

Did not disappoint. I have been wanting to visit this museum for many years but work obligations on trips to Paris have kept me away. Plus, for some reason, I thought it was further outside the city than it is but it is right next off of the Varrenne metro stop. Rodin has been my favorite French artist since I was 15 when I stood in front of the Marble Porte de l'enfer at the Musee D'Orsay for the first time. This museum does not disappoint in it's outdoor collection of sculptures displayed among the gardens of tall trees and beautiful flowers. Inside there is an educational gallery of Rodin's process as an artist which reminded me of the basement museum at La Sagrada Famiglia in Barcelona in that it showed models, test versions and different medias that Rodin used to create the final product and in many cases the different versions of his final product. This is a very easy and accessible museum for Paris. I recommend it to art lovers but also as an introduction to art because there are recognizable works but also educational and engineering aspects that will interest many. Entry is free on Sundays. The Kiss is much more moving in person than in pictures.
One of the must do's in Paris. Spend a couple of hours at this museum for the art which is incredibly contemporary, the building that houses the museum and the wonderful gardens
The Thinker. This que line moved the fastest. Parts of the museum are under construction. The gardens are beautiful and very well maintained. The Thinker is everything I imagined!

Musee Rodin is undergoing renovations. While renovations are necessary, the current works limit the quality of the visit. Nevertheless, the Museum has opened a temporary exhibition in which the process of creation of a masterpiece is thoroughly studied. It is still worth visiting it, but I would suggest to come back to see the final results in the near future.

Beautiful - don't miss it!. Seeing The Thinker was a must for my visit - and definitely ended up being one of the highlights. The roses in the garden were gorgeous! I loved the relaxed atmosphere you get from being in one of the smaller and less visited museums.

Musee Rodin. There was a lot of construction and didn't find the staff at all friendly. The gardens were okay but certainly not spectacular. Found it rather boring. Can say that I saw some of Rodin's sculptures but that's it.

Great museum . I have two teenage boys who hate museums. They liked this one. The sculptured gardens house at least two dozen sculptures. The most famous being the "Thinker." Very informative about his process and shows Rodin's work at various stages. A family can get through this museum in about an hour. This coupled with being, in part, outside makes it easier for those with younger children.The only disappointment was that audio tours are only offered in French.Tip: Wednesday is late night. Check hours and go later in the day.Tip: You can use the Paris pass At this museum.

Musee Rodin......my favorite house/garden in Paris. This is another one of the Paris attractions that I visit EVERY time I'm in Paris. Was just there in May and the house is under renovation and closed. The entry fee is reduced and the gardens/outdoor sculptures are why I visit. Just a beautiful beautiful place to be!!

great collection in wonderful setting. we've been to this exhibit several times and always enjoyable. word of caution if you are visiting right now - there is major renovation happening but exhibit is still worth viewing. there are both an inside and outside exhibit. there is an outside wall with a wonderful description of Rodin's life and artist's career.
Museum was closed.. I am not sure when it will reopen but the rose gardens were absolutely beautiful! My trip is never complete unless I get to see the Thinker.

Great place for rodin lovers. IT truly is an incredible museum. IT shows the progression of such an incredible artist. Some are actual works, other copies, tho i think they all give a great picture of his life

there was construction.... This had been my favorite "museum" many years ago. Unfortunately, there was a lot of loud and dusty construction going on and the house was completely closed down. It's worthwhile going when everything opens back up

Didn't want to leave. If you are a fan of Rodin's work, this is a must see. There are two parts to this museum - the formal inside, and the breathtaking garden. I can't comment on the inside tour, as we opted to walk the gardens. His sculptures are brilliant and thought provoking, and their placements in the garden have been well thought out. The garden itself is almost enchanting. Along with many of Rodin's pieces, lounging chairs are scattered about and tucked under shady trees, and quiet corners. There you can relax with a book, or just take in the ambiance of this wonderfully peaceful place. One experience you will want to deposit into your memory bank.
Beautiful garden. I didn't know what to expect when I gave here but quickly fell in love with it. Even though the main house was under restoration, it was a beautiful museum to behold.

Half the place closed, still paid same price. The artwork is beautiful, and if you go on a nice day it's a perfect place to relax and enjoy the sunshine in the garden. The indoor museum is small, but easy to get around and with plenty of space. Unfortunately the house and parts of the garden were closed which was very dispointing as have heard the house is one of the best parts. A discount would have been nice, otherwise I would not have bothered.
Splendid. It's a beautiful part of the world that one must visit while in Paris. To get to experience the sights creativity of some of the worlds great painters and sculptors is a great treat.
Beautiful outdoor museum. On a gorgeous Paris day , this is a must. Stroll around and enjoy but look up also to enjoy city landscape
Rodin oh Rodin. Place was under restoration when I visited . However the exhibits had been moved out . A very well laid out place , very neat as well . Nice Souvenirs to buy

Just visit the Garden during construction. The displays during the construction were disappointing and not worth it. The garden however is still worth a visit during the construction. Unfortunately, it's difficult to get a good picture of The Thinker due to the sun.

Meh.. I'm sure the fact that there was extensive renovation going on while we were there did not help, but this was a disappointment. Though one or two famous Rodins are there (notably The Thinker), most of what is here is stuff designed by Rodin but actually cast by others, or preliminary work-ups in plaster or other media of final works that are actually on display elsewhere. The current (June 2015) exhibition focusing on Rodin's working methods is fascinating, especially in that it shows photographs of him at work, pieces in various state sof preparation, etc., but it still was a let-down.

For 1 Euro the Price is Right. Since the chateau is closed for repairs the museum right now is letting in guests for 1 Euro for entry into the gardens. To be honest the gardens are what most people want to see anyway as the Divine Comedy gates and Thinker are displayed there. Don't let the construction scare you off like most of the rest of the crowds.

This place got me thinking.... Rodin lived and worked here, and one look at the garden will tell you why. Short queue to get in, and not too many visitors around, so a more comfortable experience than some of the other Paris attractions.The Thinker, of course, is the star of the show, but there is a lot more to see, and this quiet house and garden is a joy to visit in the hustle and bustle of Paris.

Great garden visit. I only visited the garden, as other areas were under revision. That visit is VERY inexpensive and more than worth the time and money. Many of Rodin's pieces were on display in the garden and it was a pleasant, shady walk to see them. Cafe there is a nice place to rest and have a snack or meal. Musee Rodin is very centrally located and easy to find.

Wonderful spot for picnic or afternoon lounge. Not usually my cup of tea but I was very impressed by the Musee Rodin. It was very interesting to see "The Thinker" in person and the grounds were very well maintained. There was a lot for us to see and do, including a large variety of sculptures and artistic pieces. Very glad we took an afternoon to discover all that the museum had to offer. Would definitely recommend people to go and see for themselves.
Lovely Venue. Musee Rodin is a delightful museum. The Thinker is on display in a lovely garden. I am vrery glad we visited. It is a small venue with beautiful sculptures for your enjoyment.
Rodin Museum is a MUST. This charming home of Rodin's holds most of Rodin's most famous pieces. Learn about one of the world's greatest sculptors, his life, his work and his art.
My favourite place in Paris!. One of the most beautiful museums I have ever seen. The location is perfect and the garden is gorgeous. It is a perfect place to relax and just enjoy the works of Rodin.

One of the most amazing and prolific sculptors of all time!. PROS: beautiful garden; amazing sculptures sprinkled throughout the garden and grounds as the mansion is currently off limits due to construction; there are separate buildings housing his unfinished works and a temporary exhibit area behind the gift shop. CONS: most of the works there I also found in Musee D’ Orsay (except the Thinker); the Walking Man is not on display but was in Musee D’ Orsay. TIPS: The Museum Pass gets you right in; no waiting in line!

Homage to August Rodin. Most of Rodin's life was spent on the Left Bank. In fact, he lived and worked here at the Hotel Biron. When he died, his sculptures were given to the State. The Hotel Biron then became the lovely Musee Rodin that we enjoy today. Althoug castings of many of Rodin's sculptures can be seen around the world, the depth and breadth of the collection at the Musee Rodin in Paris is not to be missed. So glad that we were able to visit!

Small and lovely. The queues to get into this museum was much smaller than the larger ones. You can get a ticket just to go around the gardens, which contain a lot of the sculptures, or you can pay a little more and see the museum. We thought we were going to see his house but it is under restoration at the moment which was a little disappointing. A must for anyone who enjoys this art form.

Loved it. What a beautiful museum! Loved the way everything is displayed - throughout the home and then the gardens. We did not eat at the restaurant but it looked great. The audio tour was very helpful too!

All things Rodin. Everything Rodin,. Unlike many other artists Rodin was rich and he donated the building and the art to the state. The best thing about this place is that they sell a two pack that also gets you into the Musee D'Osay so you save the two hours waiting in line for tickets at that place.

Unforgettable!. It was incredible to see so many of Rodin's exquisite sculptures amongst perfectly manicured rose gardens. A unique and unforgettable experience in central Paris. "The Gates of Hell" and original "The Thinker" reside here and are so beautiful.

Museum Under Renovation - Garden Still Nice. The museum is slated to re-open later in the year...unfortunately, this meant many of the unique Rodin pieces were simply unavailable. The Garden was still open and did offer a nice respite from the Paris traffic and crowds. There are still great works to be seen in the garden -including the doors titled the Gates of Hell and more. If you get the Museum Pass, you will surely avoid any wait to get in. The museum is a short walk from Musee d'Orsay, and there was a nice cafe in the garden as well.

Gates of Hell. If you're staying in the St Germaine area then a visit to,Rodin's Museum is a must. The sculpture's in the gardens, and the gardens themselves are well worth the visit, but the "Thinker" and "the gates of hell" amongst many others just make this place so special.
Get on with the renovations. The art here is wonderful but it is under constant renovations so it is dusty and dirty as of my review. Get the renovations done and all will be well

Worth a visit. Relative tranquility in a major city. The house wasn't as much fun. As much as I like Rodin, there were too many sculptures packed together and too many people. So had a quick look round and then escaped to the gardens. It was lovely to wander round. There is a good selection of sculptures carefully positioned in all directions. We thoroughly enjoyed it and were able to look at Rodin's work in a relaxed manner. There's a good café with friendly staff on site. Can easily spend a couple of hours there or more.

Great little museum, beautiful gardens.. This great little museum is set in a lovely old building, with beautiful gardens. The work by Rodin is amazing, and you can see it inside in the exhibition space, and outside, in the gardens as well. Fairly short queues, friendly staff. Well worth a visit!
Peaceful and Perfect. I simply pay the one euro and spend at least an hour in the garden. Very peaceful. If you go early, you can probably walk around all by yourself for a while.
Small and lovely. If you like sculpture you'll love this museum and it's gardens filled with some of Rodin's best works. Two highlights are THE KISS and THE THINKER.

Magical Place in the middle of a busy city. I visited the Musee Rodin not really knowing what to expect and I was in shock with the beauty of the whole thing. Not only is Rodin's art and sculptures beautiful but the property itself is magical. What a beautiful place to even just stroll the gardens and take a walk.

A total bliss!. Most probably the most romantic museum in Paris. I love Rodin and there is so much to see. Visitors can get to choose between the museum and the garden. My mum and I went to both and it was worthed. The garden is really lovely. Lots of space to walk around really liked after. The cafe is great too.
ART. To this small beautiful museum I'll come every visit in Paris. Amazing sculpter sculptures spread indoor and outdoor in a beautiful garden

Rodin's house. If you are an admirer of Rodin you will visit but if you a novice you simply cannot afford to skip this museum. The bronze sculptures in the garden are so well done and well placed. The Thinker, The Kiss, Cathedral, Sorrow, Three Shades and many more to appreciate.

A perfect museum. unfortunately they were re-doing the Hotel park, but we were able to enjoy the gardens with the beautiful statues that Rodin created. It is a peaceful location in the middle of a very busy city. Rodin created amazing sculptures for us to enjoy

Unfortunately, under construction. Really enjoyed visiting this museum, but the main gallery was closed and seems to be evolving into a hotel? Most of the sculptures are outside, so thank goodness for a beautiful day and gardens. It is so impressive to see art you have known about but never seen.

Excellent way to spend a morning in Paris. Go early to avoid the crowds; it gets much busier after lunch. While the main building is undergoing renovations, they do have a small, well-done exhibit inside on the ground floor. The real gem, though, is the sculpture gardens. It's laid out beautifully with plenty of shade, seating, and meandering paths. I recommend bringing a book about the museum or getting the audio guide because the plaques are not translated into English that I recall. This is the museum that really made me recognize my love of sculpture!

Beautiful Place to visit. The sculpture garden was amazing. You almost can't believe you are seeing some of these pieces in person. They are so big and beautiful. The landscaping is really fascinating too.

Under renovation but enjoyable. The gardens are beautiful and they are really working on improvements. You need to realize that these are bronze castings of the originals but the setting is wonderful and it will be incredible when completed.

Great afternoon visit. This is a great little museum. We only went to the outside attractions. The weather was gorgeous. The grounds were very well kept, beautiful everywhere you looked. There is a small café to grab a snack and a drink and sit in the shade. Nice way to enjoy the outdoors and see some remarkable art.

Nice hour or so. Since the previous reviews mention the renovation, I will talk about what you can do. The garden is still open and very nice, with an attractive cafe for a snack or lunch. The flowers and fountains were attractive, and you can still see many famous Rodin works like The Thinker or the Burghers of Calais. However, The Kiss appears to be unavailable.This is a good museum for a quick visit if you have the museum pass. I'm not sure I would make this a destination for your day, or even pay the single entry fare.

Renovations will improve it further. Well worth a visit to get a grasp of he breadth of Rodin's astonishing artistic gift. The Hotel Biron, the 18th century residence in the museum grounds, is closed for renovations until late 2015. When this is complete it will make a better setting for the interior exhibition, presently in a temporary facility and reduced in scope. However, don't let this put you off. The most marvellous sculptures are dotted around the grounds. Set aside at least an hour for this; more if you can manage it.

Under construction till September 2015. We have happy memories of visiting the Rodin Museum in the past. During this visit, Hotel Biron was being renovated, but there is an exhibit in a nearby building on the Laboratory of Creation; visiting the garden (with Rodin sculptures) is included in the price of admission. You can also just tour the garden for 2E. I have to say, having seen Rodin’s works in Hotel Biron in the past, this exhibit was somewhat disappointing. I don’t begrudge the museum’s need to bring things up to date as far as security, etc., goes, but the exhibit on the Laboratory of Creation may be better suited to art historians and Rodin specialists.Four stars for the museum under construction, five stars for the museum when it's in the Hotel Biron.

Warning! Museum is under renovation!. The museum is undergoing what appears to be a major renovation. Rodin's home, which typically houses the majority of the sculptures in the collection, is not accessible. A temporary exhibit was set up in a different building, but it was mostly photos/placards - looking up info about Rodin online from my home in the US would have been more pleasant and just as informative. The whole point is to see the sculptures in the context of his home to understand how he lived and worked, so I don't understand why they didn't shut down entirely for the renovations.Even the gardens are filled with construction equipment. We were able to see The Thinker and The Gates of Hell, which are outside in the gardens, but there was a lot of construction equipment and noise. I was surprised that the museum was charging its full admission price. Had the tickets not been included in my Paris Museum Pass, I would have asked for a refund.

Under renovation now:. The inside museum is closed so only the large outside sculptures can be viewed. I was there years ago and was quite impressed but I would make sure that the museum is finished before making the trek. By the way, the museum opens at 10:00, not 9:30 as some tour books suggest.

Fascinating. It was fascinating to walk through the early part of the exhibit and learn about the sculptures that were not accepted and see the variations through time. I loved the garden and The Thinker of course!

June 2015 Parts Under Construction. We could only see parts of this as there was quite a bit of construction going on. Only a portion of the gardens are open and many of the buildings are partially closed. I can see how this would be a nice attraction when everything is open.
A must-see in Paris. We love this out-door museum, even though the house was closed for renovation this visit. The weather was pleasant. The sculptures are presented in a marvelous way.

Don't miss this beautiful museum. It is easy to get caught up in the Louvre and also Musee D'Orsay but this museum is in such a gorgeous setting that it needs to be high on the arts list when in Paris. Although there are some renovations going on at the moment you can still enjoy the magnificent works of Rodin. The rose garden was stunning and sitting eating an ice cream and looking at "The Thinker" was memorable. The crowds, compared to the other museums was very manageable and it made a lovely break in a busy sight seeing day. It is close to Les Invalides. Not to be missed.

Now I'm a fan!. This was a great break from walking inside and looking at paintings. Many of the statues were outside- and the gardens were lovely. I had no idea Rodin was such close friends with Victor Hugo- seeing so many statues that he had used Hugo as a model was really interesting- we really enjoyed some time outside. They were rehabbing part of the exterior while we were there- it will be even more lovely when completed.

Disappointing. The works of Rodin are beautiful and a must to see. There is no detracting from the genius of this artist, but we were very disappointed to find that the museum is being renovated. There was no warning of this when we purchased our tickets and entered and were shocked to discover that the museum we expected to visit was closed entirely and being subjected to major renovations. There was noisy drilling, the bustle of workmen, and large parts of the beautiful garden, a major attraction for a visit to this museum, were inaccessible. Some of Rodin's works were on display in a temporary museum, but the appeal and charm of the original display was lost. I would not advise a visit just yet.

FABULOUS Museum, But Under Renovation Until November 2016 - Go Anyway!. We had a lovely few hours at the Rodin Museum in Paris. It's in a gorgeous spot right near the Hotel Invalides. Gorgeous setting, great sculptures. The only problem right now is the museum is undergoing a major renovation until November 2015. Don't let that stop you though. There's a temporary exhibition and you can walk around the gardens with Rodin's most important works to keep you company!

Very nice. Of course you need to like Rodin, but why wouldn't you? The museum is in a nice location near the city center, in a nice area. So you can just have a walk along the Senna river, then continue in the antique trade area, always interesting until you reach the museum. It is a small museum compared to other museums you can find in Paris, but it is a bit of a jewel. It is worth going there when it is not raining as most of the exhibition is outside in a lovely garden. The rest of it is in a nice palace. You can wonder around and enjoy Rodin's work of art including of course the thinker, Balzac, the gate of hell... You name it.

Fantastic Museum and Sculpture Garden. One of the most enjoyable Paris museum to visit. The artwork of Rodin is breathtaking and the crowds compared to the other museums are much more sparse. Inside the house are smaller objects and lots of interesting information. Outside scattered around the grounds are the bigger sculptures including of course The Thinker and The Gates of Hell.

Loved the Rodin Museum and Garden!. My husband loves Rodin sculptures, so we went to the Rodin Museum. When we arrived, it was 5pm and they were closing at 5:45pm. 45 minutes was just enough time to see what we wanted to see; one hour would have been better. The museum was under renovation, but we still enjoyed seeing the beautiful garden and the sculptures of Rodin.Our Museum Pass included admission to the Rodin Museum.The first sculpture we went to see first was The Thinker, where my husband took many photos!Then, we walked through the garden to see The Burghers of Calais, The Gates of Hell, and the Three Shades.We also saw the Gallery of Marbles where was saw unfinished statues. There were statues of Victor Hugo, author of Les Miserables and The Hunchback of Notre-Dame.Even though it was for only 45 minutes, we enjoyed the Rodin Museum and would recommend other\s to visit.
Being renovated, open only gardens. The building is being renovated, can visit only the garden with a few sculptures of Roden, including famous Thinker

Rodin's Masterpieces. This is one of the most enjoyable museums to visit. Rodin's sculptors are beautiful and there are beautiful gardens to walk through with his works. It is a pretty easy museum to get through and something that will be appreciated.
Relaxing walk through amazing sculpture garden!. What a treat to see a collection of so many Rodin works. In addition the cafe, on the grounds, was a welcoming and delicious break.

parc hide in the museum. you will go through the different art done by Rodin, the best of it, is in summer as you get a beautiful parc where you will see some statu of the artist.perfect to go with your girl friend.

Interesting Sculpture. Musee Rodin has an excellent collection of sculptures within the home and out on the well maintained grounds. It's an easy to get to site and it's focus on french sculptures is a bit divergent from the other major museums in Paris. Worth a visit if you already have the museum pass or otherwise enjoy sculpture.

wonderful museum and park experience. a real surprise was this museum.. not only that I didn"t know how much I love the work of Auguste Rodin.. the set up there is beautiful. besides the museum there is a park which surrounds it and shows a lot of sculptures of this master of arts.. enjoy!

quiet beauty in the middle of Paris. I love Rodin's work. This is a beautiful display of many of his works in a gorgeous garden setting. There is a cafe on site and it was only 2 euro to visit the garden. If you are in the area you must stop in. It is under renovation (I visited in June 2015) but still the gardens are so pretty and the statues are all there. It was a nice place to visit after stopping at the more crowded venues.

Wonderful gardens and great sculptures. The museum houses a rich collection of Rodin's sculptures. Take a stroll in the beautiful gardens. You'll find some sculptures there, especially near the front of the house. Don't hesitate to go to the very end of the garden behind the house. On the way back, stop and admire the marble gallery.

Beautiful quiet park. The Musee Rodin is beautiful. The gardens are the backdrop for his sculptures, there are formal areas, as well as a more natural wooded area. The sculptures are large and overwhelming. You have a lovely sense of peace in the grounds, after the hustle and bustle of the city. The house is lovely, looking over the water feature. I didnt see the inside exhibitions. The lady at the selling the entry tickets was rude when we were there.

Beautiful Garden, Amazing Sculptures. When we visited this museum it was under renovation but it still did not take away from the experience. This was my favorite part of my trip to Paris. The garden is beautiful and the descriptions of the sculptures are written in French and English. The inside exhibition gave a great description of the process of Rodin. Loved my experience here!
Under renovations now..... There were only few sculptures to see because it's under renovation now. However, if you are looking for a short visit, this place can be glanced within 30 minutes.

A nice surprise. Our visit to Musee Rodin was a pleasant surprise to me. The sculptures were huge and powerful but the roses were so delicate and fragrant. Quite a contrast. I didn't realize there were gardens on the property but was thrilled to find them. Rodin's story was very interesting to me which is what brought me here. So glad we visited.

Less busy but no shortage of masterpiece s. I didn't plan to visit but we had free time and we're in the area, with our museum pass. Really enjoyed how close you could get to the various pieces. There were not so many people so we could take our time and enjoy on a winters afternoon.

Check before you go..... We only did the Gardens and were very disappointing that there were renovations underway and large tents being set up. The pond was totally neglected and covered in green algae. Roses are beautiful and it was nice to see "The Thinker" in such a pretty setting but it would offer better photography opportunities when all the work is over with.
A great art exhibition.. This museum is a very well displayed exhibition of brilliant art. Easy location to find and good value ! We are so luckey to see so many pieces by this brilliant artist.

Never forget The Thinker. My wife and I enjoyed the Musee Rodin, both inside and out. The building is beautiful, and the works of art are impressive. The grounds are stunning, making you forget that you are in the center of Paris. Seeing Rodin's "The Thinker" statue was memorable.

Chateau under rennovation. The grounds are quite pretty, and some of the sculptures are impressive. The famous "Thinker" is here, as is an impressive entry door with over 200 images entitled the "The Gates of Hell". However, during our visit, they were setting up for a large gathering, and so some of the gardens were closed. Others were partitioned due to renovation, and the chateau was closed and surrounded by fencing.

Relaxing Environment. Didn't go inside but definitely would next time. Had a walk around the outside grounds which are kept immaculate. A nice bit of calm and peace quite after the hustle and bustle of the Eiffel Tower.

A hidden gem!. if the sun is shining and you enjoy sculpture then this is a must see. Absolutely incredible, beautiful and peaceful and you walk away smiling at how amazing Rodin was. His works of art are truly captivating and magnificent.

The museum is closed for reno but the gardens are very good. There are many of the casts for Rodin's bronzes in the garden and it is a very peaceful pretty place. The explanations are well done and I felt like I learned a lot about Rodin and the time period. I expect the museum will be very good when it's finished.

A very relaxing museum with nice gardens.. The museum was under renovation so we could only visit the gardens and the exhibition hall. These areas contain many wonderful works including "The Kiss", "The Gates of Hell" and "The Thinker". The Garden is a lovely and relaxing place filled with roses. The small outdoor cafe sells pastries and beverages.

Wonderful artwork, bored, disinterested staff. Just before leaving Paris, we decided to have lunch here and take a look at Rodin's work, especially "The Thinker", which is located in the gardens surrounding the museum. Unfortunately, they were renovating the museum, so only the Garden's were open. The Gardens alone are worth the visit, so that was OK. We got in the queue for entry and were greeted by a very bored and surly clerk who clearly did not want to be where she was. Once past this bear, we enjoyed a lovely walk through the gardens. Most of Rodin's work is wonderful, but some of it is pretty black given his fixation with Dante's Hell and it's nine hideous rings. Even, so the dark bronzes were quite fascinating to see. Our lunch in the garden cafe was simply divine, and seemed to us what a Parisian lunch should be! We thoroughly enjoyed the experience here.

Usually a Five Star, But Building Is Being Renovated. The gardens and sculpture are always a beautiful, calm experience. I always enjoy the serenity of experiencing Rodin's sculpture in the lush gardens, with the lovely fountains. We were lucky enough to witness a small, intimate wedding in the romantic gardens. A fairy tale!The only downside was that the chateau was under construction. Therefore, we could not see Camille Claudel's sculptures -- She worked with Rodin, became his model and lover and eventually ended up in an asylum. She worked with Roding, sculpting the hands and feet for his pieces. The museum should be spectacular when it's finished. This is still worthy of your time and a visit.

Gardens are the highlight. The gardens at the Musee Rodin are a peaceful little respite from the city, and the sculptures are obviously a worth attraction for any Rodin fan. Unfortunately, the museum is going through renovations (June 2015) so we didn't get a chance to see it.

Terrible maintenance, very disappointing. Rodin is one of the greatest sculptures ever, so we though we're in for a real treat. However, it turned out the the sculptures outside are dirty - covered with dust and bird droppings. The gardens themselves are not properly maintained. The inside exhibition was closed because of renovation so they took a bunch of sculptures and tastelessly stack them together in a small building near then ticket office. IMO this museum shows disrespect to both the artists and the audience. You're really better off looking at pictures of Rodin's sculptures... at list you'll see them clearly and without bird droppings :S

Lovely break from museums. The Rodin Garden was a lovely break after the Louvre and the D'Orsey. It's primarily a sculpture garden with his famous pieces such as the Thinker and the Gates of Hell in a beautiful rose garden. It is very pleasant to walk through the gardens and look at the statues. There is a cafe in the garden as well and although I can't comment on it as we didn't eat there.
