Under reconstruction. The chateau is being renovated. The is a display in the entrance building and they have done a good job with the space telling about some famous projects of Rodin. Most of what is available is in the garden. The gradin is large and it is a nice break to be outside instead of in the building on a beautiful day. After several long stay big museums this shorter visit was a relief.

Insight into the working of an artist. The Rodin museum was worth visiting. There is the famous statue titled "Thinker" in the lawns. The rooms are filled with moulds and gives an insight into how the artist worked. He worked in marble and metal. Truly a collection worth seeing.

Under Construction -- check progress. Typically this is a 5 star attraction. The gardens and villa are spectacular. Our June 2015 visit was great, but very limited. The villa and some of the gardens are under renovation. In the end it will be great, but until then the visit is compromised. The museum is great, though, and has lowered admission for the limited tour. Many highlights are still on display, but you are not getting everything. My advice -- check with them before you go -- or at least know that things are disrupted, likely through late 2015.

Little slice of heaven. After a few trips to Paris, I discovered my new favorite spot for peace and serenity. Musee Rodin has a sense of calm, a retreat from the business of Paris. The gardens and grounds were so well kept. It was a great place to spend the afternoon for shade and rest.
Great Sculpturer. This museum was actually his house at one point. They are still renovating it so parts may not be open.

Don't miss this museum. The Louvre is something to see and shouldn't be missed, but Musee Rodin is also something that should not be missed. A sort walk from Napoleon's tomb, pay the 2E and walk the gardens. When we went, the museum building was being renovated and while you could pay the extra to get in, it was going to be limited versus when things are completed. We decided for the extra money, it wouldn't be worth it but the gardens are well worth the 2E. You can even see the Thinker in the gardens - you don't have to enter the building. Don't miss the Gates of Hell - unbelievable.

So much construction, there is little to see. I LOVE this museum, but between the construction and the rentals to other museums, NOTHING is here. Read a little about the museum and then pay to see the gardens only (2 Euro). There is nothing in the museum itself, and you'll wind up paying to see nicely arranged photographs. In the gardens, however, you can see the Gates of Hell and the Burghers of Calais. If you know what you are looking it, it's fine. It's a sin that they can still charge a full admission to a museum that is practically empty and non-accessible.

Construction. Because the museum was under construction, we only got to see the gardens. The gardens were beautiful, with sculptures scattered about but we sure wished to see the museum. We stopped in after visiting the Army Museum and Napoleon's Tomb. Honestly, I would wait until the construction is complete.

My favorite museum in Paris. I visited this museum in 1975 and 2007. It is my favorite. Small, intimate. Tells the interesting story of Rodin. Nice café at the back for lunch at the end of your visit. Beautiful gardens.

Still not finished. Since years it is a problem, that there is always some kind of work in and on the museum. Ridon sculptures you will find everywhere in the world in big museums. But such a ollection as here, nowhere. Even the garden is already a piece of an exhibition.

Essential Rodin. This small museum is an essential for those who admire Rodin. The museum is currently under renovation, so only part of the collection is available. The maps of the site are not great.
Interesting!. Do go to this place! Especially with Paris pass, it is actually worth the visit even if you are not that great a museum lover

Backpacking quickstop. Got in free and skipped the line (not much of a line for a Saturday at 4:00 pm though). If you like Rodin, a must see obviously, for me and my gal, it was just a stop included in our museum pass next to napoleons tomb and military museum. The thinker is obviously a well-known work and it was great to see. Didn't like the fact that there is reconstruction occurring now, and it makes any photo of outside and a lot of garden area obsolete.
Under construction. We went to see the museum, but only saw the gardens really. The hotel that houses some of the exhibits and art was being remodeled. So the experience was not up to par.

Under construction, but grounds were great. It was an ugly day, the museum was under construction so this is a bit biased for that reason. However the great sculptures were in the garden, and there was display of models and modifications and that was interesting. Wait until it re-opens.

No queue and very interesting. No queue at around 11am, an interesting presentation of the work of Rodin and a wonderful, uncrowded and serene park with Rodin bronzes among the flowers and garden beds. The old hotel which forms the core of the gardens is being renovated at present (due for completion later this year). This was a worthy addition to our list of places visited with the Museum Card - well worth a look.Only a short walk from here to Napoleon's Tomb and the Army museum.
A great artist!. Among the many museums in Paris, the Rodin's museum is a must if you like sculpure set up in a beautiful and peaceful envirnoment.
It was hot. Went to Rodin's garden and very hot but very nice exhibit. The flowers were perfect and the layout of gardens is nice also. It was worth the visit

Under Construction, but still worth seeing.. The gardens are beautiful. The Hotel is under some renovations, so nothing was on display in there.There was a display in the building you enter through. Very beautiful! Well worth going to. We walked from the Orsay. Not too far. Then we walked over to see Napoleon's Tomb.Great afternoon!

Under Renovation Sadly. Sadly, the museum was under renovation when we went a few weeks ago. The outside gardens were still available to see but I would've loved to see the interior. The gardens were pretty and "The Thinker" was available to see obviously. Walk farther into the garden and there's a cute little cafe, get some gelato and sit and people watch on a warm Saturday afternoon- definitely a cute little spot.

Under renovation. The main building is under renovation so only a limited number of works are on display including The Thinker and The Kiss. Some of the prototype casts, photos and clay models are on display now and are worth a visit. The sign says the renovations will be finished in September. I still enjoyed the visit, but be prepared to walk around workmen using jackhammers and other tools until the renovations are finished.

Beautiful Sculptures and Grounds. The Rodin museum is a small beautiful peaceful place with Rodin's home and garden. The garden is filled with bronze statues and has places to sit and relax and well as a café where you can get lunch and a drink. The facilities are very clean and well kept and the gift shop has some nice gifts some of which are made in France I was happy to see. The museum is very close to Napoleon's tomb and the army museum which makes it a convenient additional place to visit. They are doing some renovations on the home of Rodin at this time and so you cannot visit the home, however, still worth the visit.

Gardens are a good value. It is much cheaper to visit just the gardens and on a nice day in Paris, well worth it. The most famous of Rodin's works, The Thinker is there, as well as many other remarkable pieces. If you have the museum pass, or can't fathom missing the indoors, by all means, go, but if you are short on time, the gardens can be enjoyed in a solid hour.

Great art in an enchanting setting. Such a delightful way to display great art! The gardens are beautiful and inviting, and the indoor/outdoor cafe is just a bonus.The main exhibits were not accessible when we visited but that did not detract from our experience. Looking forward to returning someday.

Under remodeling/construction. The gardens are open to public and only a limited wing of the Rodin is open when we were there 2 days ago. I don't know how long construction will be. But the garden is beautiful and worth the trip if you use your museum pass. I don't think the full price ticket is worth it since most of the indoor museum is under remodeling.

This is a place to Think(er). All of us know Rodin's The Thinker. We have seen copies . We have seen photos. But here we see the real think in all it massive glory sitting the beautiful gardens.Walking around the garden we see many of Rodin's sculptures and are overwhelmed by The Gates of Hell.Inside the house among others is The Kiss. This is an incredible piece that is most sensual.The gardens are impressive particularly as they are situated in the city. The house and the gardens were given to Rodin by his lover. Nice gift.

Tribute to France's most famous sculptor. The Rodin Museum is located in an eighteenth century mansion where the artist once lived and worked, tucked behind a walled garden away from the hubbub of the city. The building is located next to the Invalides.This wonderful museum hosts many special programs, lectures, and classes, including events for young children to better help them understand what they are viewing on their tour. Check the museum's website for a schedule of events.Metro : Varenne ( line 13 ) or Invalides ( line 13, line 8 ) Open daily, except MondaysMusée, garden and shop : open from 10am to 5.45pm
Very nice museum and garden. Very nice museum and garden. The Thinker, The Kiss, The Gates of Hell and much, much more. The sculptor's work shop was very interesting also. Last visited May 1998

Lovely gardens. Unfortunately during our visit the main museum was closed, but the surrounding gardens were still open.Truly beautiful gardens, a great place to take a stroll through or eat a picnic.The Thinker, The Three Shades, and The Gates of Hell, were still on display in the gardens and were what we most wanted to see. The Gates of Hell have so much detail, and I could spend some time looking into each part.Worth a visit even if the main museum will not be open until November.

A quiet place in the centre of Paris. I am not the biggest admirer of Rodin but the museum is very nice. The museum is located in the beautiful little park where the sculptures are exhibited. Very nice place for those who like Rodin's work. You can see all of the famous sculptures of the author without a hurry. In addition there is a little coffee-restaurant with some tasty meals if you are tired or just want to stop and rest for a while. Very pleasant combination of art and relaxing place. I recommend it!

A Perennial Favorite, Under Renovation. When we visited, the museum was under extensive renovation and the permanent indoor collection was not available, but the garden was beautiful and a new temporary display outdoors told the story of the building's history and rodin's involvement, both in English and French.Check the website before you go - I don't recall when the work will be completed.

My favorite museum in Paris. My favorite museum in Paris because it is understated and simply beautiful. Rodin had a way of sculpturing that was very melancholic and sincere. The gates of hell are absolutely fascinating, if you walk around the garden you will see miniature replica us in the gate of larger statues that are in the garden. One of the main reasons I always go to my dad is I love Victor Hugo and were dancing to be fascinated by Hugo as there are many sculptures of him. We were there in May 2015 and then main museum is closed however all the grounds are accessible for two euros a great deal ,for a little while anyways .

Excellent place to visit with kids. My 20 month old daughter loved the gardens. There is lots of room for running around and two sandpits. It's 2€ for entry to the gardens or free if you have a child! An excellent outing!

Understated and Artistic. Quietly located in a plush garden, the Rodin museum is dedicated to just to work of one artist - a nice change from the thousands and thousands of varied work in the Louvre for example. His sculptures are vivid and fluid, and the garden is relaxing. You can see the whole exhibit in 25 minutes, or spend an hour by fountain and take it all in. Note: it's very close to the Armory and Napoleon's Tomb, so try and do it all together. Gift shop's a little expensive. Overall a must if you have the Paris Pass.

Under renovation. The museum was being renovated and consequently I did not get to fully appreciate all it had. I was pleased that I could see some of Rodin't work, but look forward to returning and really enjoying this extraordinary building.

Beautiful pieces in the garden. This museum has an inside and an outside exhibit which were both stunning. All of the pieces were made by Rodin (obviously) and they were all placed among the grounds as if it were an adventure to see the next piece. The gardens themselves were very beautiful as well and it was nice that it was in a quieter spot in town- but still very accessible. If you have the time I would definitely stop by there for an hour or so.
Awe Inspiring. Just WOW! They were working in the gardens, but still plenty to see! Very nice, take your time and enjoy!

RODIN SCULPTURES - NEED TO SEE. The famous Thinker and The Kiss are well-known and should be viewed along with several others. The Kiss is located inside the house and the Thinker is in the garden center. No crowds and takes lerss than an hour. Included in the Museum Pass....otherwise 9 euro for admission.
Tranquil surprise. I was expecting to be impressed with the sculpture, but the gardens were beautiful and so relaxing. Incredible cafe too!
its ok no great shakes. If around worth walking around the property and checking out. Contained in a house and not that large. An easy hour trip.

Renovation! . The bad part is that the main building is in renovation, so you only have access to the garden sculptures and just a creation atelier in the inside. Even so we did not see much, is worth the visit. The gardens are beautiful and the sculptures there the same.
Closed for renos. The main building is closed for renovations however there are excellent sculptures in the gardens and a charming cafe. All his famous works are there well worth it.

Beautiful views and gardens!. The museum was being renovated so we just paid 2 euros each to visit the Rodin Gardens. First of all, they are beautifully landscaped with gorgeous flowers, fountains, and benches. The sculptures are spaced far enough apart that you don't have people crowded around you to see the sculptures, read the descriptions, or take pictures. You can see the Eiffel Tower and Les Invalides from the gardens so it's great to be able to include that in your photos. It's a beautiful, tranquil space in which to enjoy a nice spring day.

Under Construction. This is a jewel of a museum, when everything is open. When we were there, the museum was under construction so had only one small interior room and the grounds for sculptures. Would like to go back when the museum is fully renovated.
May 2015. even though the house is currently closed for renovations, the grounds and the museum building are fabulous!

An oasis in Paris. Gardens contain several of Rodin's statues so if all you want is quiet reflection there's no need to pay extra to visit the house (museum).For us the attraction was to visit a museum that was not spoiled by endless queues and crowds of people. There is a cafe in the gardens serving food of a high standard.If you're in the area of Les Invalides this is worth a visit to rest and reflect for an hour or two.
Great museum. I love the works of Rodin and the sculptures in the garden are a special treat. The museum and gardens are not large so you can easily fit it into a day of other activities.

Worth a visit even if you're not a Rodin fan............. Only in Paris for a day, so maybe having the museum closed for restoration was a blessing. The gardens looked amazing with shaped yew trees and masses of roses in full bloom. What a wonderful setting for some incredible sculptures. The temporary display was very interesting but still didn't really explain how these masterpieces were made.

Pleasant gardens, main building under renovation. Even though the main gallery is presently closed for renovation the gardens with many Rodin works nicely displayed are worth a visit especially for the princely sum of €2.

A must see. The Thinker sits in the garden.The house contains elements of the life and history of Rodin the sculpture. Tours are in English and French. It is interesting and educational. As well, the museum sits in the middle of Paris, is so easy to get to and something not to miss.

If your a Rodin fan, don't miss it. Otherwise.... Gained access to Musee Rodin via our Paris Pass (museum entrance and free metro), so we didn't have to pay and skipped the queue for tickets. The gardens outside are beautiful, and are a great setting for the sculptures. Museum inside was small but a few interesting bits and pieces. As others have said, there's ongoing construction so check before to see whats accessible and what's off limits. Wasnt too bad for us, but could definitly ruin your visit if Theyve shut down half the site. If your a Rodin fan, or a lover of sculpture, then definitely don't miss it. If your only going because youve heard of the thinker, it may not be worth your money. Consider getting the Paris Pass, or maybe spend your precious holiday time elsewhere.
Under Restoration in 2015. This is a great place - been here before. But, it is under restoration now and not worth the effort - such a disappointment.

A gem in the city. This museeum is a beautiful spot with a lot of beautiful work from Rodin. When we visited the building was closed due to improvements, but the garden is still worth the entrance. It's a wonderful garden and it can obviously be hired, at least for major sponsors, to have celebrations of different kinds. This day it was preparations going on for something later on.Take a chance to visit i and see the Thinker !

Great sculptor, beautiful grounds to walk around in.. Rodin is a truly great sculptor and the setting and grounds around the collection are quite beautiful to walk around in or just sit and take it all in. I would highly recommend a visit to the Musee Rodin.

Tied for best small museum. During a 10-day trip to Paris we focused more on small museums than the large ones. Rodin was my favorite. (In fairness, my wife's favorite was the Musee de Picasso, although she agreed that the Rodin was excellent.) Of course the sculpture was wonderful, but I found the rose gardens, while not as large as Portland's, were an equally beautiful part of the experience. It didn't hurt that we were there on a warm day with blue skies - rainy weather might have made this a different experience as so much of the museum is outdoors in a beautiful park setting.

Would have been great but a large part is closed for renovation.. This would have been one of the best places we visited, except that one of the two buildings is closed for renovation. The garden is really nice and there are several sculptures on display there. Like any other attraction in the center of the city, it gets really crowded. One odd thing: it's the only museum I've ever visited in which the gift shop closes half an hour before the museum closes. It was really disappointing not to be able to buy a picture book on the way out. Would gladly go again next time we are in Paris. By then the Hotel Biron, where Rodin had an apartment should be finished.

Not your typical museum. This home is where Rodin used to live and gives you a sense of the scope of this artist. His genius, relationships and uniqueness really comes through at his home/museum. truly enjoyable with all of the works you would ever want to see of his.

A Tranquil Garden Filled With Impressionist Sculpture. I'm not sure if Rodin's work has ever been classified as impressionist sculpture but that is what his pieces evoked when we visited the outdoor gardens. Although the indoor portion of the museum was closed for renovation (as of May 2015), the outdoor art was worth the ticket price.

If you like sculpture, this is a do not miss!. This is one of my favorite museums in Paris, Devoted to Rodin's sculptures, with smaller exhibitions that rotate, the museum is small, elegant and presents his work in an exceptionally beautiful setting---much of it outdoors in various gardens. In particular, the "Thinker" is a work to behold.

Small Musee Rodin had lovely gardens. Most of the museum is dedicated to showing the way Rodin worked and how is works were often rejected by officials because of their rich emotionality and interpretation. The museum features sketches, preliminary works in plaster, with many of the bronze works outside in the garden. The inside museum is quite narrow and small and very popular.The museum is housed next door to the building in which Rodin lived and worked (he purchased it and donated it as a museum) which is currently undergoing reconstruction.The gift shop is lovely and has gifts featuring Rodin works and other artists.The outer gardens offer a lovely stroll, pretty plants, and a natural setting with birds and benches and Rodin sculptures including one in a pond and The Thinker.

Oasis in Paris. The Museum was closed for renovation when we visited, & the day was marred by intermittent showers. But the sculpture garden alone was well worth the visit. It had been recommended as a perfect place for a picnic lunch after a visit to a deli or market for supplies. Beautiful tall trees would provide welcome shade on a sunny day. Will definitely keep it in mind for a relaxing break on a return trip.
Statues!. This was the best museum that we visited. The museum is under renovation right now, but most of the important statues are out in the garden anyway. A great way to spend a morning in Paris.

Worth a Visit. During my visit the historic buildings were undergoing renovation and not open to tour, but being able to walk through the beautiful grounds was worth the trip. The cafe in the garden is worth a stop for a beverage or a meal. I would visit again if I get back to Paris.

Inept queuing / ticketing spoit the visit. We arrived to find a long queue snaking out from the museum and done the road. We only wanted to get access to the garden and not the house itself - but it is one queue for all. The queue moved incredibly slowly and would stop regularly as a large organised tour group got priority. When we did get in we found they only had one ticket till operating! They actually had 3 staff in the ticket area - but obviously not in their job description to open another till. You buy your ticket and then you have to hand it another person sitting a meter away who "checks it" and takes it off you. Totally inept process! For the place with the famous "Thinker" sculpture, this museum should seriously think about how to improve their ticketing arrangement! They need to beautiful sculpture gardens to de-stress from your arrival.

Let Me Think.... The inside main museum wasn't open, but the gardens where you can see The Thinker are full wonderful of sculpture. Grab a ham & cheese (jambone & fromage) sandwich and make a picnic out of it!
Go to the Gardens. Bypass the inside part completely- it wasn't as amazing as the gardens- which is where the Thinker is. We went just as all the roses were in bloom and it was beautiful.
Small museum . This is a very small museum with a nice garden that has a few sculptures of Rodin's work and there's an exhibition as well. It's a small nice place in general, but nothing impressive.

Stroll around the garden. We don't have an art background, however we really enjoyed the beautiful gardens at the Musee Rodin. Many of Rodin's sculptures are placed throughout the garden, it was a lovely way to spend a couple of hours in the afternoon. Even though the garden had many visitors, it is large enough not to feel crowded. We recommend visiting on a sunny afternoon.
Amazing . Incredible works of art including Rodin's famous Thinker sculpture. The gardens here are also beautiful on their own. The crowds are very light here as well.
Best €1 I ever spent.. The museum building was closed when I went, but I still had an amazing time! Very cheap as well. Highly recommended!

beautiful statues and beautiful park. This is a very beautiful museum. It can be a little long to wait on line and buy your ticket. Once inside, the exhibitions are very nice. Rodin's statues can be beautiful. The park is very nice too, with its statues among the alleys.

Visit the gardens. Amazing works of art, loved the smaller sculptures and paintings inside the museum. The gardens are where the very best sculptures are kept, which are large and totally stunning. Lovely gift shop, too.

Rodin was a gifted artist that captures the spirit of man and the French culture. The Rodin museum is worth the visit. He was a gifted artist and the museum's garden alone is worth the admission. Keep in mind that as of May 2015, most of the museum is still under restoration but it was still worth the visit.If you can visit Rodin's house in Verdun (take the metro to the end of the line - you can find directions in the brochure at the museum) to see where he lived. Also, if you are a fan of Midnight in Paris (Woody Allen), its a treat to see where he filmed some great scenes. Both sites are included in the Museum Pass. A wise investment.

Musee Rodin Delights the senses. The Musee Rodin is a treasure worth visiting. The sculpture garden is a peaceful respite from the bustling city. There are many major works displayed throughout and the museum building is Rodin's former residence. Arrange your visit to coincide with the one night a week they stay open past sunset. The ambiance is magical.
Check about construction. The museum is currently undergoing some major maintenance. We still enjoyed but the main museum is closed
Great walk in the garden. Even though there are renovations in progress, you can still see the master works and an exhibit of how he created his pieces.

Rodin being renovated. This is a simple and enjoyable outing to see the great works of Rodin. Its gardens and sculptures are beautiful and it is very peaceful considering it is located in the centre of Paris. The house of Rodin is currently being renovated so the scaffolding detracts from the beauty of the house. There was an another construction being erected with plastic tents etc and this also impeded the overall view of the house and some scultures. I appreciate that renovation is an ongoing necessity so it was not a big problem. Just forewarning visitors.

Sculpture in the gardens. Wonderful Rodin sculpture amongst the trees. The museum is currently under renovation so there is a temporary exhibition set up as well as the pieces in the gardens. It is a lovely informal museum where one can get up close and study Rodin's mastery at one's leisure.
totally worth a visit. The museum is really interesting – but the garden alone is worth the price of admission: fabulous place to contemplate life.

Go to see The Thinker. Brilliant!! We were disappointed to find the museum closed but were able to walk in the gardens. Perfectly manicured lawns, trees and pretty flowers. And everywhere we looked there were fantastic sculptures. The Thinker was so beautiful, he alone was worth the visit. Great gift shop too.
a lovely museum and gardens. Do yourself a favor and go. You can walk around the lovely gardens to see the sculpture. A very nice museum.

Roses & Rodin. Lovely setting for Rodin's figures. Garden areas very peaceful. The roses were incredibly beautiful.
House (museum) not open due to renovations but rest was definitely worth seeing.
CLOSED until November 2015. CLOSED until November 2015 due to renovations. It looks beautiful otherwise, wished it was open. Don't include this on your trip of to do things until November.
Not so great, but is Rodin. The museum has not so much sculpture, but is rodin. Nice gardens by walk. Go early because, after mid day, starts the school tours.

Relaxed spot and beatiful garden. Musee Rodin, with its wonderful Rodin sculptures is a truly beatiful experience in Paris. Unfortunately the inside museum was closed for renevetion when we visited, but on a sunny warm day, that didn't matter. A ticket in costs only £2, and there are plenty of Rodins magnificent sculptures places round the park. The park is really nice and relaxed. Perfect spot to just wander around, sit and relax on the benches, or have a snack at the restaurant.

Peaceful respite from busy city. Take time out here and chill down. It's a delightful small museum and lovely to relax in the garden. Quick coffee or lunch available in the grounds. And that's apart from admiring the beauty of seeing Rodin's sculptures in perfect settings.
Serious Paintings. A nicer place than the Louvre to visit and viewNice gardens surround, river is close by and you can just relax and enjoy. The air-conditioning is also good.

Beautiful gem of a museum. A beautiful oasis- museum and garden- with some of Rodin's most famous and iconic pieces. The gardens are simply stunning. Definitely worth a visit if you have an hour or two!

Beautiful Pieces. I visited this museum on a lovely sun filled day and it was lovely. The building is currently under restoration but the green space was lovely. To see Rodin's famous pieces the Gates of Hell and his final resting place with the Thinker was worth the time spent.

An unexpected pleasure. I wasn't sure if I was interested enough to visit here, but am so glad that i did. The works both around the grounds and within the building are just fantastic.there is also a lovely cafe in the gardens
Unfortunately under renovation till September. Means you don't get to see inside, so miss The Kiss and other things, but the gardens are lovely and there's quite a bit there still to see.
Great. Life of Rodin is well documented. I am an art lover and of course loved this!!! The gallery is very impressive and the location is the best
Wonderful!. This was one of my favorite stops in Paris. The sculptures are really amazing and the gardens are beautiful. I would really recommend the Musee Rodin on your next trip to Paris!

My visit to the Rodin Museum in Meudon France. El museo Rodin - Meudon La villa des Brillants Built on the heights of Meudon, the Villa des Brillants is a modest-looking, Louis XIII-style house in brick and stone, which Auguste Rodin purchased at an auction sale on 19 December 1895.Just Beauty and History
Not wonderful. I expected more. The construction underway was a significant distraction. The. Garden was nicely maintained.

Rodin at his best. It is one of my favorite museums in Paris. As a fan of Rodin, I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. My husband though is not a fan of Rodin, he also enjoyed the visit very much. Through Rodin’s collection of paintings and sculptures of other artists, and his own sketches and drawings, one can understand more about the work of this genius. His work alone is very much worth visiting whereas the garden is truly an extra bonus. The layout of this little charming garden is very well thought out. Together with the beautiful flowers as the background, the big outdoor sculptures help surpass the art appreciation experience.

Quiet solitude in the middle of the city. This is my favorite place to visit in Paris. One of the first sculptures seen in the garden is The Thinker. The view of The Thinker with the Eiffel Tower in the background is incredible. The little cafe is a great place to sit and have a coffee or lunch. Some renovaation is going on but it does nothing to detract a visitor from the splendor of this magnificent museum.

Beautiful setting for the work of a great artist.. The home of the sculptor is a treat to visit, and the works are exhibited appropriately in adequate spaces that allow one time for contemplation of these masterpieces. The Claudet Claudel sculptures are also beautifully exhibited, although it makes one sad to know of her sad fate.
World level. One of the most beautiful museums in the world. It's collection is outstanding. The building is a work of art, and so is the beautiful garden.

Currently under refurbishment. We were disappointed upon arrival to find out the museum was closed for refurbishment with access to a smaller area and the gardens. The gardens were beautiful with many sculptures. Much to our pleasure we did see The Thinker and The Kiss.

Beautiful garden stroll. Rodin's sculptures are beautifully displayed in a peaceful garden setting. The indoor exhibit provides additional insight into the artist and his work. Another museum pass must see.

Under construction. The main part of the museum was not available during our visit. The gardins are nice and have several famous sculptures - but the lack of access to the majority of the collection detracts from the experience. If your time is limited would wait go when it is fully open.

Garden setting.. Another fantastic museum in a beautiful part of Paris.Much of the work is displayed outdoors in the museum garden.The life and work of Rodin is also well recorded and explained in some detail throughout the museum.

Even if your not into sculpture.... This museum would be a good place to go for a change of pace. the gardens are really nice and the sculptures impressive. The house is different in that it give you a look into the process that Rodin went through.

peaceful and magical. This gem was told to me from a fellow traveler before me. I am an art lover and found the set up of the grounds, artwork, and mood magical. It was not overly crowded when I was there. The grounds were well maintained, and placement of artwork inside was inviting. If you are a fan of artwork and in the city, I would suggest not missing if you are in Paris!
Beautiful pieces in a nice home+garden. Set in a nice and quiet garden is a collection of this master. Nothing to add, as there is no need to describe a genius.

Garden Under Construction. I was looking forward to seeing this site but was not aware it was currently under construction. We stopped by towards the end of the day so we were only able to walk the gardens, but that was the main area i wanted to check out. The garden is kept up beautifully and i love the roses around the Thinker Statue. I thought this garden would have more too it statue/art wise, but I don't know if some of hidden by the construction going on. Luckily we had the museum pass, so i don't feel like we wasted money. Gotta go back in the future to actually see all of garden in its glory. I suggest finding a bench and just admiring the scene around you.

Lovely park with famous masterpieces. This is a great museum, less crowded and half of it is outdoors. The statues are exposed in the garden of the museum. The Rodin is being renovated at the moment so part of the park and the house are closed.
Rodin museum. The building not accessible due to ongoing renovation, but garden and annex with selected works makes it worth the visit.
Lovely grounds. The Rodin Museum ws under renovation but we were able to go into the garden where there are many sculptures and places to sit and enjoy them.
Vacation 2015. Rodin's sculptures are so lifelike. Interesting as well the history of the building. The park setting and the displaying of his works are wonderful.

See French life through the gifted eyes and hands of sculptor Auguste Rodin. Though the museum is under renovation until late 2015 (only reason for 4 instead of 5 stars), a visit is still a must for all who appreciate fine art and especially sculpture. You will see several famous Rodin statues in the garden, where you can also enjoy a nice lunch outdoors or inside. The small temporary indoor exhibit space features a number of interesting exhibits. The rates are discounted while the renovations are ongoing. Combine a visit here with the Army Museum/Napoleon's Tomb across the street.

Beautiful gardens well worth a visit. Although smaller than most in Paris, we found the Rodin museum a real joy. Strolling thru the gardens was amazing. If you get a museum pass you can catch this before walking to the museum d Orsay.

Unforgettable.. I have seen Rodin sculptures in many European museums, but in Paris, where he lived and worked- the biggest impression. Most impressive- "Les bourgeois de Calais", :" La belle Heaulmiere", "L'age d'airain".
rodin amaze. a really lovely gallery very well considered and the history of Rodin is there to be explored, although the main house was being restored the temporary exhibition did not disappoint
Still Under Construction. Only a small portion of the museum is available. But what is available, is wonderful. The gardens are beautiful and the setting spectacular.

Rodins little piece of paradise. Rodin was a prolific sculptor and his house and garden in the middle of Paris provide the perfect backdrop to his works. Some of you may remember the Thinker from the movie "Midnight in Paris" and you will find this here in his garden. Walk beyond the house and there is an amazing garden that has sections within it that you can rest your feet, run around or just savour the tranquil environment. The café there is fantastic and has delights like violet icecream, pastries and crème brulee with coffee that was the best I had in Paris (not fond of French coffee!). This musee if often overlooked but I think it is superb.

Fantastic Sculptures. This is mostly an outdoor sculpture garden. As luck would have it we visited the 1st Sunday in May when all the museums are free (except Les Invalides--Napoleon's tomb). While it was cold and drizzling rain off and on, it was worth the time to see the work of the master sculptor Many of the sculptures are from his "Dante's Gate of Hell."

Under construction. Difficult to review as most of the museum is still closed for renovation works. The temporary exhibition shows some of the plaster casts of famous works but I would have liked to see more about the creation of these works (an exhibition with the title "Rodin, le laboratoire de la création"!). The gardens are beautiful, here you can see casts of nearly all of the most famous sculptures Rodin has made and just spend some time walking around.
small, which i love. this is an awesome small museum. i have been a few times and it is never too crowded. the grounds are beautiful and you get a great feel for the artist and the period he lived

Not worth going during renovation. Not worth going while the museum is undergoing renovations and only a temporary exhibition is open. The garden is nice but it was raining while we visited. There is a nice cafe in the garden with tasty not too expensive food.

Good to see and understand what went into the "manufacturing" of the Thinker statue.. Gorgeous home and gardens of Rodin. The Thinker is right outside the back door. The grounds were definitely beautiful as is the home. The "house" was under construction when we went, but you can truly admire the beauty of it. If you're already at the Rodin Museum, you might want to pop over to Napoleon's tomb which is just around the corner. We didn't visit there, but it looks impressive from the outside with the big gold dome.

Perfect change of pace. After a busy morning walking around Paris we came to have a look at the gardens and some lunch. The choice was limited but I still thoroughly enjoyed sitting in the gardens having the chicken and couscous from the lunch menu. A quiet stroll aftwerards to soak up the sculptures. Lovely.

A garden of Serenity. The museum is closed for renovations until November but the gardens were open and that was the best part for me. It was at the end of a busy day of sight seeing and the gardens were quiet and peaceful in the midst of this busy city. The statues were placed around the spacious gardens and under the trees. It was just a lovely place. I look forward to seeing the inside of the museum someday

under renovation. This was a beautiful museum to visit after long lines at the other museums. The gorgeous walk in the gardens with the sculptures all places throughout the garden was very peaceful. The inside of the building is under renovation, putting "The Kiss" in a corner! I had to ask the museum shop cashier where it was!

Interesting and peaceful oasis in Paris centre. When we visited Paris a couple of years ago, we found it a wonderful way to pass a morning or afternoon - an ideal place if you want to stop rushing from one tourist attraction to another and recover your energy . Here you have important sculptures in an interesting house, set in interesting gardens. You can slacken your pace a little here.You need pay very little to go only into the gardens, and just sit if you want to. There was a very nice restaurant in there, reasonable cost, with a good lunchtime menu.

Beautiful gardens, squashed exhibit.. The gardens here were wonderful, it's just such a shame that while the renovations are going on, the Rodin statues have been stuffed into a small area. The statues are wonderful, but its clear they're not in situ yet.

It seems like the main building has been closed for years. When we last visited, the the main building was closed for renovations. Now, four years later, it is still under renovation! However, the garden and the statues contained there are worth the visit. Since our last visit, a small gallery has been opened and contains copies of a few of Rodin's best known works.

It was okay. The scenery was beautiful and I was really privileged to see "The Thinker". However, there were renovations being made at the time so, other than the garden and the lovely sculptures, there really wasn't much to see when I went.

Main exhibit closed until September 2015. We were so disappointed to learn that the main exhibit is closed until later this year. The gardens were open to visitors, but it was pouring rain and blowing wind the day we were there so we decided to give it a pass.

The relaxing spot in Paris. Most of the sculptures are in beautiful garden. You can not only enjoy the walk between flowers and bushes you can sit and relax contemplating the beautiful sculptures. At the moment the Hotel Biron is in process of renovation and closed to the public.

Peaceful gardens. For only 1 EURO (if you are under 26) you can escape the crazy tourist traps and wonder around the gardens exploring and enjoying the beautiful sculptures. It's a lovely way to spend an afternoon

Nice little museum of the sculptors work. Definetly worth the vist to see the artist most famous sculptors- the Thinker, the Kiss, Hell's Gate. The grounds are also pretty and you can do it in about an hour.
Under construction. Very interesting, but largely under construction. The gardens are open and most of the art work is on display, but the atmosphere is sadly lacking in it's current condition.
Nice sculptures. Beautiful sculptures, uncrowded museum. The setting is beautiful as well. There is a nice cafe inside.

Pretty but under construction. The main building was under construction during our visit, but the gardens and extra exhibits (open with a general ticket during construction) allowed us to appreciate the process of Rodin's work. Pretty gardens with interesting work tucked in throughout. Absolutely worth a visit on a sunny day.

Return Visit. Absolutely adored this museum. The way they show off Rodin's work is fantastic. The pieces set in the garden just makes the whole thing more real in that you can get very close to the sculptures and look at the detail. Will always visit whenever I go to Paris.
Small but beautiful. Strolling through that garden is so peaceful and relaxing, it's the perfect break to a busy touristy day in Paris.
I love Rodin. Propably one of the best places you can go to explore art. I payed 2 euros to see the park with the statues made by Rodin. He is a genious.

A lovely setting for Rodin's sculptures. Absolutely loved Musee Rodin, the gardens are a beautiful backdrop to Rodin's sculptures and a lovely way to spend the afternoon.This offers a nice contrast to other galleries. A pity there is maintenance work being done but it has to be done at some point and it is all self funded rather impressively.The exhibition gives further understanding to the development of the work - the photos are a great asset and for once going to a artist's museum that really has some of their most prestigious work as part of the collection was nice.A small cafe to grab a coffee in the garden if you fancy it and a small shop are present yet are tasteful

beautiful. the best museum in Paris..very small and manageable, lots of outdoor works in the garden, beautiful house, if you don't have time for much cultural activity do this, amazing and very central and very small, Rodin's works are so intricate, so beautiful....
Superb but was helped by the weather. On a sunny May day this museum, which is mostly sculpture gardens, was a perfect place to be. Nice bistro next door. Friendly staff.

Would probably be nice if it was sunny and no construction happening. The gardens and sculptures look like they would ordinarily be beautiful. However, it was raining (which isn't the museums fault) and a large portion was railed off for maintenance/renovation. No discount on the price even though I am fairly sure we missed a very large portion of the exhibit. I did enjoy the part I saw.

Who doesnt want to see the thinker!. Great sculptures held in a garden that is so beautiful and peaceful. You don't need hours to spend here. They were renovating when we were there but you could still see the thinker.
Peaceful gardens. And interesting sculptures. Don't miss this museum off the tourist trail. It's Walking distance to nepoleans tomb.

Respite after a day in the city. Really loved this museum as it is Rodin's sculptures scattered amongst the gardens. Had a lovely coffee and baguette in the cafe and chilled out amongst the spring flowers and sculptures

Second visit and now quite commercial. We visited here 3 years ago and loved it being unspoilt. This has changed with it becoming a real tourist spot and the main house under repair. The Thinker is still my favourite

Fabulous Rodin Sculptures. A short metro-ride from the Ile de la Cite, but worth the trip. The mansion which is the main indoor part was under renovation so we saw some items in a former chapel. But the main feature is the garden (says feel free to walk on the grass and picnic!) where major Rodin works (Balzak; the Thinker; Dumas; the Burgers) are displayed in a beautiful park setting. So it's art-worthy, but also a lovely, quiet rest from a go-go-go tour of Paris.

Lovely collection. I have seen a number of these statues in other locations, but I loved the layout and number of sculptures in the garden. The garden is laid out in such a fashion that the sculptures can be seen on their own, without the feeling that it is cluttered or busy. Rodin often sculpted his subjects nude before clothing them, and there is one pair where one can compare the two against each other. There is an inside exhibit that enhances the sculptures. Unfortunately the house was closed - so we will have to return!
Enjoyable garden. Only visited the gardens as museum under renovation. Smaller than anticipated, but lovely and calm, seats to sit and ponder, and of course, The Thinker is there

Great museum but the main house is under repair. Visited on the first Sunday of the month so it was free. The main house is under repair for several more months so right now there is a temporary exhibit set up. It was raining quite hard so we did not get to enjoy the gardens as much as we would have liked but it was a very informative and interesting exhibit and the sculptures were incredible, especially in the gardens.

Wandering the Garden. The actual museum was closed inside to update and repair the building. So the only option was the garden with an excellent cafe. The garden is laid out with Bronze Rodin statues including the thinker this was a delight. We will return when all is completed.

Garden w Sculptures. Nice last minute add. When we went construction had most of the inside closed. Gardens with the sculptures were worth seeing.
On Museum Pass.
Rodin visit. museum was in dis array... and still was outstanding...gardens are meant to sit and ponder...sunday am with the newspaper far away from the maddening crowd

Out and About in Paris. I missed this Museum on the first three times I was in Paris. It was a rainy day and a perfect time to visit. The gallery was under renovations so we basically visited only the gardens where most of the sculptures are. There is a lovely cafeteria in the garden with very reasonable rates and lovely sandwiches, salads and baked goods. We sat outside while the rain had stopped and enjoyed the beautiful setting. Seeing the larger than life sculptures in the garden and learning more about Rodin's life and philosophy was very interesting. He sculpted many tributes to the 100 year war between England and France. There's more to this museum than just seeing "the thinker".

Probably not worthwhile until the renovation is finished. The garden is nice, but the temporary exhibition is pretty boring and the main museum is closed. Since this place is a long way from anywhere else you might want to go (Napoleon's tomb is nearby but boring, the Musee d'Orsay is further away than it looks) I don't think it's worth coming here unless you're a huge Rodin fan.

memorable. so much beauty here it is a pity that every single tourist has to strike up a ridiculous pose in front of the Thinker. If you are tempted to pose in front of the famous statue, just don't be silly unless you are a kid

Serenity. A gem of a museum set in the trees and shrubbery around the old house. Quiet and peaceful. The café serves really good meals which are fresh and tasty, with a glass of wine. Take some time to take a relaxing view of the exhibits or just sit and chill out.

I thought about it- I went.. Well worth a visit. You'll learn a lot about Rodin and see sculptures by many artists. The gardens are nice as well. No point in filing this out, check it on line if you need to but going is doing and seeing is believing.

Lovely garden and sculptures. We opted to only visit the gardens as the museum was closed and we didn't wish to visit the temporary exhibit. The garden price is only 2 euro and well worth it. The garden itself was beautiful and the sculptures too. There are little plaques at each sculpture to give a short explanation of each and make sure you pick up a map so you know where things are located. It's not a large area, so you won't get lost, but just in case you are looking for a specific sculpture, such as The Thinker. There is a cafe in the garden, the gelato was very good and refreshing in the heat. Pack a lunch and sit on a bench enjoying the garden.The only thing that made me rate it a 4/5 is that a group of high school students arrived and ruined the ambience. They could have cared less about the art and just decided to run around and shout. Otherwise this would have been a 5/5.

A peaceful oasis with amazing sculptures in the heart of Paris. We love sculpture and Rodin is one of our favourite artists. To be able to see his work in the gardens of the building that he lived was a fantastic experience. Well worth a visit when in Paris.

Ok but not as good as expected..... I was glad we went to this museum on the first Sunday of the month and did not have to pay, otherwise I would have been disappointed. The sculptures are interesting but sparse, the gardens are under renovation, and the experience was not what I expected.

No crowds, nice sculpture garden, powerful works of art. I have fought crowds at the Louvre and D'Orsay and never visited Rodin's museum. We were over by Napoleon's Tomb so decided to stop in since it was right across the street, and with the Paris Pass, it is a free entrance. We especially liked the sculpture gardens with The Thinker right up front. I had forgotten how powerful Rodin's pieces are. There is also a nice bistro right next to the gardens. Others have used the word peaceful to describe this place, and I concur. That is what makes it such a nice place to visit away from the hustle of the city which surrounds it.

worth it with MP. A good museum, but a bit on the smaller side. Worth it for me because I had the Museum Pass, so I wasn't paying any extra - not sure I would pay the fee just for that, but once inside it was quite interesting and had a good amount to see. The gardens were also quite beautiful.

Maybe the best museum to spend an afternoon. Relative to the other museums, this is a small, easy to manage museum. Sensational sculptures and peaceful grounds. You get an understanding of the creative process of the artist. Highly recommended.

Magnificent, intimate Museum.. After the hurly-burly of several days in Paris and in need of some tranquil time visit the Rodin Museum! The treasures inside the museum are superb sculptural creations with something for all ages and the highlight is The Kiss. The gardens are an extension of the interior with more sculptures arranged tastefully along the walkways - including Balzac, the Gates of Hell, and the renowned Thinker! To end the experience a visit to the cafe/restaurant with its splendid variety of lunches and wonderful pastries is a must.

The Thinker. I went to the Rodin to see the Thinker so I only paid to visit the garden.It was a very relaxing place to wander through. It is only small but with plenty of sculptures in a natural setting.The main building was under renovation while I was there.

Garden good/okay, check first.. The garden is pretty and peaceful, the sculptures appropriately depressing. The thinker is wonderful, so is the kiss. However, I was surprised at how manicured the garden was. I was expecting it to be more in line with how Rodin experienced and loved it. The museum is also under maintenance. So check before you go.

Musee Rodin Garden Visit. Due to time constraints I only had time to visit the garden at the Rodin Museum in April but I found it very enjoyable. There are a significant number of pieces, well identified and displayed. The garden is beautiful, well maintained and very peaceful. There were many people just enjoying the beauty. I would definitely return to see the entire museum.

Fabulous garden and sculpture. The Musee Rodin is a lovely way to spend an hour or so, the garden being an especially peaceful and interesting place. It is filled with incredibly beautiful sculptures by Rodin, including the emblematic "The Thinker" . The works are beautifully displayed in a fantastic, natural setting. This is how a museum/gallery should be - alive and relaxing, showing the works to the greatest possible advantage.This is one museum among several in Paris that should be on the must see list!

'The Kiss' and 'The Thinker' in a quiet setting. These most famous of Rodin's works are wonderful, and easy to see well from close up - no big crowds here. In April 2015 the main building was still being renovated, but there was no restriction to the gardens, which are the main exhibition space for his bronze castings. It was a revelation to discover that much of his work was concerned with topics like the 'Gates of Hell' and the suffering 'Burgers of Calais'. But his great masterpiece, 'The Kiss' is marble and therefore housed indoors - in a temporary location while we were there, but nonetheless very accessible from all angles. Nice simple cafe (salads and so on) in the garden.

Beutiful museum dedicated to the work of Rodin. This is not one of the big museum of Paris. It has a lot of work from Rodin inside. You can appreciate the different stages of his work. The property is also a lovely place to enjoy. The garden is so beautiful in the summer with all the flowers.(Note this review is from a previous trip done in the summer. I forgot to review at the time).

Wonderful Museum. Rodin's famous sculptures all displayed here both indoors and throughout an outdoor garden. So nice to stroll along the paths enjoying the beautiful gardens and seeing Rodin's works. There's also a wonderful little café on site, which helps make the visit even more enjoyable. Relaxing experience..

If you like sculptures. you'll love this museum and garden. It appears to be under renovation right now which compromises the experience somewhat and makes it less enjoyable than it was when I visited 20 years ago. I hope to visit again next time and have the entire collection available including the house which displayed the sculptures so beautifully.

Still Great Even During Renovation. The Musee Rodin was a very nice experience. Even tthough the museum is undergoing a renovation it did not take away from the creativeness of the pieces from this master. The outdoor gardens are a perfect place to casually walk around and admire the work. The Kiss and the Thinker are what many think of when they think Rodin, but his pieces on the Gates of Hell are breathtaking. You can see most of the musuem in just a couple of hours or you can spend a lot more time there if you wish. Since a good part of the museum is outside, it is also not a bad place to go with younger children who you may just be trying to expose to art.
restoration. The chapel exhibit is a mere nod to Rodins work. The gardens do him justice during the restoration and are worth the admission

Amazing. I did this because my son wanted to go, I loved it. It was amazing I had no idea how much I would enjoy seeing the statutes and all the details as well as the story behind Rodin as an artist. Great little outside café within the gardens where we enjoyed a bottle of wine and some waffles with whipped cream.

It was like seeing your hero in dirty underwear. Feel free to ignore my opinion expressed here; I do have some training in sculpture, but I'm probably way out of line thinking that I have a mandate to be critical of Rodin. Nevertheless:Because I've always enjoyed sculpture; I naturally assumed that I liked Auguste Ronin's work.It turns out I was only partially correct. My visit to Musee Rodin exposed Ronin's feet of clay. And they were pretty big feet at that. Much of what I've seen to date of the man's work has demonstrated power and emotion; much of what I discovered at his home and gardens in Paris was the dark side. His statue of Victor Hugo being inspired by a tortured muse is excellent and inspirational; his gates of Hell is somewhat of a mixed bag with seemingly inappropriate figures; but some of the lesser works on display in his garden display an awkward, almost clumsy aspect to his execution. This was one occasion when I wished I hadn't visited an exhibit.But, don't let me stop you; the experience is yours to discover.

A lovely mix of indoor and outdoor beauty. We rode our hire bikes here. The best aspect was the fact we could walk around the garden admiring the outdoor art and greenery and also see the indoor art work. It is not a large museum so it is a good one to visit if filling in time between activities OR if you have already seen the larger museums. Really lovely service as well.

Rodin experience. It was under construction and will be for a while. We still enjoyed our time there in the garden with his huge sculptures. Part of the museum is open and we learned a lot even still.
Peaceful Musee and gardens. Take a visit , stop to "think" for a while. Relax at the cafe. Enjoy amazing sculpture. Invalides is next door so combine the visits!

The Thinker, and more. Rodin's sculptures always inspire. We enjoyed a leisurely walk through the gardens and believe everyone should see this nice area off the main tourist map. We highly recommend it!

Beautiful garden. We went here in April 2015 when the museum was closed for renovation and only the garden was open. This was the best 2 euro I spent in Paris. We could wander the garden and see all the beautiful sculptures and read all about the history of the Rodin and the hotel where he lived in the gardens which is now the museum.

An experience - highly recommend . Sadly the museum shut but the gardens are still worth the visit.Amazing to see this place - where artists used to get "cheap" space to work back in the day (think hackney or Brooklyn today), except that it's sezanne, monet and rodin!The placards are all very informative and a real delight to see these extraordinary creations

Closed for renovations. Only the outside gardens and a temporary exhibit are open since the museum is undergoing renovations for most of 2015. We enjoyed the gardens and Rodin's most famous sculptures are on display outside, but I wouldnt go on a rainy day!

The gardens were lovely!. We enjoyed our walk through the gardens, viewing many Rodin Sculptures. Unfortunately, the main museum was going through renovations. There was a small temporary exhibit inside. However, it was a lovely day out, and it was wonderful to walk through the gardens.
Absolutely recommendable. Small and cosy, with beautiful gardens . Perfect in the summer. A visit you shouldn't miss if you go to Paris.

Stunning Gardens, House under Renovation. The gardens are open, as is an exhibition on how Rodin worked, which I thought was wonderfully done, with photos of him working, his studio, photos he had sketched on, casts of works in progress in various sizes, and the chance to see the overall process of the work. Unfortunately the main house is undergoing renovation, so was not open.If you have a handicapped placard bring a photo copy with you, and your entrance and that of your companion is free throughout the major museums in France. Be sure to allow time to simply sit in the gardens, and enjoy the sculptures where they were meant to be.I did find everything to be handicapped accessible, and had no trouble with my walker. Most of the pathways are a firm enough, and small enough, gravel, or are firm dirt or pavement, so navigation was easy. At one point we did have to do stairs with no rail, but we could have backtracked around the house if necessary to avoid that.There is a handicapped accessible toilet at the back of the gift shop.You may have to walk half a block or so to find a taxi upon leaving.
Gardens are nice. We had the museum pass and that made entry free. You can simply pay the 1Euro admission for the garden and get to see everything worth seeing.

What a beautiful place. It is such a lovely, relaxing environment. No wonder Rodin spent most of his life there. The gardens are exquisite, the building beautiful and of course, the art is amazing and some of it is amusing. A very leisurely, romantic afternoon, and we walked here from the Musée d'Orsay, along the Seine. Also, a lovely little cafe for lunch.
Love Rodin - Musee under construction. We couldn't get into the gardens because of high wind. The chateau is being reconstructed. It was disappointing. Of course what we could see was fabulous.

Surround yourself by beauty and peace. Go as early as you can. If you can: wait for the renovation to end...if not just the garden is worth the visit if you have over three days in Paris...Besides Rodin ... beautiful art by Camille

Worth the trip just for the gardens!. I was a little iffy on visiting with all the options of things to do in Paris, but I'm so glad we did! The grounds are immaculate and the gardens were in full bloom during our visit last summer. Highly recommended!

Perhaps not during the renovation. My wife and I have visited the Musee Rodin now at least 4 or 5 times. During the last trip (April 2015) the mansion was closed for renovation and thus really the only things to see were the statues in the garden. (There was a small indoor exhibition too, but nothing compared to what one would see in the Manor House.) The statues in the garden included some of Rodin's most famous works and they are breathtaking but not being able to see all the works in the mansion really detracted from the experience. It's a tough call for the first time visitor, but if you've been there before and only have a limited time in Paris I would probably not go there. Once the mansion opens again, I am sure it will be on the "Do Not Miss" list.

Under renovation, but still a "must see". The history of this building and museum is fascinating. The old residence is under renovation, so we cannot go in at the moment. But some of the best of Rodin's sculpture is permanently in the beautiful gardens. Even in the rain, it is a lovely experience.

Beautiful Gardens. Visited the museum today with very nice weather. The gardens are only 2e and well worth the time. The chateaux is closed until Nov, but a small exhibition is available. Be sure to have a bite to eat at the garden cafe and enjoy the ambiance. Fresh food that is reasonably priced.

The great place to visit while in Paris. It is a beautiful and interesting place. The mansion is great with marvelous statues, the garden is magnificent. If you like Rodin's creations you will definitely enjoy this museum.
The Garden is amazing. The museum itself was closed for renovations whenn we visited. The gardens are beautiful and house many thought provoking sculptures.

here for the Paris Marathon 2015. so as part of the Paris Marathon, we had a few days to look around. one of the attractions was the Musee Rodin. we got here with one of our friends who is a professional photographer. He urged us to come. so we came. it was a great idea. unfortunately, it began raining. for this reason, we did not have a chance to see most of the gardens. we then went inside and were told that most of the museum is being renovated. even though the trip was short lived, we did have the chance to look at some of the restored art. the work was incredibly neat. the pieces at times exquisite. actually humbling.i for one had a great time. i wish i had the chance to look through the gardens more.....Next time.
Rodin. What else can you say?. The Thinker and The Kiss were as advertised but there is so much more. Unfortunately the main inside exhibit was closed.

Lovely, and overlooked!. Small groups, a beautiful garden setting, charming cafe in the garden, and some of the most historic statues ever created. This often overlooked museum was actually a highlight of our trip. A lot of it was closed for repairs during our visit (boo!) but we still spent about 90 minutes here. Highly recommend including this on your trip!

Just go for the gardens for now is right.. It's very true what one reviewer said about going to the gardens on a nice and sunny day. The mood and atmosphere would have been different had it been rainy or cloudy. The mansion and main museum are closed until Sept 2015 for renovations so I would not even bother with the temporary exhibit, and just go for the gardens where Rodin's famous sculptures are.We have a 7 year old so he had a blast running around the garden. We spent a good 1.5 hours on such a lovely and warm spring day in April. This is very good for kids. I don't know if we would feel the same way if the weather was 80 degrees F, where it might feel sweltering and tire one out, but when we went it was good in the 70s. This place would be a once in a lifetime deal, but the flowers were not all in full bloom so my opinion might be different if I had come in May.
Bigfoot. The indoor part of the museum was closed inApril 2015, so I just visited the garden. It was a lovely stroll. The statues had huge feet and were imposing.

Go for the garden . For the most unexpected and captivating oasis of calm in the centre of Paris, please go to this museum and then spend most of your time in the garden.Indoors the exhibits are wonderful. They provide a near unique insight into how sculptors scale up their works to become the most majestic features in the public realm.
Museum and Garden. One of the most attractive places in Paris. Masterpieces of Roden are exhibited in a perfect Garden too. Excellent feeling. Visit the café in the garden.and relax.

If you love Rodin you need to go to his "hotel".. I have always loved Rodin and the power of his works. The gardens were a nice place to stroll and just enjoy. As the renovation was supposed to have been done by 2015 it was disappointing that the "hotel" has not open.
only with good weather!. garden is a huge part of this museum so for you comfort - dont leave it for bad weather, with sun it so much better!

Nice for a free visit. Me and my boyfriend recently attended this museum in finding out that the museum was free as we are EU citizens and aged between 18-26. It was interesting to see The Thinker, and as we only had the free admission, this only permitted us to see the permanent collections and the gardens. The weather was a little grey so although the gardens were lovely, it was a little dim. There was also some construction going on there. However despite all of this, it was nice to see the works and find out more about Rodin!

Grim and Arresting.  Only the gardens are open at the Rodin Museum in Paris while the building undergoes a renovation. Still, the gardens capture the gist of Auguste Rodin’s greatest work—his slightly larger than life bronze sculptures of the Burghers of Calais, Balzac, the Gates of Hell. He wasn’t the first to shun sculpting heroic decorative monuments, or to master the anatomy. His genius is in molding his bronze casts to express the overwhelming emotions of terror, love, dejection and loss. His figures, barely a shade less than funeral black, set a depressing tone for the museum’s gravel paths, lawns and alleys of tightly pruned chestnut groves. But that’s the measure of Rodin’s talent.

Lovely garden. The main museum in the Hotel Biron is closed for renovations. Too bad! But you can wonder the gardens & see quite a number of Rodin's famous sculptures. Not knowing much about his work, though, I didn't appreciate the place the way someone else might have.
Picnic, sculpture, and gardens. the ability to traverse a sculpture gallery and beautiful grounds makes this museum the ideal visit on a Paris afternoon.

A Jewel of a Museum. The house is currently being renovated so only the grounds were open. No crowds (unheard of in Paris) made our visit delightful. The sculptures were scattered throughout the compound with the Paris skyline as a backdrop. A wonderful way to enjoy Rodin's sculptures.
Must see in Paris. Make sure you stop by. It is cheap. 1 or 2 euro depending on your age/student. Unfortunately it was under reform when we went. Still beautiful and must see.

one of my favorites in Paris. This museum is easy to locate and not too crowded. Included in the visit Paris ticket.
Loved the outdoor statues and garden. there is also a very nice cafe with garden side views. All in all it was a lovely place to spend a few hours.

A must-see in Paris.. So wonderful to see so many of Rodin's sculptures and many of Camille Claudelle. This is a 'must see' museum for all who enjoy sculpture and what an experience to see the gates in all their glory.
Amazing opportunity to see the genius work. Dont forget to visit the amazing gardens where you can pass through not only the scupltures, but well designed garden with amazing bushes and trees.

Well worth a visit. It's great being able to see the real thing. You can actually time the time to visit & enjoy without being pushed around. The park in itself is lovely too. Allow half a day for this visit and there is also a small souvenir shop.

The thinker. When I see Le Penseur de Rodin, I feel he should have taken me for a model. I keep thinking, but I'm far from his fame! Well, apart from the thinker, there are many other statues. But it the end, this is the one you remember.

Beautiful and quick.. I visited and very much enjoyed walking the grounds (even though there was renovations going on) and finding the works nestled amoungst the garden. It was interesting and beautiful but a short trip. Probably didnt stay even an hour. Worth it in my opinion, but only if you are a Rodin fan and know what you are going to go and look at, if you are not interested in sculptures then there is not much for you. The location is prime and close to a lot of other things so visit if you get the chance.
Love Rodin. Love Rodin, see some of his most amazing works, went in the fall and it rained during my visit, so bring an umbrella since there are many sculpures in the garden that are a must to see...
Disappointed. Only the gardens were available so apart from the Thinker sculpture there was not much to see as the building was not available
Sculptor's masterpieces. Although, at this time, the museum is undergoing a restauration, we could walk through the gardens and have a closer look at some of his studies and sculputures.

The highlight of our Paris visit.. Rodin's most famous works are beautifully placed in the lovely gardens.
The Thinker and the Five Burghers of Calais are very moving.

Not to Be Missed. When you want to avoid the overcrowded tourist filled museums of the Louvre & Musee D'Orsay...Head over to the Musee Rodin. We went with 3 of our children on the 1st Sunday of the month. (All museums in Paris have free admission the first sunday of the month.) It was a beautiful day and we were able to walk around the gardens and eventually sit at the cafe to have some cafe and soup. You are able to walk up to the sculptures up close. We enjoyed not only "The Thinker". We also enjoyed the sculpture of Victor Hugo.
Interesting . Very good museum. I recommend buy the audio guide. It explains a lot of things that you would never realise and it makes your visit much more interesting.

A quick visit to see "The Thinker". I visited this museum since it was close to Invalides and admission was included with the Paris Museum Pass. This small museum is nice with outside gardens. The gardens were roped off during my visit, so I really didn't get a chance to walk around. There is a decent cafe on the premises that overlooks the gardens. I had a late lunch here and continued on my way.
Great museum and gardens. One of my favourite spaces. Even when the garden isn't in bloom it is lovely. Nice for a quiet walk and to see Rodin's amazing work.

The Thinker and The Gates of Hell and A Great Cafe'. Love, love, love this musee. It's mostly outdoors - at least The Thinker and The Gates of Hell are - and has a wonderful cafe', too. I ate outdoors and a cat jumped up and ate the remainder of my salad. Bizarre! Only at a Rodin Musee!!!

Beautiful gardens but renovations on. Rodins sculpture garden was stunning but rest of museum under renovation . We had Paris pass so didn't cost anything but only half of museum in action ( being the gardens)

Partially closed at the moment. We planned only to visit the gardens, but as it was a very raining day in Paris we decided to make a longer and dryer stop. The museum itself is closed for some sort of refurbishment, gardens are open and even under rain they were surprising lovely. There was a crowd close to the thinker, but the rest of the sculptures were ok to stop, appreciate and explain something to the kids. Inside there was a small exposition that was very nice, not sure if it was worth the extra fee, but was interesting, several pictures and developing work of some of the most famous works. Also the history behind of them. Will not take more than 30 minutes even stopping a lot and reading all.

Just amazing. Right in the heart of Paris you have this gorgeous museum with a unique and lovely garden with sculptures in bronze from Rodin. From the well known pieces such as the thinker or the kiss to the least known ones passing by the drafts and sketches, it's just an amazing place. I've been in the majority of Paris museums and this one goes to the top 3. Don't miss it!!!!

Super charming. One of my favorite museum. This is the place to discover Rdin's work in a charming way.The modern building presents the current exhibition, often extremely interesting and very well documented (opportunity to learn a lot), the old Hotel particular (big house) shows the collection in a simple, old-fashioned extremely charming way. and the garden is simply unforgettable. don't miss a cup of tea outside at the museum café if the weather is nice.from there, you can head to Invalides.

wait until renovations are finished and gardens fully open.. The museum is probably very good, but with the main building under renovation and more than half the garden closed, there's not a lot to see. It left a bitter taste to pay full ticket price. Check before you visit.

Rodin Museum. A beautiful garden to walk through while seeing some fo the best of Rodin. The signage was terrific and taught me and my daughter a lot about the inspirations for Rodin's famous sculptures. There was a cute little cafe in the garden for a quick snack.

Under construction, but still worth a visit. The garden is lovely, the museum is far less crowded than the larger (and still equally amazing) Musee d'Orsay and Louvre, and I learned so much about Rodin's work. The Musee de l'Armee is right down the street and visiting both is a great way to spend a rainy afternoon.

Renovations. Was let in for free at the garden (European under 26). They are renovating most of the indoors exhibition so I didn't bother. Garden great for relaxation if the weather's good. A little worn out.

Always Worth a Visit, Even When Under Renovation. This is my favorite small museum in Paris, and I visit nearly every time I go. Although the main house is currently under renovation and only a small portion of the collection is viewable, the garden with its sculptures is wonderful. Wandering among the flowers and seeing the works of art outside on a warm, sunny day is always a treat. I especially like being able to see the studies and smaller pieces that preceded the execution of the larger works on display. The Musee Rodin offers a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Paris.
Statues Statues Statues. Rodin is famous for his statues of people and their plights and this is what you will see at this museum.

Great Garden. We could not see the house, but the museum grounds are delightful. This location is especially accessible for less mobile visitors who feel challenged by steps. There are some steps but not many. Before going, read up on Rodin's collection, from "The Thinker" who peers down into Inferno to his other lesser known pieces, which are linked thematically.

Beautiful Gardens. Unfortunately the museum is under refurbishment and will not be open until November 2015; however the gardens are filled with Rodin pieces so a visit is still worthwhile. There is also an exhibition showing models and photos of Rodin's works in progress.

A must!. If for no other reason than to visit the quiet gardens in back of the museum and sit down on one of the benches, drawing in the atmosphere. Even better in the Spring/Summer/Fall when the trees are green!

Springtime delight!. The weather was uncharacteristically warm so strolling through the outdoor gardens was wonderful. The interior spaces had some lovely exhibits, but the outside space is just breathtaking. I expected great sculptures but didn't anticipate the lovely roses and the other garden areas. Plan on visiting on a nice day and give yourself time to linger.
