We were there in the middle of the day and it never seemed crowded at all, in fact I found myself frequently alone in some of the areas, Expensive, but nice little café in the grounds for a light snack or coffee.

Great Gardens!. We didn't get to enjoy the main museum, it was under reconstruction. However we still had an amazing time! The sculptures are breahtaking, and so detailed! We enjoyed walking through the gardens, and stopped at the cafe and had some coffee will relaxing and enjoying the view around us! You should definitly take this in!

Like Rodin?. Personally, I think if don't like Rodin, something is wrong with you. For everyone else, this place is highly recommended. Fascinating story about he old villa and Rodin's relationship to it. Also, a lovely Garden. The gates of hell is worth the price of admission just by itself.

visited during renovation. I visited the museum while it was being renovated. Everything was there but it was temporarily housed in a different part of the museum. For a non-artsy type of person like myself, it was worth while and very interesting.

Sculpture Garden par excellence. What a museum! Even though most of the interior is undergoing renovation, we were astounded by the quality, variety and presentation of Rodin's masterpieces in his garden. Don't miss it!

So fun to see a garden full of art. I got to expose my husband to a whole new world of art. He loved it. Take time to lie down on the lounges provided. There is also a restaurant the provides a nice little break.
Nice little museum. After all the huge museums Paris has to offer, this one is small and nice.It has a beautiful garden (where the original thinking man is), and it is included in the museum ticket

Wonderful gardens. My wife and I stopped here on our way to the Pantheon. It had stopped raining, so we wanted to walk around the famous gardens. Entrance was 2€ per person (full rate).As soon as you enter the gardens, you'll find a path leading to the right, taking you to 'The Thinker' and to your left, you'll find 'The Gates of Hell'. We chose to head towards the right and spent an hour looking at different sculptures and walking/sitting around. There are plenty of sign boards in English and French which provide an introductory biography of Rodin and information on some of his works. The area in front of 'The Gates of Hell' is magical, with lovely sculptures and greenery. The gardens must be absolutely beautiful in Spring and Autumn.Highly recommend a visit here which is easily accessible after seeing the Eiffel Tower or the nearby 'Les Invalides', on foot.

disappointing. Was recommended to go here. We were very disappointed; the museum section was closed & We were only able to access about 10% of the garden (just part of the way up a path at the right hand side). Able to see the thinker sculpture, but that was about it. Apparently the garden was closed as it was windy (well it was a little windy, but not very), and the museum is being renovated so no access. Despite this we were charged the full admission rate. I am sure this would be a lovely place to come if you could actually see it, but we couldn't!. Poor showOn the plus side the toilets were clean!
Beautiful estate and gardens!. The Rodin museum is in a mansion and in its gardens. You'll love it. Go on a nice day because the walk through the gardens is the best part.
Beautiful Gardens. We only visited the gardens because we were on a time limit, but they were absolutely beautiful! Definitely recommend, and with a 1 euro entry fee, there's no reason not to!

Go to the Rodin!. I wasn't excited about going to the Rodin but I'm glad I did. The Thinker is just the tip of the iceberg. The sculpture garden might be one of the best I've ever seen and I'm looking forward to going back in the spring/summer to see the garden in full bloom.

Sculptures galore. Tired of looking at paintings in Paris museums? Wish you could breathe a little at the tourist spots? This one is for you. Set in a house with a garden outside, a leisurely walk takes you through. Interesting works on display. A nice casual tourist stop with "the thinker".

The best museum in Paris. Amazing experience! I love this museum more than others in Paris because it allows the visitor enough exhibits so as to enjoy the experience without being overwhelmed. Some of Rodin's most powerful pieces are here including the kiss and the gates of hell. It was an incredible experience to see the sculptures as well historic photographs of the sculptor and first drafts of some of his most famous pieces. Outside there is a lovely sculpture garden where one can walk around and get lost in the beautiful artworks. It would be a lovely place to visit with children as well.

So good, a must! . Inspiring AND affordable. What other reasons do you need? It's also very easy to get to. To see such amazing work by a great artist will send shivers down your spine, you won't regret it!

Meh.... We were very excited to go to the Musee Rodin -- my husband fancies himself a thinker and we both love The Kiss; I had also missed it on my two previous vists to Paris. Perhaps it was the weather, but we were underwhelmed with the actual number of pieces and the inside was dedicated to one sculpture of Victo Hugo. Maybe if it was warmer and the flowers blooming in the park, we would be more enthusiastic about this site.
Lovely setting for a Musuem. A very interesting and accessible place in an elegant house with superb and spacious gardens. Generally uncrowded. A quiet haven from the busy streets of Paris.

My favorite museum in Paris.. I love the gardens with the full size statues, the front garden etc.Nice to walk around the grounds.It is very accessible if you're handicapped as I am.Good elevators, easy grounds to move about if mobility is an issue.The museum is a beautiful house ..looking out on the big windows over the front gardens is a treat in itself, then there are the rooms of sculpture.Enjoyed the art of Camille Claudel very much and as you are allowed to take photos,I have great pictures of some of my favorite pieces.Good ,clean restrooms.I can't recommend this experience enough.It's a joy.

Not for me. I was disappointed to find out that Rodin had a whole team to make his statues. He only had about 15 different designs, then they are put together in different groups around the city. Look for them on your travels around Paris.
Favourite museum. Excellent little museum, the best part are the gardens when the weather is good. Lovely respite from the busy streets.

Le Penseur, Les Trois Ombres et La Porte de L'Enfer. Take your time when you visit Musee Rodin. Take a leisurely stroll through the gardens around lunch time and enjoy the little cafe. The museum interior gets crowded...but take your time there, too. All of his work is truly wonderful.  Rodin's larger sculptures are beautifully placed in the extensive gardens of L'Hotel Biron. Le Penseur (The Thinker) is most likely the first sculpture you will see. I was actually enthralled with it! I wished I could sketch so I could sit there with the art students and just stare it all day! I arrange my tour through the gardens in a counterclockwise manner so I end up at the Gates of Hell. If it doesn't remind you of Dante's Inferno...it should. Rodin was inspired by Dante'. As with everything in Paris, I suggest reading up a bit before you get there. It really makes the experience more enjoyable. The Paris Pass gets you in FREE.

Renovation in progress but worth the time. Unfortunately there was major renovation going on, so we could not see much of the indoor museum, just a collection of plaster casts and examples of works in progress. However, the garden, though flower and leafless this time of year was still spectacular. You must see Rodin in your lifetime.

do the cafe. we didnt go in the museum, but toured the gardens and the ate lunch at the little cafe. It was a wonderful break when Paris got a little too urban for us. Very astounding sculpture, and a good history of the house and grounds on signage around the garden.
What a treat. Enjoyed this museum a lot. Was amazing to see the works of Rodin for real. Unfortunately some of the museum was close for renovations but wondering in the garden was lovely.

Our favorite museum. We are a family of six with "kids" aged 13-21. This museum houses Rodin's sculptures inside and outside in gorgeous gardens. The Thinker is in the garden where you can view it from all angles with the gleaming sunlight overhead. Fantastic. The house is beautiful and the gardens are large enough to have quiet moments in. All and all - a favorite of our whole family!

See you in septembre!. Attention, tout le monde! One of my favorite places in Paris is *still* under renovation. The Hotel Biron, which houses the Musée Rodin, has scaffolding up on both sides of it and is interdit to visitors until September 2015. The sculptures and drawings that are displayed can be found in the entrance building, next to the gift shop. Rest assured, you will see The Kiss and lots of information about the making of Balzac and Victor Hugo and les bourgeois de Calais. The gardens are still wonderful to visit, with daffodils already peeking out among the art last week (3/15/15). However, none of Camille Claudel’s work is on display. Ce n’est pas juste! It is disappointing that the curators could not find room for a few of her pieces; in fact, they warn you on the renovation page of this state of affairs with no other justification. Come back in September to see it all, post-renovation.
A restful retreat. Superb gardens featuring several key sculptures. The house was closed when we were there and would recommend concentrate on the garden, the exhibition perhaops best for artists.

The garden scultures are even better than the museum pieces. It had been about 10 years since I was here. I still adored the sculpture garden with its wonderful works, including The Thinker. But my most favorite is the Burghers of Calais. Take the time to see the individuals pieces and you will enjoy the entire piece even more

Beautiful. I took many photos in the lovely gardens, especially was drawn to The Gates of Hell, The Burghers of Calais. Gardens are tranquil and inspiring. Took one star off the review because of the renovation.

Nice stroll with art!. Great and peaceful spot. This is a great place to walk around a nice garden and see great art. It is also a nice space to take a load off and just relax. We went because we had the museum pass. I'm so glad we went. We saw and learned about Rodin and had a nice relaxing time there. This is a very peaceful spot in Paris. I recommend this museum after visiting a hectic over packed museum.

superb and intimate museum. This place was Rodin's home, and although he lived there (with his student, college, muse & lover ) in resplendence compared to many of his colleagues, his home has been converted into a proper legacy. I love that there are so many really outstanding works, including a commission of a monumental pair of doors that he cast in iron..... There are progressions of "The Kiss" and the "Thinker", which literally brought me to tears, because the hot passion carved out of the very cold stone was everywhere in this place. There is a beautiful garden, which is part of the visit, too. I loved this place. It is a two hour visit....so an excellent excursion for part of a day. FYI: It is literally right across the street from the Hospital of les Invalids....
Pleasantly surprised. I'm a big fan of Rodin, but found this museum better than expected. I could literally roam around this museum and it's garden's for hours. Must do!

Gardens only open. Our visit to the museum was wonderful as we were fascinated by the gates to hell and of course the thinker. We were disappointed that the museum itself was undo refurbishment but that did not detract. Having a sunny day made it a real pleasure to stroll the gardens containing some of the most magnificent sculptures in the world.
Favourite place in Paris. There are so many great attractions in Paris but this is my favourite. Perfectly laid out incredible art work. Could spend days just in the gardens.
Beautiful. Small, focused museum in a beautiful house setting, looking just like when Rodin lived there. All the iconic sculptures and a restful garden too.

Sculpture and Roses. Being a rose geek, I was amazed to visit this lovely museum, at the site of Rodin's home. Many of the works are outside. Some, like the famous "Thinker", are situated in the middle of rose gardens. There are lovely places to sit and enjoy the works. There is an enclosed glass case with many studies. The house also have many works, and the building at the entrance had several studies that had not been completed. There is usually a line at opening, but if you have a Paris Museum Pass, they let you in ahead of the others. Once inside, there is enough space to move out of the crowds. This is my second favorite museum in Paris, and I will visit again!

Quite a Lovely Home.. This is a museum that was once Rodin's home. A little treasure you might find is an original Van Gogh that was once owned by Rodin (I won't tell you where it's located you'll have to find it!). But definitely pick a sunny day. Some of Rodin's greatest treasures are outside such as the Thinker and other sculptures. And the gardens are quite beautiful.
Fantastic. We just loved this place. It is very nice and staff was very friendly. Rodins works are so beautifull and well done. This is something I recommend to all when visiting Paris.

If only it was open. It is difficult to fault anything to do with the genius sculptor and it is a great shame the actual museum is closed until September but still on a sunny day or even a freezing spring morning as ours it was a privilege to walk the gardens

Peaceful sculpture garden. Hotel Biron (perm collection & Rodin's home & studio) is closed for reno until 9/2015. We chose to tour the garden only (2 Euro/pp) since it has great open space, landscaping, and also major sculpture pieces. We felt it was better than paying more to see the temp exhibits (a bit stuffy inside & crowded).

Beautiful garden sculptures. Located off a side street so easy to miss this museum is definitely worth visiting if you like bronze sculptures of this period. If it's sunny it's even more worth it given the beautiful walk you can make in the garden of sculptures

Gardens are the best part. The museum is really all about the grounds, so, if you are going off season, you may want to miss this one. If you have the museum pass, you can at least stop in and see The Thinker.
Dissappointing. The Stanford California museum is better in my opinion even though I think they are replicas. Worth a stop but not worth a lot of time in my opinion.

Closed for renovations but the garden is still well worth a visit. For a couple of Euro you ca't go past a walk around this magnificent garden. An early spring visit meant that the roses were yet to bloom, but a sunny day made for an ethereal experience. Very few people so we were able to take our time savouring the works of Rodin. A nice idea is to stop at the cafe and get a glass of wine - and just soak up the sunshine! Lovely.

Closed for renovation at the time of this review. I imagine that if I could actually see the museum it would get five stars but that's a bit hard to do as it is currently under renovation. The gardens are beautiful though a bit muddy and slippery at this time of year. Several great sculptures are in the gardens so it's worth a visit but I'd pay only to see the gardens as the indoor displays aren't really worth the extra Euro. Some history, some plaster casts unearthed from the basement archives. A lot about Victor Hugo. It is interesting but not quite enough to justify paying for more than the gardens at this point in time.
Rodin Museum. What a perfectly beautiful space and gardens The sculpture is beautiful, well spaced, with plenty of room to walk around. The gardens are beautiful.
It is under construction and closed. You can still see the garden and a couple of statues inside but it is a big disappointment even if they cut the price in half.

Amazing Garden;. The Musee Rodin has one of the most beautiful, privately owned, gardens in all of Paris. It was an absolutely magical experience which I would gladly repeat;We arrived early, and although there was already a lineup of 25-30 people outside, it moved quickly and took no more than 15 minutes for it to be our turn. Blessed be the French for their discounts: because I had my EU card with me, and was under 25, I actually had free admission to the museum's garden. My mother had to pay some 2.50€ - 3.00€ admission to enter the garden.The garden is stunning, on a sunny day it's just magnificent with sunrays peaking through the canopy of trees and highlighting each statue and sculpture perfectly, giving them a new life. The Gates of Hell are just otherworldly, they took my breath away... There is a magnificence to Rodin's work, to the pained expressions that although haunting are just so beautiful...The garden also has several places in which to sit down and relax, perfect for a peaceful lunch. Not to mention that from the garden you have perfect views of the Golden Dome of the Hotel des Invalides, which is just across the street, and if you squint you can even see the tip of the Eiffel Tower.Even though we only saw the garden I still hold it as the best museum experience we had in Paris, I absolutely loved it.
Definitely worth a visit.. Beautiful setting, original sculptures, even ones by Rodin's cast-off lover, Camille Claudel. We will return on our next visit.
Must go. The wonderful garden where the masterpieces are located it the hit of the museum. Love this place and the caffes around. Must go!

Lovely exhibits and gardens. I visited on a lovely sunny day. Although the main museum is undergoing renovation there are still some lovely examples within the studion and gardens. The gardens are lovely. This is definately one that encourages you to relax and take your time. Well worth visit.

Go for the garden . The Musée Rodin's gardens were breathtaking. They are expansive and house of Rodin's most famous works. There is plenty of room to sit and have a picnic even. There's also a café in the garden. The woman at the front desk asked what age we were so that we got the 18-25 discount, which was nice because at some attractions they don't ask and you end up paying the full rate.The exhibition is just small, and compared to other museums in Paris it may underwhelm you. If you're a huge Rodin fan though, you won't be disappointed.

Eye Opening. In Paris for our Anniversary - Museums are not normally my first choice .... But My wife had her heart set on going.Honestly say I was pleasantly surprised - As a Non Arty person I thought it was going to be a long couple of hours .... Anything but it's well structured and more than just sculptures - There was a great deal on the history behind the pieces as well as the journey etc. A great deal about the Artist as well and his life etc.At the time the we visited there was a temporary exhibition (So maybe I only sat the best bits) not sure if this was reflected in the low entry price .... I'll go back again when next in Paris and the Exhibition is fully open again

Huge Garden in the heart of Paris. I would put this on a "must see" list for Paris. If you only have a day or 2 in the city, then save it for the next time you come back. But do not put it off forever. The garden is HUGE. We went here early on a European vacation and it was interesting to see how many of his sculptures were in other cities we visited. As others have said, the main museum is under renovation. However a fair number of works have been moved and can be viewed in the reception building. Lots of stuff to see in beautiful surroundings in the garden.
Beautiful garden. The palace is closed at the moment, but you still can enjoy the sculptures around the garden. Don't miss the Hell's Door.

Great little spot.. The sculpture gardens are wonderful, a nice little spot in the middle of the hub-bub of Paris. You can see the Thinker, and The Gates of Hell, as well as many other works by Rodin. Unfortunately, the main museum was under renovation, but I still enjoyed my time here.
Lovely gardens. Thoroughly enjoyed seeing the sculptures in the house and gardens, seems less busy than the other galleries and museums and you can get a joint ticket for musee d'orsay

Lovely Gardens. I visited the Rodin Museum last week and it is currently undergoing restoration; however, the gardens are open and there is a small exhibition going on. I'm sure once restorations/renovations are completed this museum will be even more fabulous!

Fascinating. Rodin's work is well-known, but one of the fascinations of this museum is the work-in-progress: one can see the forms emerging from the marble in an amazing way. And the finished pieces are pretty good, too...
A museum to revel in. If you love Rodin, as I do, you will be in heaven....The greatest collection of his art, the wonderful nudes, the sumptuous curves and luminosity of the marble....just sublime

A beautiful surprise. Fabulous introduction to the life and work of Auguste Rodin. Walking in the garden was the best part. Be aware that a major portion of the museum is under construction for the next 10 months or so at least.

Got to love the statues and the gardens. We loved the gardens and the art works would like to have purchased some reminders of our visit but foud the gift shop a little under stocked with reasonably valued gifts.
Bad timing for us.. It was being renovated so we couldn't get into the house. I had wanted to show my daughter it and we were just unlucky.

Gardens worth a trip and inexpensive. Very pleasant cafe situated in the gardens which are full of replicas of Rodin's key works. Only €2 to visit the gardens and a short walk from Musee d'Orsay through a neighbourhood of grand government buildings.

Pleasantly Surprised!. I wouldn't say that I had ever considered myself a huge fan of Rodin, but I loved Musee Rodin! I am a fan now! The grounds are beautiful - all the roses!!! - and it is surprisingly quiet and peaceful. The sculptures are amazing. This turned out to be one of our Paris trip highlights.
Rodan Garden. What a wonderful way to spend a few hours in this beautiful Garden in the middle of Paris. It is so quiet and peaceful here that you forget where you are.

A peaceful haven. We enjoyed our visit to the museum, but the indoor exhibition is fairly sparse. The walk around the gardens, inspecting the various sculptures was very pleasing. Disappointed to find out The Kiss had been withdrawn from view in readiness for a special exhibition.

such a personal space!. Beautiful artwork and way less overwhelming (and more enjoyable) than the Louvre. Spend several hours (preferably at least an afternoon) and you won't regret it! such a cozy and personal space compare to other museum, you could even touch the sculptures in the garden :)

My trip highlight. I have loved Rodin my whole life and being here was magical. The grounds are lovely for walking with Rodin and more modern sculptures spread out in the small front garden and the larger back garden. The food in the restaurant (eat inside or outside) was affordable and good, especially the soup. Wish I had taken time to enjoy the gelato. We used our museum pass and got in immediately.

Small, a couple hours, but really enjoyed. Bought a double pass while at the d'Orsay and walked over to Rodin. We had a pleasant stroll around the grounds, definately get the tourguide earphones as they detail the background on each piece.

A Walk in the Park. Is a great surprise to see this museum dedicated to the sculptures and other works of the great sculptor. Rodin is intense and expressionist, his work can't leave you untouched. The cultures are nicely placed in the house as well as in the park belonged to the museum. A walk in the park surrounded by magnificent and big sculptures is worth the whole visit because of the natural light, the beauty of the garden and the colour of the bronze. There is "Le Bourgeois de Calais" with its magnificent expressive figures, Balzac, powerful and gigantic, the Thinker, the Kiss and many others. If you want to take a little break before continuing, you have in the park a lovely and cozy coffeeshop and in good weather, you can seat outside were there are park tables and chairs.
A lot that will look familiar. This is a great half day tour. Take your time. A lot of diversity and a lot that will be familiar. Plus you get to see the Thinker

Monsieur Rodin is resting. Not surprising, hearing about the number of sculptures and drawings he created during his life.But seriously, the main museum at the grand Hotel de Biron is closed for major refurbishment until September 2015. A temporary exhibition is good, but as noted by other recent TA reviewers, it's possible just to pay to see the excellent park and gardens, adorned with some of the great man's best known and amazing pieces.This is a very peaceful space, and presumably bursts into even more vibrant life later in spring and summer.

Serene gardens. Wife & I visited almost as an afterthought since it was included in our museum pass. And we're so glad we did! It's a laid-back art museum and the gardens are much larger than we expected. Had a sandwich at the cafe and loved sitting outside to enjoy the gardens & people watching. Don't pass by this one!

Great museum, amazing park. One of the best places in Paris. The museum and Rodin works are amazing, but the greatest part of it is the park. Great monuments located in the park. Green park, very beautiful with a nice cafe. If you are not that big fan of arts, just visit the park. There is a separate ticket for the park entrance. Spend at least 2-3 hours there.

Not to be missed.. Bear in mind that the house itself is currently closed for renovation or refurbishment but the garden alone is worth coming in. I have been to the house itself on three previous visits and is wonderfully human sized. Check online to check when the house is open again.
Nice museum, gorgeous grounds. The garden was my favorite thing about this museum. The exhibits were nice and it is small enough to do in the morning and do something else in the afternoon.

Magic Gardens. Event you don't want to go to the museum just take a walk and seat in any bench in the gardens, you will feel transport, breath fresh air, the MR even full of people is nice and calm you can go and read have some sun or just rest for a while. The area is also quiet and far from center Paris, but is an unforgetable walk.

Lovely museum. The Rodin museum is small but perfectly formed. An excellent selection of Rodin's sculptures - including the Kiss and the Thinker - displayed beautifully and with very good descriptions. The garden is also lovely, home to more statues and Rodin's Gates of Hell. Well worth a visit - and not too crowded as not generally on the mass tourist 'tick list'.

Wonderful (also for kids), but the main building is closed. I love Rodin's sculptures. The garden is beautiful and you get a good look at all his great sculptures (thinking man, gates of hell and more).The main building is closed for renovations (I don't know until when) so they are showing a temporary exhibition of his work process which is quite interesting in the entrance building.It will take you about 60-90 minutes to stroll leisurely through the garden and museum and it will be a wonderful time. My six year old daughter, who likes museums and art, had a wonderful time.

Can't miss! Stunning, interesting. After spending quite a while in Paris, squiring many friends and family visiting to numerous museums numerous times, the place I am STILL excited to return to one day is Musee Rodin. I've been multiple times, and each time it is just as stunning as the last. The house hosts lovely final, in progress, and studies. The backyard hosts incredible famous pieces, and is generally just a heavenly place to lounge about and admire at your own lazy pace. There is also gelato...
A Peaceful Oasis. The main museum was closed for renovations, but the garden was beautiful, even in February. A small indoor exhibition was available and it was interesting. Free with the Paris Pass.

Pleasant break from crowded places. Unfortunately the museum itself was closed, but this is a lovely small place to visit. I allowed the large group of Chinese tourists to rush through before slowly enjoying the garden and statues.A lovely break from the rush of sights

Closed. The museum itself is mostly closed for renovation but that fact isn't publicized. There is one exhibit about how Rodin worked but I don't think it was worth the cost of admission. The only other place to visit which is a special, lesser charge is the garden. The garden has some nice pieces of Rodin's work and is worth a visit but try to go on a nice day when it hasn't rained in a while because it was rather muddy.

A Breath of Fresh Air. If you love sculpture, you will not want to miss Rodin's works at this small but structurally imposing building and gardens. It's so fun to stroll through the grounds contemplating his works and mimicking some poses for photos. Without believing one knows much about Rodin's work, one actually knows more than one thinks. The Kiss, The Thinker (anyone remember Dobie Gillis) The Burghers of Calais, The Gates of Hell.... His works departed from mainstream of his time and pushed the bounds to think of sculpture in other ways. What I love about his story is that he tried numerous times to get into the foremost art school in France but failed to get in - an example of . Kind of the artistic version of Howard Roark in The Fountainhead. There's a reason he is one of the most celebrated sculptors in the world which makes it all the more reason to visit this vast collection of his works. A lovely way to spend even a somewhat drab day - despite us visiting on an overcast, somewhat cold day in November, we had a really uplifting, pleasant and memorable time. There are few truly great open air sculpture gardens (Hakone in Japan!), this one is small but convenient, and easily and quickly visited. 1.5 hours of your morning will be very well spent. Entry was Euro 6/pp. Oh, and there's actually some footage of Rodin on a youtube video.
The collection is limited. I was very disappointed the collection of Rodin museum are very limited, I has seen more Rodin Sculptures in California USA.

Lovely garden even on cold february day !. Loved Musee Rodin, it was a shame that the house was closed for renovations, but still enjoyed the lovely gardens and amazing statues. Must be lovely in the spring and summer

A piece of Paris. Rodin and C.Claudel are a part of Paris history in 19th. This museum reflected this beauty and majesty.Inside or outside, you find the famous sculpture of both genious. It's Rodin museum but you'll find the best sculpture of Claudel inside and she was a great artist !If you're visiting Paris, you've to go here !!!
A nice little surprise. We loved this museum. A nice little surprise right next to Musee L'Armee. The museum is in a old home and it was just lovely.

Serene & thoughtful. The Musee Rodin is a really pretty museum dedicated to Rodin. Many of his sculptures are available including the Thinker. While Paris has plenty of larger museums, this one should not be missed and it's easy to combine it with the Eiffel Tower as they are both on the Left Bank not far from each other. Don't miss this if you appreciate seeing history come to life before your eyes!

Shame it's half closed. The main 'Hotel' is closed for renovation at the moment but the gardens are open and there is a temporary collection.We were going to visit first thing but there was a long queue. In the end we went in at 230pm with no queue at all and the gardens where The Thinker (beautiful!!) and The Gates Of Hell (fascinating!) were calm with plenty of times to read the plaques and take photos.

Favorite Museum in Paris.. This museum was not overcrowded as all the other ones. It is also a smaller venue which allows for less chaos. I love gardens and sculptures throughout. I have also always loved the art of Camille Claudel and this museum exhibits some small but important works of hers.

Well worth visiting. Musée Rodin is a very approachable museum. The garden is lovely, so be sure to go on a nice day. The collection is extensive, but the museum is certainly manageable. If you feel overwhelmed by the Louvre - make a stop at the Musée Rodin!

Beautiful property. There's something special about this museum. I prefer this over the Louvre because you really can take it all in. Although I enjoy Rodin sculptures, I specially like the emotional work of Camille Claudel displayed here. The property & garden is well maintained. I will def. visit again. It's def an experience you want your children to also have.
Renovations. While this is a lovely museum with a great garden, a large portion of the museum is currently closed for renovations.

A beautiful place, filled with treasures. The Hotel Biron is a wonderful venue for Rodin's sculptures, large and small. For me, a visit to Paris is not complete without one to this elegant mansion, the sculptor's former home. Give yourself at least two hours here. If the Musee is crowded, you will need that much time to ensure you get close to the exhibits you want to see. If there are few people there, it's even better to have extra time to wander around the lovely house and its grounds.
A little gem. A gem of a place for the sculptures in the garden alone. Small but beautiful - it shouldn't be missed.

Fun and Short even for non-art Lovers. The Musee Rodin is lovely little sculpture garden in Paris. It's not too big so it won't take long to see the whole thing - probably 1.5 hrs at most, so if you have a short time in Paris but want to see some art, the Rodin is a great choice.There is a beautiful outside garden where you can see the famous Thinker in all it's glory, and then be even more blown away by the masterpiece that is the Gates of Hell. There are many famous pieces there, but those two are on the top of the list. Plenty of opportunities to take photos.There is a small discount for students as well. The line wasn't too long when we arrived at the museum at around 10:30 a.m., maybe a half hour wait at most, but I recommend getting there early to avoid it getting any longer. That way you can do a cute brunch somewhere else and continue along your sightseeing of Paris. There's an inside part of the museum as well, which houses lesser well known sculptures, some casts, and some paintings.My boyfriend and I really enjoyed it. He has very little interest in going to museums and seeing art, and he had a great time! I chose it specifically because I knew it was much easier to tackle than the Musee D'Orsay and the Louvre (which is unbelievably overwhelming).
Must like sculpture. The sculptures in the museum and garden ware nice, but it is a small museum. Takes about 1 hour if you read all the plaques.

Dream come true. I fell in love with Rodin's work in my humanities class. I bought s a marble sculpture of his The Kiss immediately after that class. To see the real original was a dream come true!!! Thank you for such a wonderful experience!

Pleasant walk among art!. All Rodin statues are there. Rodin studied his sculptures, making models. Then he made a mold and some (4 or 5) statues of each one. Then, destroyed the mold. Kept one and sold the rest. Well, there's various Rodin museums around the world, but this is the only with all his work. Including the studies.

Small but perfectly formed. We visited during the renovation of the main museum so there was a small display in an annexe. Really interesting examination of the history an development of four or five of Rodin's most important works which could then be seen in the garden.

not that much to see now. toured the museum on valentine's day 2015 and was disappointed that there was so much construction going on . Only the modern building where you enter and the garden are open. They are trying to display as much of Rodin's work as possible, but it is a very temporary and clumsy set up. Go back in a year or 2 to see the big house restored and set up. There are too many museums in Paris to waste much time and money here at this point. The work has to be done, but until it is see other things like museum Marmottan monet......its fabulous

Gardens not to be missed. This museum has been on my list to see for quite some time and I finally made it. There are renovations going on now so I was not able to see the entire museum. The gardens would be very lovely in the spring or summer. I hope to be back!

Easy Museum to Visit in a Few Hours.. The Musee Rodin is actually Rodin's house. The sculptures are crowded together in no special order nor is there any dramatic lighting to make Rodin's work more dramatic. But you are not there to be impressed by settings, you are there to see the genius of this master sculptor. As you view each piece the placement and setting becomes less annoying and you become completely engrossed in each piece. The Museum is within walking distance of Les Invalides so you can Do both in one day.

Beautiful museum & garden in the heart of Paris. We heard about this through a friend and wouldn't have thought to have gone here ourselves. The museum is about a 10-15 minute walk from the Eiffel Tower and well worth a visit for an hour. You can see Rodin's famous 'The Thinker' as well as a lot of his other work. We very much enjoyed the walk around the gardens and lunch in the cafe as well.

My favorite and highlight of trip. Loved this place, quiet on a February week day. Great cafe. Sculpture garden was nice to walk around. Museum closed for renovation, but what they did have for viewing made it well worth the visit.

Sculptures to die for. It was a lovely sunny day so the walk around the gardens was so lovely meeting the thinker at the end of our walk. Quite a lot of work going on but the staff warned us as we went in. The kiss was just inside of the main hall. Brilliant

Perfect Size. Who doesn't know the statue of The Thinker and The Kiss? But to see the real deal was fabulous. I never knew about some of the other statues there and the connection to Honoré Balzac and Victor Hugo. I quite enjoyed if that is the right word the "Gates of Hell". Extraordinary! I loved the fact, that there is the garden to stroll and find the bronze that seem to peek from behind the trees and the house that has a brilliant collection and explanation. Thoroughly enjoyed it.

Small Museum with Lovely Gardens. After all the large museums, this was a breath of fresh air. The artist actually lived and worked in this location. The Gardens are wonderful. There are benches in various locations where one can sit and relax. A rare experience in busy Paris.

Just purely part of Paris rich beauty. Many reasons on going to visit Paris is to be swept into its histories and beautifulness. To enjoy its many artist. To appreciate, learn and become swept up in the histories of its arts. Musee Rodin is just amazing. My wife and l stayed here for hours. we took our time and just looked and appreciated Rodins arts and the building itself. The day was sunny and perfect. There was no rushing and loudness. Everyone was there to embrace and enjoy Rodin. The gardens are amazing. After coming out of the building you get to walk threw the gardens. Sit and relax and talk about what you have just experienced. Visually another beautiful wonder of Paris. I highly recommend this place to see and just embrace and enjoy. Nothing negative to be said. Beautiful
Hidden gem museum. The thinker sculptor was worth going for alone. But all his other works were beautiful as well. The gardens were ok. But I liked all the sculptures inside the best.

Use your Museum Pass. The road to the entrance is small and the line can get long. Use the museum pass to cut to the front. The museum was Rodin's former home and a pass through the masters' work was very inspiring. Camille Claudel's L'Age Mûr was on display during our visit at Musée Rodin and not at Musée d'Orsay.
Rodin's the Man!. This Museum is Great. Lovely building and grounds filled with Many of Rodin's Great works of art. A wonderful way to spend a few glorious hours in the Great Paris.

One of our fav' museums in Paris - hidden gem!. Perfect for families, or couples, or even alone, whether you are a art fanatic or just curious, whether you want to enjoy a break in the city, a quiet walk in the beautiful garden among the sculptures, or immerse yourself in everything Rodin. His statues are powerful, expressive, some are quite delicate, others almost brutal, but none will leave you indifferent!

Surprising favorite. After having visited the Louvre and D'Orsay, this was almost an afterthought. Reading about it, it just seemed like a smallish collection of works by Rodin and Camille Claudel. It actually turned out to be one of our favorite sights in Paris! The outdoor space was our personal favorite - it was very quiet and peaceful, the roses were in bloom and there were a couple of rabbits scampering about the grounds. Some statues are staged thoughtfully among the gardens and it just makes for a wonderful stroll. I'd recommend getting there first thing in the morning, as I did notice when we were leaving, there was quite a line and it was not nearly as quiet as when we arrived. Definitely a wonderful surprise!

Indoor and Outdoor. Set in beautiful gardens I found it less crowded than D'Orsay or the Louvre. You can work around the gardens, sit back and contemplate enjoying some sculptures and also take in the museum. Ready access via the Metro.

Currently under construction- otherwise excellent. the garden was all chewed up and it was difficult to approach the statues because it was so muddy around where they have temporarily placed them. Still worth seeing, but bring your wellies!

Sculpter as 'Rock Star'. For his era Rodin was definitely not a conservative, mainstream artist. Given his brilliance it seems the natural course that the establishment would balk at his creativity. Yet that kind of talent earned him international fame much as modern rockstars do in their medium.
So many museums but this one feels special. Accessible, not overwhelming, well organized - One of our favorites. Exploring and sculpture garden felt a bit like a retreat.

Museum under restoration. Visited before but surprised to see so much restoration work going onOnly 2 euros to enter the gardens where most of the statues and sculptures are kept so that part was alright September is the date of completion of the works but glad that we saw so much in the Musee D, Orsay of works by RodinNice cafeteria in the grounds and had a healthy lunch there

Must visit.. We didn't book but queued early afternoon but for only about 20 minutes. I had always wanted to see 'The Thinker' so was pleased to see two statues, one inside, one outside in the lovely gardens. Plus so smaller version/copy in her gift shop. Had fun having a photo taken copying the pose. Also unexpectedly found some Van Goghs too. Bonus! Well worth a visit.
Unbelieveble.. It is pure emotion to stand beside the "pensador" and take pictures, ou even feel like going inside a palace through the big door.
Freezing cold but worth it. A great garden with many many sculptures. Book tickets as the queue was long even on a freezing cold December morning - ice on the pond in the garden.

Relaxing visit to admire beautiful works. Fairly easy to miss this museum but oh so worth a visit. Personal highlight was exploring the peaceful gardens where many of Rodin's sculptures are displayed amidst flowers, fountains and greenery. It really was very picturesque and you can picnic and relax on the various benches around the main fountain.

Lose yourself in the beautiful gardens.... Fifteen years ago I went to the Musee Rodin and I've never forgotten it and always tell people to visit it when they're in Paris. The images of figures and faces stay with you for years. I went back this year and it was just as I remembered. The gardens are just stunning and full of bronze and marble figures striking poses and of course the wonderful Thinker is pondering the world out there too. The house was being renovated but there was a temporary exhibition to do with how the Gates of Hell were made in another part of the musee and you could still see the beautiful Kiss. Great place to clear the mind.

A small but insightful space with a fabulous garden. A great space both indoors and outdoors. Indoors inform the viewers of Rodin's sculptors, piece by piece with photographs of works in progress and outside the actual bronze sculptures. The Gates of Hell is so intricate and mind blowing to see it as one. Indoors show casts broken down on how Rodin thought his work through. We went on a wet day and still enjoyed the garden but on a sunny bright day is definitely would be a splendid place to sit and look at all the art works. Reasonably priced and it also has a lovely bright shop.

Great Visit Even With Renovation In Progress. While the Museum is undergoing renovation many of Rodin's works have been placed strategically in the garden areas. Beautiful works and very relaxing visit even in the winter.

Must visit fort art lovers. Small cosy palace with amazing sculptures. In house and in the garden. Sit for a minute in front of Calais citizens.... enjoy the atmosphere... like they would be still alive.

Beautiful museum and garden.. The museum is the building where Rodin lived his last years. It includes the exquisite garden with Rodin's magnificent sculptures located throughout. These include "The Thinker" and his masterpiece "Gates of Hell". Nice display of his art collection inside. Don't miss it.

Such a peaceful garden !. When we went to that museum which has a big sculpture garden, we just didn't want to leave.
You must see the "Gates of Hell" by Rodin

Don't Miss Out. This museum was one of the highlights for me, as totally unexpected. The gardens are beautiful and such a peaceful place to enjoy Rodin's work, even just to see "The Thinker". This is included in the Paris Museum Pass.

My favourite museum in Paris. Even though the permanent exhibition was closed, this was my favourite museum. There was a fabulous temporary exhibition about Rodin's working methods and really 'got' him for the first time. Gardens are great to wander about in and fab bookshop.

Delightful. Great museum f you like Rodin, wonderful garens with his scultures nice vies in distance of Eiffel Tower, inside wonderful too with more sculture and paintings (yes, he did paint and sketch too)

Wish statues had more information. A lot of the statues had great descriptions. But some didn't - would have liked that. Very unique outdoor statue museum with some very moving statue sets, particularly the French martyrs.
The Thinker. Came to experience the garden which is cheap to get into. Got to see The Thinker and that was pretty great.

I think it's worth it!. Even if you just see Rodin's masterpiece "The Thinker," it's worth visiting. But there's also so much more to see, and not just of Rodin's work. Plus, the property itself is exquisite, as is the outdoor collection of statues and sculptures sitting in the beautiful garden. The entrance on the street doesn't seem like much, but once inside, it's incredible.

it's at the very top of my list!. the garden is so pretty, the mansion itself is manageable and the arts and statues are stunning. the birds will eat your lunch in the garden which is the most fun park and then you can relax on a lounge in the very rear of the grounds. It is a definite must-see destination, you have to love it.
Rodin is alive.... useum that combines external and internal works visitation, easy to visit. Ideal for a view combined with the "Hôtel des Invalides" (Napoleon's tomb)

Beautiful gardens and interesting museum. Worth an hour for the non art fans and more for art fanatics. Loved seeing the Thinker and taking pics in the gardens. Print out information about the works before you go to appreciate them more. A small museum.

Well worth a visit.. Musee Rodin is not a large museum but is packed full of interest for anyone with even the least interest in Rodin's life and work. Many of Rodin's masterpieces are displayed in a way that helps the viewer understand every aspect of his art, beginning, of course, with The Thinker as you enter the grounds. This is truly one of the world's most distinguished collections of Rodin's works (Auguste Rodin being the French artisticgenius regarded as the father of modern sculpture). Included in the displays are The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, Balzac and Eternal Springtime as well as many lesser-known works both inside the house and outside in the gardens. Inside, the displays of Rodin's creativity are both informative and fascinating, showing visitors not only examples of his work but also the whole creative process from sketches to finished sculpture. Well, well worth a visit.

Beautiful gardens. Auguste Rodin was a sculptor who lived in and converted the Hotel Biron, which is now a museum to his works. The most famous of which, The Thinker, is in the lovely gardens around the hotel. We wandered around and took in his other famous sculptures, including The Gates of Hell, Orpheus and The Burghers of Calais. Then head in to the hotel, and the gentle afternoon light streaming in the big bay windows was perfect for capturing some great photos of his smaller sculptures such as The Kiss and Fugit Amor.

A thorough picture of the man. My husband is a wood sculptor, and the Musee Rodin was therefore a 'must-see' for us. The museum contains a large number of sculptures both indoors and out in the gardens, and does not disappoint. It was good to see Rodin's paintings as well as sculptures, and to see displays of unfinished works that demonstrated the processes involved in developing the finished works. Apart from the famous "thinker', there are other major works such as the Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell (which has so much detail in it, that you need to spend several minutes examining it up close). The house itself is magnificent, and the gardens a delight- a little oasis of peace in the midst of Paris.

Best museum in Paris. Hands down. For a delightful afternoon, there's absolutely nothing that beats the Rodin museum. Don't let the current renovation (til Sept '15) stop you: the garden is still open, where most of Rodin's masterpieces are displayed in a way that enables you to explore every aspect of each piece. The temporary exhibit is very informative and fascinating, helping visitors understand Rodin's creativity, and his design and construction processes.

Very good . I gave this good, failing short of excellent because the builders are in giving only partial assess. Gates of Hell, the thinker, Balzac are a here to wonder at. Rodin was a genius, and his gardens are a joy to wander around. At 7 euro's its a small price for a couple hours. It's a small island of peace

My Favorite Museum in Paris. I took my wife to this museum, which I remembered as my favorite from back when I was a student studying in Paris. It holds up great. Spring for the audio guide, which includes many interesting stories about Rodin's life and the stories that influenced his masterpieces.

Lovely work. Usually at the front they have an introductory exhibition of a different artist that was inspired by Rodin work. When i went it was a photographer that concentrated mostly on nude male bodies and especially some body parts. Lets just say i wish i wasnt there with my grandmother. When you pass that part though the sculptures are stunning. My favorite part was the garden outside though. This museum also doesn't require hours and not as physically demanding as some bigger places so you don't need to dedicate a whole day to it. Would go back there again.

Beautiful works in a beautiful home. I adored this museum. The works were well displayed in a beautiful house. I was thrilled to stand underneath The Thinker. The garden was a delight to explore and the cafe provided a welcome lunch stop.
Not worth. Rodin museum was having reconstruction when get there, and there are only few sculpture and the garden. The Gate of Hell is very detail but it doesn't really attract me.
see and return. One of the best musea of Paris. You like or do not like Rodin but the art scene of that period is great

Beauty and tranquility. I have always loved the strength and sensuousness of Rodin's sculptures and I wasn't disappointed when I visited Musee Rodin. I arrived as the doors were opening on a damp winter day and virtually had the gardens to myself. It was magical to walk through the peaceful garden and get up close to the sculptures with no one else around. I bought the ticket which not only gave access to Musee Rodin but also express entry to Musee d'Orsay.

Inspiribg. A definite favourite for my family. Rodin's story is one of such inspiration, to be able to visit his beautiful house, closed for renovations, and garden with family, to enjoy the space and to see his works and the story behind them is truly wonderful.

Nature and sculpture. This museum resides in a beautiful house and surrounding park where Rodin lived and worked for some years. My favorite is the park area where his sculptures are complimented by the green foliage.
A fantastic place to visit on a Sunny day. It's the most wonderful way to see Rodin's work. On a sunny day, you get to admire some of his pieces in the most charming Parisian garden.

Second visit still blew me away. This time I brought my husband to see Rodin's masterpieces and it was still amazing. I love walking in the garden in winter, mistiness makes it appealing (to me, anyway!). Being able to spend as much time as you like looking at the pieces outside is great; looking at pieces inside a gallery it is difficult to linger sometimes.

Quiet and off the beaten path!. I am not an art enthusiast but I was familiar with Rodin from a course I took in college and everyone has seen pictures of "The Thinker". While this was originally not on my must see list, we were in the area and it was probably going to be a once in a lifetime opportunity. The Thinker was displayed on a pedestal outside in a garden. It was so cool to see the famous statue up close, and there were virtually no crowds so it was a joy to get close and take lots of photos. While reading some of the materials at the museum I learned that the statue was supposed to be in the image of Dante. I also saw another beautiful work titled the "Gates of Hell" that is supposed to represent the entrance to the 'underworld'. After learning about the Dante I was able to follow the theme from Dante's Inferno. If I had done a bit of research before I visited the museum I am sure I would have enjoyed it more but it was still a great visit - even for someone that is not an art enthusiast!

a money trap. Disgusting!. This museum sold us tickets and neglected to inform beforehand that the exhibits were closed for renovation. So, we paid 14EUR to see the garden! Oh yes, their argument was that the tiny ticket had " travaux" (meaning " works") printed on it. Therefore we were supposed to know what we were getting.Unbelievable dishonesty, basically stealing money from naïve visitors. Doesn´t this attitude bring shame upon the Paris museum system?Rodin Museum - never again!

Great sculpture - great setting. wish the gardens had been fully open the day we went. It was very windy and they were not open. The Thinker does not disappoint. Smaller museum, so less crowded and plenty of beautiful sculpture to see. If you frame it right you can get the Thinker, the dome a Les Invalides and a bit of the Eiffel Tower into one shot.

A beautiful sanctuary. All of Rodin's most famous sculptures set in a beautiful house and grounds. You feel as though you are out in the country but can step back out into the streets of Paris. A definite must-see if you admire the work of Rodin.

Check the museum opening times. We didnt realise that the museum was closed on the date we wanted to see it so we just came back another day. The collections are minimal but here you'd be able to see the Le Penseur (The Thinker) and the Gates of Hell -- Rodin's famous pieces among others. The souvenirs were overpriced and limited in variety so we ended up buying our mini Le Penseur in a souvenir shop in the Latin Quarter instead.

Beautiful place. Not to be missed.... Loved this museum. The works are extensive and the grounds are beautiful. Go early and you will have the grounds to yourself before crowds arrive. The outdoor cafe is wonderful and we enjoyed a snack while sitting in the garden. This is very close to the Army Museum and we saw both the same day along with Napoleon's tomb.

An easy visit. A large section of this museum was closed when we visited (a fact about which the staff informed us before we bought our tickets). The section that was open was easy to navigate, see, and appreciate, and all of the signs contained a section in English.

Excellent collection .... The museum contains many works by August Rodin and his student Camille Claudel. The Thinker is on display in the courtyard, as well as bronze casts of The Three Shades and Monument to the Burghers of Calais. There are a 100 or so sculptures on display inside, as well as three painting by Vincent Van Gogh. You need about an hour here and the crowds are fairly large late in the day. This is well worth your time. I would make a return visit. Photography is allowed.
A really different museum. Most of the times I get a bit bored with museums but not in this one. Rodin is one of my favourite artist and the museum is small and nice.

Great despite renovations. The gardens included all of the great pieces, with the Gates of Hell a particular highlight.Obviously has to be a good weather day to enjoy this at the moment.The temporary exhibition was surprisingly fascinating as well.

One of my favorite places in Paris. I love this place! It is the total package, beautiful art and the perfect atmosphere to take it all in. It is included on the museum pass, so you can skip the line and cruise right in. If you do not have a museum pass, I believe I was told the tickets are pretty inexpensive, but you will need to wait in line. As another reviewer mentioned, there are indoor and outdoor exhibits so make sure you pick a day you can take advantage of both. This museum won't disappoint.
Love this museum !. Have been to Musee Rodin and never tire of it. It is easy to navigate and not too tiring. You can enjoy the outer areas as much as inside the building.

Perfect little museum. A great alternative to vast museums with long waiting queues. What I like about this museum is the variety it offers: You can enjoy the inside of the house with paintings, sculptures and letters of the artist. You can admire the beautiful city palace. And you can stroll through the gardens filled with sculptures and old trees. Despite the number of visitors, this place always has a natural calm to it, almost meditative.

Beautiful spot. We love art but aren't major fans of Rodin. Despite that, we thoroughly enjoyed our hours here. The grounds are lovely and the house is full of beautiful things, including multiple versions and studies of major works.

One of the best treasures in Paris!. This museum was exceptional. There was a line to get in, but if you go to the tourist office and buy a museum pass, you can skip the long line of those without tickets. It is comprised of wonderful, famous statues and works of art. It helps you gain an insight into the artist's life and issues he faced. You see where he lived and how the surroundings must have inspired him. There's descriptions both in English and French. There are both inside and outside exhibits so choose a nice day to visit as you won't want to miss a single exhibit.

One of Paris best kept secrets.... Maybe this museum is not the one that you visit the first time in Paris but it is really breathtaking! Auguste Rodin was a genius of soul expression into bronze, stone and plaster also. You won't leave this amazing small museum without falling in love with most of his sculptures! What to say for the world know sculpture Le Penseur as well as Le porte d'Infer (Hell's door). Speechless.. and so many other masterpieces inside.. You may combine this visit with another museum of Paris such as The Orsay which is nearby or the War museum at the neighboring building of Les Invalides. The museum shop sells some great museum copies in case you would like to bring home one of them....

wow. this was my favorite garden. The landscaping was beautiful and the statues (including "the thinker") were amazing. Inside, the art was good, but the building itself is a masterpiece. DEFINITELY GO!

A rich and powerful experience - soak it in! (we did literally in the rain). Last time I was in Paris this museum was closed for rennovations. We made it this time. What a powerful place. I think a museum devoted to one artist is a big gamble but this one hits it out of the ballpark.We were there on a wet and chilly day so had most of the gardens to ourselves. So powerful. The house with the exhibits has an intimate experience for the visitor.Some people had the audio guides but we just liked taking it all in.

Well worth a visit. Others have stated that this would not be a museum that you would want to consider if you were in Paris for only a short period, or even one in your first visit to the city of lights. If you have the time, or are here for a second (or more) visit, this place is very interesting. The gardens were closed when we visited in December (due to weather), but we could see the statues from a distance. The two buildings housing other works by Rodin are worth seeing. We would highly reccommend taking your time to see this place.

Beautiful museum, and far less people than in Louvre. Went there right after vising Luxembourg Gardens, took us 15 minutes walking. There we were happy to see that queue wasn't too long unlike other places in Paris (Notre Dame, Eifel Tower, Louvre). We waited for around 30 minutes to get in (If you have Paris Pass, of course, you dont have to wait at all). Full rate admission is only EUR7.00Museum has stunning front and back gardens, filled with sculptures and beautifully cut trees. Very neat, it summer you could spend there hours and hours just chiling.Permanent collection was very interesting, beautiful statues and busts both big and small. Highlights are the "The Thinker", "The Gates of Hell" and "The Kiss". Because it is not too crowded, and you can actually take your time and have space to look at each piece on display (this wouldnt be possible in Louvre).If you are in Paris, visit Rodin Museum, it is not going to take more thatn 3 hrs of your time. For me, it was definitely time and money well-spent!

WOW...amazing display. It is a small museum but nonetheless a must see. The statues are spread out in the lush gardens and it was a treat to walk from statue to statue and admire the amazing work that Rodin did. Such emotion and expression in each piece. Definitely worth the hour and half to see it all.

What can I say - the thinking mans museum. Fantastic museum where you can stroll freely through the gardens and view the various sculptures. Ther was not huge crowds when we visited - this is a bonus in the French capital museums.I have also wanted to see Rodins sculptures - and I was not disappointed.Well worth a visit. We visited on a multi museum visitor pass.

Rodin Museum and Garden. Every time I come to Paris- this is a must for me- the museum itself is not too large and is a wonderful exhibit of Rodin's work. I must say my most favorite part is the garden(which you can actually go into at a reduced rate for the garden only. It has very large sculptures with The Thinker in the front. You can sit on the bend and ponder life. Especially nice on a beautiful day.

A nice way to spend an hour in Paris. Let's be honest. When you think of Paris museums, you start with the Louvre and Musee D'Orsay. If you are short on time, you should visit those first. We had a longer stay in Paris, so we had time to take in Musee Rodin. It's a small building surrounded by well kept grounds. The Thinker and the the Gates of Hell are the highlights for sure. The museum was not crowded when we visited and it was a nice way to spend an hour walking through the museum and grounds. It's part of your Paris Museum Pass, so that keeps costs down as well.Not a "must do" compared to the other attractions, but this a certainly worthwhile if you have the time.

Quiet gem of a garden. The greatest attraction here was the absence of huge crowds and lines. There museum features a main house and lovely garden with a fountain. The sculptures are located throughout the gardens, and the lack of crowds means you have a chance to get up close and inspect the sculptures. The highlight for me was to see the full gate of hell and to learn about Rodin's lifelong work to put it together.

The Father of Modern Sculpture!. The Rodin Museum was opened in 1919 and is housed in The Villa des Brilliant, a mansion from the 18th C. where the famous sculptor lived from 1895-1917. The collection includes 6.600 sculptures, 8000 drawings, 8000 old photographs and 7000 art objects and it draws 700.000 visitors p/year. Many of Rodin's sculptures are displayed in a natural setting in the government restored rose gardens including his three world famous creations: his first major public commission, The Burghers of Calais, his single best known work, The Thinker, on Rodin's tomb, and, not completed when he died, The Gates of Hell. Inside one can marvel over The Kiss, the Nude of Balzac, the Monument to Balzac( also in the garden), the Prodigal Son, The Crouching Woman ,The Age of Bronze and even a few paintings from Van Gogh and Renoir. All his works, with some initially labeled obscene, were donated to the government in return for turning the place into a museum dedicated to his works. There 's also another site at his former workshop at Hotel Biron.

The most relaxed and joyful times in Paris. This is a great Museum. Most of the great works of art are outside in the garden. You can walk in a great environment, looking at marvellous statutes by Rodin. We were unable to see the works of Camille, because they were lent to another museum. However, we had a great time. It's a different pace than the other museums where people crowd you and bump you to get a look at a piece of art. In this museum you can sit for hours in front of great statutes. The thinker is the most visited pice of art, but you should definitely spend some time on the Gate to Hell...that was my favourite. Spoiler alert> The thinker is actually Dante, thinking about the future of humanity... Isn't that cool!!!

Amazing!. Loved this museum! The grounds were beautiful and there were so many sculptures in the gardens alone. The museum itself was very interesting and amazing to see so many pieces by Rodin. This museum was also not as busy as some other museums when we went, which meant you can actually spend time looking at the pieces without crowds pushing in front of you. Absolutely recommend this fantastic museum!

A must only if you're an avid fan of Rodin.. The museum itself is lovely, combining airy modern building at the entrance with the period mansion at the back through beautiful rose garden in between. It's quite something to gaze at "the kiss" in reality, having seen it so many times in paper. The food at the small bistro is also delicious and good value for money. The museum shop has a large variety of tasteful souvenir of all price range.The location itself is quite far from other places of interest, so it's only for those fans of the great sculpter.

If you're in Paris, you just have to go!. This is one of the glories of Paris. I have visited the museum several times before, but my lady of the moment had not, so we went. It's fresh every time you go. Because of the current rebuilding works, the first third of the museum has been turned into an exhibition of his work in progress, illustrated by photos of his studio etc., which is genuinely interesting. The gardens are spectacular. Rodin's greatest works are displayed where they look best, in the open air, with the wonderful backdrop of the old chateau-like Hotel Biron behind and the great monuments of Paris visible on the horizon. The effect of the garden is quite different in winter, when the trees are bare, from the summer, when the trees are in full leaf and the light is totally different. I always leave the museum itself until last. If you have any affection for art, or sculpture in particular, it's hard to think of anywhere outside Florence that hits you so hard between the eyes in terms of artistic impact. It's sobering to read that (like many great artists, composers etc.) much of his work was actively disapproved of when he presented it. He's also less prolific than many of his contemporaries (try and name ten of his works), mainly because he spent years on each one, changing and gradually perfecting them.I've never quite worked out what the odd Van Gogh or Manet is doing in the museum, but they're nice to see.Some things irritate. It was shut on New Year's Day (why??). The entrance formalities are bureaucratic. One lady takes the money, another sells you your audio guide (a different one for each of the three sections of the museum/exhibition!), another checks your ticket at the entrance and someone else checks it later (three times in all). But you put up with all this nonsense because the overall experience is simply wonderful, memorable and moving.

Beautiful gardens and insight into his works. Arrived about 10.30am and no line but with Paris Pass just walked straight in and the place was quite empty so easy to get around and spend time in the gardens up close to the sculptures. Inside the 2 buildings, likewise easy to get around and see whatever we wanted to see. In the entrance building, exhibit at the moment includes photos of his studios as well as plaster works, marble and bronze etc as he made samples before he final piece giving insights as to how the sculptures were created. Varennes metro is very close to easy to get to as well. Went 2nd January.

Breathtaking. We almost skipped this museum due to lack of time, but we squeezed it in and were glad we did. To see the Thinker up front, as well as the Gates of Hell components made this museum entirely worth it. Plus, the mansion that this museum is housed in is worth a visit, and the gardens are amazing too.

So Beautiful. The sculptures in the Musee Rodin are breathtaking. Just to look at the hands on some of the figures is to be amazed at the details. The setting, both the house and the grounds, are quite lovely. And an added bonus is the Van Gogh and the Monet paintings on the second floor.
A FAVORITE PLACE. Met all expectations...one of my favorite artists - love the sculpture - beautiful setting, beautiful building

Interesting. The lines for the Museum were not that horrible, but once you get inside there is yet another line to get to see Rodin's actual work, and that line was unbelievable. When you get in you get to see whatever guest instillation they have up at that time, and you get to wander the gardens that contain some of his sculpture but his body of work is housed in another building across the gardens and like I said you have to stand in another line with a LONG wait.

Surprisingly good. This museum wasn't too busy on a day that the queues elsewhere are of Disney-esque proportions. The exhibits are simply beautiful and the Van Gogh's were a lively surprise. All in all worth the time.

One of my favorite places in Paris . . .. Visiting the Musee Rodin on a lovely day has all the makings of a "fantasy Parisian day" of viewing epic art and strolling through the french gardens of a hundreds year old mansion. Very romantic! Rodin's sculpture fills the inside of the manor and is sprinkled throughout the pretty, abundant gardens. The sculpture and history is romantic and beautiful, if not a bit erotic. After having a leisurely wander, sitting in the gardens with an espresso (from the cafe) and a book is a lovely way to while away an hour or two. By the way, there's an excellent view of the Eiffel from the gardens. Highly recommend as a must do on a trip to Paris.
Beautiful. Reall lovely museum. The gardens are beautiful and it's a nice change from the madness of other tourist sights in Paris.
Impressive. well worth a visit, go early. As many of the famous sculptures are in the garden, rug up if the weather is cold.

So much better to see them in the bronze. Nearly every single work here is something you would have seen in your art textbooks as a kid - but how much more moving to see them in real life. The audioguide is excellent and the grounds are lovely, even in the rain. Everyone loves The Thinker and the Gates of Hell but Balzac in his many states is more engaging because we don't know him so well. And there are little rabbits everywhere. The renovations should be finished soon but they didn't interrupt our visit - so much to see anyway.

Nice focused museum. I enjoyed my few hours in the Musee Rodin. I was happy to have a smaller scale museum to walk through, focused on one artist/timeframe. While the Louvre/D'Orsay are amazing, its too easy to get museum fatigue there. The Rodin was nice with the beautiful garden (even in the dreary wintertime) and a nice exhibit inside.

Good short tour. Home to the famous thinker sculptor's work.Features well landscaped gardens with statues and good photo taking opportunities.This museum has short queues and sells the paris pass as well, in case one needs to buy those.

Wonderful outdoor stroll. The trees were trimmed much like you would trim a hedge. Rodin did great busts, but the full body statues had unfinished toes. Artists were hired by people with money. Those people were interested in seeing the faces on the sculptures, and that is where the artists focused their energies. Everything else was a necessary evil to finish the job and get paid. Go to the Louvre and you will see Roman and Greek statues where everything including the toes was treated with great detail. Visiting all the major Museums Rodin, D'Orsay, L'Orangerie, Pompidou, Louvre, Quai Branly was educational beyond what you can see by visiting only one.

His home, need I say more. I've seen Rodin sculpture all over the world. Been to the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia. But there is something special about going to an artist's home. To see where they lived, thought and entertained. The gardens are lovely. The museum with many unfinished works, models, casts, etc. is another education into his world. Also it is a great neighborhood in Paris. Very close to Les Invalides

Accessible Museum with fine restaurant. The Rodin Museum is one of the more accessible museums in Paris. The sculptures are distributed throughout a garden that tends to be less crowded than other venues. The restaurant is on the edge of the garden and is quite good and reasonably priced. One tends to be overwhelmed by the Louvre and the Orsay museums but we quite enjoyed this museum. You can easily visit the museum in an 90 minutes to 2 hours. We visited on the First Sunday of the month when the museum was free and even then the crowds were reasonable. Our visit occurred in early November 2014.

Weather and Seasonally Dependant. When we checked out this museum through the Paris Trip Advisor app on our smart phones, it was rated very high. We weren't too sure why but when we got there, we understood why. I would suggest to put it high on your list of "to visit" museums of Paris too. It is unique in that there is an indoor museum component but also an outdoor garden that features many of the pieces throughout. The garden must be beautiful in the warmer months and I am sad that I didn't get the opportunity to visit then. However, even in the middle of winter, it is worth taking a look. The cost of the ticket for just the gardens alone is very modest so if you skip it or not, it isn't a big deal. But I still recommend checking it out.It features only works from sculptor Auguste Rodin but his works are so impressive to see. The museum provides a better feature about the background for his works and background; it is in a workshop fashion. Most definitely recommended to visit anytime of year!

Only did the garden. The garden was pretty cool with all its statues including The Thinker. I docked a start because they have a concrete toilet as part of their display. Someone made a toilet out of concrete and it now sits in a Parisian museum.

There are Two Rodin Museums. Gardens well laid out with a number of sculptures. Be warned - there are two Rodin Museums. The one in the centre of Paris has the Thinker and the Burghers of Calais. The other has the Thinker on Rodin's grave and the Walking Man. The maps your receive have both on them. Don't do as we did and walk the grounds trying to find the other statues!
amazing garden. the museum is beautiful - I love the garden - it is really nice and romantic during the spring Joli musée et joli jardin très agréable pendant l été ou le printemps

Must see: "The Thinker" and "The Gates of Hell". The museum is located in a beautiful old mansion surrounded with manicured gardens filled with Rodin's work including the famous "The Thinker" and "The Gates of Hell". This is my number two favorite place in Paris after the museum d'Orsay

Don't think twice about paying a visit. Rodin was one of the most famous sculptors of any time and his works and home are on display in this park like setting. Go in the spring or summer as the landscaping is beautiful.

More than the Thinker. The Musee is under renovation, but that did not detract from the visit. The gardens are wonderful to stroll around and the building itself is beautiful to explore. You learn a lot about Rodin's other works as well the Thinker and the Kiss.

A lifetime bucket list thrill. Seeing these works first-hand is a real thrill. Spend time in the gardens and get a bite to eat. One could spend an afternoon here if you're a Rodin lover. I would love to have access to seeing the sketches and the other smaller works that led to his masterpieces.
Excellent Sculpture Garden, museum, and newly added area. Always a favorite in Paris, great to see art outside, great Museum and super exposition area; showing the different processes for sculpting.

Small Gardens, Big Impressions. Finally! A beautiful garden with great art pieces without any crowds at all! Go quick before the rest of the travelling world finds out about it. The Museum has a beautiful outdoor garden with many of Rodin's most famous sculptures. See the Thinker (with Les Invalides behind him), the Burghers together, and separately dotted around the gardens and the Gates of Hell, among many others. There's also an indoor area with usually a photography exhibition or something. Spend some time there but don't waste your time on the cafe please!

Midnight in Paris location. This is a small but wonderful museum near the Invalides. Even in October the roses were in bloom.
