Makes you think. A small oasis of calm containing the most famous works of Rodin situated both indoors and out. Next to Les Invalides, it is near the Metro or an easy walk from Musee d'Orsay. We're really glad to have added this on to our itinerary.

Should be a Priority!. If I had to choose between Musee D'Orsay (which is of course excellent) and Rodin, I would choose Rodin. It is small, more personal, and the sculptures outside in the gardens add that extra dimension. Especially for people who aren't "Art Buffs", the experience of seeing a beautiful sculpture in 3D can be much more fulfilling than a hanging painting that you probably have seen in print before. It is also housed where his working studio was which adds that extra historical touch.

Monsieur Sculpture. f skipping the crowds and heat at the Louvre are your bag - try this gorgeous old hotel and gardens that Rodin himself donated circa 1916 to the French government. A massive collection of his art is housed both inside and outside. Don't miss the rose gardens and lawns either.

An oasis of peace and beauty in the centre of Paris. The Rodin museum is one of the hidden gems of Paris. The art work is exceptional and the garden is an oasis of tranquility. It is very rarely crowded so one can really appreciate the collection. We loved lingering on the grounds, which were so peaceful. I would highly recommend it.

The Museum We Enjoyed the Most in Paris. Musée Rodin was the museum that we enjoyed the most in Paris, most probably because we had almost no expectations when we went. Thanks to our Museum Pass, we did not have to wait at the entrance (but the queue was not too long anyway).This museum is created by Rodin himself back in 1916 and included not only his work but also his private art collection, library, his archive of letters and manuscripts. The building itself, the famous Hotel Briton is dating early 18th century, it was used as a private house, girls' school and was finally rented as a workshop to artists such as Jean Cocteau, Henri Matisse, İsadora Duncan, poet Rilke. Combined with awesome sculptures of Rodin, this place is full of art, history and nature. The gardens are amazing: inside there is a café, you can buy some drinks, something light to eat and spend the whole day in the gardens... As it's not as crowded as d'orsay or Louvre, you can take as much time as you want to enjoy the museum, without any hussle. Famous sculptures of Rodin such as Le Penseur and Le Baiser are breathtaking.... This gem of art and history must be a part of any Paris visit, you won't regret it....

Quite gorgeous!. We did not visit the inside of the museum, but spent quite a long time exploring the magnificent grounds and the beautiful sculptures outside. Well worth the wait on line. I would explore the inside of the museum also if I went back.

Rodin the Sculptor. This is my second visit to the Musée Rodin. The musée is delightful, the grounds in particular can make for a lovely, relaxing afternoon. In fact, the grounds are the largest, privately held in the city of Paris. The grounds are definitely family friendly. It was a lovely day for our tour, hopefully when you go to visit the weather will be nice. You can see Invalidies and the Eiffel Tower from the grounds. The musée is currently under renovation. So, parts of Hôtel Biron are closed at the moment. I would encourage you not to let you discourage you from the visit. Rodin was a prolific sculpture and made f 6,500 sculptures and 6,500 drawings and other art works and the works of many of his contemporaries that made up his own private collection. There is still a lot to see and enjoy.Hôtel Biron was built in the early 18th century. It spent time as a school for young girls and then in 1904 it was handed to the French state. It was after this that Rodin was a tenant, along with Henri Matisse, Joan Coctuea (a writer), Isadora Duncan (a dancer) and Rainer Maria Rilke (a poet). Je took over the whole building in 1911. It was handed over to the state later and turned into a museum two years after he died.Don’t miss “The Thinker”, “The Gates of ****” or his private collection. It appeared that some of his own private collection maybe loaned out at the moment. In particular his Van Gogh paintings are at the D’Orsay at the special exhibit. Just another excuse to see another lovely Paris museum!
Sculpture in a variety of settings.. This permanent exhibition is well worth a visit. Numerous sculptures are thoughtfully displayed in the courtyard, gardens and main building.

Great Art, Interesting Story. The story of how this came to be a museum is probably unique, and therefore fascinating.Personally, I love Rodin's work, the energy and the art he brings to sculpture (as opposed to a more workmanlike classical style like Michelangelo's). The gardens at Musee Rodin offer an interesting progression through Rodin's work, showing the individual pieces he worked with before you get to the stunning Gates of Hell and Burghers of Calais, which contain individual figures you recognize from other sculptures. It's nearly spiritual to see The Thinker.The garden, as its name implies, is outside and therefore subject to all the fickleness of the outdoors. In our case, it was alternately raining and mosquitoing. This is not in any way the museum's fault, but a factor to be considered in your visit.
One to Visit. For the thinking man, a must to see, the Gardens and House equally excellent, take yout time hop off the bus and take in
dissapointing. I wouldn't go here unless you have been everywhere else first ,its just boring.The place is not well maintained ,doesn't have a lot of works.

The garden is very nice. Charming with a very nice garden where you can enjoy several of Rodins great works. There is also an amazing rose garden. The museum itself is interesting, but had fewer of the larger pieces than I expected. If you want information be sure to take an audio guide. The written information around the museum is not much at all.There's a small cafe in the garden which is nice for refreshments.

Don't miss it!. The museum is fantastic without going to see the special exposition. You can stroll the gardens and see the sculptures throughout the grounds. Parts of the gardens are under construction but there is still plenty to see!! One thing I didn't like was that the museum shop closed 5 minutes after the museum closed. I thought museum shops were in business to MAKE money. Most museums I have been to close their shops at least 15 minutes after the exhibits close. I would have bought more at the shop but I wasn't going to make a decision in the 3 minutes I had in the shop. People would spend money if they had the chance.Overall, I loved the museum and would go again.

The Rodin, one of the best museums in Paris. Most tourist rush to the Louvre or other museums, but the Rodin is a MUST. There are so many sculptures that you have seen over the years and in many cases are not familiar with the artist.Fortunately the Brooklyn Museum has a nice collection of Rodin, but to have the opportunity to see so much of his art work is a real treat. The Thinker is world famous, and when you see it in person you can not stop staring at it. This feeling is repeated over and over again as you see the wide range of sculptureand art work. What a treat. PLEASE make time to visit the Rodinand you won't regret it.

Pleasant Surprise. What a lovely museum! The setting was so different - walking through the rose gardens and seeing famous sculptures dispersed throughout the grounds. The gardens and the museum building were gorgeous and well maintained. The Invalides and Eiffel Tower can be seen from the museum. This was one of my favorite stops in Paris!
Great Little Museum. Great collection of pieces spread out primarily in the garden. Certainly worth the trip and a nice break from the city to walk through the gardens at a slower pace.

The garden and cafe are inviting and relaxing. Whenever we are in Paris, we manage to squeeze in a visit to the Musée Rodin for lunch or tea coupled with a stroll through the gardens. This gives us a chance to soak in the atmosphere and admire Rodin's monumental sculptures for the very reasonable 2euro entry price into the garden. The only frustration is the need to stand on line to get a garden pass- unless one has purchased a museum pass. Go early or mid-lunch hour to avoid long lines.
Very nice museum. If you like sculpture this is a must-see museum. Packed with work of Rodin and Camille Claudel in a great setting and garden.
Must go!. Must go for travellers! If you are bored with the normal stuff, this is a place for some peace and amazing statues! I love the Door to Hell!

More than an art museum, a chance to see Rodin's home as well. Rodin lived and worked here and consequently, it's not just a place to see his works but also an opportunity to walk in his footsteps and learn about how he lived. It was very peaceful to stroll the gardens and a welcome retreat after the crowds at the Orsay. We purchased the ticket that allowed access to both museums the same day and found it worked -- if you do the Orsay as soon as they open, spend about three hours, go have a relaxing lunch and get to the Rodin about 3:00 or 3:30, you will have plenty of time to see the Rodin as well. There was a wonderful Robert Mapplethorpe exhibit that we enjoyed very much. There is a small cafe out in the garden where you can have a tea or coffee or a snack and enjoy your time in the gardens a little longer. WONDERFUL sculptures. I would go back here again anytime!

a peaceful retreat. This is more than a museum. It's one of the principal spaces where Rodin lived and worked, and his outsize presence can still be felt, especially in the expansive gardens, where it's easy to imagine the sculptor pacing out the design of his next masterpiece. Even those not wholly enamored of Rodin's particular style may come away persuaded by the works on offer here, which include his remarkable "Gates of Hell" (part of an unrealized commission) and the transcendent "The Kiss." And whether you think you will or not, you're bound to have a selfie taken beneath "The Thinker." The house itself offers valuable insights into both Rodin's process and the work of his contemporaries, with some pieces by Camille Claudel that are the equal of the master's. The grounds are also home to a lovely cafe, which unlike so many museum restaurants in Paris is an actual cafeteria, so there's no problem with service, and there is more than ample seating outside (less so on a rainy day). After your visit to the museum, take a walk through the surrounding neighborhood, once the city's most elegant address, with block-long mansions that once belonged to storied families, now serving as government offices. The Invalides and its grassy esplanade are also just around the corner.
Bucket List Item. Simply a wonderful place to visit. Be impressed by all you see and enjoy a walk or sit down and relax in the gardens

A Gem!. How wonderful it was to traipse through the beautiful extensive gardens, also to know that beneath the figure of "le Penseur" Rodin and his wife are buried. Inside the private home are not only more of Rodin's sensuous sculptures but also paintings by Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh and Camille Claudet. A great photo opportunity is to imitate the embrace of " Le Baiser", The Kiss.

not to be missed. this museum was one of the highlights of our trip to paris. the sculptures are magnificent, and the gardens are breathtaking -- there is even a small cafe in the garden to stop and have a drink or a bite. it's a small museum, which for me, makes the visit more manageable; i can really take in the work. when we were there there was a temporary exhibit comparing the work of rodin with robert mapplethorpe. and the main house and garden is a great collection of rodin's work: mostly sculpture, but also drawings and paintings.and for all it's beauty and impressive collection, it was surprisingly uncrowded.
The thinker. Walking around on the grounds on a beautiful sunny day and seeing the works of Rodin was a afternoon well spent.

Beautiful on a nice day. a lot of the museum is outside around the grounds, which is really great on a nice day. Didn't experience the crowds as is typical in other attractions, plenty of space since a lot is outside. Get the audio device, it really helps maximize the experience.

Quiet, inspiring museum. An entire museum dedicated to the French sculptor, Rodin. The museum has a small entrance fee; however, the gardens are free. Not as crowded as the Louvre, the Rodin museum offers a nice respite from the hustle and bustle of Paris. The main attraction is Rodin's, "The Thinker". Located in the gardens, the statue is awe inspiring as are many true to life sculptures. Be sure to take the quick 30 minute stop while visiting Invalides or Eiffel Tower. You will not regret it!

A Breath of Fresh Air. Near the Orsay , schedule this museum after for a nice , slow uncrowded visit .Right near Napoleon's Tomb and Invalides as well and the French government / military buildings , you enter a beautiful courtyard after admission and Oilla ! there he is " The Thinker " out in one of the many gardens . His size is overwhelming along with several other outdoor sculptures by Rodin in the courtyard . The museum is never crowded . No flash on your camera , please and you can photograph . Inside is the " Dante's Gates of Hell " - simply majestic along with multiple sculptures even paintings by the master.Relax and experience a once in a lifetime experience and again at a nice relaxing pace .

Loved the garden and sculptures. I went later in the afternoon so it was less crowded and more serene. Walking the grounds was so peaceful. Sculptures are just absolutely lovely and surprisingly erotic and dark stuff Rodin had! There was a temp exhibit comparing Rober Mapplethorpe and Rodin's work side by side which was interesting. Overall, it was a memorable visit and I highly recommend.

A gem not to be missed. My sole intent was to see the Thinker by Rodin. I was not disappointed as it sits proudly as you enter the gardens.I was pleasantly surprised at what beautiful gardens and exhibits this museum has. The crowds are missing and many of Rodin's sculptures are displayed throughout manicured gardens, the nicest of which we saw in Paris in May. A relaxing cafe sits alongside the gardens allowing one to grab a coffee or bit of lunch and contemplate the quiet and beauty of Rodin's works sitting in nature settings.The mansion displays many additional works of Rodin and others.This was a highlight of our Paris trip and provided many beautiful pictures.

A Brilliant Museum.. It was an awful, wet day but this great museum really brightened things up. To see Rodin's work close up was awe inspiring. The gardens are beautiful, I would love to spend more time there on a fine day.
Best Museum in paris. Not very crowded, unlike the more popular museums, gardens are very tranquil, must see on any Paris trip.
Amazing place. Amazing inside, you need to see it, we were lucky wth weather it was sunny and it was great to drink cup of cofee in park.I really recomend it to include in your stay

Peaceful. I really enojoyed this museum. It was very different to other as it comprised of paintings and sculptures. It was great to see Rosin sculptures as well as sculptures from other artists. Some of the sculptures are outside. This is lovely because you can walk around the gardens and take in the weather if it's a nice day. For a different experience of a museum this one is worth a visit.

Sculpture by the Master. My very favorite art form is sculpture and so it's not a surprise that my very favorite museum in Paris is the Musee Rodin. Some of his most famous pieces are there; Gates of Hell, The Thinker, The Kiss, The Burghers of Calais, The Gossips. You can get incredibly close to many of the pieces. I had been once before when you could touch them if a docent didn't see you (don't worry...I didn't) but now some of the pieces are encased in a transparent container. The museum is set in a house (mansion by some standards) with a lovely garden. Be sure to walk through the garden because that's where you'll find The Thinker, Gates of Hell and the Burghers of Calais. Rodin's sculptures are powerful pieces. You can feel the emotion in each piece of work. If you like sculpture this is a must see.

A little gem. Exquisite in all aspects.. The architecture and grounds of this museum are worth the visit alone. When you add the art is a place with soul and heart. Have a caffe in the cute restaurant. Plan to sit in the gardens and just relax.

Relaxing area. Musee Rodin is not one of the best places in Paris but it is still a nice area to spend a hour and half or so. The paintings and sculptures inside are decent but nothing spectacular. The garden for Musee Rodin, however, is a very relaxing and well landscaped place.

To see The Thinker is person was quite awe inspiring.... Musee Rodin was a must see visit during my journey to France. The Gates of Hell and the Burghers of Calais were a big focus for me as well. I've seen a cast of Burghers in DC at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden and was always fascinated by that particular work of art. Many of Rodin's pieces impressed me and will definitely be a focal point upon my return to Paris.

Beautiful gardens and museum. We visited this museum today because it was raining and we had the Paris Museum Pass and decided to give it a try. The inside museum was okay, had some nice pieces and not too big to wear you out, but the gardens and outdoor statues are the main attraction. All the major works are outdoors and right now in June all the beautiful roses are blooming - it was exceptional. My tip is to even consider skipping the indoor museum and heading straight for the gardens. Also note there are bathrooms in the building at the entrance where the special exhibit is housed and one in the main museum but this one has ONE toilet for the ladies. I would use the one at the street entrance or there is another larger one in the garden (?!) not far from a cafe with gardens view.

Sculpture at its finest. I have visited this museum many times and am always moved by the great "Burghers of Calais" and the "Gates of Hell" sculptures. They are magnificent.I think the work of Camille Claudel and her story appear to have been downplayed over recent years.

Favorite place in Paris. Rodin's home is a beautiful, small museum. Walk through the gardens and sip some coffee at the backyard cafe to imagine Paris as it was years ago. Study the sculptures and enjoy
Think and Kiss!. Yes, it is awesome to view The Thinker and The Kiss up close and personal! There are many, many other wonderful examples of Rodin's varied work here as well.

Nice museum. nice museum for a rapid visit if you have just some hours. Gives a proper vision of the artist and its superb genius in an excellent scenario, his house. Beatiful gardens to finish the visit. Don´t miss it if you love art.

Fantastic on a Nice Day. What a fantastic museum to visit on a nice day, since half the museum is the garden.The mansion now housing the museum was built in the early 1700's, and Rodin rented space there, using the building as his studio in the early 1900's. The French government bought the building and Rodin negotiated being able to stay there by donating many of his sculptures. As such, it's a very unique space, providing context not usually included when viewing an artist's work.The garden is amazing to wander through on a nice day. Rodin placed his works throughout, and seeing them in an outdoor setting is fantastic. The works of art themselves are not to be missed, the level of detail in his sculptures show a masterful understanding of the human form.There are so many fantastic museums in Paris, but this one is not to be missed.

Truly Humbling and Fantastic. Tucked on a side street really, we dined at a wonderful cafe prior to coming to this Rodin. It is a small Musee, yet wonderful! The garden is lovely to stroll around and take in the Parisian lifestyle. The magnitude of his sculptures from large to small was amazing!

Very under-rated and worth a look. This one is a real treat both inside and out. The parklands and gardens are filled with statues and the museum is packed with items of interest. I only stopped in to use the bathroom and ended up staying here for an hour, and then brought the rest of my group back later. Go on a sunny day to see the gardens and fountain at their best.

A perfect small museum. A perfect small museum full of major art. We enjoyed the gardens so much we went back twice in the same week. We listened to the audio tour which gave us the breath and depth of Auguste Rodin. This is a must do in Paris.

Thinker. Came to see the thinker and found much more. The grounds were beautiful and the statues impressive. Make sure to go upstairs in the house, as there were other artworks. I loved the Van Gogh. You can spend a day here or make a quick trip. Worth the stop.

Gardens and lunch!. We were exhausted from lots of walking. The initial security line wasn't too bad (we had the Museum pass) but the line to get into the actual house/museum was very long and moving slowly with no cuts for the museum pass. We had a delicious lunch in the café and spent a lovely time in the gardens. Because part of the the museum is being renovated, a number of sculptures have been moved outside, under the dense grove of trees. It was uncrowded, peaceful and beautiful!

A classic. I love this museum. The gardens are lovely and the new exhibition rooms are gorgeous. We recently saw the Mapplethorpe -Rodin which was expertly curated and exhibited. Well worth a visit while you are in Paris. If you have a Paris museum pass you can skip the long lines.

Garden delight. the sculpture garden here is really a special place. you can see Rodin's work outside and imagine how he must have lived and worked in the lovely house. there is also a nice cafe and you can have a coffee and lunch in the garden.
Rainy, but beautiful. visited Rodin's house and gardens. Gorgeous sculptures and grounds. House sometimes has a wait if it gets busy.

Absolutely a must!. One can visit Rodin museum for two reasons. First for the excellent selection of Rodin's masterpieces. Everything you need to know about this great sculptor is there. Second, you will take a refreshing break from Paris hectic traffic and noise. The gardens are terrific, so does the silence that spreads all over the site. You won't see hundreds of tourists there, nor queues for a ticket. That could make a third reason itself, i may add...

A gem of an art gallery. This is a great little museum for art afficionados and novices alike. Rodin used the Hotel Biron as his workshop during his life and left his entire collection of sculptures and some paintings by Renoir and Van Gogh to the state, on condition that they use the building as a museum to display his works.The gardens are magnificent, with sculptures dotted throughout, and the house is beautiful in its own right, as well as containing a treasure trove of studies and plaster casts of his works, along with the paintings he acquired from other artists.Rodin's larger bronze pieces are the big drawcards - the Gates of Hell is magnificent, as is the Burghers of Calais and the famous The Thinker. But the numerous smaller pieces inside the house are just as fascinating.You could breeze through in an hour if you're short on time, but could also easily spend longer dallying in the beautiful gardens if you're so inclined.There is a garden cafe - we didn't eat there but the food looked and smelt really good. Prices were in the usual tourist-inflated range, but there isn't much choice in the immediate neighbourhood.Buy tickets online and skip the queues - we bought a double ticket that gave discounted entry to both Musee Rodin and Musee d'Orsay. The two sites are about a 10-15 minute walk apart, so easy to cover both in one day.

Even for a non-art lover, I really liked Musee Rodin!. Let me start by saying I am not an art aficionado. However, when in Paris recently, I did want to visit some of their famed art museum. I specifically had Musee Rodin on the list as I wanted to see The Thinker. I was able to see this sculpture but I also enjoyed the rest of the garden and the work in the house.Let me also recommend the Paris Museum Pass. I was waiting in line on the sidewalk and a representative walked the line asking if anyone had the pass. I was able to get out of the line, walk past everyone else, and right in to the museum. The pass is highly valuable if you have limited time!

A late review, from May 2013. I forgot to write. Very little to say save the word: Go. A great little museum of a great sculptor, simple as this. Do not forget to read about the man and his work prior to visiting else you will not really be able to understand and enjoy his work to its full magnitude, the Gates of Heaven by him is a world renowned masterpiece but you must have prior knowledge to appreciate its subtle details. Also take your time to stroll the gardens, great enjoyment. See Wikipedia for details.

excellent exhibit with Rodin and Maplethorpe. incredible comparison between Rodin and Maplethorpe's work- do not miss. There art sculptures and photos organized together with very informative and evocative examples of maplethorpe's photos as compared to Rodin's sculptures .

Semi-hidden gem. On a sunny day, this place has everything to spend half a day. Fascinating art exhibition, stunning building and beautiful gardens right in the centre of Paris. A total retreat. Mix with a lunch or dinner in nearby rue Cler. A welcome breather from a visit to the Eiffel Tower which is a 15-20 minute stroll away.
Maplethorpe/Rodin exhibit. Small but interesting comparison of the two artists and their shared erotic focus. I wished it were more extensive with more written information.

Spend 2 euros and visit the Garden(The Gate of Hell is a Must See Item). If your time in Paris or budget were limited, I suggest that you should just visit the Garden. You can find the majority of Rodin's signature works in the Garden.

The gardens, the man, the sculpture.. I could have spent an entire day in the cool of the gardens among Rodin's sculptures. The gates of hell took my breath away. I felt as if I had been transported to heaven. Next time I will take a book, blanket, baguette, wine & cheese.

Well worth the visit. Many of Rodin's works have been gathered together and are housed in the Hotel Biron in the 7th Arrondisssement. Its an 8 to 9 block walk from the Musee D'Orsay. Its a small museum, and it took us about one half hour to get in. Rodin's sculpture of his lover, Camille Claudel in bonnet is on the top floor. Major bronze sculptures including "The Thinker" and "The Burghers of Calais" are in the outside garden. Definitely worth a visit.

A quiet inspirational garden. The metro will leave you at 200 meters from the museum entrance. Lines may be long but they move fast. We had lunch at the corner and waited for opening tome. The art is of course fantastic and the gardens with all the flowers and the sculptures, delightful to spend a whole afternoon if you have the time

Fascinating. I loved the Rodin Museum. It was fairly close to our hotel, and since we had a museum pass, we wanted to check it out. There was a special Maplethorpe exhibit while we were there. The exhibit compared and contrasted Maplethorpe's photography with Rodin's sculptures. It was fascinating. Afterwards, we visited Napoleon's tomb, which was just across the street.

Eye Opening. The museum is well laid out to highlight both the scope and chronology of Rodin's work. There are stairs involved and many of the works are in the "garden", so anticipate some walking and possibly weather issues (although they provide umbrella's if needed).

love that Rodin!. I have always loved Rodin and the Musee Rodin-the outdoor gardens especially! They are currently playing with the inside-unnecessarily in my opinion! I miss the works by Rodin's companion-these plus various Rodins are not currently on display while they "reorganize"the museum. They are asking for donations, but the rationale for the shutting down of part of the museum made no sense!

Not a big fan. Of all the museums I've seen in Paris this ranks near the bottom of my list. I understand that many people like it, the exhibits just weren't the type of art I like. If you're into, Impressionism then you'll be very pleased with it.

Beautiful rose garden!. Many know about the Rodin museum, with the incredible sculptures, but the surprise may be the added beauty of the roses amidst the artwork. Wandering through the rose garden is a lovely way to spend a sunny Paris afternoon!

Beautiful. See Rodin's sculptures as he wanted you to view them in his museum and stunning gardens. I found this was a much better way to appreciate his work than in the Musee d'Orsay. The gardens were quite peaceful and overall the Museum was fairly quiet, unlike so many other Paris attractions on our visit. We had to leave for a walking tour otherwise would have spent more time relaxing in the gardens.

Small and nice museum!. We visit the museum because we are admires of Rodin.We enjoy the garden and the peacefulness you feel. The inside of the house it's under construction and the exhibition needs improvent.

I love this small museum. This is Rodin's house turned into a museum. Nice sculptures in the house and in the garden. I just love Rodin's work (Le baiser) (le Penseur) the hands representing the church. I have visited several times over the years with my American students and my children. I am planning to go back this summer.

Romantic sculpturing at its best. Rodin art is remarkable and here one's admiration and eagerness for his art is fully satisfied. Additionally, the garden is gorgeous and a beautiful place to relax surrounded by art.

A beautiful sculpture garden in downtown Paris.. We walked past this museum on a Saturday and it was closed, so we returned on a Monday and had such an enjoyable time seeing Rodin's works set in a beautiful flower-filled Garden. There was a Maplethorpe exibition there also and we had never appreciated the link between their works. The smaller sculptures in the house are worth seeing also. Do not miss this museum!

Loved this elegant museum. This fabulous museum features a large garden exhibit as well as interior space. Although crowded it handled the people expertly and one came away with an overwhelming sense of Rodin and his work. Highly recommended.

Beautifully done. This was a lovely, smaller museum. Part of a larger tour group, my fellow travelers and I opted to remain in the garden and enjoy the statuary and plantings there rather than wait in line to tour the inside. The weather was perfect for it, too. Worthwhile, if for nothing else than to see "The Thinker" in person.
Amazing gardens. We enjoyed the gardens so much that we did not bother with the museum. On our next visit, we will go into the museum that has so much history.

Beautiful Gardens. Musee Rodin is primarily an outdoor exhibit to be sure to pick a day where the weather will allow you to appreciate it. I was not familiar with all of Rodin's art and this museum does a great job of displaying his work as well as some contemporary work. Well worth the visit.

Go early or very late. Like everything in Paris, be the first in line or in this case, get there about 5pm, they close at 5:45p. Lovely gardens including display of several rose bushes/vines, all of Rodin principal works are there, plus a few Van Gogh paintings! Easy to hit Invalides before or after as it is next door. Use La Tour Maubourg station line 8.

One of Our Favourite Attractions. The Musee Rodin is a gorgeous museum located in the artist's former house and gardens. It is a loving repository of Rodin's work and located near the Quai d'Orsay Museum and the Invalides. We loved the grounds which were park like and had wonderful examples of his work such as the Burghers of Calais, There was a special ticket offering which provided a discount on admission to the Quai d'Orsay Museum.

Favorite. Museum. In. Paris.. I am a big Rodin fan, but what's more they've done right by him, what with the garden and all. I sat and meditated on a small bench off to the side by "The Thinker." Amazing. Just so well done and so true to what makes his work shine. So many iconic pieces: The Kiss, the Thinker, The Gates of Hell. And some other minor works that were equally as enjoyable to see. Also there were a few by Camille Claudel if I remember correctly. Catch a scene shot here in Woody Allen's MIDNIGHT IN PARIS!

There was only oen Rodin, Don't miss it while in Paris. There was only one Rodin and you can see pieces of his work in other parts of the world but seeing his art displayed in his home is the best way to enjoy it.

A gem. What do Mapplethorpe and Rodin have in common? 2 seemingly disparate artists-one French sculptor, one American photographer-working a century apart reveal similarities in representing a classical body ideal at a special exhibit at the museum. Be sure not to miss Camille Claudel's sculptures on the second floor of the châteaux -
Gardens are beautiful. Gardens make this museum very special. Be sure to see Napoleon's tomb, right across the street. It is often missed and is very special.
"The Kiss". Great museum representing Rodin sculptures. Beautiful gardens showcasing Rodin. Loved the statue of The Kiss.

Lovely place - hidden gem. It's a hidden gem in the middle of paris. The gardens are very pretty.
I would definitely recommend a visit there.

Excellent place to spend some time. If you like Rodin sculptures this is the place to go. The museum is nice but the place to be is the garden. There are sculptures throughout the garden that you can get up close and personal with. We were surprised by the amount of the Mapplethorpe photographs on display though they were facinating. This museum was not as crowded as others and the garden is a great escape from the crowds of Paris. I hightly recommend this museum.

The Gates to Paradise!. Contrast the pandemonium at the Louvre with the tranquility at the Musee Rodin... find the serenity of Rodin's amazing sculptural work set in the gardens. Allow time to study the work "the gates of Hell"…so remarkably detailed.

Off the beaten path. The Musee Rodin is also a must see. The line was manageable, but as always you have to get there early. It was a good experience because you're allowed to explore the interior exhibits and the gardens at your own pace. We went on a really beautiful spring day so spending time in the gardens just enhanced the experience.

A must See. This is a must see while in Paris. This museum really helps you understand the artistic movements going on in Paris. I really didn't understand sculpture or impressionist art very well, but this museum was helpful in developing a better understanding and an appreciation.

Wonderful Musee! Beautiful Gardens!. We loved Musee Rodin! I have been to Paris multiple times and did not visit until now. Absolutely loved this museum! The Rodin sculptures are gorgeous and so detailed. The gardens are beautiful and will give you several worthy photo opportunities. Take time to sit, relax, and enjoy the surroundings. Auguste Rodin's work is remarkable!

Small museum, delightful garden. If you want to see Rodin's Thinker, the Kiss or the gates of hell, use your museum pass and go here. We enjoyed that it was smaller and less crowded after visiting the Louve and Orsay. They had another artist that I had been reading about as a special attraction. Since it is not a permanent attraction I won't review it.

Great smaller museum. My husband and I loved the Rodin Museum and gardens. I didn't know much about the artist before going, but now I think he was a pretty cool dude. The audio guide was helpful, although there were a few pieces I was curious about that didn't have any information. My husband (an artist) was amazed by the Gates of Hell, and my favorites were "The Kiss" and "The Burghers of Calais." The museum was also right next to the Invalides and nearby a cute little neighborhood with good restaurants.

CLOSED ON MONDAYS. We walked here from the Eiffel Tower and entered through the glass doors marked entrance only to be manhandled out along with other potential visitors by a little arrogant man the just kept shouting FERME, FERME..... If it was closed why were the doors open, no sign on the door and also why were other visitors inside taking pictures and having a good look round.When we returned the following day it wasn't much better, a different control freak was on the door taking pleasure in randomly stopping people entering the doors, causing a queue on the pavement which made passers by walk into the road. Then once in the museum you had to queue again to get into the main part of the museum.Worst museum in Paris!

Un petit tresor!. Tucked away, yet at the same time very accessible is the charming Musee Rodin. If you want part of the wonderful ambiance of a Parisian museum without the crowds that you encounter at the Louvre or Musee d'Orsay then this little museum is to be highly recommended.

Rodin & Mapplethorpe. This gorgeous museum and grounds, a former grand hotel and the final home and atelier of Rodin, is a cultural treasure in Paris. Now on show In their Gallery are the photographs of the celebrated, and sometimes contoversial American photographer, Robert Mapplethorpe. This exhibit, on til Septeber 21, 2014, is expertly curated. It highlights Mapplethorpes approach in photograhing the human form, and reveals the strong influence of Rodin's sculpture.

Enjoyable. The gardens with, "The Thinker", as the main attraction was beautiful. The roses were out of this world huge and smelled heavenly. There was a special exhibit inside while we were there which is often the case; exhibits are routinely swapped out. The Museum pass is a must purchase so that you can go to all of the museums.
Delightful. We loved this. Auguste Rodin lived in this home and created his remarkable art here. Seeing it here and walking the beautiful gardens was a lovely experience on a sunny afternoon.

Go visit!. The best part of the Musee Rodin is the gardens because they are filled with his sculptures, most of the pieces are from the sculptors own studio. As you wander the pathways you come upon The Thinker, Balzac, Ugolin in the middle of a pool, The Burghers of Calais and The Three Shades in the rose garden. Inside the a Hotel Biron is the permanent collection of bronzes and plaster casts by Rodin and works by some of his contemporaries, including Camille Claudel. The lovely old buildings and the gardens help to make it one of the most relaxing museum visits I have ever experienced, and it did not feel excessively crowded.

Musee Rodin. The gardens are well laid out giving prominence and position to all the statues, showing them of to the their best. the Kiss is in the house which we didn't visit.The restaurant in the garden is good value for money and interestingly stocked as all goof French café/restaurants.

I think you should go!. A little out of the way, but still close to all the action. Very well kept grounds, with Rodin's famous "Thinker"as the standout feature. The museum is filled with outstanding works on several levels, but without having the feel of a "museum"- much more intimate. The surprise was rounding a corner to find a van Gogh on a wall, without any fanfare. Amazing!

My favorite museum. This is my favorite museum in Paris (maybe my favorite in Europe!) The sculpture garden is not to be missed. (The Thinker was the highlight). We bought a Museum Pass and would highly recommend that. It is a smaller venue and includes many Impressionist paintings, but can be "done" in a few hours and not feel overwhelmed. A beautiful museum, a beautiful experience.

May is the best time!. The roses were in bloom and the weather was perfect to enjoy this loveliest of museums. If you love gardens and sculpture, this museum will be a favorite, as it was for my daughter and me over Memorial Day weekend.

Chez Rodin. The house and grounds of the Musée Rodin were well worth fitting in to our Paris trip! Here sits the famous "Thinker," as well as many of Rodin's lesser-known works. The house itself is an elegant piece of history, and we learned a great deal about its former occupants. The weather on our visit was unfortunately a bit mixed - would definitely recommend catching the museum on a nice day, in order to really enjoy the gardens with their sculptures. The setting is idyllic. A real jewel of a museum.
Beautiful Museum. The Rodin Museum is in a wonderful house and garden. A must visit museum in a wonderful part of Paris.

beautiful Rodin. beautiful pièces gardens house, pictures from Mattlethorpe
finally not an expensive museum and beautiful surroundings
Musee Rodin. The exterior sculptures and gardens were our favorites! Many pieces inside, including artwork collected by Rodin of other artists. Worth the trip, on the Paris Museum Pass.

Love this museum!. Even with half the museum closed due to renovation, this is still one of my favorites in Paris. (It also helps to have Museum Pass so you don't have to wait in line to buy tickets!) The grounds are just beautiful and give you the opportunity to view the sculptures from all angles. The studies inside give real insight to Rodin's creative process. Whie the Orsay has many of my favorite paintings and the Louvre is, well, the Louvre - this museum gives you the chance to be quite intimate with these great works of art without being overwhelmed.

Intimate Beauty. Many museums are so vast that their collections blend into a mishmash, often resulting in an experience so overwhelming that the observer is left almost exhausted. Not so with the Musee Rodin! Peaceful gardens are a backdrop for many of Rodin's sculptures. The galleries offer an intimate look at not only Rodin's work but also Camille Claudel, Rodin's mistress, herself an exquisite sculptor. The museum's atmosphere is unhurried, allowing one to savor beauty at it's best. Highly recommended.

Lovely (but better in winter without the crowds!). I've been to Musee Rodin twice now. Once in December and once in May. Unfortunately, as it's a small space, I think it's better when there are fewer people there and you get to appreciate the pieces better. But it's a beautiful place and the gardens are wonderful too.

Rodin with Van Gogh Thrown In!. I loved this lovely mansion with its astounding collection of Rodins....the gardens are glorious, full of flowers and quiet little nooks. Don't miss the great bonus of the Van Gogh paintings inside!

Art meets nature. I can't conceive a better environment for Rodin's masterpieces. You can find his sculptures both inside the beautiful and simple palace and outside, in the gardens merging in with the trees and lakes. I've visited nearly 70% of all museums in Paris over the years yet this one remains my all-time favourite.

Highly recommend. We were surprised at how much we enjoyed this museum. The crowds were small and the Paris museum pass was given priority. The walk through the statue lined gardens was a real highlight. There is some restoration work happening on the top floor but don't let that stop you enjoying the rest of this great museum.

Glad I visited this museum. I was lucky to visit the museum on a sunny day. The museum is Rodin's house and garden containing most of his masterpieces such as The Gates of Hell, The Thinker and The Three Shades. A significant part of the museum was under reconstruction but to compensate free entry to a temporary exhibition of works by Robert Mapplethorpe juxtaposed with Rodin sculptures was included in the ticket. Not as crowded as some of the other popular tourist locations and a charming place to visit.

Refreshingly Compact. The gardens alone are worth the price of admission. Unlike other Paris museums, this can be "done" in a few hours, which for me made the visit much more enjoyable, without the pressure of having to see as much as possible like in the Louvre.

Highlight of our trip to Paris. After giving up on the Musée d'Orsay due to horrific lines we were thrilled that we could just stroll into the Musée Rodin and not have to fight any crowds. Georgeous inside and out. We were lucky enough to be there on a sunny day which made walking through the blooming gardens even more pleasant. Thoroughly enjoyed the Robert Mapplethorpe exhibition, a perfect fit with Rodin.Also enjoyed the cheeky sense of humour of the lady at the door.

An elegant, peaceful gallery experience. The gardens are the real highlight here as the gallery is currently being partly restored. You can still see the main highlights (The Kiss is still inside) but many of the other sculptures are in storage while the top floor is restored. The gardens are stunning though, especially in May when you can see The Thinker amongst the blooming rose garden. We bought the joint Rodin/d'Orsay pass which is 15 euros to see both galleries in the same day. I'd definitely recommend this as it reduces cost and means you can cut the inevitable line at the d'Orsay later in the day!

Great museum shame about the queuing system...... Instead of being able to walk around the grounds and enjoy the sculpture on show most visitors spent the majority of their visit queuing for entry to the house - timed slots would have helped sooo much!!! The queue became fractious as members of a party all tried to push in front of people who had been waiting over an hour. It's great to limit the numbers but poor to keep everyone in line. Once inside the offending tourists showed no interest in the exhibits and exited almost as soon as they had entered - to the relief of the rest of us...The exhibits are superb, well laid out - but two of the eight rooms were closed for renovation which was a shame.

Day 4 First time in Paris Diary. Part 2- Rodin Museum. The Rodin Museum is for me one of the more fun Museums in Paris. The Thinker is the main attraction and it is perched on a high pedestal in Rodin’s intimate garden. There have been many interpretations regarding this sculpture including constipation. Also not to be missed is the “Gates of Hell, “the 3 Shades” and “the 6 Fathers” Statues.Inside Rodin’s house are more bronze and marble statues. The statue of “Camille”, “the Kiss,” the Walking man” and “the Hand of God” are the notable statues that are not to be missed. A visit to this museum is best done after Orsay and before Invalides. The 3 museums are 10-15 minutes away by leisure walk through narrow streets lined with government offices. All 3 are covered by the museum pass. Nothing like a whole day of to absorb French culture.

Very doable museum. Small and personable. If you don't have the kind of time you should spend in the Louvre, go through the Rodin. His piece, The Kiss, is worth the price of admission alone, and the grounds are lovely.

Rodin, Creative, and Innovative. Rodin loved the human body, and it's evident in all of his magnificent works of art. It was wonderful seeing the more popular pieces like The Thinker, and The Kiss. The grounds were magnificent, clean and very well maintained. Mapplethorpe exhibition is a must see. Definitely worth a visit.

Musee Rodin. Musee Rodin is one of the must see attractions in Paris in my opinion. It is located close to Napoleon' Tomb, and Les Invalids (Museum of the Army). It houses many sculptures by Rodin, and in a garden you'll find the famous Le Penseur (The Thinker). The Museum is actually Rodin's magnificent house - I don't think he was a starving artist. A must see if you're in Paris.

We would never go toParis without returning here. Musee de RodinSimply lovely. My favorite museum in Paris along with the Jacque Mart Andre. Outdoor sculpture garden both peaceful and exiting. Don't forget to compare Paolo and Fracesca on the Gates of Hell with the inside sculpture of the Kiss

Compact & beautiful. Definitely top 5 for any art lover visiting Paris. Great setting. Neatly captioned in English. Photogenic. Friendly staff. The hotel turned museum lends itself well to the outdoor & indoor displays. It is an easy place to visit with family & children . The museum sells a combined day pass for musee d'Orsay as well. So if you visit the Rodin for 1 to 2 hours in the morning, D'Orsay is feasible post lunch as this museum will need at least 4 hours.
Great museum. Much smaller and intimate than the big boys- beautiful garden area and works that we had never seen. Café is reasonably priced and a pretty spot for coffee or lunch.

Enjoy the delightful garden and masterpieces.... One of my favorite places in Paris, really. It is small, but don't miss it, it worth the time you will spend there. It is magic, the garden is absolutely delightful. One advice, spend a few euros for the audio-guide, it is really a good way to enjoy the ride...

Glorious. What a lovely way to spend an afternoon! The mix of interior and garden exhibits was perfect. My husband and I spent a partly sunny, partly overcast afternoon leisurely strolling through the grounds, marveling at the artistry of Rodin and the clever placement of statues on the grounds. It was uncrowded and unhurried. Definitely a delight for photographers.

A Nice Place to Visit. A nice collection of the work of Rodin. If you are a fan, you should plan a visit. When we were there, they had a special exhibit that compared the work of Rodin with that of Mapplethorpe. Now that was an interesting mix!

Beautiful small museum and gorgeous garden. Beautiful sculpture at the museum... the museum is small and easy to do in an hour or so. The accompanying garden is noteworthy and amazing with sculpture as well beautiful roses (it is May, so they are there now). I would go as far as to say I enjoyed it maybe more than the Palais Royal and the Tuilerie, because of how small and intimate it is.

Wonderful museum and gardens. This is one of our favorite museums in Paris. A must each time we visit. It displays a fine collection of one of the world's finest sculptors, in a gorgeous setting, which provides insight into the life of Rodin, while he lived here.
If You Like Sculpture.... If you like sculpture, are close to this museum, and are holding a Paris Museum Pass, it's worth a stop.
Gorgeous. Not to be missed. What an amazing place...beautiful and charming and uniquely Rodin. I highly recommend this spot.

Our favorite!. While all of the museums are grand in Paris, my daughter and I particularly liked Rodin. The grounds were magnificent as well as the actual museum. Lines were not too bad. Be sure to get the ticket prior to going. Makes the wait a little less.

Absolutely gorgeous!. My husband and I really love his work and we were excited to see some of his best pieces, including the Gates of Hell, The Thinker and the Burghers of Calais. Most of the works are placed in a beautiful garden. It was early morning, the sun was shining, birds tweeting....really idyllic. Best on a sunny day early in the morning, it gets crowded.

the best parisian garden. secluded in the 7th, the Musee Rodin is not only a great museum but one of the most peaceful and relaxing garden of Paris with fountain, ducks and a little restaurant. perfect to relax

A little country hideaway in the centre of Paris. My absolute favourite museum in Paris, beautiful gardens and a serene and peaceful quality after the hustle and bustle of the rest of the city.We used the Paris Museum Pass and so skipped the queue, as we had arrived just after breakfast time it was nice and quiet and we so we felt we had room to explore and just stand and look at the paintings.The thinking in the garden is incredible, as is the gates of hell and the Kiss is as beautiful as i'd always hoped it would be.Could spend hours here on a sunny day.
Rodin's house. The thinker and the eternal kiss, the gate of heaven or hell , not to mention his other great works.

Another great museum. Rodin sculpted "the thinker" along with many others. His work is on display here inside the building and out in the gardens. It doesn't take a long time to see everything, but it's easy to spend more time in the gardens than inside the building itself. I guess that depends on the weather too. The staff here are knowledgeable and friendly. No rude staff here. Best thing is to get a museum pass to avoid the lineups. The security guard will let you bypass the line. We chose to do the gardens first, then the building. If you're a photographer, a 24-70mm lens will cover everything.

Beautiful house and garden. A Parisian jewel. The house is beautiful. The sculpture is just astounding. If its a pretty day go sit in the garden and enjoy the day. A special small museum in a beautiful part of Paris.

The Kiss. I wasn't a huge fan of Rodin until I saw "Le Bisou" or "The Kiss" in person. Absolutely gorgeous and romantic! We ended our tour of the museum with a walk through the gardens and a cup of cafe creme at the coffee shop. Very nice relaxing experience overall.

Definitely a worthwhile visit. This is an amazing place to visit. First the grounds. Beautiful lowers, garden-with Rodin sculptures all around. Worth the price of admission alone. The house is charming- and loaded with his works and works of friends. A must go!
Stunning Gardens. We really enjoyed the Rodin collection which included two Van Gogh paintings and a Monet. The gardens were amazing and we visited the garden cafe for tea and coffee as well.
This is a Thinker. The grounds are nicely kept with a large garden area, indoor and outdoor works Some nice early works.

The Kiss. We visited the garden around 4Pm. Relaxing, not a lot of people about. An excellent place away from the hubbub. Only 2 euro to visit the garden. The garden handout does not mention the satues on one side. Do not miss. Before going to Paris I bought a book, "Hidden Gardens of Paris" by Susan Cahill. A most excellent book. Be forewarned about the garden in Valle suisse, the name of the garden has changed. still in same place.430 pm they allowed us entry into the house without charge. That is where "The Kiss " is.

Beautiful Museum. Went on a stormy, rainy day and was tired so didn't end up seeing everything; however the garden is lovely--and huge. Lots of art students near the exhibits drawing the sculptures. Don't forget the gift shop, unfortunately I couldn't take a heavy statuette on the plane! But there are plenty of prints etc. If you walk out the front, turn right there is a metro station right there.

Must See Museum in Paris. Even if you only go here to see Rodin's The Thinker it is totally worth it. The museum is set in an old villa with nice gardens you can relax in. Some of Rodin's great classic works like The Thinker and Balzac are all displayed here. It is right next to the Invalides so makes for a nice 2 stop visit. There are 2 parts to the Museum with famous sculptures in the gardens and others in the house where he stayed. A few famous impressionist artist paitinings are also included in the collection).

Very Nice, Less Crowded Museum. Of course, if you like Rodin, you'll love this museum! I was familiar with only a few of Rodin's works but wanted to see more from him. The museum provided a great look at his portfolio as well as work from a few similar artists. The house and grounds were lovely. It was not very crowded which allowed us plenty of time in front of each piece, so that was nice after feeling crowded and rushed through other tourist attractions. I recommend putting this on your itinerary if you're planning a more laid-back tour of Paris' cultural attractions.
I Think, therefore I am!. To see one of the original sculptures of The Thinker. To also see The Gates of Hell, which was the inspiration of many of Rodin's pieces.

One of the best museums in Paris. This little museum is a masterpiece: I suggest a quick visit to the inside, that is interesting but nothing so special. The most beautiful thing is with no doubts the garden: especially in a hot sunny day, the garden with flowers and rodin's most famous statues (including the thinker and the hell's gate) is a piece of heaven.

Average Museum. I had looked forward to visiting the Musee Rodin, but found the museum to be a bit of a let down. Still worth it though to see the most famous pieces, The Thinker, The Kiss and Cathedral Hands.
museum visit. Lovely all around. The gardens are beautiful in May. Nice quiet place to contemplate the art and the building as well

A must-see museum in Paris. The house and gardens where Auguste Rodin lived and worked is a relaxing gem in a city of endless lines. Stroll the garden and view, The Thinker and other sculptures by Rodin. There is even a cafe to sit and sip a coffee on a spring day. Inside the old house you view The Kiss and other works. They regulate the number of people in the house so that you can stroll through it in a relaxed fashion. They are in the middle of doing some renovations, which the house needs inside. A Maplethorp display in the chapel compares Rodin's work in sculpture to his photography. They are a surprising reflection of each other. Enjoy!
It's all here. Walk with Rodin in his gardens and his creations. What a lovely way to spend a lazy afternoon. Don't miss the rear of his home to his treasured gardens.

Cute little museum. Definitely worth the visit. The museum is small and cute with a lovely garden and the cherry on top for us was the Maplethorpe exhibit that was there as well. Loved the sculptures outside and in, beautiful.
Great scupltures. This was a good experience to see the sculptures of this great artist after studying them at school! They are set in magnificant gardens and worth visiting.

'THE' museum to visit in Paris. One of the most beautiful museums in Paris, not only because of the art works but this is also a place to just stroll in the gardens and take in the energy. I always come here also to get away from the hectic of so many other places in Paris.

Best Museum in Paris. This is our family's favorite museum in Paris. It is refreshing to be able to focus on one artist and to see all the sculpture both indoors and out. The grounds are beautiful and allow for a more relaxed immersion in the contemplation of the works.

An old house with magnificent works of art. The house that Auguste Rodin bought and where he lived was transformed in a museum. All his sculptures can be seen there. While you walk through the garden, admire Les Bourgeois de Calais, the different portraits of Balsac and The Thinker, that was created for the Door of Hell.

Wonderful Gardens. A welcome change of pace from the other museums; beautiful, relaxing gardens, magnificent sculptures, and a nice cafe within the museum (garden side). We combined with a later walk down Rue Cler and some people watching at Cafe Marche
very nice museum. This is such a pleasant museum. Much more interesting than I expected. Be sure to go through the house as well. There is a very nice tea salon in the garden.
The Kiss!!!. It was more peaceful in Musée Rodin compared with crazily crowded Musée du Louvre and Musée d’Orsay.
Small and Beautiful. The Rodin Museum is a small museum but quality time spent here. The outdoor gardens surrounding significant sculpture was a delight. Pale pink roses in full bloom early May.
hands and the door. This is an amazing museum with a nice garden; It should be a very nice area in spring and summer. Dont forget to see the gates of hell and the Thinker!

A small museum rich in masterpieces. A particularly good museum to be viewed in a couple of hours (at most) in which one can see masterpieces of the French sculptor Auguste Rodin. I'd just finished Camille Claudel the film when I went and managed to pick out 'The Thinker' sitting on top of 'The Gates of Hell'. There are a variety of pieces from his personal collection (works not his own) and many statues he began or left unfinished; we get, as visitors, a personal insight into his work as it took shape. The centre-piece is 'The Thinker' which lies in the courtyard- one might remember it being featured during Woody Allen's Midnight in Paris recently- is just fantastic.

Rodin. Excellent museum and gardens. The thinker was really concentrating the day we were there. I shot a great picture of the thinker with a glimpse of the Eiffel Tower and Napoleon' s Tomb in the background. Be careful with small children as the special photo exhibit while ok for adults is pretty graphic for children.. Be sure to have your Paris Museum Pass as it saved us 45 minutes in line.

Excellent place to visit. The gardens are a joy, being an excellent showcase for the brilliant statues. It has a calming atmosphere after the bustle of the city and was most welcoming. We had to queue to enter the house but while waiting you could observe glimpses of what's to see in the garden. It is a photographer's dream location, loved the place and would definitely return. One of my favourite museums in Paris

Beautiful Stroll. The grounds are beautiful with more rose bushes that one can imagine, grafted to offer each bush a variety of colorful blooms. Small wildlife abounds in the form of birds of all types, butterflies, rabbits and other small creatures vying for a place within the beauty. Paris is blessed with an abundance of museums, and Rodin should definitely be on your list.

Statues & Gardens. World famous romantic statues in a nice setting. The garden only ticket is very reasonably priced and there are copies of some statues in the garden also. Gift shop rather small and does not sell miniatures of Rodin's works such as The Thinker or The Kiss

Excellent few hours. Not as busy as some of the more popular museums which makes for a more relaxed experience. Combine that with the open spaces of the well manicured garden of this old hotel and it really is a great way to spend a few hours on a Saturday afternoon in Paris. The upstairs gallery even houses a couple of Monets and Van Goghs.

Don't leave Paris without seein this place!!!. One of the most beautiful museum in Paris. The gates if hell and the thinking man is well worth the visit. The museum has so many exquisite figures Rodin made that would amuse you. I would definitely consider this same level as orsay as the pieces of items on display is a memorable one.

it's Rodin's home. What's not to like?. We have been here a dozen times and never tire of it. The building, Rodin's home, and the gardens are beautiful, and the art inside is astounding. Not only do you get to see all of Rodin's major works in one place, you also see the work of his immensely gifted protégée Claudine Claudel. A rare and wonderful experience.

Soothing environment. Spent an hour here this afternoon and found a soothing interlude to a hectic week in Paris. The sculptures are magnificently offset by the well maintained garden. A delightful place to visit...

A peaceful Paris setting.. Get there early or late as it is not as busy then. I found the garden and Rodin's statues very peaceful yet thought provoking. The museum contains wonderful works and well worth seeing.

Relaxed museum and wonderful garden. We visited Musee Rodin on a free Sunday afternoon. The outdoor garden was lovely and well laid out for a casual stroll around the grounds. We ate at the outdoor cafe and were pleasantly surprised by the prices for sandwiches and ice cream. There was a long queue to enter the museum section, but they allowed families with small children to skip the lines- such a blessing. Rodin's art is incredible and there were also a few other pieces from well known artists in the museum. Truly a charming experience!

A Very Pleasant Experience. It's the home of the Thinker and other famous statues and it has a terrific garden cafe. We sat back, enjoyed the garden and had a wonderful lunch. With the museum pass we had no wait.

Probably my favourite museum in Paris.. This museum is my favourite in Paris. The atmosphere is so relaxing and calm. I have been there three times and never was it crowded and not a pleasure to visit. Great garden with well-placed statutes so you don't have to move along in queues to see them. Allows for great photos with nobody in the background. Very interesting to see how Rodin worked and I will recommend Musee Rodin very highly.Last visit was before June 2013, but the setting does not allow me to select an earlier date in 2013.

the loveliest place. Rodin Museum is one of the most charming places in the world. I return to it every time I Paris.I personally love the works of Rodin, but even if you are not a sculptures fan, Rodin's home and particularly its garden are beautiful.During our last stay in Paris , the Museum held an excellent exhibition comparing the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe with Rodin's sculptures. highly recommended.
Beautiful. If u like Rodin, you gotta go there! The House and the Garden are unique and bis sculptures are truly special.

Romantic must. This is a repeat visit for us to the Rodin Museum, so romantic, so lovely. This time we also took in the Maplethorpe exhibit. I had not realised before but yes now I understand why this is a good marriage of exhibits Rodin/Maplethorpe. Each with their view of the human form and sexuality, lust, love. I was somewhat surprised to see some tourists bringing quite small children into the Maplethorpe section, possibly setting them up (both male and female) for a life time of crushing disappointment. 'No honey, they are not all that size.' Note to TripAdvisor - I bet you censor this one, though I hope not. Back to the Rodin side of things, the gardens are beautiful, the cafe is good. Just don't rush the visit, relax and take time to literally smell the roses.

Use Your Museum Pass. To a certain extent, the title sums up my most recent experience with Musee Rodin. We had Museum Passes and, as a result, managed to skip a huge entry line that was here-and-gone down the block. I don't recall an entry line at all two years ago and so didn't expect to be so completely happy to have those passes in hand.This time we focussed on the big pieces in the garden. I was surprised that despite the long entry line, the garden was not crowded. I think this might have been because there was a new queue forming to see thd special exhibit in the older building. I felt that since it was not yet raining that I was able to take in the garden as a garden with the pieces forming a pleasant counterpoint to the landscaping. Fewer people also seemed to mean fewer people posing in front of the bronzes, which gave greater opportunity walk around, step back, and view in contemplation.

Relaxing Museum. Lovely picturesque museum.There was a l-o-n-g line to go in the house so we took the audio guide instead for the gardens only .Very easy to follow.We saw the Thinker and Dante's Gates of Hell.The grass was soft as velvet.The crowds sparse.It is lovely to just roam and walk around with an ice-cream in hand.Beautiful setting and landscape. Soothing and calming.Would not miss.

Great, but one needs to know the setup!. The queue was not too long as we got there at opening time. The outdoor displays are marvellous and the gardens are quite beautiful. We did. To go to the interior displays as the queue was at least 200-300 long and people were only being admitted as others left.It is highly recommended that you go to the interior section first if you get there early as the outdoor section is available anytime.

Worth the visit. My sister and I visited the Musee Rodin after spending a week cruising down the Seine and it was well worth the stop. We were aware of his two most famous works (The Thinker and The Kiss) so it was nice to see some of this other works.

This was my favourite Musee. It was a very wet day when we walked to the Musee Rodin and so when we arrived we were rather wet and tired. Because of this we headed straight to the little café which turned out to be an absolute gem. We enjoyed beautiful soup and crusty bread and shared a little fruit tart. All were very fresh and delicious. This delicious food having revived us we then enjoyed the wondrous delights of Rodin's work in magnificent surrounds.
Current exhibit fab!. Current exhibit compares Rodin and Robert Mapplethorpe and is really interesting. Please get the audio tour!

Beautiful Small Museum. This museum is lovely. It is a small, easily digestible museum in a beautiful house and gardens. You probably only need an hour to see it. The garden is very picturesque with Rodin's statues placed throughout. I definitely recommend a visit to this museum! In general, I prefer small museums to larger ones -- especially in Paris -- large museums can be hard to digest and overwhelming, whereas a small museum feels manageable and cozy. The Rodin museum is a beautiful small museum.
Excellent 2 star musuem. not too crowded. house and art inside is great. but the gardens with the art out and about is really something. do not miss the gatres of hell.

Must see, away from all the tourist traps. I just returned from my first trip to Paris, so I of course wanted to visit all the must-see destinations- Eiffel Tour, Louvre, Versailles. However, I found that the incredible amount of tourists ruined the experience a bit. The Musee Rodin, however, is a wonderful change from those places, as it's the perfect size for a museum (not overwhelmingly large), the location is spectacular, the curation of art is beautiful, the museum itself is gorgeously decorated and there is a lovely garden courtyard and cafe in the back. You won't feel exhausted after visiting it, and you'll avoid having hundreds of visitors on top of you. Highly recommend!

Must see on the left bank. If all you knew about Rodin was "The Thinker", you'll be surprised at the variety of his subjects. Smaller sculptures and larger sculptures in the gardens. You can get very close and view them from all angles, unlike in many museums where sculptures are behind ropes. Nice cafe.

Quiet Museum in the Heart of Paris. A very pleasant alternative to the busier museums in the area. We were only able to see the garden but that in itself was worth the price of admission. The sculptures in the garden are magnificent & the setting is perfect. A must see. Good museum shop.

Awsome. We went to visit the Musee Rodin because our daughter thought we might enjoy it. She had visited it one day last summer while on honeymoon. They had arrived late in the day and were only allowed to visit the garden but because it was late they were not charged an admission fee. We loved our time there. Well worth a visit. We began our visit with a coffee and cake in the very nice coffee shop and then did the house tour. To see some of the sculptures was amazing, the detail, the finish and to read the background to some of them and of course the history of the house. It sounded like name dropping.........We had a very nice lunch in the cafe and then spent a few hours in the gardens. These have to be seen. To me it was like a hidden gem in Paris. We loved it and I am thrilled to have seen The Thinker and The Kiss. Great day

One of My Favorites. I visit this museum every time I'm in Paris. It is small in comparison to the other well known museums and it has a very personal feel to it. I particularly like the garden areas. Not only does it contain Rodin's many works, you can also see a couple of Monet's as well as Van Gogh's paintings. It seems far less crowded even during peak season and you won't feel rushed when trying to absorb the beautiful art.

Very impressive. The Rodin museum is more than a museum, it is also a garden with beautiful landscapes and colors. Most of Rodin's most well know pieces are here. Loved it here, very good value only 6 Euro entry, lovely house and garden.

Hidden treasure. With so many really famous museums in Paris, many of which are so large you feel like you rush through them, the Rodin museum is a real find. The sculpture in the garden is particularly fascinating. The many studies and versions of the works he's famous for are also on display. You will be mesmerized by "The Kiss"--it is absolutely beautiful. This is possibly my favorite museum in all of Paris.

Walk in the park. This is a quick museum for those of us who get tired of seeing museums. And the good stuff is outside so you can avoid shuffling through halls and rooms with hundreds of others. The statues are amazing and some you will recognize! For the Rodin fans and art lovers you already knew all this, right?
Great museum for a hot sunny day. Lots of sculptures arranged in the gardens, and very relaxing to stroll around both the gardens and house. A great museum for a hot sunny day!

Double Your Pleasure!. Some of Rodin's most famous sculptures are housed in this gorgeous 18th century residence. The garden is one of the prettiest in the city and contains many sculptures as well. Visit a little early and start with lunch at the on site cafe (you'll beat the lunch crowd and get a good seat! I sat at the outside tables and even with the light rain it was delightful! Fair prices-I had the Tarte Poulet-chicken tarte-and an espresso/total just under 14euro) I will gladly go back again just to spend time in the garden-lovely!

don't miss. OK the Louvre is all it, right? Well, I would say skip it and its crowds and go to this lovely place. ESPECIALLY the garden. Only 1 euro to get into the garden and stroll among all the amazing Rodin sculptures. It was our favorite Paris experience.

Easy and beautiful. This is one of the gems of Paris. The gardens are beautiful and generally there is not a long line, as there can be at the Louvre or Orsay. It is a museum that you feel you can actually take in - small and accessible. On a nice day the gardens themselves are sufficient. A great cultural activity that doesn't take a lot of logistical planning to accomplish.

Excellent. We went to this museum after the Musee d'orsay and we both preferred the Musee Rodin. Much of it is set in an open garden and as none 'art lovers' we found the exhibition just right both in size and information given. There were no crowds just a pleasant few hours wondering around enjoying the exhibits.

One of my favorite museums. This is a must see museum. Wandering around the garden area with all his sculptures are breathtaking. In the distance you see the top of the Eiffel tower peaking through the trees and over his masterpieces. The Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell are my favorite pieces. Inside his house you get to see The Kiss and so many others.

Great slice of Paris. If you love sculptures you MUST go here. The garden is beautiful with Rodin's sculptures placed in calm surroundings. The house is well set out. No huge queues, good value for money (only 9 Euros for an adult and free for under 18s). Beautiful Art. If you go before Sept '14 you MUST see Mapplethorpe's photos - they are immense.

Musee Rodin. Not the biggest museum by any means but has an excellent collection of Rodin's work, not just the Thinker. interesting that there are oils and sketches that many are not aware of. Should be seen by anyone who admires Rodin.

A piece of Heaven. This was the highlight of my trip. The setting is simply perfect with Rodin's work around a beautiful landscaped garden and in the house in which he lived. The icing on the cake was an exhibition that had just started of his work alongside that of photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. Absolute perfection and I feel so blessed to have seen it.
Best museum in Paris!. If you are a Rodin fan, thus is a must. So too is the audio guide, which I don't usually go for. Relaxed but informative.

Go especially for the Gardens!. Great sculpture garden which includes The Thinker and The Gates of Hell and other works. Don't miss having a bite to eat in the gardens- very pleasant place to have lunch and relax, etc.. We encountered no line due to having the museum pass (included). Great photo opportunities in the gardens..After your visit , the military museum (les Invalidses) is very close by to see Napoleon's tomb.

Lovely exhibit of Rodin's Work. The museum (Rodin's house) is lovely and the gardens are exceptional with sculptures throughout. You can see the evolution of his work. A lovely break from the buzz of the city.
Wonderful. Great museum. Great sculpture garden. Wonderful joint expo with the works of Mapplethorpe. Highly recommended.

Great oasis. Although I've been to Paris before I had never visited this museum. It was great to see The Thinker and many other sculptures and art works. The gardens are relaxed and pleasant too. I couldn't find the promised works by many other artists but perhaps they were there. A good gift shop too!

Rodin-defintely worth avisit -beautiful gardens. We bought a combined ticket to Rodin and Musee d'Orsay IN ADVANCE-this is a top tip as we sailed to the front of a very long queue (particularly at Musee d'Orsay). Both museums are just beautiful and about a 10 minute walk from each other so can do both in the same day.

If you like Rodin, you must go. The sculptures are beautifully placed in the Garden. It is a very tranquil place. Of course there were people around, but the tranquility won out. We ate at the restaurant in the Garden and it was a nice lunch that you pick up cafeteria style

Beautiful garden of Rodin sculptures. Best known for The Thinker under which Rodin and his co-vivant are buried. The gardens are beautifully landscaped and I got to enjoy my favorite lilacs in full bloom, so fragrant like perfume. The perfect warm Spring day added to the joy of admiring so many famous works of art.
Couldn't be asked to stand in another queue!. So, we left, knowing that we'd seen everything already at the awesome Rodin museum in Philadelphia (no queues)! Disappointing but there you go.

Rodin/Mapplethorpe. If you are looking for an excuse to go back to this wonderful museum, the exhibition "comparing" Rodin and the photographer Mapplethorpe is a masterclass in how this type of exhibition should be done.Small but well organised you can only leave having even more respect for these two artists.A must in summer 2014.
Inside-outside. The park and indoor museum are both wonderful. Meeting The Thinker in person still holds its charm. You learn more about Rodin here than simply his love of ballet.

Rodin Reviewed. Have to be honest here... we had greater expectations for this museum. We had visited Rodin's works at Stanford U. in Palo Alto, CA and Paris left us a little empty by comparison. Worth visiting for sure but not as thrilling as we would have thought.

The Garden Alone is Worth a Visit. Being pressed for time, my husband and I purchased a ticket only for the gardens and were delighted by the amount of artwork we were able to see in such a beautiful setting. It didn't hurt that we went on a beautiful sunny day. We spent over an hour admiring the sculptures and sitting on a bench and just taking it all in. Don't miss this museum!
Great picnic opportunity. We found great wine, cheese, hummus, olives, a baguette and rotisserie chicken at a market on the way. We ate by the fountain out back. it was an awesome day.

A favourite.. As with other first rate venues with gardens or human sized rooms you need to work out the quieter times. We have been here early morning and late afternoon but I guess it's also a question of picking your time of week.
