The bronzes in the garden and the more sensitive objects inside together with the very personal feel make this better than many of the more formal institutional galleries. Recommended.

Rodin's home is his museum. The inside is partially closed for some reason but what remains is well worth a visit. The only disappointment is that none of Camille Claudel's sculpture is currently on display although you can see her in the sculptures of Rodin she modeled for. There is one of her sculptures on display in the Orsay.The grounds are lovely and uncrowded and the little cafe in the garden is a great place for an informal lunch.

A must visit. The Rodin museum is a paris must, located near Invalides. It was the home to Rodin, a vast, impressive mansion now converted to Rodin's museum and dedicated to his works. The grounds get only brief mention, if at all. They enhance the splendor of the mansion/museum with sculptures artistically placed in the natural landscape. Be sure and take time to walk around the entire gardens and take a light lunch or simple coffee in the cafeteria located on the grounds.

Nice museum. You should definitely visit the museum on the nice, sunny day because there is a beautiful garden where lot of statues are. You can take a walk and relax by enjoying the view of statues. Inside of the museum you can also see the pictures of Monet and Van Gogh. There are lot of statues of Balzac.
Worth a visit. We happen to like the works of Rodin so we enjoyed this museum. "The Thinker" is here...worth a stop when in Paris.

Beautiful Sculptures in Gorgeous Gardens. If you buy a Museum Pass (which I HIGHLY recommend doing), this is one of the attractions that will honor it. I highly suggest going on a mild day so you can enjoy the large garden with several Rodin sculptures. You could even do a snack or a lunch there, as there is a nice cafe' on site. We did not visit the special exhibit taking place inside the "palace," as there was a long line, but we spent a good hour in the gardens, and you can see the top of Napoleon's Tomb from there. There is something so cool about seeing "The Thinker" up close!
our favourite place. So relaxed, it has stunning artwork and great gardens. A really lovely way to spend a couple of hours before having a great meal

The Thinker and The Gates of Hell. We didn't plan ahead for this museum but were happy we added it to our itinerary. Many impressive works of art from Rodin and a few others. The famous statue "The Thinker" is in the garden and viewable from all angles. "The Gates of Hell" is an incredible piece also outside that has such incredible intricacies and details you can stand and gaze at it for an hour and still miss something. Many other pieces inside the museum and in the gardens. Not too crowded in the late afternoon and easy to navigate. Centrally located near the Invalides Metro stop and easy to walk to. Is included in the Museum Pass.

Don't miss the gardens. Unlike other museums in Paris, this one doesn't take a long time to see. There's a special exhibit or another artist's work at the beginning, the main building houses mostly Rodin's work. Don't miss the gardens, they are beautiful and contain great sculptures!

The Thinker in Paris. One of my favourite museums in Paris! Conveniently located near the Eiffel Tower, stop here to see some of Rodin's most famous pieces and enjoy the beautiful gardens. A must visit

Magnificent...inspiring. Wow! We went to this museum as we were fans of "The Thinker", but came to appreciate Rodin and all of his works. The gardens (in back) are really nice, with many sculptures scattered about. It's a relaxing, park-like atmosphere, where one can sit on a bench and take in the beautiful surroundings. The museum was also not overwhelming like, say, the Louvre.

Worth a visit. We thoroughly enjoyed out visit to the Rodin Museum. Allow a couple of hours to wander the garden and visit the indoor museum space. The garden is well laid out, so that we didn't feel that there was a crowd, unlike most of the other attractions we visited. There is a cafe in the garden if you want to make the visit longer.

Gem of a Museum. Many of the sculptures in this museum are placed in a beautiful garden so go when the weather is nice as it will make a world of difference. I went on a clear spring day and really enjoyed the sculpture garden. Altogether, the museum is lovely and very accessible. You can spend a few hours here wandering through the garden and then through the house where the sculptures are placed strategically to take advantage of the light in each room. A big surprise were the inclusions of Camille Claudel's works in this museum. That was a treat. The museum was not crowded and it is possible to enjoy yourself amongst the art without a million tourists taking photos. Note - You do not need the earphones to guide you through as there are plenty of written explanations under each sculpture. The museum fee is included with the museum pass if you purchase one.
A delightful surprise. Interesting and thought provoking sculpture in a wonderfully put together garden & house. Good cafe too

Peaceful, beautiful, a lovely experience. Gardens were very peaceful and well laid out. Museum was bright and you could very easily picture what it must have been like to live there back in Rodins time. Worth it.
Great art. Enjoyed the sculptures at this museum. A unique experience to see some works in progress and fantastic to see the famous works in the garden. Spend some time contemplating in the garden.
The Kiss. Small museum with statues made by Rodin. Also large garden with more figures. Specially liked the Kiss and the Thinker

One of the most beautiful museums. This is my 4th visit - I love this museum. Rodin's work is beautiful, as are the house and gardens, which are used so well to showcase his works. The staff were really helpful and friendly, even when it came to closing time.It is an oasis of calm after the bustle of Paris - you walk through the entrance and feel like you have stepped back in time.

Not to be missed. This is the ideal museum for those who wish to see fine paintings and sculptures without risking the exhaustion and overload of a visit to the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay. It is in a delightful townhouse with a splendid garden, just right for a spring afternoon.

The sculptures are breathtaking. Take your time and walk the grounds. Sit by the pond in the back and just contemplate what you gave just experienced. Look to your right and experience a cool view of the Eiffel Tower

Fascinating and great cafe. I loved this museum, the staff were very friendly and it was a gorgeous building. Fans of The Thinker and The Kiss won't be disappointed - and please don't miss the cafe. The coffee and chocolate mousse were gorgeous and very good value for money!
Impressive Museum and Garden. Please visit and support this incredible, privately owned museum. The collection is vast indoors and outdoors without being overwhelming.
Beautiful. Our third time and still beautiful. We especially love the gardens and the statues there. Especially beautiful in Spring .

Relaxing and beautiful. We loved the Musee Rodin, perhaps it is because we were at the Louvre the day before. We enjoyed the serenity, the art and the gardens. Less crowded then most places and a relaxed atmosphere.

I expected more about this place!. It was my third time in Paris, and It was a sunny day, so I decided to go to Musee Rodin, because everybody says about the gardens. The museum is where Rodin lived the last years of his life, it is quite small, and the gardens not that much. The garden was under refurbishment and part of it was restricted.

Kids Love the Gardens and Photos Ops. This is a highlight for kids. The outdoor sculpture garden was the perfect place for kids to run around and the gardens were beautiful. We were there in March so not much was in bloom and we still loved it.

Excellent viewing pleasure. Was so happy to get an insight into Rhodin's life and view all the sculptures. The house is amazing and the gardens are beautiful on a warm spring day!
A must see in Paris :)

Not a must see, yet great. I attampted to enter the museum several times, however as cliché as it may sound, the museum was always closed due to one of many Parisian strikes.So when I finally managed to get there, I did not expect much. I honestly just wanted to cross this one out of my list. Unfortunately the weather was not the best so that I spent the majority of time in the inside part of the museum which was not that exciting (unless you are a really big fan of Rodin). However the gardens are just beautiful! I absolutely loved the iconic statue and moreover enjoyed the gardens in general. There is a lovely cafe where you can overcome a little rain tasting some of the tastiest macaroons. Also if lucky you may rest on of the benches while reading a book or perhaps writing a poem.Overall it is beautiful, however if you are in Paris just for a few days I personally think that there are much better things to do and see in Cité de la Lumiére :-)
My other favorite!. Again, if you haven't been here, what are you waiting for? It's an oasis in the middle of the city! I could have spent hours and hours just hanging out in the gardens. LOVE it!

Winter Garden Sculpture. While the main museum is currently closed for renovation the garden, even in winter is filled with magnificent sculpture that defies the weather. Enjoy it along with exploring the nearby streets.

One of our favorite museums anywhere. The combination of Rodin's amazing sculptures, coupled with the beauty of the grounds and gardens make this one of our favorite museums. Strolling in shady lanes of trees past Rodin's sculptures--which shimmer with light as you move from the texture he imbued them with, is such an inspiring and peaceful experience.

hard to find but worthed. If you have the time I recommend you to look for this museum, specially if you have seen Rodin's sculptures in pictures only or just part of his work. Check before you go to see if the sculpture you want to see is on-site, sometimes they are on tour.

There are sculptures and then there are Rodin Sculptures. The Rodin museum is more than a museum, it is also a garden with beautiful landscapes and colors. And how about those sculptures? Auguste Rodin was a true genius in his interpretation of the human anatomy with all he twists and turns and his life's work is exhibited throughout the garden and the house.
Very impressive. We were very impressed with this museum. The quality of the collection is very extensive. The walk around the garden is beautiful. Will be back to see again!

Rodin Fanatics' Delight. Definitely visit this museum if you are interested in Rodin or in sculpture. If you are not, it might be better to skip this one. The garden is very nice, not crowded at all. Most of Rodin's most well know pieces are here. The museum itself is in a lovely old "townhouse". Unless you are a fanatic, you can visit this museum in 1/2 hours; spend longer in the gardens/

Great value. We only explored the garden (1 Euro for entry) and were able to see some impressive pieces. The garden itself is beautiful and nice to walk through, and the sculptures are situated throughout the garden in a great way. It also wasn't too crowded when we went ( 4pm on a Saturday) which is a huge bonus in Paris.The FREE telescopes pointed towards the 'Gates of Hell' piece were so helpful and allowed for closer inspection of the intricacies included in the sculpture. It really made it even more impressive.
Fantastic Museum. Loved it here, very good value only 6 Euro entry, lovely house and garden. Definitely worth a visit.

Half shut when I went. I loved it here one of my favourites when I visited but, half of the gardens and building were covered in scaffolding so not sure what else is there. Which is a shame because it would easily be 5 stars. You walk around some beautiful gardens while admiring the work of the great Rodin. On show are for me, are his two greatest pieces "The Thinker and Dante's Gates Of Hell" absolute outstanding craft he was one of the best. I spent hours wandering around here.

Up close with Rodin. This is a fabulous museum comprising the house and its contents, as well as the garden with famous statues such as the Thinker. Like most French museums you can get right up to the sculptures to appreciate them best. Excellent history of Rodin's life woven into the display.

A Day visiting Musee Rodin. The statues in the gardens are impressive. The sculptures in the museum were spectacular. It was very interesting to view the process, a sculptor goes through before the product is finished.

Beautiful!. See the thinking man, and many more works of art from Rodin, while also enjoying the sites in the background to include Napolean's tomb. TIP: BUY the Museum PASS, you are treated like royalty when you wave it in the air bypassing the crowds.
good stop. this is a good stop before/ after you see the grave of Napolean and the war museum, this is a real neat house with very cool art - there are some sexually explicit sculputures up staris

Very nice Garden. If you visit the Musee Rodin take time to either visit the cafeteria or bring a little snack to enjoy in the garden. Only 6 euros for the garden and museum and you could wonder at your own pace. On a sunny day great location to just relax and enjoy being outside in Paris.
Rude staff inside. What is with the bag check staff there, they won't take handbags, won't take coats but will only take some backpacks?????

A lovely museum in a beautiful garden. The house is beautiful and the garden is a lovely setting for the sculpture with great views of Les Invalides as well so peaceful and you can get a nice cup of tea or an ice cream in the garden too.
Beautiful. It's such an experience not only to see the statues who seem alive, but also the gypsum studies opening the vision of how the masterpieces have been created

A Wonderful late afternoon. The garden is lovely, cool and refreshing on a hot day. The café was refreshing and an excellent resting place; walking amongst Rodin's outdoor sculptures is always wonderful. His house was under extentsive renovations but with a bit of effort all pieces could be found.

Great garden, sculptures fit nicely, you can relax there. That was first time that I really felt the sculptures, even "Thinker" that you saw many times - up close in person - impresses you really, The garden itself is so nice, you can lie down on the wood bed at the far end of the garden and enjoy the view.

A must for anyone interested in sculpture and everyone else. A great and comprehensive exhibition of the masters work. A lot of sculpture in a compact space. The exhibition of his drawings are, perhaps, not for the easily offended or children.
Pleasant lunch. Visit Rodin's house and garden and enjoy a pleasant lunch in the garden bistro. Tasty and good value on a warm and sunny day.

Stroll through. This is a great garden museum - nice cafe to grab a lunch or just a drink in the gardens. Didn't have time to wait to go into the house because it was a "free" entry day, so the lines were ridiculous.

The best attraction in Paris. We visited Musee Rodin and found that overall we enjoyed the experience more than any other in Paris. The gardens are beautiful and we were able to go around and admire Rodin's work in peace and transquillity. Do a little reading on his work before you go and this will give you added understanding on each creation, from the burghers of calais to the Thinker and of course the Gates of hell. Just excellent!!!

A must see for a leisurely day. Although the mansion is really deteriorating since the first time I went there in 1986/7, this is such a lovely place to go and spend some leisurely time away from the buzzing metropolis of Paris. Especially wonderful in spring and summer with all the flowers in the gardens around. The toll of so many visitors in the mansion is a pity, but it is still wonderful, the sculptus of Rodin and his muse Camille Claudel are spectacular!
Magnifique !. The museum is not very big but full of excellent collection inside even in the outside garden.

Yummy macarons. We popped in closer to the end of the day. It wasn't overly crowded. The grounds, buildings and gardens are beautiful. They have yummy macarons at the area to purchase food/drink. 4Euro for 4. Was a steal :) Worth going and having a look around.

Awesome!. This was an unexpected surprise on my trip. The house and art inside was awesome but the gardens were just amazing! Well worth the entry price on a nice day and the sculptures are just amazing. Must see!!!

don't miss the work of Camille Claudel. After a visit to Les Invalides, don't miss the lovely Rodin museum, situated in the Villa Hotel Biron, and garden. His most important works are here, and in a great setting. Rodin himself used to use the place as his workshop, although the larger pieces were made in Meudon where the second Rodin museum is located (just a 15 min ride outside Paris, SW of the city centre). Hotel Biron is currently under reconstruction so not all the permanent pieces are exhibited. The reconstruction will finish in 2015. On the website of the museum further details concerning the reconstruction can be found (www.musee-rodin.fr). A gift shop is located next to the main entrance. There is a restaurant in the garden. I'm a great fan of Rodin's pupil and lover Camille Claudel. She inspired many of his works and apparently assisted him in the realisation as well. As a woman she never had the same recognition as he did... Success is always related to power isn't it. Camille died in a psychiatric hospital. Her works touch the heart. Deeply and endearingly. Her splendid work "Abandon" wasn't on display as we visited the museum. But other pieces were. Other art by artists that were contemporaries of Rodin is also part of the permanent collection. I clicked very good instead of excellent because of the inconveniences of the reconstruction. The museum is definitely worth the visit, also before 2015! Access for the disabled will be improved after the renovation.

A stroll through art. I really appreciated this small and quiet museum packed with great works of art.The hotel Biron which houses the collection is an amazing mansion and the garden is even better.Don't miss it!
Lovely Place. I love this place, Rodin is my prefered sculptor, I always came here, when I came to Paris, at least once per year. The garden is wonderful and the kiss is the best art in whole world.

Gifted artist, wonderful museum. I love the Rodin museum because it is small enough to visit in an hour or two, and you will be simply amazed at the sculptures. To think that they started as a slab of stone, and then Rodin created such masterful work is really amazing. The museum is set up beautifully, easy to navigate, crowd controlled. Don't miss it!

mostly under construction. During my visit there was a lot of construction work going on. This was not the perfect condition to visit the museum, although the collection was good it was not the best experience. This museum in included in the museum pass.

Small, but perfect.. If you are overwhelmed by the Louvre or the Musee d'Orsay, this is the perfect antidote! A comparatively small museum, it is well worth a visit. The audio guide is really informative and useful, you can choose to do things at your own speed. The exhibits in the house are lovely, but the garden is even better. Being able to sit in the open air and take time to really appreciate such great sculptures is an unforgettable experience.

Nice for a quick visit. We really enjoyed our night time visit to the Rodin Museum gardens and the lighting and creepy music made it very interesting. I would like to return again during the day but the night time visit was great.

One of my favorite museums of all in Paris!. The museum rooms are set out so nicely - you can follow Rodin's pieces throughout his life and process. You see beginning draft work right down to the finished piece. I really enjoyed learning about the love of his life Camille Claudel - I actually found her pieces pulled me into their playfulness and I wish she had more for me to see! There are also a few of Rodin's personal paintings by Van Gogh and Monet and Renoir. See the pieces in the gallery first and then tour the garden to see the finished pieces of the Thinker and the Gates of Hell in the fountain. The only reason this doesn't get 5 stars is because they had a fashion week event being set-up in the garden which spoiled much of the overall experience of the peaceful garden setting. But Rodin's work is still magnificent.

Dont Miss It. If you have to choose one museum in Paris, make it the Rodin your choice.I went 3 times and I am not tired of it.Nice location, you could spend ages there staring at the beautiful bodies of Rodin's sculptures
Nice small museum. Perfect to visit with children. It does not take much time, part of the collection is outdoors? And there are a few masterpieces which are worth the trip to Paris.

Brilliant collection. This has to be the best couple of hours spent in Paris.
The collection of art is stunning with"Gates of Hell"being my favourite.
The walk around the garden only prepares you for what is inside,a collection of a true genius.
A must see,don't forget it is closed on Mondays.

Magical garden. If you have the gift of time, try and visit the Musee Rodin garden and museum separately! The garden is magical on a clear day and is cheap at €2 per entry. ( if you do not have your museum pass yet) We had to make a decision because of time and decided to spend our time in the gardens which are really wonderful. Rodin's sculptures are placed beautifully and you get a beautiful sense of the setting and what he intended. We went back when we had more time and saw the inside of the museum, it was busy and full but filled with treasures.

Favorite Paris Museum. Had been before but this time hired a private tour guide (through Unique Paris Private Tours) which made it much more pleasant and personal. Stunning mansion filled with Rodin's art and exceptional gardens also filled with Rodin's art.
great museum. This is a great museum! Don’t miss this one if you go to Paris! Is a hidden gem! If you like Rodin, Is a must!

Perfection in a smaller museum. If you like Rodin, this is a must see, stop and savor. It's set in his former residence and it features sketches, paintings and, of course, sculptures. The real must see, though, is behind his residence in the Rodin Gardens. It is peaceful respite full of glorious sculptures. My favorite space in Paris.

Beautiful masterpieces in the garden!. Went specifically to view "The Thinker" and the breathtaking "The Gates of Hell" (- true masterpieces !) and then was stunned at the number of sculptures in and around the garden! A must-see in Paris, and you will linger longer than you expected! And when you travel over to the Musee de'l Orangerie, stop to admire a bronze cast of "The Kiss". Wonderful afternoon!

lovely. Part of the garden and the main building was closed for repair during our visit. There were part of his work - sculptures and sketches - on display though. The garden was very,very lovely - I imagine it would be awesome in spring. There were benches so one can sit and enjoy the view, figures, blooms and background. A quiet place to think and reflect. Gates of hell were interesting but prefer the thinker.Not everyone's cup of tea - failed to appreciate any artistic value of some of his sketches. You can always walk to the Invalides nearby too.

Beautiful and Peaceful. I have been twice and the second time just paid the small fee to wander the art in the gardens. So worth it. Not crowded and wonderfully arranged. If the house is closed I would still go if you love sculptures. The gates of Hell were amazing.

Overcast Day, Museum Closed, Garden Open. Of course we were disappointed to learn the museum is closed for renovations and the only indoor exhibit were copies of classic scultpture- we passed on that........Despite the overcast day and puddles, the garden is enchanted with beautiful scultpture and tree lined ways. We did not regret our visit and viewed the garden in its entirety

my favorite spot in paris. in late May the roses are amazing...anytime it is a joy to sit and rest by the Thinker..hard to believe the traffic and noise just outside the gardens..stop for a coffee or snack..just do not miss it!! easy walk from the L' open bus tour or the metro stop varenne
Would have been excellent. But the house is closed for rennovation and only the gardens were open when we visited in January 2014 and probably will be for some time.

A great, small museum. The museum (building and contents) are amazing, but so are the gardens. As such, if possible I would prefer to visit in the warm weather months when you can spend more time outside and appreciate the sculptures, etc. Really, however, there is no "bad" time to visit.

A treat for the senses.. One visit provides you with three distinct experiences. Firstly, meander through Rodin's house to see smaller sculptures, casts, works by his mistress Camille Claudel and the surprize of seeing a couple of van Goghs in one room. Next, take your time to stroll in the marvellous garden to admire the great artist's work. Then visit the new gallery by the entrance to round off your learning experience. Finally take with you some items from the shop and a lasting memory of one of history's greatest sculptors.

Magical house. Not only is this a wonderful opportunity to see Rodin's magnificent sculptures, but the garden even in winter makes a lovely setting for the works of art and I found myself to be intrigued to think of the history of the house, from its beginnings as a mansion for the wealthy, to its time as a girls' convent school and then culminating as a home for so many fine artists such as the writer Jean Cocteau, the painter Henri Matisse, the dancer Isadora Duncan and the sculptress Clara Westhoff. Then of course it was Rodin's home and he saved it from destruction. Well worth a visit - I hope to return when the restoration is finished.

Worth the cost. I'd visit on a nice day/non rainy day as many of the pieces are outside in the garden. Be ready for crowds in the on season and be quick if you want to snap a picture without people walking through your shot.Great gift shop.

One of the Finest!. This has to be one of the finest museums in Paris and well deserving of a full afternoon visit to thoroughly enjoy the gardens and museum itself. This will remain my #1 Paris museum.

My favorite. Great for kids!. So incredible. Love the grounds. Serene and beautiful. Kids enjoy this place more than any other museum in paris, Get the kids audio guide. It is interactive and gets them going on a bit of a scavenger hunt with questions to answer along the way. It is as all museum so it is perfect with kids. Should take about 1-1.5 hours.

Lured into the lair of Rodin. I love this museum. . . I could spend hours just walking through the garden, staring quizzically at The Thinker or pondering the immensity of The Gates of Hell. . . Every sculpture beckons your attention and imagination, wondering what was traversing through the mind of Rodin when his hands morphed the marble. Stunning!

Very good but I'd defer it if your time is limited. "The Thinker" is impressive and the maison gorgeous. This is the home of Rodin and its filled with his works, but if you have only a week or less, there is so much in Paris, I would recommend you consider this for your second trip. Of course if you are especially interested in sculpture or Rodin himself, then the home and grounds are well presented and definitely go. There is a fee.

It was a quick trip. I went to the museum to see "The Thinker". Since it was outside, I walked around a bit, took my pictures and left. There was construction, and I didn't much more, but it was fine. Probably prettier in the spring.
wait until renovations done. The inside museum is being rennovated. The garden is great but in January somewhat cold. Good cafe in the garden however and the entrace fee to the garden is only 2 Euros

Currently a muddy construction site. We enjoyed seeing "The Thinker", and imagining how gorgeous the gardens must be in summer. However, at the moment the house is closed and is a construction site, the gardens behind the house are mud and (of course) bare trees and much of the garden was inaccessible anyway because they were erecting a huge tent structure - presumably for some sort of function as this museum is privately funded and has to raise money though private functions. Still it would be a great place to visit when it is all open and the gardens are green.
Favorite. This is my favorite musee in all of Paris. The buildings have a history of their own.The rose gardens are fabulous. Rodin sings to you here.

Digestible. An intimate museum and garden with digestible amount to see in a few leisurely hours. Interesting to see familiar works, like "The Kiss", Gates of Hell" and "The Thinker" in smaller scales, studies for final large bronzes.

Perhaps a lesser known gem~. This museum wasn't on my "to do" list when I went to Paris. I am however, glad that we spotted it and decided to go and check it out. So much to see! The house itself, the art, the art in process, the large sculptures inside and out are not to be missed. The garden and grounds are just a bonus. Truly beautiful!

Wonderful place to stroll on a clear day. I save visits to most museums for overcast or rainy days but this is one where you can enjoy world-class art and gardens both indoors and out. Don't miss it! One of Paris' true gems!

ANOTHER JEWEL NOT TO BE MISSED. Conveniently located right beside Les Invalides with Napoleon's Tomb, this was Rodin's Paris home, a former convent, and is filled with famous works -- "The Kiss" probably being best known. The surrounding gardens are even more interesting and beautiful. Don't miss "The Gates of Hell" and "The Burghers of Calais": try to read about them before your visit. There is a delightful lunch bar in the gardens -- nice picnic arrangements. Those who travel with me rate this as one of the five great highlights of their trip.

One of my BUCKET LISTS!!!!!!!!!!. Gorgeous, spectacular,amazing !!!!! Any more adjectives? I literally cried standing in front of one of the most talented sculptures in history outside his garden at Musee Rodin!!! The Thinker stands proud and tall in the setting of his magnificent garden. I only remember all of his sculptures from my art history books back in college sooooo long ago!!!! Dreaming of a day that I too will come and be so close to perfection. "The Gates of Hell" is out rite splendor. It was a beautiful day when we were there, and spent at least 3hrs. Do your self a favor, we bought a 5day pass to all of the sites, and breezed through the lines without waiting. Gave us plenty of one on one time with Rodin and his wonderful. Works of fine art!!!!!

one of my favorite places. Set in a lovely mansion and it's gardens Musee Rodin gives an excellent overview of Rodin's best work. Love the indoor, outdoor aspect of this gallery and the benches in the garden thatallow for a drink while taking in the sculpture
Open air museum that should not be missed. This is the place where you must go on a pleasant day when you are not rushed, to give time to leisurely examination of these masterful works of art.

perfect little museum. If you like sculpture this place is not to be missed. It is the perfect size, with sculptures not only by Rodin by also many by Camille Claudel. The gates of hell is incredible, the garden setting is perfectly conceived to complement the beautiful sculptures.The only thing I didn't like were the weird noises emanating from the speakers surrounding the sculptures - a little strange

Good, but in reparation. The museum is really good, every year we come to Paris we visit the place, but this monts and next is on maintenance, so the garden has partial access, and the house-former-hotel, is semi closed, there is a partial exposition by the main entry, but , not as great as regular access.So be prepared after mid Feb to get full access, anyway the garden and partial exhibition is good enough

Parfait!. For people who like Rodin this place is a must-see in Paris, the museum is fantastic and the gardens absolutely wonderful. It is possible to spend the whole day there as there is a good restaurant inside. if the weather is good spending time on the gardens is one of the best things to do in Paris.

A garden of Art. This is a terrific museum that houses some absolutely amazing works both indoors and outdoors. Of course, the highlight is seeing The Thinker and The Gates of Hell. The weather was bsolutely drop dead gorgeous that day, bright, sunny and warm. Just perfect for seeing some of the most wonderful works of one of the great artists of the last century.

Outstanding Sculpture on Display. Beautiful sculpture in a museum garden setting. Lines may be long for the tour of the restored Hotel Biron on the grounds, but well worth the wait. Works by the woman sculpture Camille Claudel are on display in the Hotel Biron and are outstanding. For picture taking outdoors, the cloudy overcast days are best as there is less reflection off the bronze sculptures. You can take all the pictures you want (without flash).
You will not beleive the talent of this man and the rose garden beautiful!. The gardens are fantastic, his sculptures fabulous, one of the best museums to visit in Paris and he has a VanGogh too!

Best museum in Paris. Took us a while to get there, but it was worth it! You don't have to be an avid sculpture fan to appreciate this special Museum. The interior is packed with many great pieces by Rodin from all parts of his long career and the garden hosts the famous Thinking Man. The Victor Hugo portrait is a personal favorite.
worth a visit. The gardens are lovely and would be more so in spring &summer. The house/museum has a nice selection without being overwhelming. I love sculptures, so this museum ticked all the boxes.

Stunning Garden and House. Just a stunning garden and house, it is worth a visit just to see these alone then you remember there are beautiful sculptures throughout by a master. Just get lost in a wonderland.

Am now a Rodin admirer.. We just returned from Paris and took the time to visit the Rodin museum. It was wonderful. The museum is not as daunting as the Louvre and contains many of Rodin's famous pieces. I would recommend the English Audio guide. It is very well done and gives you lots of pertinent information. We spent less than 2 hours and felt like we had seen everything. The only downside was, we were there in the winter. I am sure the gardens would be spectacular in the spring/summer.
Plaster Casts of Rodin, and his house. If you are looking for his sculptures for get it. Try elsewhere. This is his workshop and casts. I love his sculptures and I am not a mold person.

Just admired the gardens. While I can't say I went into the actual house/museum, I did spend time in the gardens, and if you just want a relaxing day, you could spend an entire afternoon here as it is very quiet and relaxing. You have several of Rodin's most famous works in the gardens anyway.

There's a lot more to Rodin than the Penseur. The sculpture garden is not quite so impressive, though there are a couple of sculptures you should not miss. It feels a little abandoned, specially in the marble area. The inside, however, is quite a nice collection of Rodin's works (a series of his pieces are exhibited in chronological order while the museum's works are in progress), as well as a temporary exhibit with his insights on classical sculpture. Worth the trip and just across the street from the Invalides complex.

An beautiful garden. The garden of this museum is worth visiting for the beautiful sculptures set in a lovely garden. There is also a cafe in the garden with nice tables and chairs under parasols. The food and drinks were simple but good. Unfortunately self service but otherwise excellent. A lovely place to sit and enjoy the garden.

Intimate museum, lovely grounds. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing Rodin's sculptures, and the Camille Claudel's pieces were a particular favorite - enjoyed them even more. The museum is a nice scale. Significant works in an intimate setting. We visited in the winter and the grounds were lovely. They must be very beautiful in the spring and summer. If you are going to tour a number of museums, get the museum pass and skip the entry line. The cafe here is also very nice.

Hard to fault a memorial to genius (but be warned!!). The location and layout of this museum is just stunning and there is little I can add that others have not already written. But be warned!! When we visited we purchased the 'passport' ticket that supposedly provided 'express' entry also to the Musee D'Orsay on the same day. It does nothing of the sought. While the price is currently 15 euro for both museums (reduced from 25 euro), when we arrived at the Musee D'Orsay the queue for ticket holders (like us) was nearly as long as for those people queuing to by an 'ordinary' ticket.It is probably better to do the Musee D'Orsay early and then go to Musee Rodin, rather than the other way around.

Quaint. One of the few smaller, more quaint-feeling museums in the area... and dedicated to a sole artist (which I prefer). There were a few works from Rodin's disciples and it's best to begin with these an the other unfinished works and build up to Rodin's Masterpieces.Rodin's Thinker (large) and the museum cafe are outside so be sure to take a stroll.

for lovers. I do prefer sculptures then paintings. in this place i had and incredible time, sayer for all day long.all those images in pieces of rock converted in amazing and gentle images. the contour of the bodies, the expression on the faces.the garden itself is so beautiful and the building as well deserve part of your time.

Sculpture at its best. As a Rodin fan, I had to visit the Rodin Museum with my wife and 13 year old son whilst in Paris. We all had a fantastic time. Since art is a very personal thing, you should check out Auguste Rodin's sculptures on-line before you attend if you don't know anything about his style, but just about everyone knows "The Thinker" and "the Kiss". This museum has the advantage of having a beautiful garden containing his larger pieces, where you can find a quiet spot to just sit and ponder or chat quietly in the cafe, and then carry on with the rest of the museum. You can cover the whole place in a few hours. One tip is to get there early and avoid the queues that form on the street and inside the gate. Besides, the roses are better earlier in the morning, even if the best sculpture in the world is not your style! ;-)

favourite place in paris. Grey November day in Paris yet as I walked through the gardens the sun came out and changed everything. This is a place where you can sit and stare at some of the best sculpture ever made and as the light changes so does how you see the sculpture. Indoors is equally lovely, an old and creaky building with high ornate ceilings. It is showing its age but somehow this adds to the feeling. Loved this place. Can imagine it would be a good place to go with children, there weren't any when I was there but there was lovely space for them to move in. If you just want entry to the gardens its only one or two euros so a cheap but delightful place to go. Has a small cafe - nothing exceptional but adequate for a quick coffee.

A most precious gift by Rodin to Paris. This museum is absolutely a must see while you are in Paris. Formerly the grand residence of Marechal de Biron , built by Jean Aubret during the early 18th century. On view is the world renowned "Thinker", "Gates of Hell" , and" Eve". View Rodin's expansive working collection and personal collection of exquisite masterpieces. Stroll through the gardens outside the residence and feel the presence of this master artist.

Visit the Thinker. This is a small museum that has a building and park area with Rodin sculptures. We found the visit to be very interesting and the viewing of both large and small bronze sculptures well worth the time. The building has drawings and smaller bronze sculptures. The garden has the larger sculptures and a very nice restaurant. We had the quiche and found it to be very good.

Art Fabulous, Staff & Facilities Average. We visited the Musee Rodin on December 24th and it was clear that the staff did not want to be there. The cafe and garden was closed. We understood why the cafe might be closed the day before Christmas, but many of Rodin's pieces are in the gardens and it was not clear to us why they were off limits. But, thank goodness the art does not know the calendar because Rodin's genius in the indoor pieces is there no matter the time of year. We recommend the audio guide to fully appreciate his progression as an artist. We visited the museum many years ago and had fond memories...this visit was disappointing. But, despite the let down, we recommend the museum for fans of sculpture in general and Rodin in particular.

Best deal in Paris. The interior of the museum teaches you a lot about the sculpting process of Rodin, but the best part is the garden in the back. If you skip the official museum, you can get access to the gardens for just 1 euro, an incredibly cheap price to see examples of Rodin's awe-inspiring sculptures. Its really cool to see the Gates of Hell, and then find the larger form components scattered elsewhere around the grounds. The Burghers of Calais is my favorite sculpture there.I recommend packing a light lunch and a book or a newspaper and spending some time at the back of the garden, one of the great secret hideaways in Paris.

Good museum. Great museum. The museum is located in a huge garden which has an air of tranquility which is unexpected. This museum is not so busy as some of the other paris attractions. The works of Rodin are amazing and area must see. Lunch or afternoon tea in the garden are a must

Quiet intensity. This museum is enclosed by a high wall, near the center of Paris, and --once you're inside the gates -- gives you amazingly quiet moments of reflection and solitude with the incredible statues by Rodin, most of which are outside the house, on the manicured grounds. Your first confrontation by "The Thinker" may be a surprise; you're not looking down on him, or looking at eye-level, so he's not sitting in a restroom -- he's on a pedestal, above you, looking down at you -- and the effect can't be captured by a photo in an art book. Before you visit these works, though, in fairness you might be interested to find out some information about Camille Claudel, Rodin's mistress, and competitor.
Interesting. To see Rodin's work and his collection gives a new unique insight beyond reading and seeing the pictures in the books.

Not to be missed. The museum itself is one of the most interesting in the city, however the same stands for its beautiful gardens. Take a little extra time to enjoy the magnificent works of Rodin, and stroll in the gardens of his old house.

Underrated and overlooked museum of a master sculptor's works. Easy-to-find museum with more than enough works of beauty by the master sculptor Rodin besides the famous The Thinker (you can sit (and think?) with him in the garden) and The Kiss.

hidden gem!. My family and I visited here during the height of tourist season. It was fantastic! While the super popular sights were packed with people we enjoyed this peaceful, beautiful garden almost by ourselves! The works here are outstanding. The gardens are meticulous. The "Gates of Hell" is amazing and of course the "Thinker" is a classic. Excellent place to visit when the Louvre is packed to the ceiling! And it's included in your museum pass!

The Master Sculptor. One of the greatest sculptors of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Rodin comes alive at two museums in Paris. At the Hotel Biron museum I was able to walk through Rodin’s professional life and savor his decorative works, be introduced to his circle of friends, learn how he played with materials and discern the subtle differences between his works in 1880 and those in 1900. He was one of those rare artists who could organize an exhibition of his own works in the Pavilion de l’Alma in the year 1900. Meanwhile, in the museum in Meudon, I, an art lover was enchanted by the collection displayed there and of course, by the workshop where Rodin spent a majority of his working life. As an art lover, I would have been chastised if I did not visit the Rodin museum when I was in Paris. The monographic museum is an art lover’s temple.

Nice suprise. I took my art illiterate husband to this museum on a quiet rainy day in Paris, he thought looking at sculpture would be more his style rather than paintings. Well this museum has it all, I saw my first Monet of the trip here, the stone and marble work was very impressive but the 'Gates of Hell' alone is worth admission!!!Gorgeous grounds, filled with works of art, all made for a lovely afternoon.
a most see in Paris. in a beautifull old mansión with beautifull gardens this collections is shown in a nice way to enjoy it m ost.

I'm a sucker for museums, especially with a docent. The Rodin Museum was very enjoyable. Lots of beautiful sculptures of all types. Many of the sculptures are outside in a beautiful courtyard/garden setting so you can see them in interesting light. This museum was not crowded at all so you could get good up-close views of the work. And it's not a far walk from the Eiffel Tour where many are likely to visit anyway.

An Artistic Marvel. Go see this incredible house and the gardens filled with sculptures.The museum is filled with more of Rodins works than imagined. Then stroll the gardens afterward, superb. Not to be missed.

A lovely place!!. I was never a huge fan of Rodin's art before I visited the museum. I love how his sculptures are outside and you can view them in the round. The estate itself is lovely for the gardens and greenery. We ran out of time and didn't get to visit the museum inside unfortunately. However, the outside sculptures and gardens were worth the admission price (was included in the Museum Pass).

Beautiful sculptures. Free with museum pass which is a must. Many of Rodin's sculptures are outdoor at the museum and make this worth the visit. In doors is most of his collection which is hit or miss.

A small oasis. Behind the walls that you see from the sidewalk is a small oasis. Rodin works are placed throughout the gardens which surround the house. There is a small café in the gardens for lunch or refreshments. We found the gardens more interesting than the interior of the house.

A wonderful museum. The Rodin Museum is situated in the middle of a lovely park/garden which, on a sunny day, is a delight to walk through. When we were there, an exhibit of Camille Claudel's sculptures was being shown, and I particularly appreciated her work, having read about her and seen an old film about her, it was touching to see her work there among that of Rodin, a man she loved so passionately.

Lovely. This is a beautiful house with amazing art in it, but they need to spend some money of renovating the house as it is shockingly in disrepair especially on the inside. It is very eductional and romantic. The gardens are lovely and the outside of the house is idealic. My 14 year old who loves art loved it. You only need a couple of hours there so you can fit in other things too. A good price to get in too a family of 4 only 10 euros. How good is that.

small but very cute. it's in the garden where we can see the most beautiful work of Rodin. the rooms are interesting too when they present the history of Rodin's work and some collections. in the garden you have a very nice cafeteria for sunny days

Great. I traveled with my vision-impaired mother in a wheelchair. Unfortunately. the lift was being renovated so we were limited to the main floor. Mom was thrilled that they gave her a glove to touch some of the works.

Beautiful Gardens Surround 'The Thinker'. Even if you never went inside the lovely mansion that houses Rodin's and other artists works you can feel the serenity that surrounds it in the beautiful gardens. A perfect location with the golden dome of Invalides visible just past 'The Thinker'. A lovely and well presented museum. Beautiful roses and very nice little cafe tucked away in gardens behind the mansion. This museum is quaint and only requires about an hour or so. A must see!

Very impressive. You don't even need to go inside the museum to see most of Rodin's most famous sculptures. They are displayed in the beautiful formal gardens surrounding the old building where he used to live. If you go inside you can see other works, portraits of the artist, and also works by Camille Claudel, to which he was not very kind. I'm sorry I found that out. If you are in a rush to see the sights in Paris, spend an hour in the gardens. Use the spare time to see Napoleon's tomb in the building next door (only half a mile away)!

House and garden behind the walls. The house portion of the museum has a varied history--owned by the Church, and then the state, and used by various artists as studio space in the early 1900s. (It could use some restoration…) In addition to a portion of Rodin's works, there are some paintings by famous people like Van Gogh….The extensive garden/lawn is a peaceful respite from the city streets. The cafe is a small modern cafeteria along one side of the gardens. Standard fare.

An absolute jewel. This petit hôtel presents a collection of some of Rodin's best known works. Very well displayed, the best is to stroll the gardens and see the placement of the Gate to Hell (were the Thinker is the center piece) and the Bougeois de Calais. It is good to read about the museum and its exhibits before going because then the statues speak to us. Just a few blocks away you can also visit Les Invalides (Napoleon's and his most important general's tombs). Do not miss, you will then understand why English has kept the word 'grandeur' in French

Visit in Summer. While the sculpture in this museum is outstanding, the best part of the visit was strolling through the gardens. A respite from the bustle of the 7th arrondissement. Hard to believe that this museum is situated in the center of Paris!

Wonderful Museum at 7th district. Museum is wonderful with a nice park, in a beautiful house.Very quiet for a nice visit in 7th district Paris. Also, Museum is not too far from Eiffel Tower by walk, you can cross nice areas such as Rue de L'Exposition, where Art Galleries and restaurants are located.

The hands of a genius. Most of us know about The Thinker, probably the most recognized sculpture in the world. But Rodin created much more, and even more beautiful and powerful works which are on display at this dedicated museum and garden. Some have written that you only need to see the gardens, which are beautiful, but the house contains so much in addition that it would be a shame to miss it. This is a "don't miss it" destination for sure. Enjoy!

Another little known spot. I went to Paris with my wife with the intent of showning her things she never thought she'd see and for me to see my list of things to see before I die. The Thinker was on this list. I thought this would be a relatively small museum but the garden was amazing we ended up having lunch and spending most of the after noon there. Lots of statues,a nice stroll around beautiful gardens. It was a nice deversion from the touristy spots in Paris.

Don't miss it!. I kept missing it on previous visits for lack of time, so I planned to go there on the second day of my visit this time. You'd be enamored of this place, the sculptures are breathtaking, the building is beautiful though it could use some care. Take a walk in the garden and enjoy the many sculptures scattered along the way. I particularly liked the several busts of Balzac who was apparently close friends with Rodin. And, have the best ice cream in town at the small stand outside the cafeteria! We tried the famous Berthillon ice cream but preferred the chocolate Rocher served at the museum.

Under Extensive Renovation. This (the greatest collection of Rodin in the world) museum is self-financed (no government money supports it) and both the lovely gardens and museum itself are undergoing extensive renovations. Go for the incredible collection but wait until the rebuilding is done.

Don't miss this one. We visited the Rodin Museum because we had time on our fifth day in Paris. It is a must see if you like sculptures. Rodin has been described as one of the best modern sculptors we have today. I am glad we had the time to visit. It is across the street from Napoleon's tomb which was interesting but certainly not as wonderful as the Rodin.

Outdoor Exposure - Beautiful. If you are in Paris, you must to see this Museum. It is very beautiful.It is an outdoor exposure, with beautiful gardens.You walk on the extended garden looking the Rodin's sculptures. It is a nice and relax ride.

Fantastic location and garden. We bought a joint ticket with Musee Orsay (which is fantastic) so Musee Rodin was a little disappointing. The house (under much needed refurbishment) is magnificent and some information about its history would have been interesting. The garden is magnificent and the bronzes at their best. The exhibits within were a little disappointing.

Peace and tranquility. During our visit in October there were renovations taking place, so there was limited access to the premises. Despite that we were able to access many of the sculptures in the garden. The children loved being able to touch and interact with the massive static lifeforms. The gardens also have a sand pit - despite the ages of my children (6,9 & 11) they all enjoyed some time out having a play in the sand. While the parents enjoyed being able to sit and enjoy the lushness of the garden. bring a book or good companion while you watch the children play.
Amazing Sculpture and Art. The art and sculpture was amazing. Unfortunately the grounds were under construction so I was unable to enjoy some of the gardens and outdoor sculpture.

Small, charming museum. This was a small museum that was partially closed off for renovations. What we could see we loved though. The gardens are beautiful and the old house that it is housed in is amazing all by itself.

A must see. Nice small museum. Great work. First we had a walk through the garden and we ended by the famous sculpture "Le Penseur" . Inside the old villa you will get a good impresser about the life and work of Rodin.

Great museum but.... I have been here twice. Beautiful works of sculpture, great gardens. This visit, howevwer in November of 2013 was disappointing as half the house was closed for renovation and "The Kiss" sculpture was not on display. Check before you go.

A nice place to escape to. A wonderful garden atmosphere with Rodin sculptures scattered through out. Had a quick lunch in the outdoor cafe. No too many people when we were there so it felt like we had the place to ourselves.

Unbelievable gardens and sculptures!. Definitely worth a visit! Both the inside and outside sculptures were fantastic, but the garden setting made the outside better, even though it was raining the day we went.
Very nice. If you like Rodin, you'll like both the museum and the garden. It's a very nice stroll through the garden. Walkable from the Rue Cler area. Napoleon's tomb is nearby also.

Well worth a visit. I have been to Paris 20 times and have visited le Musée Rodin three times...not enough. This museum is not only an exhibition of the works of this great master but it is also a beautiful setting in a lovely neighborhood. My favorite thing to do is to walk outside on the lovely grounds, surrounded by the great sculptures amidst the beauty of nature. If you seek a quiet environment with magnificent art in a fantastic city, this is the place to go.

Stunning. Rodin's work is amazing and if you're in Paris you have to see 'The Thinker.' Large replication outside the museum in the terrace but the real one is inside. The museum is Rodin's old house, I believe. You get a entrance time and then wait in a line with people that were given the same time to enter, 1:30pm, 2pm for instance. Depending on when you get there you may have to wait 30 min for the group before you to finish.

Exactly as Rodin planned!. When in Paris, save time for a visit to the Musee Rodin, located near the Eiffel Tower and Les Invalides. The restored mansion that is the home of the Museum is part of the grand plan that Rodin put together as a lasting monument to his work/life in Paris. There is also historic representation of the work of Camille Claudel, his protege and lover. The grounds are magnificent and provide a perfect setting for some of Rodin's most famous sculptures. Plan a few hours and let your heart take you on a journey through some of the most beautiful evocative sculptures ever made.

People climbing all over the statues. What a circus this place has become. SEveral years ago it was a lovely garden with fabulous statues. Now it is so full of tourists, many Asian, who climb all over the statues and pose for hundreds of pictures. They really ruin the experience. Not as bad indoors where there is no where to climb and mug for photos. Aside from that, the work of Rodin and Camile Claudel is worth the visit.

A lovely way to spend a couple of hours in Paris. The exterior gardens, full of statues and greenery, are a wonderful place for a short stroll in Paris and the small museum within the chateau is just the right size for the museum-loving and not-so-museum-loving crowd.

too many people to get in. Walked around the grounds which were full of statues from Rodin, but could not get into the museum due to a one hour wait! This was October at 4.00 in the afternoon, so very surprised and didnt bother waiting.

Only for Rodin fans. This is the Museum to see for amateurs of Rodin. It's very close to the Invalides and you can visit that place as well. The lighting in the building in not top-notch but the sculptures make up for it.

Excellent and Relaxing. This is a lovely museum that is a lot quieter and more relaxing than some of the other museums in Paris. Some of it was closed for refurbishment when I visited but there was a selection of marble statues on display, you could also visit the rooms in the house and the gardens were fantastic. Great for wandering around with hidden statues and other works of art as well as benches for sitting and relaxing and taking in the views, you could forget you were in the centre of a city. Entry free with Paris Pass.
If you like Rodin, you have to go. A small museum with beautiful grounds. Two floors of all of his sculptures with more scattered around the beautiful grounds

I loved it, family less interested. I could not get enough of this museum, really enjoyed the fine collection of Rodin pieces, particularly the pieces that are more "raw". It was a nice day so also enjoyed walking the grounds, the garden is pretty. My family was less interested in Rodin; while they enjoyed the museum they were "done" well before me and could not find a comfortable spot to sit and wait.

Park meets art. The garden is lovely to stroll around and chill in and admire the sculptures. One of the things that makes this museum especially interesting is exactly the fact that the sculptures are exhibited outside in the park and not behing fences or glass or indoors like most art. It's worth seeing :)

A lovely museum if you like sculpture. The Musee Rodin is a delightful spot in Paris where you can stroll in the garden and then have a glass of wine. I must admit I was a bit "sculptured out" by then end of. The Gates of Hell are beautifully and intricately carved.

Love it!. The first Sunday of each month the admission is free. If you arrive early you enjoy the museum without the crowd. The early bird gets the worm. The museum is very small, however the pieces are amazing: the kiss, the thinker, Iris messagère des Dieux among others. There are also pieces of Camille Claudel (Rodin’s lover), and two Vincent van Gogh. The gardens are beautiful and peaceful, and you can walk around Rodin’s sculptures, or just relax and read a good book. This museum is a gem in Paris. It’s worth visiting.

While away a few hours absorbing the sculptures. Do get the audio guides. The outside is much improved on my last visit and would be good for a picnic. The sculptures captured the full attention of my 10 year old and a near octogenarian who said before going he never really got this medium.
A True gem. The many Rodin sculptures as well as Impressionist paintings in a lovely home with exquisite garden setting make this a not to miss museum in Paris

Nice to see variety and evolution in style. You can wonder indoors and out to see various works in different mediums. They are able to show you how Rodin's works changed as he moved ro different media. Visited Sept. 2009.

An amazing collection of great works. This museum offers a low cost taste of Rodin's major works in the garden. His home was a great building and hold many more works, but I personally prefer the garden and its cafe. The statues get lots of space. It is also a good place to buy a Museum Pass to avoid lines in other musuems.

A must. Our day for a visit was a free day so lines were long and light rain scared us from waiting. But the outside sculptures were great especially the Thinker...
Small outside snack area also available.

Peaceful Gardens. One of the few museums in Paris without a long queue for entry, this is great value at only 1 euro to see the gardens only. The sculptures are well placed out and there is plenty of room for a wander without feeling remotely crowded. The gardens are lovely and peaceful, and there is a cafe to the side with a fair amount of seating. Well worth a trip.

One of my favorite places. Not only does this house many of Rodin's great works, but from an historical point of view, it's exciting as it is actually his home and his grounds. After going through the museum, be sure and save time to go through the grounds. There are nice arias to sit and contemplate and the grounds have many of his works on display as well. It's a highlight by anyone's standard.

More than the Thinker. This is a small but worthwhile museum. There were so many different styles of Rodin's work - both inside, and out in the gardens. We even saw a Van Gogh hanging on the wall. The history of Rodin and the hotel turned museum was very informative.

Beautiful gardens. We went to the Rodin museum when the Orsay was closed due to "safety concerns". We were glad we did. The gallery itself is a good retrospective of Rodin's work, but the gardens are the perfect place for his sculptures.

One of my favorites, getting a little run down.. I have always loved Rodin and his elemental, powerful sculptures. The Museum is a must visit, if nothing else, to see the Thinker. The grounds are wonderful but the museum is pretty run down. They are refurbishing it now so it may well be better in the future but could be a bit of disappointment before it's finished. One particularly nice bonus is they have some of the works of Camille Claudel (his wife and student). Where Rodin shows raw energy and power in his sculpture, she shows incredible sensitivity. Frankly, there are times when I like her work better as it conveys beauty while Rodin's often conveys pain, suffering and anguish.

Hidden attraction away from tourists. It's hidden in a quiet place in Paris and I would recommend if you really want to appreciate some beautiful artwork and history - this is away from all the tourists attraction so you can really take the time to appreciate the work and the environment surround. Although renovation still under development, but it's still worth the visit. Each sculpture is beautiful crafted and still in awe how much time, effort and energy that's put into each as you can see in the details. In addition to Rodin's work, it'd be good to see more of his life. He's fought three times to secure Musee Rodin to store his life work but it's a pity he never get to see this through before his death.

Living Stone that Moves You. We all know Rodin was a good sculptor. This lovely "hotel particulier" near Les Invalides (Napoleon's tomb and the military museum) brings home the fact that he captured humanity in sone and bronze. The sculpture pieces outdoors (including The Thinker, The Kiss, Balzac, the Doors of Hell, the Burghers of Calais) allow you to see his work in natural light, and to walk around the pieces as you cannot indoors. The works inside are smaller and bring you closer to Rodin's mastery. Art students often sit on the floor inside or on benches outside, sketching. And there is a good gift shop. Worth two hours, or more.
An oasis. Some fantastic sculptures in a peaceful setting. Some areas still under development but worth the visit
A must see!. This museum was lovely, charming, and showed the most famous works of this artist. The self guided tour with commentary just added to the experience.

Didn't meet expectations. While there were plenty of sculptures for viewing, the museum is run down. The is little explanation or history to accompany the art work, and the art is not particularly well displayed. The gardens were partially closed off due to another event that had closed and was being deconstructed. This museum is not supported by the state, relying on private donations and fundraising... and it shows.

Great Gardens. This should really be on the list of must do attractions. It is much more than just the thinker which should be enough. Try to go in the afternoon on a nice day. The gardens are great and there are plenty of shady areas that allow you to relax.
The Thinker!. We wanted to see the thinker & as the garden was under renovation to our luck there was no charge. We even got the opportunity to see a whole lot more.

Lovely indoor and outdoor collection. Exceptional opportunity to balance indoor exhibits with the well kept, pleasant gardens with so many scuptures.Weather permitting, use a nice sunny day for this excellent museum: you will not regret the time spent between the gardens where giant sculptures will be waiting for you.You can see roof of Les Invalides from the garden, as well as the Eiffel tower, so it is a lovely way to capture different pictures. The house and indoors collection is the expected experience you'd have in most museums. Would go back again and again, just to watch the different looks provided by the flowers !

Amazing and a must see!. Toured the grounds only, but still worth the time! Serene and haunting. Amazing to see the individual statues - The Thinker, Ugolino, and the Three Shades joined together on The Gates of Hell piece - wow! The crowd was manageable and unrushed. My 2nd favorite museum in Paris! Entry included w/Museum Pass.

Didn't make the interior. It was closed the day we tried and we regret not having enough time to return. Sit on the top of the double decker Red Bus tour - you can photograph the Thinker from that vantage point if you have no time left to visit.

A must see if you have the time.. This was the first time I visited the museum in all of my trips to Paris and it was well worth it. It was a beautiful day and the grounds and statues were a lot better than I expected, especially at the far end of the grounds near the fountains. Obviously the "Thinker" is a must see. I was surprised it was outside. Inside the House I found it to be a delightful treat. Seeing "The Kiss" was a thrill. I spent two hours at the museum and wish I had stayed longer. Some things were better than others but the skill and tallent of the artist was quite evident.

Lovely, country feel. We loved the art as well as the space of this museum. It almost feels like you're outside of the city in the French countryside. Try to get there early before the crowds. We got there when it opened and an hour later, it was pretty crowded so I imagine it's a lot worse even later. We liked the outdoor space and sculpture the best so perfect for a good weather day.

To see Rodin and Claudel in one spot - marvelous.. I liked that there was sculpture in the garden. Unfortunately, a good part of the garden is under some type of renovation so we couldn't see as much of it as I would have liked. I was very happy to see that along with magnificent sculptures by Rodin, there was also work of Camille Claudel. It was presented inside an old mansion, beautiful old windows, and a sweeping staircase. We visited it with the pass that we bought before we traveled that gave us admission to over 70 museums in Paris. Highly recommend getting a pass, as a lot of the museums had long lines for people waiting to buy tickets, even though we were after the season, visiting in October.
Wonderful. This museum is just the right size. The sculptures are beautiful, the grounds are very well tended and the satire experience is not to be missed. A must do for art lovers.

Reconstruction underway. We looked forward to seeing this lovely garden and the beautiful mansion that became the Museum. Unfortunately for our timing there is major renovation and conservation work going on limiting you access to the gardens and the house. We toured what space of the garden was open and it is lovely with lots of roses in bloom. The original thinker, the Gates of Hell and Balzac among other works are on display in the garden. Sadly after our entrance, we were told the wait to view the museum collection in the building would be 2 1/2 hours . That was just to long to spend in the limited space available in the garden so we put off the tour until another trip.If you have a city pass you will bypass the long line but be prepared for a significant wait for your chance to tour the main building.

Disappointing but relaxing. There was the The Thinker, Gates of Hell, a plaster model of The Kiss but everything else was underwhelming. Forget the sculptures, take the opportunity to walk in the garden behind the home, sit in the museum cafe and relax in this tranquil oasis in the middle of the city.

still thrills after 45 years. a tranquil beautiful spot in the heart of Paris.. I haven't visited for 45 years but was thrilled all over again by the incredible contorted passion in the the statues... they are in the middle of refurbishing the gardens and some of the inside rooms... but it didn't make any difference.. there was plenty to see and enjoy... couldn't recommend it hightly enough

Hauntingly beautiful. Hauntingly beautiful (even without the creepy music and laughter playing in the shrubs.) Great place to pass 2 hours in Paris and not overcrowded or overwhelming. Hard to believe that such tranquil gardens can be found in the midst of a city, but then again this is Paris. The Thinker is the most striking piece as you enter (or leave if you work from left to right!) while the Gates of Hell is superb from a craftsmanship perspective but scary from any other.

Well worth visit.... The Museum Rodin is located beside the Army Museum and it was one of the museums I liked most. It's entirely dedicated to the sculptor August Rodin. You probably have heard about his work or even seen them...the most famous are "the thinker" and "the gates of hell". The second one, in my opinions is the most amazing sculpture I've seen...full of details. The price is quite cheap (6 euros for adult) and you can see everything in 1 hour or 2 hours maximum depending on your taste for Rodin.O museu Rodin fica do lado do Museu das Armas e foi um do museus que eu gostei mais. Ele e inteiramente dedicado ao escultor August Rodin, Voce provavelmente ja ouviu falar das esculturas dele ou ate mesmo ja as viu...as mais famosas sao "o pensador" e "os portoes do inferno". A segunda em particular, na minha opiniao e a mais magnifica que eu ja vi na vida...cheia de detalhes. O preco tambem e bem justo (6 euros para adulto) e voce pode ver tudo em 1 ou 2 horas dependendo do seu gusto por Rodin.

The garden makes this museum.. The museum itself felt crowded, and not well cared for; it is still easy to wander around and get caught up in the amazing pieces of art. Walking outside of the buildings and into the garden is what really makes this small museum worth the trip. Scattered throughout the garden are paths leading to various sculptures and quiet benches. Walk anywhere through the garden for gorgeous views of the glistening dome atop Napoleons tomb, and the Eiffel tower peeking through the trees and shrubbery for some lovely photo opportunities. Well worth the 6 euros, I would definitely make a second trip my next visit to Paris.

Great for history, art and a pleasant distraction. Musee Rodin is easy to find near Invalides. This mini-estate features a beautiful home that has been restored and filled with art and sculpture by Rodin and his contemporaries. The grounds are landscaped to enhance the many sculptures. Seeing the Gates of Hell is a moving experience. Take the time to walk the gardens and get caught in the rain (like we did). It is a wonderful memory that will stay with you for a very long time.

Disappointed my favorite pieces were not on display. Apparently our mid-September visit coincided with the Musee Rodin's revamping of the facilities and displays. My favorite pieces were not on display; the main building was being renovated; and the special display area was closed.The Musee Rodin is one of my favorites in Paris. The gardens were still beautiful in September, even though it was cool and rainy. And Rodin's sculptures are incredible.

What a gift of work and a life of dedication to enjoy. the title says it all. The history of Hotel Biron alone which houses the treasures of Rodin along with so much more, including public gardens and exhibits. Easy to get lost for an entire afternoon.

Delightful!!. We attended the Musee Rodin on the first Sunday of the month which is when most museums in Paris are free. It is a smaller museum and is an easy visit. I loved the exhibits and the garden.

You should pay a visit for sure.... The museum has a wonderful garden with many of Rodin's sculptures around. The museum (former home of Rodin and also Matisse) also includes varios studies of Rodin. You can also get a chance to see two Van Goghs and a Matisse painting.

Its a Museum!. To me, I have a joking limit of 17 minutes in a museum! I do enjoy walking through, but they are not my favorite attractions. If I break 17 minutes it must be good. This was good as was the Louvre (huge crowds). Well worth a look.

Fantastic body of work. Loved walking around the garden looking at these incredible sculptures. If on a tight budget, just visit the garden. Visit here first and buy a combined ticket to the Musée D'Orsay to avoid queuing at the latter.

Disappointing. Perhaps the museum has indeed a great collection, however when I visited the garden was closed. Embarrassingly, only one side of the garden was fenced off, so when I entered through the other side a guard followed me to tell me the garden was closed. Therefore, what's inside the building is extremely poor and I would have preferred for the museum to get on with their renovation works without taking my money. There was some warning at the ticket desk, but you don't know exactly what is unavailable to view unless you've been before. The two best works on display inside the building are the Age of Bronze and St.John the Baptist and if you happen to live in London like me you can see them for free at the V&A anytime.

Can someone please donate a fortune .... This museum isnt befitting the artistic monument Auguste Rodin. It's shabby, worn down. Yes they are currently refurbishing a apart of the museum but that looks like just a patchup job, nothing structural. Such a shame. Tip: When visiting Orsay and Rodin in one day you can buy a combiticket. With the museum de rodin in this state its worth the discount. If you leave room for an hour and a half you have plenty of time to visit the museum itself. The garden is a nice place to relax from the parisian busy streets.

"Le Penseur" sculpture is not the only artwork at this site!. Of course, "The Thinker" sculpture is something all tourists should view. However, the outdoor grounds of this museum has so many other wonderful sculptures. Take the time to walk around and view them. Also, inside the museum are not only more beautiful sculptures by Rodin, but also artwork he purchased Van Gogh, Cezanne, and many other famous artists. Don't miss out on this wonderful museum.

Wonderful sculptures. We loved the sculpture garden. The museum building was less engaging. the day we visited was quire hot and the museum AC was not keeping up -- it was unpleasantly humid, warm and stuffy inside. We could not tolerate it very long. But most of the well-known sculptures seemed to be in the garden, and it was a lovely, shady, cool place, very peaceful and quiet, a nice respite from the bustle of Paris in June.

Most of Rodin´s works concentrated in a beautiful building. From time to time, I come back to the Rodin Museum. For those who appreciate his work and the work from Camille Claudel, who was his lover for life, this is the place to visit.The building is a beautiful chateau, former Rodin´s house, and it has a very nice garden also full of art, including his famous works the Thinker and the Gates of Hell. It is the type of museum that I like, because you can manage to visit it all and not become frustrate that most of the collection was not possible to see. No, here, if you have 2 hours, you still can see the collection. But I would advise making it a half day, so it is possible to see well works both inside the chateau and in the garden and yet relax a bit in the nice environment.Nowadays, there is a late opening until 11 PM on Wednesdays.

A New Appreciation for Rodin. Rodin's greatest works are in this museum and the gardens around it. I always liked this artist, but I was unaware of his paintings and ceramic works. The Thinker is here, of course, as is The Gates of Hell. In addition, there are several of his works with which I was unfamiliar. It is open late on Wednesdays.

Musee Rodin. My companion was a fellow art teacher who also spoke fluent French making for a perfect day. Within this intimate building and exterior yard showcasing both his creative process and his completed sculptures was amazing. Auguste Rodin's small portrait busts were an unexpected element as well as his sketches and other 2-D art.process. Of course, his famous bronzes "The Thinker" & "The Gates of Hell" were featured outside. Surprising to me was the beauty & expertise of his lover's work by Camille Pissaro. Unfortunately, he apparently took credit for some of her sculptural pieces so she never received her well-deserved aclaim. Lovely Luxemburg Gardens we strolled through was close enough to do same day. Don't forget cash for the use of public toilets--attendants expect euros for keeping facility spotless.

Great Museum to see Rodin's Work. We visited the Rodin museum and enjoyed our visit. The museum is not a large museum but houses many of Rodin's pieces and is nicely set up to enjoy the pieces without being overwhelmed.
