The gardens outside are just as nice; however, we visited in early October when it was quite chilly and did not stay outside. We had the museum pass when we visited so again, were able to skip the lines. There wasn't an overly long line to gain entry to the museum but time spent not waiting in line is better spent enjoying the great pieces of art. Additional pieces of Rodin's work can also be seen at the Museum D'Orsay.

Wait until the renovations are finished. I checked the website for Musee Rodin before going but it doesn't really give the fairest impression of the extent of the renovations or the character of the temporary displays. They looked and felt very temporary, displayed in a cramped and uninspiring way, and generally gave the air of being half-finished. Even the park was undergoing some kind of work so was only partially accessible. No doubt the reinterpretation of the collections and new displays will be fantastic, so save your money and avoid disappointment and go in 2014.

Not Crowded at all. Lovely and the gardens are a nice retreat. Not only Rodin's work, but several of his cronies art is there too. You will be walking up stairs. I did not notice an elevator for the main building. Nice little cafe toward the rear, not cheap, but a for a quick coffee or water and salad it's reasonable.

Beautiful estate and museum. We loved both the museum and the grounds. The museum is very well done, not too dense with art. I can get overwhelmed by the density in art in museums like Louvre, but not here. This was a relaxing experience. I recommend the Paris museum pass, which covers entry to the Rodin. Don't miss this!

Must see if you love Rodin. I've seen a lot of Rodin's work over the years, but the breadth and depth of the exhibit were eye-opening. The center of the garden was overtaken by the Fashion Week tent but the building and the work inside was wonderful. Also, it is only a short walk from Musee d'Orsay.
Small and Lovely. This museum can be seen in an hour and is a nice change from the lines ups at the Louvre. The artwork is lovely inside as well as in the gardens.
Was not impressed at all. I was looking forward to seeing more art work and sculptures. Unfortunately, I was disappointed. The gardens were the only thing I liked about this museum.

Enchantment,spicy detail and Rubenesque figurines. To dedicate a musee to a French sculptor is one thing, but to consecrate a beautiful building to house a collection that exceeds 6600 sculptures,8000 drawings,8000 old photographs and 7000 objets d'art,is simply amazing,astounding and profoundly intriguing. The prodigious Rodin was a master of his craft and as you are assaulted by the sheer volume and intoxicating depth of his character,you begin to appreciate the complexity,warmth and passion, that his collections evoke. So,if you want to see 'The Thinker,The Kiss and the Gates of hell', you have to pay homage at this remarkable edifice located near Varenne Metro station. The gardens is where you will appreciate many of his large and whimsical works in a natural surrounding with a lake, and a small eatery. The galleries along the garden paths are a tranquil oasis. Considering you are within striking distance of Invalids and the Eiffel tower,this 18th century mansion is surrounded by 3 hectares of peaceful and romantic gardens decorated with plants,shrubs that showcase Robin's sculptures. But its only inside that you see the magic which his avid collections of drawings,engravings,ceramics and antiques, truly enriches our sense of the charm and sophistication that this master conveys. The diversity of his offerings is amazing,for not only did he create,but was an avid collector of other artists' works. See if you pick the casual,Monet,van Gogh and Renoirs around. I was astounded by how much his works were based on allegory and mythology.  You lovers of curves,will not miss the definite Rubenesque touches to his figures. i was particularly drawn to his drawings, which are equally mesmerising as his sculptures. This establishment cannot be viewed in a hurry,so rewind your time-clock and allow the beauty and the magic to seep- in.  I am thirsting now to see his studio in the heights of Meudon and wish i could attend the wonderful programmes of events that always occure when i am not here. Boo-Hoo.

Just wanted to eat cheese. I just wanted to eat cheese after a grueling cycling holiday but my friend dragged me to the Rodin Museum and I'm glad she did. I had been there before but never inside. There is always a bit of a wait for the interior of the museum (the gardens are free on Sundays and that is where you will see Balzac and the Thinker) but the wait is not bad and the museum is worth it. All the work is shown in the context of this extraordinary very old building. The Camille Claudel show was on when we were there. She was a fine artist, a very skilled sculptor you may never have seen before.
Excellent garden for relaxation. This is a great retreat from central Paris. It has great gardens and Rodin's sculptures are amazing. Reasonable price and close to other attractions.
Great for when the weather is good!. This museum has many things to see outside. So good weather is a plus. The Thinker, The Gates of Hell - just to name a few. The Museum Pass is accepted here.

A feast for your soul. Obviously you will be enchanted by Rodin's work (If you did not meat the gentlemen yet please do your homework before), life and spicy details.
But the wonder is the garden. This oasis of calm and serenity completed by some monumental sculptures is a rare treat.
Feel the karma

Enjoyed this Museum a lot. This was one of my favorite museums that we visited in Paris. I enjoy sculptures over paintings and Rodin specialized in sculptures. We used Rick Steves Guide book to get more explanations of the life of Rodin, how the museum came to be and the background on many of his sculptures. Rodin's works are found both in the museum as well as the surrounding gardens, which were beautifully maintained. Unlike so many famous painters/sculpturers of his era whose works were largely unappreciated during their lifetimes, Rodin achieve fame for his work during his lifetime and used that fame to ensure the mansion where he had worked would be turned into a museum and his works exhibited for all to see.

Seeing art where it was made. Rodin's workshop, now a museum...all in a beautiful garden setting just made for the sculptures. I have previously commented how overwhelming I found the Louvre - save it for a day when you have a lot of appetite. The D' Orsay is also pretty filling and yet less overwhelming. The Montmartre Museum and the Rodin are more digestible. They all have their place you just have to know your appetite.
I felt like I was back in his time. This is a great museum, in Rodin's home. The creaky wooden floors make you feel you'll see him around the corner. Be sure to spend time in the gardens.

Absolutely charming. Beautifully done museum. The best part is that so much of the sculpture is outdoors in a beautiful garden setting. This is where Rodin also lived so you get a real feel for the artist's life as well as his work. This was my third visit and I loved it every time. Not nearly as crowded as some of the other museums in Paris.

Visit the gardens even if you're not a Rodin fan!. For 1 euro, you can take a wonderful break in the garden of the Rodin museum where you can see some of his most famous works, relax and enjoy lunch or a snack in the little café, use the restroom, and visit the lovely gift shop. Of course, the museum itself is delightful also, with not only Rodin's work, but also art he collected and works of his model/mistress/assistant Camille Claudel, a talented artist also.
Best museum in Paris. We visited many of the museum's in Paris, and we enjoyed this museum the most. The gate of Dante's Inferno is amazing. Make sure you rent the Audio tour.

Still interesting. I first visited the Rodin Museum nearly 30 years ago, and honestly I don't think it has changed much since then. The exhibit areas are still just rooms in an old house, with little apparent environmental controls (the windows were open when we were there), but that does make for an interesting, in situ sort of experience. The gardens are really nice, with the major statues placed here and there. However, while we were there, there had apparently just been a fashion show in the gardens and bunches of workers were there dismantling a huge tent, which detracted from the ambience and cut off access to part of the gardens. Gift shop/welcome center is much improved.

A secret you will want to share!. The Musee Rodin is how the artist desired his collection to be viewed! The gardens are beautiful with each sculpture placed perfectly to get up close. The "Thinker" sits perched in his own area within view of the Eiffel Tower in the background! Stroll through at your leisure and enjoy some of the greatest bronze sculptures of the time!

A Gem. The museum is fascinating, and the gardens are a delight. This is a great way to spend a few hours in the afternoon away from the tourist mobs. For most people, just visiting the gardens may be enough, because all of Rodin's famous large bronzes are out there. The museum itself has smaller scaled works, drawings, casts, and other material that allow you to learn about his work in more depth. I remember my first visit with fondness and keep going back. This is on my short list when friends ask what to see in Paris.

cafe in the gardens. Would never think of going to Paris without a stroll through the gardens and enjoy a refreshment break at the little cafe there. You won't be disappointed! The museum in the mansion is great too. But the gardens are a must stop every visit to Paris. Only 1 Euro (maybe more now but it's cheap, beautiful and relaxing at any price!)
Beautiful. I have been entranced by Rodin's work since I was a young teen. This was my second visit and I hope to go again. The gardens are beautiful so go when the weather is good if you can.

Well done. I am not the biggest fan of museums, and as such don't visit huge numbers...friends suggested this one, and as The Thinker is a piece I do appreciate I thought "why not". I was very pleasantly surprised. The Museum is easy to find, and easy to get in to without huge queues first off. It is an old house and the exhibits are spread around the house, and also the gardens. Make sure you pick a dry day to go to this as the gardens to me are the highlight. Lots of great photo opportunities with these extraordinary pieces in very attractive grounds, well manicured and kept. The house section is well laid out and takes you around in a circuit. The highlights for me are The Gates of Hell and of course The Thinker in the gardens. Very interesting exhibition though and highly recommended. As far as museums go I would say fine for kids too, the gardens being a place for them to run off energy, and the house section not being terribly big and could hold their attention for the hour to visit that part. Also of note was a very nice cafe in the grounds, with decent and healthy food as well as Carb loaded treats. All up, a worthwhile visit a little off the main circuit in Paris.

Beautiful gardens, great sculptures. Went here on our Museum Card, really enjoyed it, the old hotel that houses the artworks is run down but interesting to see what happens to a building that is not maintained, worth a visit

Lovely visit. Beautiful museum premises, within lovely garden. Smaller prints and sculptures indoors, large statues in the gardens. Also very nice cafe in the garden where I had violet ice cream for the first time in my life.

An oasis of quiet reflection. For a single Euro the garden is yours most days, and it is filled with Rodin's works, including some fascinating preliminary pieces that are not typically associated with the sculptor. There is a fine little cafeteria in the garden, and on a warm day in Paris, we had dessert and cafes au lait. The service is brusque, this is after all Paris, but the food is wonderful. Spend and hour, spend an afternoon with a book.

Inside and Outside delights. The visit was very relaxing and enlightening. The audio guide well worth the price.Everyone knows about the "The Thinker" but the other sculptures were incredible as well.After viewing the smaller sculptures inside, you can stroll in a beautiful garden and view the larger work done by Rodin. The museum entrance is new and really stands out, Rodin would be proud.The Army Museum is right around the corner so you could visit both on the same day. I would visit when you want to combine viewing art and taking in a garden stroll.The souvenir store was overpriced, but the items were of top quality.

Oasis. Beautiful gardens with a number of grand statues. Plenty of fantastic photo opportunities. A nice, quiet mid-afternoon getaway from the hustle & bustle elsewhere. Definitely worth going if you have the Paris Museum Pass.

Worth seeing.. I found that I was a little disappointed with The Thinker statue. I always imagined it bigger. My fault. It is an impressive sculpture none the less. My favorite was The Door To Hell. I did not previously know about Rodin's work being so much about Dante. Half of the garden was closed at the time we were there so they let everyone in for free. The gardens are beautiful.

Renovations Ruined My Visit!. I visited this magical museum and gardens twice the last time I was in Paris. I was so disappointed this time! There are major renovations underway in the museum, and a great deal of the artwork is not on display. There was also some kind of function being set up in the garden which closed off more than half of it. Lots of hammers banging and loud workmen which disturbed what would normally be a quiet, peaceful respite from the bustling city. I think both the renovations and the set up of functions could have less impact if they were better thought out. Also, from what I can see the renovations are removing the beautiful plaster work that made the interior of this museum so beautiful, what a shame.

Amazing artwork in a beautiful setting.. I love Rodin, and was thrilled to be able to see his original work in such a beautiful, peaceful setting was so relaxing, it was almost like a day trip out of Paris. So easy to find and to get there, you have no reason to miss out!

A favorite of ours. The museum is a preserved hotel with wonderful rooms displaying a variety of the works, including clay models, sketches, and smaller castings. The gardens are beautiful and showcase the bigger works so well.

Low key yet entertaining. My husband and I stopped by on a whim. It was a small museum so it wasn't overwhelming. Yet, it had interesting sculptures and history to make it worth while. It wouldn't be a must do but nice to stroll through if you have some extra time.

All Rodin, all the time, in his wonderful house. This is a world-class museum in an in-town villa wth wonderful gardens front and rear, and spacious, beautifully decorated galleries throughout the house displaying a gratifying number of the Master's works. A Paris must-see.

Loved it. I loved this stop. The only negative was that a large part of the garden was inaccessible due to the setting up for an event. The house itself though is gorgeous, and we were able to see some (just not all) of the garden and the outside sculptures. Definitely worth the visit.

A Nice Outdoor/Indoor Museum. This is a great museum to visit on the same day as the D'orsay or when visiting the Rue Cler area of Paris. The sculpture collection is extensive and it was wonderful to be outdoors. This could be a good place to take kids 5 and up since they can have an opportunity to run about. Everyone poses with "The Thinker."

Musee Rodin, Paris. What a wonderful, hidden gem right in the heart of Paris. There is an entrance fee but you could spend some hours there, the gardens are beautiful and peaceful ! The museum is well run and interesting as well. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth Seeing Even During Construction. I had been meaning to visit the Rodin Museum garden for years and this time I finally did. Unfortunately it is under construction now, so the garden is not at its loveliest, but my husband and I enjoyed walking through the paths and looking at the impressive pieces. My vision of sipping pastis in the garden café (open 10-5 Tuesday-Sunday) was not realized because the café serves no spirits (just wine, beer, coffee, and sodas) . Admission to the garden only is 1 Euro but they were waiving the fee due to construction the day we were there.

small but excellent. We went here on a rainy day but the place was still bustling. Even my teenage son was quite impressed with the works on display and the five year old seemed quite stunned and wanted to run around the garden to see everything. We all enjoyed this very much and will come back on a sunny day. Did not use the audio guide but just enjoyed the excellent works.

Wrong time. We stumbled to the Musee Rodin when we got out from the Metro going to Les Invalides, knowing Rodin by his work like the thinker, gates of hell and the kiss, we happily went there first before Les Invalides.The garden sculptors where really great to see but because of some repairs, renovations and an event we could not feel the grandeur and soul of the place at least we the the thinker, the kiss and gates of hell among others.

For Rodin fans a must, for others .... While I count myself a Rodin fan, I was not overly impressed. As we had the Museum pass we included this in our travels. However, between the apparent repairs in progress and the setting up for an event, much of the garden was inaccessible (or un-photographable). Combine this with the tour groups and you may decide to visit this museum based on your location and a hole in your schedule. On balance, I am glad that I visited as a part of my pass, but I can't see myself visiting again or recommending it to others.

worth the visit for the collection of Rodin works, works by Camille Claudel and the home and its gardens. This museum is located in a beautiful 18th century hotel particulier and gardens where you can enjoy a light meal but the focus has to be the beautiful collection of works by Rodin and smaller collection by his mistress, the gifted artist Camille Claudel.
delightful. charming house with super gardens to wander around. Good collection of Rodin work. Good audio guide.

One of my favourite places in Paris. Love the scultpures, the gardens and the serenity found at the Musee Rodin. 'The Thinker' in the front garden is worth seeing and you can get a great photo with 'The Thinker', the gold top of the Ecole Militaire and the top half of the Eiffel Tower all in the one shot.

Our little kids loved the garden and so did we.. This museum has a large garden with heaps of Rodin's bronze sculptures. This in my opinion was the highlight of the visit and was very cheap, maybe just a euro, to enter. The indoor museum cost more and was good but I liked it better a decade ago and this visit, it was the gardens which were excellent. Inside, we had to park the stroller and carry our little person which was not at all satisfactory. He was protesting and one of the attendants came and told us to leave just as I was calming him down. We just ignored her and continued on. Little kids can safely walk independently and explore outdoors but give the indoors a miss. The flowers and garden beds are lovely. There are toilet facilities but I couldn't find a nappy change place. The pathways were easy to navigate with a stroller. I think this is a really good place to let the little people enjoy garden and art combined. There are places to sit and think and munch on your sandwich lunch whilst you enjoy the calm and quiet location before you hit the busy city sights once more.

A little gem among giants. Don't dimiss this little museum when visiting Paris - Rodin was a genius and his works are some of the finest sculptures in Paris. The house and gardens are lovely. And don't forget to see the famous Thinker! FYI: this is a great place to buy your museum pass and then "jump the lines" at the other museums.

Lovely, tranquil and uncrowded. The Rodin Museum is a breath of fresh air (literally!) after time spent fighting the crowds in the oppressively hot Louvre and Orsay museums. The grounds and gardens are lovely and peaceful. There is a charming cafe which offers sandwiches and light meals; it's an excellent place to take a break. At the time of my visit in early September, The Kiss was not on display, which was somewhat of a disappointment. If you are lucky, you might be able to secure one of the reclining benches that are hidden beyond the hedge arches at the far end of the property.

Different experiences in different years. The first time I saw this museum it was a small place that hardly any tourists seem to stop by, and it was magical. There was amazing audio guide, every room was open, and the garden fully accessible. The last time I saw it, half the rooms were closed, half the items I came to see missing, and most of the garden was marked off for some event or repairs and thus you could not walk amongst many of the statues. Perhaps it was bad luck - I hope so. This used to be one of my favorite museums in Paris.

Definite Must See. We only had had 3 hours to spare in our last day in Paris. Since our hotel is close by (500meters) we decided to come here and also see Ecole Militaire on the way.This place for me is by far the best garden in Paris. It is smaller than other gardens in Paris but the place is just breathtaking. The landscape and the sculptures are just beautiful.I am certainly going to visit this place again when I come back to Paris.

A Must See for Rodin Lovers. I purchased online a combination ticket for the the Musee d'Orsay and the Rodin and save money as well. His work is overpowering and don't miss out on the garden. It was free when I visited as they were doing a lot of maintainance work.

Great place for a quiet lunch. The Rodin Museum is one of the best kept secrets of Paris. It's an absolutely beautiful setting with Rodin's sculptures set throughout the grounds. The gardens are magnificent, especially in spring and summer when the roses are in bloom. We always try to visit in the middle of the day so we can have lunch at the outdoors cafe. Basic fare but you can't beat the setting for a peaceful break.
A must see. A good museum. Great garden with the thinker, the gates of hell and the burgers of something ( I forgot). Didn't appreciate Rodent until seeing his work in total.

If you want something doable without miles of walking and line ups. A lovely little Musee ,if you are a fan of Rodin. As a bonus it also has a lovely garden also full of sculptures by Rodin. Go on a nice day to enjoy garden and architecture. Enjoy a gelato while strolling

A Must See for Rodin Fans. My high school mascot is the Thinker, so I had to visit the Rodin Museum. There is much more to the museum than just the Thinker. The museum offers an excellent mix of interior and exterior settings with which to display Rodin's works. The garden was an unexpected bonus.

good, not great Museum. The Museum is going through a remodel, so the garden is a mess. The display was Ok, but very little in English to understand what you are seeing. it is worth a vist, but don'y expect a lot.

Great museum. I really enjoyed a morning of walking around the Rodin museum and gardens in Paris. I didn't know much about the man other the 'The Thinker', but learned so much. The building was the hotel in which he lived and worked and you can see pictures of him in the actual rooms which now contain works of art. They introduce his friends and their works, too. The gardens contain statues and it makes for a very nice place to spend some time. I had never gone to one museum dedicated to one artist before and really enjoyed it. I must say the chanting music in the gardens were a little creepy, but also gave us a laugh. This is well worth the 6€ we paid for admission.

K & S @ Rodin. The Thinker in the garden caught our attention, as Rodin was not on our list of Museums. We enjoy the grounds, and buildings as we wandered through. His models in marble and bronze shared space with both his art and Monet, Van Gogh and several others. Seeing the Thinker, both larger and than life in the garden, and the original inside, was our highlight.

Not just sculpture...an exquisite home and garden. An absolutely delightful way to spend an afternoon. When you get to see the sculptures close up you cannot help be amazed at how much expression Rodin could bring to each individual study. The faces seem alive and although the eyes are made from clay (in the studies for the bronze sculptures" it is as if you are looking at a live person. The most interesting thing for me, other than the sculptures were the very early landscapes Rodin did as a young artist. They were so bad that it is a wonder his teacher's encouraged him but when you see the later portrait paintings you are just stunned by the intensity of the expressions which of course he was somehow able to translate into clay. Do not leave without touring the gardens..."The Gates of Hell" will astonish you...even more so if you have seen Ghiberti's "Golden Doors" in the Florence Cathedral.

Amazing!!!. Rodin's sculptures are simply amazing. After seeing so many 'classic' sculptures throughout the world the sculptures of Rodin's at this museum are an oasis. AND the audio guide heightens the experience. Hard to believe that in his time so much of his work was unfairly criticized by the 'experts'. An exceptionally pleasant way to spend hours.
Outdoors. Much of the museum was outdoors as the inside was being prepared for another exhibition. However, it was a peaceful walk through the park with chanting music piped in in spots.

Quite peaceful spot to view famous art. This is an excellent small museum with two floors of Rodin's work and a large outdoor park-like setting featuring the famous "thinker" statue and several others.We visited on our first day in Paris and walking around in the museum and sunny gardens was a great cure for our jet lag. It was nice to see the famous works and it was not very crowded during our September visit making it very easy to see all the famous works and get great photos.Definitely something to do once you've seen all the more famous attractions of Paris.
beautiful building and grounds. If you are an admirer of the sculptures of Rodin this is a great place to spend an hour or two. A beautiful building and grounds just across the road from Invalides.

Go- it is amazing. Well worth a visit. The etherial singing trees just add to the wonder of this museum. To have lived in this amazing space would have been incredible.There are some wonderful sculptures in the garden.incredibly clean toilets with a lovely attendant. The cafe doesn't serve champagne so they lose a point. ;)

Wonderful Museum. Rodin's most famous works are here and several are in the beautiful gardens in between the buildings. Sadly Le Baiser was on loan. I was surprised that we could take photos inside which is rare in most museums.
The Rodin gardens and museum. Loved the special exhibit, the gorgeous gardens and Rodins amazing sculptures. Easy entry, lots of visitors. The special exhibit was solely marbles. So very beautiful.
Great place to get so close to iconic sculptures. Where else can get to touch iconic sculptures? The "Thinker" is a masterpiece. I actually touch the base of it (it is about 15 feet tall)

Incredible artist; incredible museum. I will always want to return to the Musee Rodin -- the combination of sculptures in the garden, as they are 'supposed to appear', along with the exhibits in the main hall, are a rare treat. I had been here once before, in the late nineties -- but I suspect when back in Paris, I'll keep coming back.

Don't Miss the Rodin!. We totally enjoyed visiting the Rodin! Wonderful few hours inside and outside looking at all of the sculptures. Also has a great gift shop/bookstore! Buy a Museum Pass for a better value.

weak collection, garden is better. Museum is in horrible condition screaming for renovation, which is underway. Collection is less than breathtaking. Half of the garden is closed, the rest presents pretty good samples of Rodin's works.

The thinker. If you know anything about the famous Thinker, then you must visit this little museum. Rodin the sculptor lived here and then donated all his artwork to the museum. It's a quick museum to see

Amazing gardens. The museum does not overwhelm you like the Louve but the art is nonetheless superb. The real gem is in the back garden stroll and cafe for a great recuperative respite from the often hectic Paris museum scene. Don't miss it.

WARNING: The Rodin Museum is undergoing a multi-year restoration.. Officically this is supposed to be completed in 2015, but staff told me that, because of financial woes plaguing the project, inside word is that it won't be completed until at least 2016, maybe longer. In the meantime ( we visited in September 2013 ) the Rodin is a shadow of its former self. Virtually all of the fabulous, best sculptures have been removed, placed in storage or traveling ( to help raise money for the restoration ). In their place is a mess of second rate works and models for final works, most of them small and undistinguished. A real shame for visitors who haven't been tipped off by the usual variety of U.S. Paris guidebooks. Part of the garden has been unaffected by the restoration project. There you can still see bronze greats such as Balzac, The Thinker, and the Gates of Hell. But a good part of the garden has been devoted on apparently continuous special uses by non-connected parties, rented out by the Rodin as part of the restoration fund raising. So even the lovely garden has been compromised. Having thrilled to see the sculptures in the house during our 1989 Paris trip, we were keenly disappointed to go through the Rodin last month under the circumstances described. It will be interesting to see if 2014 U. S. Paris guidebooks level with their buyers re what's really going on at the Rodin and re what that means.

Quiet spot in Paris filled with sculpture masterpieces.. This is wear you see The Thinker, The Kiss amongst a myriad of brilliant sculptures set in a beautiful garden around an old hotel. Great place to sit for awhile and enjoy sublime Paris art in intimate garden setting. We visited on a Sunday in late September and not too busy
The Thinker. We went to see the Thinker and was worth it. Although it is a little walk from the Louvre or Orsay, it is still worth it if you have the 2 day pass.
Small Museum. Nice small museum that doesn't take long to get around. Has some amazing Rodin works, set in a nice building and garden.
Compact Excellence. The Rodin Museum is a beautiful compact wonderful Parisian gem. Proximate to a variety of Champs de Mar/ Eiffel tower/ Invalides/ Pagoda theater attractions it is a pleasure

Don't miss the garden. Another of my favorites in Paris. It is worth the walk off the beaten path to spend and hour or so in the gardens with the Thinker, the Gates of Hell and many other sculptures. The indoor portion is educational and if you're lucky the Kiss will be there - one of my favorite sculptures - such passion!
Over taken by Fashion Week. As a Fashion Week venue, much of the gardens were overtaken by a large tent like structure (disappointing but interesting).
old museum. museum is old and need of repair and upgrade. except for "the thinker" and "the kiss" it's dumb. I'd say this is one to miss.

Get away from the crowds. This is a lovely museum which is part indoors but the best part for me are the statues which are on display in the wonderful gardens. Great works of art just scattered about with plenty of ares to sit. This museum is not as popular as some of the other so does not get throngs of tourists.

Nice small museum with a sculpture parks. Overall it was very nice visit. The museum has all significant Rodin creations (The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, The Burghers of Calais) as well as some works of Camille Claudel. Some paintings by Monet, Renoir and Van Gogh from Rodin's personal collections are also presented.
The garden is now going restoration work, it's a little messed up our experience.

Favorite Museum in Paris. I know, I know we were suppose to love the Louvre and the Orsay (well actually we DID love the Orsay), but we found this charming museum set in a garden as well as in Rodin's home, to be a real winner. We walked from our hotel in the St. Germain area to the Rodin and arrived about 30 minutes after opening. We headed first to the gardens (which we were told cost nothing to visit) and low and behold, there is The Thinker sitting amongst rose bushes. We must have taken a dozen photos from all sides before I even realized that the Eiffel Tower was in the background.It was a glorious day without a cloud in the sky and the sculptures were very impressive. I cannot stress enough the importance of buying the audio guide. We learned so much which just added to the enjoyment.Then we went inside and saw some of Rodin's smaller pieces in different mediums. It was just so impressive. Then back to the gardens and we stopped at the lovely snack shop and got something to drink and just enjoyed people watching and relaxing in such a great atmosphere.

For Sculpture fans. This museum are works of Rodin in a beautiful setting. Though not exhaustive, it had some of the best that I would expect. It had a good selection, enough to be able to appreciate them. The free guide was a great description of his life and work.

A magical museum. The Rodin museum is one of my favorites in Paris. The inside of the building is beautiful with many of Rodin's most famous sculptures, but the garden is what truly makes this museum magic. You can spend hours strolling in the tree shaded garden and admire Rodin's work from all angles, have a drink or a bite to eat at the outside restaurant, or just sit down and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere of a magical place in the center of Paris.

cool sculptures. Been to the Philly Rodin garden, but the Thinker is most impressive in Rodin's place. There were many pieces that I did not think Rodin would have made, being exposed only to his famous sculpture. The garden itself is a nice and easy walk and culminates at the end with a beautiful pond. I did not bother to go inside the actual museum since i enjoyed the garden so muched.

Indoor & outdoor scupture museum. Even for those not interested in Rodin's works, this is an intriguing museum - set in grounds and a building with interesting history in their own right - the sculptures are well presented and the experience can be relaxing.

Never realized Rodin painted; lived in a remarkable house. We loved everything about his home. The presentation of his art is wonderful. The statues are both in his hone and the extensive gardens. Check out the restaurant in the garden because the food is delicious
Peaceful garden.. Fascinating place. Sculptures outdoors in perfect setting. Peaceful place to sit too. View of golden dome of Invalides completes the view.

Very unique. What a special museum! We were lucky to be able to experience the gardens and sculptures for free admission and it was really beautiful. It is such a quiet and peaceful place full of beauty.

The Rodin gardens, best secret in Paris.. We spent an afternoon on a glorious day in the Musee Rodin gardens. What a deal! Beautiful gardens, great works of art, an outdoor setting and in central Paris for 1 euro. Mais Qui!

So Happy We did Research. We've been to Paris before but never stopped here. So glad we made this a go-to place this time around. The grounds are magnificent. Although we did miss some of Rodin's work (as it was on loan elsewhere), we had no regrets. It is truly magnificent in every respect.

Great sculptures in the garden. This is a must if you are a Rodin fan. The museum inside is looking rather tired. It contains interesting maquettes and other items that give interesting background to the major works in the garden.

Nice to walk in the gardens. We went on a gorgeous, extremely sunny day, so walking through the gardens and admiring everything was a perfect way to spend our last afternoon in Paris. Highly recommended, plus it was another tick on the 'Midnight In Paris' checklist!
An Artful Respite. Loved the art, the home and the gardens! Maybe an hour or two for the full tour through the entire property.
Great. Wonderful, inspiring museum. Loved the walks through the sculpture gardens. No wait at all to get in on the Wednesday that we went.
great sculpture garden!. Easy to walk to...Nice gardens..great master sculptures...such a nice serine setting ...worth going to see as nd visit!
Partially open. Majority of the building is in renovation. Great pieces of art are still on display. The gardens are filled with Rodin pieces
Indoors and Outdoors. Easy to find location. Just enough exhibits to enjoy before getting bored as I like Museums but we were doing a lot of them that week. :-)

Just visited the Garden. We just visited the garden which cost just a few Euro each. There is only so much you can see in a few days and as statues are not big on my list we decided to only visit the garden and not the whole museum. We got to see Thinker and a collection of other statues in the garden which was quite picturesque.

Not what I expected at all.... Before leaving the U.S. I kept hearing go to the Rodin go to the Rodin so I added it to our tight schedule on our first visit to Paris. It was not at all what I expected. The house was ok and the gardens ok but the sculptures themselves were subpar. All of the sculpture display out of proportion grotesque hands and feet. Some in very poor condition considering the relatively young age. We breezed right through it. If you like modern style art you will like the Rodin otherwise skip this and move on to real art at Louvre or Orsay. I would have been upset if we paid outright to see this but with the Paris pass whatever. FYI obviously I am not an art major but I think I speak for average Joe...

Wonderful museum although currently under renovation. This is a beautiful museum and garden of Rodin's works with a nice garden cafe. You can easily spend a few hours here. It is currently under renovation so not in its best form, but still highly recommended.

Devine museum. I liked this museum, it was small and outside. The sculptures were brilliant and was nice to see them in the gardens rather than in the building, although the originals were inside. Excellent museum to visit and was recommend in our guide book

Great. I have always loved Rodin's sculptures. We lived in NYC and saw his works at the Met. I have seen other shows featuring his works. The museum brought me to a whole different level of understanding and appreciation. The grounds were lovely: the roses were in full bloom. The audio guide was great. Inside were the studies and preliminary models for his works, especially for the Gates of Hell. He really worked hard to get the human body right-strong men, desperate, dispirited men, women, and old people. He then reworked several pieces into other works. I learned a lot. This is a must see.

the best sculpture museum in the world. I was encoraged by lonely planet rating it 2nd in the list of Paris must do attractions.very worth it. dont miss the gardens with great views of Invalides. the cafe in the garden seves good salads and baguettes.

Delightful!. Even though some the jardins were under construction we still enjoyed the walk One of our best visits even though we have been to Paris several times, the house itself is interesting and so are the exhibits, be sure and see "the Gates of Hell " and spend time just wandering.

Tranquility away from the hustle aand bustle of the City. This is an absolute MUST.If like Rodin - or even if you don't! Some VERY famous sculptures here. Gates of hell / The Thinker / 5 Burgers of Calais.

Gorgeous gardens and sculptures are awesome. I am no art expert, but this place is worth seeing--they are renovating but the gardens are gorgeous and the sculptures are just amazing--very impressive and not crowded.

C. Claudel the highlight. This is a sweet museum to visit on a nice day. Much of the garden was under construction during out visit, but we enjoyed ourselves anyway. I got the audio tour and especially enjoyed the Camille Claudel works on display. The cafe in the garden is a touch overpriced (as is to be expected) but situated in a nice space. Stopping by here after Napoleon's Tomb made for a refreshing change from all the grandeur.

Tired of typical museums? Visit Rodin Museum. We've come here little bit tired of all these endless halls of Louvre and Orsay, so we were very glad to see placid park full of famous sculpters of great Rodin.Relax, walk around, enjoy your promenade amid Le Penseur, Les Bourgeois de Calais. Don't forget to visit La Porte de l'Enfer (Gates to Hell) - incredible peice of art

A must see for art lovers. After your trip at the Invalides, a stop at the Rodin museum seems the right thing to do. Access is free in the gardens and with a museums pass also in the buildings. Interesting to see by daylight, it really comes alive at night. Not too crowded, it will let you take direct contact with the works of one of the greatest sculptors of our time.

Worth a quick stop to see the sculpltures. It wasn't all the big (part of it was closed at the time), but it was covered by the Museum Pass and well worth the hour or so we spent there. You'll see The Thinker and other famous sculptures. It's near the other major museums, so it's worth dropping in.

Bronze and Marble-who knew?. I enjoyed the grounds, the Hotel Biron, his home, his life story; seeing "The Gates of Hell" and seeing where The Thinker was first incorporated there. It was the highlight of my two week trip. It was a warm day so I wouldn't recommend visiting in the summer. The rooms would be miserable and there's much to look at and read.

A favorite in Paris and a wonderful bargain. I have made it a point to visit the Rodin Museum every time I come to Paris. Admission to the garden is free and includes The Burghers of Calais ( my favorite), the Gates of Hell, The Thinker, and Balzac. If you want more, you can pay extra to visit the house. There is a small cafe on the grounds as well. It is very beautiful and very relaxing

Worth a look. This museum is under renovation right now ... when its done it will be even more amazing.Didn't know much about Rodin when I went so it was very interesting to me ... get the audio tour ... it has lots of good info . The gardens are beautiful and you can skip the inside and just enjoy the outside for about 1 euro . Its definitely worth a trip .

Get there fast for the amazing sound installation. And light show. The sounds that drift about the yews are magical and alas will close Sept, 29. The jardin is a great escape from bustling Paris, and the simple salads and tea in the garden cafe are all you need.

Wonderful!. We wanted to do Musée d'Orsay but the wait looked too long so we went on to Musée Rodin. And what a delight. Seeing the sculptures only seen in art books before was wonderful. Unfortunately some of the gardens were closed but all in all, it was a wonderful experience.

Rodin was a genius and this museum is wonderful. There are lovely gardens and great museum showing the artists career. The sculptures are absolutely amazing. This museum is worth a visit. There were no lines when we went too, a big plus in a city filled with tourists where many museums have lines around the block.

Nice Garden. The museum is currently under renovation, which was a little disappointing. However, the beautiful garden made up for it. Be sure to go when there is no rain in order to fully enjoy the garden.

Just beautiful. Rodin is one of my favourite, the gallery has an outstanding collection, the gardens are simply beautiful to stroll through and see some of his works in amongst the garden. The collection is also superb!

The Gates of Hell. Gorgeous gardens in the middle of Paris surrounded by sculptures from the 1800's...it is really worth a visit - you can spend a long time or a short time here but spend some. The thinker, the gates of hell, the kiss straight out of a senior school art lesson definitely worth it....
Beautiful Sculpture Gardens. We skipped the museum and paid the one Euro to just see the sculpture. Huge bang for the Euro. Beautiful!

A great small museum. We are in Paris for 10 days and have rented an apartment. The only way to go in Paris.We have been to several Museums and love this one. This was Rodin's home turned into a museum. The grounds, gardens are very special. Not to be missed: The Gates of Hell. An very large sculpture in the setting of the gardens. You can see his wonderful sculptures in the gardens and more of Rodin and Camille Claudell (his muse and mistress) has some wonderfull ones in the house. A don't miss small museum. We went at opening time and bought tickets at the entrance with a very small line.

Beautiful!. We visited a large number of museums in Paris and this was one of very favorites. We had a Paris Pass so we were in quickly. There were extensive beautiful gardens to explore and the sculptures and work are just breathtaking. I am so grateful we took the time to explore this one.
The Thinker. Walking Man, and so much more.The Gates of Hell has to be seen. I definitely have more appreciation for his work now. The wailing through the speakers in the garden was interesting.

"The Thinker" - the original one. Come here and admire Rodin's most famous and most reproduced work - the thinker. Beautiful garden setting for a lot of his sculptures on the grounds of his old house/studio. About 20 min walk from the Orsay museum. Allow for 2 hours to walk the grounds and appreciate Rodin's works. I think it's also ncluded with the Paris city pass.
Rodin's Kiss is Wonderful. Loved this museum. So nice to see his garden and how he worked. Very near Eiffel Tower so can be combined in same visit. His sculptures are bigger than life.
Surprising little gem. Spent over an hour at this smaller museum but learned a lot about Rodin's unique and amazing creations. It's conveniently located close to the Army Museum.

Wonderful use of time. Yes, you get to see close up & personal, The Thinker, and The Gates of Hell. It is a beautiful setting in the gardens, too. Amazing rose garden! Such a value for only 1 Euro for the garden only. Don't miss!!

Visit the Gardens if you don't have time to tour the Museum. We didn't have time to tour the museum so for one Euro, you could tour the garden. VERY nice. Lovely sculptures and even a small cafe with refreshments. A most enjoyable afternoon strolling the gardens and looking at the sculptures.
Pretty garden. Sweet, small museum with beautiful sculptures scattered through a pretty garden. Go on a day that's not too hot so you can enjoy the gardens :)

A pleasant stroll in a stunning garden. We visited the Musee Rodin with friends and were wowed by the statues, the roses, the models in the house, and the overall beauty and serenity of this gem of a museum. We took our time and enjoyed looking at each masterpiece outside.

do not miss it! it just takes a while. if you are short of money, you can just visit the gardens. Its cheap. You can even take a nap there! or take small children to play in the sand. really a special place.The sculptures are incredible. Worth going round each one of them!! If you like it as I did, take a while to see the books at the store. Some are really at good prices and it´s a nice way to take your trip memories back home.

Beautiful Sculpture Gardens. If you are a fan of Rodin's work, this is not to be missed. He bequeathed his collection to the state the year before he died, and it is housed here. A collection of his larger sculpures are housed in beautiful gardens which have a lovely, peaceful feel. Smaller sculptures are in a relativel small museum, so the entire collection is very approachable.The collection also includes works by Monet and Van Gogh that Rodin had owned, which was an unexpected pleasure. I also liked the gift shop, with a wide range of books and some funky gifts, including bags and tshirts with a cute Rodin caricature. It's right beside Les Invalides, and near Varenne Metro Station.

Tranquility and shade on a hot summer day. The house is great, but the garden is what I come here for. Just 1 euro to get in and there you find an oasis of peace. snoozing among trees, fountains, flowerbeds and of course the sculptures on a hot afternoon is the perfect counterpoint to bustling central Paris.There is a cafe for cold drinks and bathroom available too.There is a velib bike docking station nearby on Bd des Invalides towards the intersection with Rue de Grenelle.
Visiting Paris. The Muse Rodin it is a must when visit Paris. Especially the gardens that are beautiful and exhibits a lot of well know of Rodain's sculptures

Unexpected pleasure. We had museum passes and a little time to kill and figured that we would stop in to the Rodin Museum. It was a nice afternoon and we loved spending time in the sculpture garden. It was a beautiful place to walk around and spend about an hour or two. Our three teenagers had a great time trying to imitate the statues, especially, The Thinker.

Well worth visiting. Rodin is a genius in my view - and the museum is worth the visit if only to see where he lived and worked. It was a run down hotel before Rodin took the place over. It is now a great house - bit it is the garden that is the highlight - scattered within it are pieces of the artists work. The main exhibit is currently being renovated - hence 4 stars. If you like Rodin - go here. I had never been to Les Invalides - which is literally round the corner - worth a look round if only to see the tomb of Napolean....

Worth A Visit. Having visited back in 1989, this return visit found a much improved experience. The gardens are beautiful, the sculpture astonishing, and the building housing the museum itself is fascinating.
What a great museum. Loved all of Rodin's sculptures. I liked the "mini Le Penseur." However, the museum was extremely hot (I know it was July but no air circulating at all

Some Good Impressionist Paintings, Too. Although the museum is dedicated to the works of Rodin, it should be mentioned that there are also some original Van Gogh, Monet and other Impressionist paintings on exhibit.

Revealing. Seeng several attempts at a statue and for some a different context (like the groups first made for the "gates of hell") was revealing. The museum is undergoing some repair but leving many of the. statues in the garden unlabelled is hardly acceptable.

Tremendous Art, Beautiful Setting, construction hampered the experience. Rodin is one of my family's favorite artists. The line was long but manageble. Much of the museum is under construction so some of the works were difficult to see or the queues were troubling. The gardens were wonderful, peaceful and restful. The main part of the museum was a little hot but Paris was suffering a historic heat wave when we were there so I cannot really blame the museum for that.You must walk the gardens as some of the most beautiful works are there.If we go back to Paris this will be a place we will visit. Normally there is a fee but it was waived on the day we were there so that improved the experience.

Museum solely dedicated to Rodin. This treasure is a combination of an outdoor sculpture garden with some of Rodin's better known works -- The Burghers of Calais, The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, and a sculpture of the French writer Honore de Balzac. An indoor museum in the Hotel Biron on the property, where Rodin lived at one time, showcases smaller models of The Kiss and The Thinker, as well as a full-sized John the Baptist, a model of John the Baptist's head and a sculpture called The Age of Bronze, a sculpture so lifelike that Rodin was initially accused of creating it from a life cast of the body of his model. Eventually he proved that this wasn't true, but the publicity helped to make him famous and brought him the commission for creating the bronze Gates of Hell. There is a small restaurant onsite and a lovely pond and green space on 3 hectares at the rear of the Hotel Biron museum. Renovations are ongoing at Hotel Biron, so some exhibits, i.e. The Kiss, etc., have been moved to a space inside the chapel on the property where the entrance, ticket desk, and museum store are located. Well-worth an afternoon visit for all lovers of Rodin!

Huge, unexpected treat. I figured I'd quickly "do" the Rodin museum and ended up spending most of the morning here. You will see incredible sculptures in a peaceful and beautiful setting, including The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, and so much more. Many of the sculptures are placed in the gardens which adds to the enjoyment. There is a lovely restaurant where you can eat el fresco in the gardens.I went early in the morning and had breakfast, then toured the gardens and sculptures in the gardens. Then I went into the palace where many more of his works are on display. If you enjoy sculpture this is one museum not to be missed.
Impressive. Museum was close to hotel we stayed at in Paris. The Thinker Is in museum. Sculptures throughout meticulously maintained grounds. Quiet respite from outside traffic and distractions.
A must to visit. The rodin museum was great, though only small it has fantastic sculptures and the gardens are very tranquil, a beautiful place to stop for lunch on a hectic day in Paris.
Great selection of sculptures!. A nice small museum on the way to Napoleon's Tomb. If you are limited to time, the d'orsey has quite a few Rodin sculptures as well. I would spend time at the d orsay.

The Master of Sculpture - Rodin. Don't miss this .. his work is incredible - to gain such perfection of form - so clear expressions of anguish and love in this artform - it is a beautiful Museum - absolutely worth the visit.The building is currently being repaired.. so is a little out of order, but the gardens are lovely .. if you need a rest there are perfect reclining chairs down the end of the garden where you can snooze in peace for a while regaining strength to view again.

What marvelous sculptures!!!!!. To be here standing in the gardens of Rodin!!!! The Thinker, Hell's Gate, please stay and enjoy his works he was a inspiration to all that admired his art! To see his actual works of the Original Thinker inside the museum, with The First Kiss,, was amazing. The gardens are wonderful to see, and standing on a high pedestal RODIN'S THE THINKER!!! all I can say is WOW!!!!
Sculptures outside too. Having decided the Louvre would be too large and all inside, the Rodin was ideal. Many of the sculptures are outside, great on a fine day! Enjoyable visit.

A Very Interesting Museum. This museum, housed in a stately mansion, makes for quite a lovely day. In addition to the museum, tickets include admission to gorgeous grounds and gardens. Rodin's most famous works, the Thinker and the Kiss, are both housed here along with others I wasn't previously familiar with. I also found the hints about Rodin's life derived from his work made this a person who seemed to be very interesting. I'm currently planning to read a biography of Rodin because of this visit.
Nice small museum. Was under construction at the time, but with a good special exhibition. Nice gardens with sculpures, small cafe inside.
Beautiful Gardens, Awesome Sculpture. The garden and art was incredible, too bad the security people had such bad attitudes, they ruined a nice afternoon.

What a Gift. What a gift Rodin gave to Paris. This Museum is fantastic. The gardens are so beautiful. The sculptures are well displayed and spaced so one can really enjoy the beauty. The house is a wonder with beautiful architecture.
Best museum in Paris!. Happened to go here on a beautiful day! What an awesome treat! Quiet, beautiful atmosphere and friendly, helpful staff
Here you can touch and feel to your heart's delight. The French believe in touching sculpture instead of only looking at it. It's a whole new experience. You start to engage two senses at once.

Amazing work of a lifetime. Very interesting collection of sculptures that conveys so much story and emotions. Really recommend the audio guide to understand the meaning of each story. Rodin's work is just breathtaking and are beautifully presented especially those in the gardens. This museum far exceeded my expectations and is one of my favourite museums of all I've visited in Europe.

Better than expected. Initially, this was not on my must-see list for Paris, but the friend I was with really wanted to go. I have to say I was really impressed. Both the house and gardens were laid out very well and, even in July, it was not overly crowded, like the Louvre. You could get very close to the sculptures, which was really nice, especially for the most famous ones, like The Thinker, Burghers of Calais, and The Gates of Hell.

Beautiful sculptures and lovely garden. Worthwhile a visit to the museum & gardens. Not to be missed is Camile Claudel's sculpture, The Age of Maturity. Camile herself is on her knees and seems to be imploring her much older lover, Rodin, who is placed in the middle and looks as if he is being forced to make a painful decision. His older mistress, looking very aged and sinister, is pulling him, demanding he leaves Camile for good. She wins. Beautiful sculptures, impressive building. A view of the dome of Les Invalides is seen from the lovely gardens where you can enjoy a cold drink or delicious ice cream. Plan your visit so you have time to enjoy both.

Go on a nice day and wander the grounds. While much of Rodin's art is agonizing in its subject matter, but agonizingly beautiful, it really comes into its own in the outdoor sculpture garden. Seeing The Gates of Hell outside was really intense, as you could watch the sun move across the 3-D figures and feel as if the bodies were moving as well.

For children 10 and under the gardens are enough Rodin. We really like the Rodin museum. But sometimes for small children too much of a good thing comes fairly rapidly. so we recommend that young families pay for admission to the gardens only on the first visit. Children were free, and the gardens provide a really nice sample of some of Rodin's most famous work as well as enough history of his life to satisfy most first time visitors. We understand that inside, there is a terrific exhibit detailing the manufacturing process of these sculptures, which i think we will go back to see once the weather turns and we are looking for a fun rainy day activity.

Beautiful gardens and sculptures by Rodin. We love the rose garden and sculptures best. This musee is a jewel in the heart of Paris. We have been twice, but it is so beautiful, we will return each time we visit Paris. Due to its small size, this musee can be seen in a couple of hours.

Beautiful and well worth 1 Euro!!. Went here to have an outdoor lunch with a friend who works a few streets over. I have never been, and I was just visiting Paris for a week. We brought our own lunch from a restaurant down the street, paid the 1 Euro to go to the Gardens, and had a wonderful 1.5 lunch just enjoying the beauty of Rodin sculptures and the gardens. What a wonderful place to spend a few hours for only 1 Euro.
Let Me Think. With just a 1 euro admittance to the gardens, this is a true bargain in Paris. Beautiful place to visit and contemplate life.
Compact. It was easy to view the inside and out door galleries I only a couple of well spent and enjoyable couple of hours.

Go on a nice day!. As most of the sculptures are outside, it is a good idea to try and get to this museum on a nice day. However, I have been on a rainy day too, and had it pretty much to myself! The grounds are very well kept. I am not a huge *museum person* but I enjoy this place.

outstanding. A must for all art lovers.This is one of the best museums I have been to in Paris, the gardens are beautiful and it is amazing to wander around admiring these bronze sculptures in such a wonderful setting.Inside the house the theme continues with amazing works by Rodin including paintings and drawings and many works by artists such as Munch, Van Gogh and Monet.Outstanding !!!!!!!!!

Loved the laid out gardens and sculptures.. From the moment of walking into the gardens, one is transported back to the magical period of Rodins time. The statues of the Burghers of Calais, the Walking Man, Balzac and the Gates of Hell to name but a few are inspirational. The manicured lawn and tree lines within the gardens are most tranquil. The house is beautifully proportioned housing more works of art and sculptures. One of the best visits in Paris.

A must for a Rodin fan. Some time ago we watched a French movie about Rodin and decided that if we were ever in Paris, we should visit Musee Rodin. A visit to Paris happened in July and we visited the museum. The museum is in his old house and contains all his pieces. "The Thinker", his famous piece is in several places including a large sculpture in the garden. There is separate admission to the garden and is very much worth it. There are many sculptures here too and you could easily spend an hour walking through the garden. You can also read about how cleverly he negotiated with the government to house his museum at the hotel where he lived. Overall, a nice morning outing. The day we visited there was some sort of memorial day and some troops were marching on the street. It was delightful to watch it over cold beer.

Garden tour only. The garden tour is only 1 euro. When you're tired of museums, this is a nice place to visit and just wander around the gardens. You'll get to see The Thinker. However, The Kiss is inside the house so you'll need to pay to see that. I think it was around 10 euros a person. I liked just visiting the garden personally.

A lovely mansion filled with works of art. This was one of my favorite museums since it was more like a large manor house than a just a building to house art. Rodin lived here for a while and when the home went into foreclosure, offerred his artwork to the city of Paris to display to save the house. His artwork is full of personal thoughts about his wife, his mistress (one of the statues has them pulling him in different directions) and his thoughts about the world around him. Although going through some reconstructions, we found most of his works there. The Thinker is in the entry garden (outside) but we could not find "The Kiss" until we went to the L'Orangerie - it's near the entrance overlooking Condorde. The gardens are just as beautiful as the artwork inside and out. We attended on the first Sunday of the month (when it was free) and got there early with no crowds! I highly recommend that you read about Rodin and his artwork (I used Rick Steves guidebooks) before you visit - it was much more enjoyable having that knowledge when viewing the artwork.

Beautiful gardens, building and art. What is not to love? The building is gorgeous, although in need of repair. The gardens are gorgeous. The art is beautiful. The Thinker, The Kiss, The Gates of Hell, and many, many more masterpieces.
A must stop when in Paris. One of my favorite Museums in Paris. The gardens are beautiful and it is a wonderful treat to be where he worked.

Welcome to Rodin's house. I am a huge Rodin fan, so I am partially biased. What's great about this museum is that everything is there and, for the most part, you can touch and turn his work. The thinker and gates of hell are featured, but the Hotel Biron and the Garden are an awesome laid back way to spend time. The audio tour was good. If you want to go, watch Camile with Isabel Adjani and Gerard Depardeuax, it was fun going to my wife and saying, "I remember that from the movie!".

Oasis in central Paris. As a rule I am generally less interested in sculpture than I am painting but I am super glad I ended up at Musee Rodin as part of a combo ticket that I bought at the Musee d'Orsay up the road.The museum, set in the artist's former house, is an oasis in Paris, nearby the Invalides. Sculptures are set within the garden, which is quintessentially French with boxed hedges, pebbled footpaths and fountains, and the artist's former home, which has been stripped back to its bones to give a rustic chic feel.There is a small cafe on site and space in the garden to relax if you are not in a rush. I would recommend a couple of hours, but you could do it in less.

If you like Rodin, you should stop. Nice, pretty big Rodin collection. Broad range of media that he used. Also, I think there were works there by others of his contemporaries. Thinker is in the garden.Covered by the Paris Museum Pass.

To be visited for the garden and the place. Is it a "must" ? No it is not.I have studied close by 15 years ago, it was nice and sleepy.I have been there in june, there was a queue and it was rather crowded.Nonetheless, there was some reshaping and 1/3 of the place was not accessible.To be avoided till the end of the reshaping.

Ok, mainly for the thinker. Ok, we mainly went for the Thinker. We stayed for the rest, some paintings and sculptures. Nice garden, and other sculptures outside, It's right next too Les Invalides. So with your museum pass, you can see both.
Thoughtful. This small museum is so lovely. Again the museum pass helped avoid long lines. The house and gardens and lovely and thoughtprovoking. We enjoyed our visit.
Genius and a garden. The sculpture in the house and garden make for a beautiful and peaceful interlude during any visit to Paris. And it's right in the middle of the city, next to Les Invalides.

Beautiful - Must See. It's Privately Supported and because of that I think it's more cared for because they take pride in it. The gardens are breath taking. Stop and have Lunch in the gardens. Share a glass of wine with someone you love and imagine what Inspired Rodin to create these masterpieces.

Possibly my favorite place in the whole world. I've been to the Rodin Museum 4 times now, visiting over many years. It keeps getting better, more informative. Now in Aug. 2013 there was a display of gorgeous marbles I hadn't seen before, not sure if that's permanent or not. While I recommend seeing the inside of the hotel/ex-residence of the great artist, where there are many of his plans, hand drawings, and works of his lover and notable artist herself Claudine Claudell, I'd say the greatest bargain in all of Paris is just taking the garden tour. For the really bargain conscious, for one euro you see a collection of simply marvelous bronze statues, The Kiss, The Thinker, the Gates of Hell, all tastefully scattered around an idyllic garden setting. There is a rest area in the back where I spent a peaceful hour in chairs provided. It is simply wonderful, art, history lesson, place to relax during your busy Paris traveling. A pleasant and reasonably priced outdoor cafe also. I quite agree with previous reviewer, absolutely not to be missed!!

The thinker!. Auguste Rodin is the more well-know french sculptor. In between Le Louvre in which you can spend your life, and le musée d'Orsay, spending less than 2 hours in this little museum is a human choice. The park and its restaurant on the green is very pleasant. And the Camille Claudel artworks are around... The emotion is everywhere. Close to the Invalides area.
The Thinker. We came here just to see The Thinker statue. It's located outside, just behind the main building. The garden is pretty and nicely laid out.

Paris and art. to be able to touch The Thinker in the flesh it incredible. the gardens are also worth the trip. there are many sculpture I was not aware he had done dont miss the very large sculpted door.

The Thinkers Roost.. A sunny day and light visitation by tourists was a delight. The building is plain, not overly impressive, giving the sculptures their best backdrop. We were surprised about the artist, and how much he had done outside our knowledge.
Do not miss. This is often overlooked but do not. The art is amazing but the gardens are just as special. Spend several hours and really relax at this special location

An Afternoon with Rodin. It was a very hot afternoon by the time we made it to the museum. The interior was very interesting with a display of Rodin's "rough drafts" of his pieces. Unfortunately, the gardens were under construction so many of the usual pieces had been shipped to other museums until the work was done. The gardens, however were in full bloom and "The Thinker" was seated surrounded by green bushes and roses. This museum is not real handicap friendly, although a discount on the admission is given. The grounds themselves are gravel or packed dirt and even that was difficult to maneuver over. Overall I was a bit disappointed because of the lack of Rodin's works.
take the time to see. If you are pressed for time, take the Garden tour only...it is a delight! You also hae access to the Models facility to see how the statues were made

Joy and sadness all in one place!. I love this place! beautiful garden contrast with life and death. This place will make you think(er) and appreciate ur great life (well you in Paris after all) to me its a must see place.PS: for fashion lover! this is the place where Valentino have his last couture collection so feel free to walk down the partway like a supermodel!

Thinking. We actually visited Musee Rodin with our kids and it went surprisingly smooth. It was a good way for them to get some culture and also be able to be themselves without worrying about offending anyone. Very peaceful garden.

The most relaxing place in Paris. I loved this museum. It was beautiful and relaxing. The gardens are a respite from the commotion of the city. By far the the quietest and refreshing place we found. Rodin's sculptures atre great too.
Lovely museum. I really enjoy this smaller museum. The gardens, the statues( the famous 'Penseur' among others) are well worth the trip.
Always a beauty and a favorite. A pleasure to behold more beautiful each time a Paris favorite! They have updated the gardens. Pleasant quite stroll in the city that is very relaxing.

Love the gardens!. This museum has lots of Rodin's work in former workshops as well as through the beautiful gardens. At each turn, there is another sculpture. It was a pleasure just being among these beautiful pieces.

Go on a nice day and bring a snack!. These gardens are one of the finest things in Paris, a city full of some of the world's finest things. Make sure you check their hours, and try and go on a nice day as the things to see are outdoors (the museum is nice, but the amazing bronze works are in the gardens).Bring a picnic to enjoy in the gardens, lots of people were doing it when we were there!

One of the most beautiful gardens. It is a small museum, but a fantastic one! The most amazing thing is the garden, with lots of Rodin sculptures and great light.The museum itself has the face of Rodin made by Camille Claudel, which is, in my opinion, the highlight of the place.It is really a must go

Lovely break from Paris without going anywhere!. Sit on comfortable benches under huge trees looking at the Thinker and such iconic works whilst in the middle of Paris. Phenomenal. Much shorter queues than most museums, and my favourite in Paris.

great musée - inside and out. Of course, the Musée Rodin is a must-see. It's nicely set up with collections inside and in the gardens. There are the permanent collections (inside and out) and a temporary collection in another building. I happened to visit on the first Sunday of the month - which in Paris is a free day for most (if not all) musées, so I don't know the price. I really liked the permanent collections and saw some great things in the house (with the permanent collection).
Never ceases to amaze. It wouldn't be Paris, for me anyway, without a visit to at least, the garden. Beauty and peace abound. Find a spot, take some time, and just breathe.
Beauty personified. It was free. 1st Sunday of the month. Great audio guide. Away from the crowds. Easy Metro ride. Gardens were exquisite.
dont miss.... really great museum, though just so you know its not a big one. anyhow really beautiful, and definitely for sculptures lovers a serious dont miss!

As wonderful as remembered. My husband and I went to Paris 10 years ago and remembered the Musee Rodin as one of our favorite attractions. We went again with the kids age 10 and 13 and had a great time. The sculptures are absolutely beautiful and all in the gorgeous outdoor setting in August. Since our last visit they have remodeled the gardens so that they are even more beautiful. There is a small café outside where we had some gelato. The house we toured last and spent about 15 minutes there versus 1 hours in the garden. Since most is outside I would not go when it is raining. About 10 to 15 minutes from the muse D'orsay. You can buy a combined pass rodin and D'Orsay but it was less for us to buy them separately due to rodin family pass (2 adults and 2 kids) which was about 9.5 euros and less than the cost of 2 adults alone (?) the D'Orsay had a Eurostar ticket holder buy 1 get one free admission for adult. (no charge for children).

20 yr. Not being an Art nut, this was a really cool place to visit, have lunch.Only day we got rain in Paris, wasn't a bad place to hang out .Share an audio guide to save a few bucks. Not that many sculpture that

A delight for Rodin lovers. Relatively small museum with a very nice collection of the great man's works. It was interesting to see drafts/ different versions of the various well known pieces. Compared to some of the other larger more hectic museums, this was almost peaceful. Don't miss !

The thinker and the kiss. were our favourties but we also discovered the more gloomy side of Rodin's work, the gates of hell are impressive and can be cause for nightmares. Monet's painting of Belle-Ile-en-Mer can also be seen in the Museum, the gardens are a lovely spot and you forget you are in a museum, very lovely walk to the Pont Alexandre too, not far and in a flash you find yourself on the Champs d'Elysees.

A good little museum. Visiting this museum is difficult to consider an independent campaign, most can look back on the way to one of the major dostoprimechatelnostets Paris. However, you are waiting for a beautiful park and a beautiful sculpture

Disappointed. We expected to see a lot more. The grounds are pretty, and we got to see The Thinker, but overall we were unimpressed. Certainly something you could do very quickly. We saw much more impressive sculptures and statues at Versailles and in the Musee du Louvre, so you could skip this without being upset. If you just want to see The Thinker, it's the first thing on your right once you get outside.

So glad we visited. The Rodin was not on our must see list but we walked by on our way to Napoleon's Tomb and decided to visit. It ended up being one of the highlight of our trip. The work on exhibit is expansive and the house and gardens wonderful. On my next trip to Paris, I will definitely return to have lunch at their cafe and spend more time surrounded by Rodin's amazing works.

Lovely museum. This was one of my favourite museums. It is housed in Auguste Rodin's former workshop and showroom. You can see all of Rodin's famous sculptures. The garden is just fabulous! A nice change to all of the other museums in Paris.
Awesome. My favorite of all the museums! It was beautiful, inviting, and extremely enjoyable to walk around the gardens and see the amazing sculptures within the gardens. Highly recommend.

Beautiful Gardens. Almost all of Rodin's famous sculptures are housed in the museum's gardens, so you really don't have to pay full price for entrance to the museum - it's only about 1 euro to enter the gardens alone. When I visited, the main building was closed for renovations anyway, so my full-price ticket only allowed me to see a temporary exhibit of Rodin's drawings (not worth the price, but interesting). This is a quick and easy stop for art lovers and a must for Rodin fans.

I return every year without fail. It's not because they charge a mere one euro entrance fee for the gardens. It is because it is beautiful and has to be the most delightful garden to sit and people watch for hours or just read a book. The weather has been lovely this week and browsing amongst beautiful sculptures is what Paris is all about. Highly recommended.
Definitely will come back. Museum of Rodin was exactly what I expected. The sculpture was magnificent and we had a lovely small tour of his best work.

Amazing collection of works by Rodin. This is an amazing collection of the works by Rodin and some of his students. Of particular significance are the large statues displayed in the garden, i.e. The Thinker and Balzac.
Paris Trip. Great museum. No waiting in line. You can pose with the statues in the gardens. Very relaxed atmosphere. A fun place to go.

I love the Rodin museum. It was nice to see an outdoor museum in Paris, especially after being inside all day at the other great venues such as the Louvre, and D'orsay. Take your time going through the gardens, as there are so many sculptures to be seen that are not labeled on the map they give you at the entrance.
Nice little spot. Small in scale and scope, easy to get to, if you are into The Thinker or The Kiss it's well worth an hour of your time.
Gardens are a must see. Cost is extremely reasonable for the gardens, and that is where the Thinker statue among others is located.

Beautiful and Relaxing. There's no question: this is a great museum, both inside and out. The maison is lovely and there is art of both Rodin and his mistress, Camille Claudel displayed, including The Kiss, lots of busts of Balzac and of course, The Thinker. A smaller version is in the musem, the original is in the garden, surrounded by beautifully trimmed shrubbery and roses. A stroll in the garden is relaxing and the cafe is very nice. The gift shop is nice, too!

Gardens are great bang for the buck. This review only applies to the gardens, not the museum proper.For an entry fee of one euro, one can easily cover the grounds in an hour, or just as easily spend hours whiling away a lazy, peaceful afternoon away from the bustle of the city.Since you're already in the neighborhood, drop by les Invalides to check out Napoleon's tomb and the army museum.

Beautiful Garden Walk. On our recent trip to Paris, we visited the Musee Rodin and only toured the outdoor garden. It was an impressive walk, and only cost one Euro (very affordable for such a nice place!). We admired the famous "Thinker" statue, as well as many other beautiful Rodin sculptures. We also just sat on a bench in the park and relaxed. It was very nice, and less crowed than other Paris attractions we went to. We were glad that we included this stop on our holiday.

Thinker & Gardens the Highlight. I didn't know what to expect from Musee Rodin, so I was both pleasantly surprised and disappointed. The gardens and statues outside were beautiful and a highly enjoyable walk. The work inside was nice was well. Overall there wasn't a great deal to see though. Our visit took less than 1 hour.
