I'm thinking, I'm thinking. The garden with all of the sculptures is worth the walk around. I was especially impressed with Rodin's "Burghers of Calais". I also liked The Shades, the Gates of Hell, and of course, the Thinker.

I hope the changes are permanent. Musee Rodin is one of my favorite places in Paris yet this trip things were different. Many of Rodin's most famous marbles were moved out of the chateau and into the entry/gift shop building. Part of the beauty of the sculptures was seeing them in such an amazing setting in the chateau with the gardens in the background. I really hope they are just doing some renovations and will eventually move the sculptures back to the big house. It really took away from the experience.

Venture into the gardens for more!. It was raining, it was cold, but I ventured out to the gardens anyway, because that is where quite a bit of Rodin's works (Gates of Hell, The Thinker... ) are placed, so do go have a look, don't let bad weather hold you back.I appreciate the Lourve for its amazing and massive, important collections, but I prefer Musee Rodin because it's very compact, not overwhelming, you can spend a good three hours there and still not get museum-ed out!Part of the museum (the Hotel Biron wing) was undergoing renovations when I visited, apparently renovation works would be completed next year, but they won't affect your visit to the museum, so no worries.

Thought Provoking. See the thinker live and many others of his sculptures. Up there with David (in Florance) for the Wow factor. You can also stop in at Le Aporgee Alan Passards restraunt across the road.

Very pleasant experience. When we were there the back gardens were not available but the bronzes had been moved. The inside/outside experience of the bronzes and the sculptures was excellent, although you can't take pictures inside, which seems strange. The museum is very simple and clean, and was not crowded

Do not miss this GARDEN!. I've never visited the residence, just strolled this garden. It's not to be ignored, always thrilling. "The Thinker" is here, among other stellar sculptures. It's not far from Napoleon's tomb at the Ecole Militaire, so make a stop at both and then eat at Thomieux! Nothing to lose on these suggestions.

The outdoor sculptures. The outdoor sculptures are the highlights of the musuem. The mold for the incredible bronze door is at the Musee d"Orsay. Rodin is simply the greatest sculptor that ever lived and this musuem has the largest collection of his works.

head straight for the garden. The garden is stunning - and only costs one euro. The collection and exhibits in the buildings themselves are surprisingly uninspiring. And cost nine euro. My advice? Don't go into the buildings - spend your time in the garden admiring some of Rodin's masterpieces. A lovely, inexpensive hour or so and a uniquely Paris experience.

Musee Rodin. Perhaps not the best museum in Paris but there are some great examples of Rodin's work, both outside in the gardens and inside. Small enough to enjoy without succumbing to culture overload.

Enthralling collection.. Although the museum is currently undergoing extensive renovations, this is a wonderful, focussed museum on Rodin. Many of his grand (enlarged) sculptures are presented in the extensive gardens, which adds a different perspective than seeing them indoors. I found the audio guide seriously enhanced the visit. Two and a half hours flew by!

A bit disappointed. Perhaps I was expecting too much but was let down by our visit. The garden was pleasant (though with a surprisingly expensive cafe!) but I expected to see more of Rodin's work. There are so many fine museums in Paris. If time is limited, I would spend my time elsewhere.
rodin. You can always return to this museum to llok at the work of Rodin and his school. t's small and nice to see

Excellent alternative to the crowds at the Louvre. The Rodin museum was a great stop for us. Of course, the Louvre is much more famous but if you want a great introduction to art and artistic thought in a more intimate atmosphere, the Musee Rodin is a great alternative. It is definitely more narrowly focused than the Louvre but the overall experience is not to be missed. OK, the other museums in Paris are worth while but to appreciate the art without being jostled by 2,000 other tourists, the gardens of this museum are an excellent alternative.
great location!!. I love the fact that is close to the city and other museum, beautiful statues, lovely gardens where you can enjoy book reading.

Thoroughly enjoyable. The statues in the garden and house are very well displayed. This was one of the highlights of our visit to Paris. It was easy to access and reasonable cost, especially for a family.
Picnics not welcome!. Part of the gardens closed at present but still worth a visit> asked to pack up our picnic which seemed a tad churlish!

Any time of year..... ... the most perfect oasis in the city centre. Whatever your views on art, sculpture. Rodin..... this is the most beautiful place to take time out from your busy trek round Paris. Gorgeous gardens with plenty of space cost very little (1euro?) to visit and you can enjoy the marvels of The Thinker amongst other delights there. A few more Euros will take you into the Musee... so worth it, rain or shine.

Up close and personal. We visited the Musee Rodin while a temporary display of Rodin's finest works were on display. The display allows you to view up close the finer detail of Rodin's work and the helpful information cards accompanying each work provided context and points of interest on each piece. Don't miss The Thinker.
Accessible and Relaxing. Wander Rodin's rooms and spend time with his studies... wind up in the rose garden before wandering back through the academic neighborhood to the busier streets of Paris.

Old Museum that needs a lot of renovation. My visit at the museum is always entertaining. I love coming here, but bare in mind for those who visit this museum in winter, it might not be as pleasant as if you would have gone during summer or fall. First of all, it is chilly and sometimes windy during winter in Paris. When you see the garden, it is very plain and simple. It's not as attractive to look at compare to when there are flowers in the garden and when the fountain is working. Also, it does rain sometimes during winter so to visit the garden can be a little slushy. The temporary exhibition is remarkable, I wish there were more and only if we can take pictures....The museum needs major renovation. It looks good from the outside but inside is a different story. The floors are uneven (on some hallways), the windows needed to be cleaned or changed because it looks so outdated. The lighting is very poor, with my flash on, I sometimes still don't get a good picture.Overall, it's a nice museum despite the major renovations that needed to be done, I like the artifacts in display. The bookstore has a lot to offer, from notepads, school supplies and books, you are likely to leave with at least a souvenir from this museum.
Beautiful. Definitely worth seeing. It is not as big as I expected, but very beautiful. Also free entry the first Sunday of the month!
Serene. If you want to commune with some of the best sculpture in a quiet setting and garden, this is a must

Excellent. Adjacent to Les Invalides, Musee Rodin is small but packed with his amazing sculptures. The gardens are tranquil and probably best visited when the flowers are in bloom.Fantastic to see his most famous works in such simple surroundings.

The collection is not as good.. I am a huge fan of Rodin's work and I travel to visit museums around the word that is one of my passions. Visiting the museum was a disappointment. I found a few pieces that could highlight. The majority I had already seen through the world. The gates of Hell are a spectacle but I had seen a better version in Philadelphia. The gardens are magnificent and the palace is beautiful. A good surprise was the amount of children in contact with a museum taking art so special.

in need of restoration. Enough has been said about the collection... Rodin was definately a great artest, but also a good businessman employing marble workers. That's why I probably like the (plaster) models as much as the final work, and sometimes even more.The garden is lovely, as is the hôtel de maître... However it needs urgent repairs. The floors are in a terrible state, the paintwork is gone, windows need to be treated, the lovely mirrors and woodwork are begging to be taken care of... The contrast with the restored chapel couldn't be bigger. The gardens are lovely. There is a cafetaria as well with an outside terrace. This is, I'm sure, a nice place in the warmer months of the year, but on a cold February day, it felt not very welcoming with its glass panels.

Much more than Rodin. It was pleasant surprise to see not only Rodin's sculptures, but also some paintings both by him and other artists such as Van Gogh and Munch. Some of the best sculptures are in the garden, so if the weather is not on your side, wear a good raincoat and water repellant shoes!
A gem. With the lovely gardens and manor house, the Rodin museum is a great place to spend a few hours. See 'The Gates of Hell' and 'The Thinker' among other famous sculptures in this quaint spot.

My favorite place in Paris?. While in Paris, I stayed not far from the Musee Rodin, and with a Museum Pass was able to enter without being in lines much. I began every morning and even ended some of my days in the gardens. I walked spellbound around the sculptures and wound through the rooms in perfect contentment. Rodin's work is some of my favorite, and this place is up there as well.

Quiet Beauty. Although when I went part of the museum was closed, Rodin was a nice step away from the gigantic Orsay and Louvre. Rodin's work is nicely displayed inside and outside in the gardens. For me it was one of my favorite museums I went to my whole time in Paris and I would think it a shame to miss it upon my next trip.

Okay. We couldn't fit everything into our four day trip and decided to visit this one over so many others on our last day. We really wanted to see the Thinker and the Gates of Hell and we weren't disappointed with these but that's just about it. I understand that they are showcasing just one artist but it's quite disappointing the way it's laid out. It wasn't a great day weater wise when we were there which took away from viewing the Thinker and Gates of Hell which along with other sculptures are displayed throughout the garden. The marble pieces including the kiss are displayed indoors and are magnificient, it's a pity they don't allow non flash photos, overall we were sorry we choose this museem over many others to finish our holiday, okay for a visit if your a Rodin lover, cost 18Euro for two which I thought was pricey for what little you got

Beautiful Any Time. If you like Rodin, you'll love this place. The permanent collection is exciting and there are related artists shown here regularly. Spring in the garden is reportedly breathtaking.

A refreshment in museum visits in doors. Tired of visiting museums and getting closed within four walls? Rodin museum has all the works scattered in beautiful gardens. Is a small museum, not usually too crowded and the sculptures are absolutely lovely

Great to see his works where he placed them. There's something about being in the actual place where a genius lived and worked that's special. It's even better when his contemporaries walked there, too, and the work of some, like van Gogh, are represented there. All or most of Rodin's major works are represented, oftentimes in the spots he wanted them placed on the grounds. A plus is the view from the sculpture gardens of the Dome des Invalides (above Napoleon's casket) across the street.
Rodin gardens in Feb - a bit chilly but worth it. Lots and lots of great Rodin sculptures including the Thinker and the Kiss.Surprising painting of the Thinker by Munch in the house.

Don't enter if the garden is closed.. I guess I can't fully rate this because the outside garden was shut down since we snuck in to enter less than an hour before closing. As far as I can tell there was only one room of statues and sculptures indoors, which were rather intriguing. We were kind of able to breeze through this room in about 10 minutes. I would have disappointed if I actually paid for admission, but since I had the Paris museum pass in was on to the next site.

Two complementary Rodin collections in Paris...and Meudon. The hôtel particulier, former Hôtel Biron, is worth a visit by itself. The various rooms and staircase gives you a glimpse at what the Parisian gentry'life could be in the mid-XVIIIth...Icing on the cake, the garden has been maintained almost in its original size, something pretty rare in Paris, allowing you to have stunning views on nearby Dôme des Invalides and to rest, far from the city's buzz.The collection itself is just wonderfull with the bronze casts of all Rodin's majour masterworks (Bourgeois de Calais, Porte de l'Enfer etc), many marble masterpieces and gips from the master. A must see for any art lover and a milestone for scuplture history...If you loved it, go on and take a ride to Meudon, a close suburb distant by only 7 km that allows you to visit Rodin's atelier, last house were he spent his last years from 1895 to 1917 (a mooving dining room where he once had supper with Stefan Zweig, Emile Verhaeren, Clemenceau etc) as well as a 1930 pavillon that houses most gips statues he gave to the French state upon his death. are especially mooving his evolving projects for Victor Hugo's funeral monument, as well as the gigantic "La Defense de Paris" assessed as too revolutionary by the committee which opted for a more conventional sculpture that can still be seen in Paris business La Défense area.

What a treasure.... This amazing collection of Rodin's work is housed in this 'shabby in a good way' mansion. A beautiful garden, and a cafe. It was such a lovely afternoon seeing the collection, and enjoying a bottle of wine and a salad from the cafe....aaaaand some great cheese we snuck in our bag.
A great little Museum.. We have been here twice. A house and garden of Art. Statues, yes, but a lovely peaceful place in the middle of Paris
Brilliant sculptures . If u like sculptures visit here. Well worth a visit . U can see works of art . How he found the time to do so much brilliant sculptures is mind boggling

Fabulous. We visited in January so the gardens were not at their best, but there were few crowds. Rodin is a master and all his best sculptures were here. Many old friends from the Smithsonian are here. (More than one copy were made of bronzes like The Thinker and The Burghers of Calais.) Beautiful building and great art.
Green and cozy. I dont go here because of the art. I come here once in a while because it is one of few outdoor places in Paris that are quite. It's quite and the garden is beutiful.

Loved the gardens. The gardens are the highlight of the museum. I went on a colder day so it was pretty quiet outside and you could really take your time and walk throughout the space. I didn't really care for the interior of the museum though.
Musee Rodin. Just cannot resist.. love the art of Rodin myself.. the museum is not huge but really worth to see..

Surprising highlight of my trip. I didn't expect to like this museum as much as I did. I'm not a huge art affacianado, but this museum was such a delight. The house and grounds are lovely. A nice place to spend an hour or two.

Very Interesting. The drawcard here is, of course, Rodin's 'Le Penseur' (The Thinker).Having so said, however, his other works are brilliant and I very much liked 'The Kiss' and 'Cathedral'. The grounds are gorgeous (even in Winter) and it was a pleasant way to spend an afternoon.
among the best museums in Paris. Very nice small museum that exhibits Rodin sketches! Really enjoyed the exhibition! Though is better to visit the museum on a sunny day as the garden is very sweet.

Best Museum. In September 2012, I went to Paris to celebrate my 50th birthday. During my visit I went to the Musee Rodin. WOW!!!! Sums it up. While like most people I was familiar with Rodin and The Thinker but there was so much more to this place then I imagined. It is set in beautifully manicured grounds with sculptures all around the gounds. A great sitting area to view the rear of the Musee and gardens, a place to have a quiet snack or beverage. It was a beautiful sunny day to spend roaming the grounds. The inside exhibits were fascinating as well. I will no doubt return on my next trip to Paris.
Boring!. I thought it was completely boring apart from the gardens. You aren't allowed to take any pictures at all which kind of sucks as you'd want the memories.

One of our favorite Paris Museums. There are several small museums in Paris honoring specific artists. This is one of our favorites. Wonderful gardens full of sculptures with smaller and other works inside. We visit this every time in Paris.

Worth the visit. The grounds are spectacular so make sure you take the time to walk through the garden. The camera is a must in this place but taking a good photo that is not packed with imaged of strangers is difficult. It can become a very busy place on a nice day.
Oasis. What a lovely way to spend the day. Normally not that busy. A beautiful garden and the food is quite good as well.

Absolute gem! MUST visit. You can see The Thinker of course but rest of the museum is awesome and even my teen was impressed ! Surprisingly, they did not sell "thinker miniature" - none I could afford anyway !

Sculptures - and a bit more. Rodin was a magnificent artist and his work is truly impressing. In his home which is now the museum, you will find many of his finest pieces. Unluckily for us, the garden was closed due to the snow conditions when we visited, hence we were not able to walk around in these beautiful surroundings with many more of Rodin's masterpieces.But the interiousr was also absolutely worth while, and in addition to the sculptures, there were also a couple of van Gogh paintings, one by Claude Monet and even Edvard Munch's painting of Rodin's very famous sculpture of the thinker - "Le Penseur".Next time I will visit this museum in the Summer time.....

Nice stop on the way to the Eiffel Tower. We stopped here on our way to the Eiffel Tower on a hop-on, hop-off bus. We just wanted to walk through the gardens and see The Thinker, and Gates of Hell with our young kids. We read that it was only 1 Euro to visit the gardens, but we were let in for free! Great stop on the way to the rest of the sites in Paris.
Incredible. We enjoyed walking around the gardens and examing these amazing scultpures. The layout was good- not too crowded- and we were afforded the opportunity to relax and soak in the beauty.
Worth seeing. This museum shows a grest collection of nice sculptures. It is really world class, and the gsrden is quite beautiful. Veru worth seeing, if you have the time.

A favorite destination in Paris. The Musee Rodin is one of my favorite spots in Paris. I love Rodin's sculptures, which is much of the appeal of the museum for me, but I also love how peaceful the gardens are, especially right in the middle of Paris. The gardens are only 1 euro to access, if you don't want to go on sculpture overload, and wandering among the trees and flowers is pure stress release. You can find most of the "big name" Rodin sculptures in the garden: Le Penseur, Les Trois Ombres, Balzac, Ugolin, and La Porte de l'Enfer. There are benches throughout the garden to sit and rest or reflect. A cafe in the garden provides a chance to enjoy a coffee or snack (or even lunch). When I visited in October, the Hotel Biron (the main house on the property) was undergoing renovation but it is worth the visit, as well, for the opportunity to see many of Rodin's smaller works and studies as well as a number of works by his mistress, Camille Claudel. Also, the gift shop, though small, is wonderful with plenty of trinkets, books, art, and so on that you'll want to take home. I know I have to watch my spending!

A Fantastic Surprise for Us as Thinkers. The Thinker is one of the pieces of art that my wife and I had been looking forward to seeing. We went to this museum and were very pleased with everything that we saw....including the Thinker. There was so much more. First there is a temporary exhibition that has many marble pieces, including The Kiss, as well as clay models .Get the headsets so you can listen to the details associated with these art pieces.The garden was FANTASTIC....The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, The Three Shades as well as many others.The Hotel museum is set up very nicely.There is a cafe in the gardens where we had lunch, the quiche and salad was good.

Well worth visiting. Wonderful collection of Rodin's sculptures in bronze and marble. Can't help but be amazed by the huge bronze "the gates of hell" . The only reason I never gave 5 stars is the lack of name/description plaques for the exhibits. Otherwise excellent.

Love Rodin? Must see this!. Love scuplture? Love Rodin? in thsi case, Musee Rodin must be on your hot tourist map! The place itself has a special aura and prooves to be more attractive than presented. My advice is to be informed before you set such an objective. Loved it!
Enjoyed it!. The Musee Rodin was a real treat. There are statues everywhere inside and all over the gardens. Very interesting!
Brief stop. The Thinker is the main reason to stop to see this museum. Rodin was a sculptor, so there are many to see but the rose garden & thinker are the best. Bypass the line with a museum pass!

So much scuplture. all the famous statues, the thinker and the burgers of Calais where created here. The gates of hell... excellent place to visit. The house is lovely and houses 'the kiss'. Ideal place to visit with the wife and glance lovingly back......

Awesome!. The weather wasn't that great while we were there, but we still managed to make our way through the gardens with our umbrellas. Rodins' work really needs to be digested and not just looked at as his work is really deep.

A nice change of pace. I waited a while to visit this museum as I thought it would be like the others; special, but crowded and overwhelming. I was surprised that it is the complete opposite. With collections both indoors and outdoors, the Musee Rodin is a nice change of pace and a very manageable museum to visit Oh, and the fees are really low...perfect for a quick stop or romantic stroll. I enjoyed strolling the grounds and marveling at the statutes and the skill needed to sculpt such pieces. There's a cafe on the grounds and I would have been happy to conclude my visit just outdoors but there's more inside if you wish to visit. All in all, I'm placing Musee Rodin amongst my favorites in Paris simply because I got a bit of culture- the gates of hell, the thinker- without all the fuss that usually goes along with museum visits. I enjoyed the open air and the intimate feeling!
a treasure. The gardens have been improved over the years and the building is a true treasure. wonderful way to spend a few hours

Rodin Fan. Yes it was a freezing day, the garden was bare, it's winter... But the exhibit ... Was fantastic along with the interp. The staff were great friendly and knew their stuff. I loved it.... It was so wonderful to be amongst his art.

Indoor/Outdoor. Beautiful exhibition building, visited in January but the gardens would assumably be beautiful come the Spring! The collection is wonderful and it's nice to be able to wander around outside - weather permitting! As always, grab an audio guide - it's worth it!

A must-see. Rodin is one of the best sculptors in the world and the museum is a must see. The garden contains many replicas of his statues and gives a nice view over the Invalides. I found all the sculptures extremely interesting, from the busts of Victor Hugo, Bernard Show, Balzac and others to the famous Le Baiser and Le Penseur. They are so expressive that they almost seem alive.The ticket (9euros + 1euro for the gardens) also comprises the access to temporary collections. As for other museums in Paris, for EU citizens under 26 the access is free.One hour would not be enough to see this museum so I recommend at least 1h30-2h for the visit although the museum itself is not big.Nearest metro station: Varennes.

Good collection, indoors and out!. A nice way to spend a rainy afternoon, or to take a break for lunch. Set in spacious gardens, the museum is a good place to zip into for lunch (it's not far from my husband's office). For just 1 or 2 euros, you can access the gardens, which have plenty of Rodin's larger works, and there's a no nonsense restaurant / cafeteria there, where you can buy decent food and enjoy on a table in the sun.
Excellent. We passed this on the tour bus and all agreed to go back, we were not disappointed. Many of Rodins works are here, the gardens are great to wander around, and the cafe has great snacks

Rather splendid. When you enter via the ticket office, it is difficult to appreciate the extent of this site and its collection. The first indoor area contains various marble statues Rodin made, some, such as The Kiss, very famous but there is really much much more to see. The grounds of the Villa are very beautiful, and must be splendid when all the flowers are out, and contain many pieces, such as the Thinker and the fantastic Gates of Hell (also in the Louvre) The Villa is not very well kept but also has interesting collection including some fine paintings. Well worth a visit for those with an artistic interest.

Loved the Gardens. We came here on our last day in Paris as an afterthought. We had several things we wanted to do that morning, so we only toured the gardens rather than the entire museum. It was peaceful, serene, and beautiful. Loved seeing the famous "Thinker." Would definitely recommend a quick (1 hour) tour of the gardens. It would have been a great place to go on a lunch hour if it had been sunny, but it was winter and slightly raining, so not so great for sitting out on the benches.
Beautiful sculpture garden. A walk through the gardens on the grounds of the home Auguste lived in is worthwhile. Take your camera.

An antidote to the Louvre. Rodin's work and his assistant's is housed in his former home and garden. Large and seemingly relevant work. The emotions wrought in the bronze and plaster still feel real now. Their size demands attention. A terrific gift shop too containing well priced quirky souvenirs beyond the literal or pompous.Negative: a little difficult to find down a side street with narrow footpaths.

A must for those on culture trip. Very nicely, lively display that lets you look at the works very closely (though you can't touch them, obviously!). We last went in winter so outside was cold and was being done up, but summer evenings are lovely.

A great surprise. My husband was not thrilled when I suggested we visit this museum - but by the end of the visit I had to drag him out of the place! The bronzes are fabulous but the marbles are out of this world! And we had no idea that Rodin painted! The site is under going some renovations but the work did not distract from the works or the visit. The inside of the museum would be even lovelier if there were rooms "staged to reflect Rodin's living." The star of the museum is, of course, the gardens! And they are breath taking! Even in the dead of winter it is worth visiting this wonderful museum!

Fun Grounds; Dilapidated Building. Musee Rodin offers a pleasant park-like setting with numerous outdoor Rodin sculptures. We brought a lunch and enjoyed it on one of the benches facing The Thinker. While the contents of the building were interesting, the structure itself in in serious need of refurbishment.

Rodin gardens a nice spot for lunch. If you don't have time to take in the entire Musee Rodin, spend one Euro and get entrance to the gardens. Join "The Thinker" in the garden and enjoy lots of other art and the gardens and stop for lunch or wine at the little Pavillion.
Great Museum. This museum demonstrates how prolific Rodin was. The original "thinker" is there in the garden. The museum pass is god here to speed things up.

Time of reflection. I squeezed a visit to the Musee Rodin on my last day in Paris and I wish I had more time. This is the type of museum where it is best to sit, reflect, and relax. The day I visited was the first "blue sky" day I had in Paris, and while it was winter-time, it was enjoyable to sit and gaze upon the amazing sculptures in the garden. The interior exhibition is also good, but the garden bronzes are the highlight. I can only imagine the gardens in spring, when it is in full bloom, and must be incredibly picturesque. If you have the time for a leisurely stroll around these masterpieces on a good weather day, then do take advantage of visiting this museum. No guide is necessary. It is easy enough to do on your own.

Need to Think about a catchy title. Exciting to see "The Thinker" in person. Beautiful gardens, but sparse collection of sculptures. There was an old colonial style home that housed additonal sculptures and paintings, but nothing that stood out as a highlight.

For sculpture lovers. Another must see for art lovers . Beautiful garden filled with wonderful sculptures so nest on a nice day . The inside gallery also contains many lovely works and the complete history of the artist

Great museum. Rodin is awesome. His sculptures are so full of emotion and the gardens outside are beautiful as well. The thinker is great but there are a lot of other "thought-provoking" pieces. Give yourself at least two hours to see everything and don't wait too late in the day because we went in the afternoon and they closed the temporary exhibit at like 5. Included in the museum pass which I recommend you get if you plan on going to at least 2-3 museums while in Paris. I really enjoyed my visit.

It's very nice. The Musee Rodin is not a very big museum. The thing to see is of course, The Thinker. The original, not one of the many casts which have been made and sent around the world. The original sits there in the garden, contemplating who knows what. That alone is worth the price of admission (bought ahead of time online, of course). The house does not have a lot of pieces to view, but what is there is very nice. The gate to Hell is also on display, where The Thinker first made an appearance. Overall it is worth it to see this important piece of art.
Peace. On a quiet, clear, cool morning I visited this museum, and found walking through the gardens admiring the sculpture one of the most peaceful experiences I have had traveling. A must see.

The Statues & bronzes are AMAZING. We were totally surprised by how much we enjoyed visiting the Rodin Gardens & Museum. It is a real MUST do.When you go, be sure to rent their Headsets/audio tour. We came with a Rick Steves' version on my IPod--which is usually very good-- but you miss a lot by not having theirs. In fact when we return to Paris, which we will do sometime in the future, we will again visit Rodin, and this time we will use their audio.The gardens with the statues about is unbelievable. Earlier in the day we had seen several Rodin works at the d'Orsay --which is also NOT TO BE MISSED!!!!!!-- but here at the Gardens they were at an entirely different level.Friends had told us about seeing the "Thinker" in the garden setting with the Eifel Tower in the background, however viewing it in person and seeing his "Dante's Door" and several other pieces were AMAZING!DO GO THERE!!!!

Great Museum. I took a long, safe and great walk from the Hotel St. Sulpice to this museum. If you walk you get to take in the regular city sites (kids going to school, shops serving the locals, etc.). If you like sculptures, a great place to visit. The gardens are beautiful as well and it's located behind huge exterior doors... you may not realize that a museum lies on the other side.

Interesting museum. This is my favorite museum in Paris! The building is in not fantastic condition, however this adds to the charm. The art works really shine in this environment as they are not competing with the building. Explore the whole garden for lots of surprises.

a rare treat to see all of a masters works in one place. The Thinker, The Kiss, The Shadows, The walking man, everything both inside and in the garden is great. And with benches to sit and contemplate the best sculpture since Michelangelo. Must be better in the summer.

A artistic gem. A bit off the beaten Paris museum path. A significant portion of the work is displayed in the lovely gardens. Not overly crowed even during peak season, when we were there. Allow time for a light lunch at the reasonably priced museum restaurant.

Dont be sad you missed it. I wasn't sure about this museum but was able to fit it into my schedule while I was in Paris. I have to say I'm very happy that I did. A walk though the musee Rodin is worth the time. Just through the entrance you are introduced to some amazing works of art. Continue into the garden and visit the thinker, the gates of hell and many others. The garden itself is lovely. I visited in November and still found the garden to be full of beautiful flowers. The thinker surrounded by rows of roses. Before you leave enter a house on the premises. As much as I enjoyed the works of art in the home, there was also a lot of beauty and history in the home itself. Inside you will enjoy art not only by Rodin but also by friends and other artists of his time. As much as I enjoyed the Musee Rodin I believe that it would be worth going to see it in spring and summer. One thing I will say that I didn't like about this museum is it is repetitive. You will find that you are looking at the same sculptures in different sizes some in stone some in bronze, etc. Covered by the MUSEUM PASS!

Do not miss this one. I lived in PAris for three years and have visited many times since. The one museum I always recommend is the Musee Rodin. It is easy to overlook situated in a villa rather than some grand faux greek temple, but don't overlook it. It has all of the master's great works, displayed as they were meant to be. If you only think of The Thinker when you think of Rodin, you are in for a treat. Check out the Gates of Hell and my personal favorite The Trois Ombres. You will also find works done by Rodin's mistress who was herself an amazing sculptor.

Thrilled to see it!!. Having been to Paris last year and finding the Musee Rodin was closed...we were delighted to be able to visit this time. What an amazing place and what wonderful art!! We went on our first day into the city and it was a great way to start the week.I have to imagine that the gardens are extraordinary in summer since they were actually beautiful in Dec.This would be a "must see" stop on your trip.

Well Worth A Visit. We went to the Musee Rodin to see The Thinker, of course, but were equally impressed by the other sculptures on display inside the building as well as in the surrounding gardens. The gardens were striking enough in mid-December; they must be outstanding in Spring or Summer. The paintings on display inside ere equally impressive. All in all it was a trip worth making to visit this museum. We would highly recommend it to others.

Didn't even have to think about it. This was on our very short list of places to visit on our three day tour of Paris. We rode the hop on hop off bus, and it dropped us off approximately two blocks from the museum. The admission price is very fair, but the cost of the audio tour was equal if not more than the admission itself. We visited during a rain spell and decided to start outside during a break in the weather. The outside sculptures were my favorite part of the entire museum. Beautiful in the dead of "winter," so I can only imagine what it would be like with the trees in bloom and the gardens. If the weather is not perfect or it rained recently make sure you have practical shoes as there are no sidewalks or proper walkways outside. The grounds are gravel/sandstone and after a rain are nothing but puddles and mud. The gates of hell and the thinker are outside and you cannot visit here and not see these sculptures. The emotion, detail and size of his work is breath taking. There are two seperate buildings that house smaller scale sculptures in various materials, paintings, models, etc. Overall well worth the visit. Two to three hours would be sufficient to get a good sense of the entire museum. Wear your wellies or rubbers if the weather is bad so you don't miss the out doors.
Must see!. We hadn't planned on seeing the wonderful sculpture garden - but once we walked by we had to stop. Gorgeous grounds!
A quiet interlude.. Come in the morning on a summer day. You can sit and gaze to your heart's content. Find a favorite bench and let your mind wander.

Warm Welcome to the Artists Home!. There is a peaceful welcome to the art at the Rodin Museum, an invitation to slow down and enjoy life. Maybe the warmth and serenity of this museum is due to the fact that the estate was once home to the artist, Rodin. His art is still home and in the nurturing atmosphere that created them; and something about that makes me pause and examine the statues here in a little bit more intimacy. Needless to say, I love this museum which is well maintained in both Rodin’s house and in his garden. The ultimate star of the museum is the Thinker, who sits in perpetual contemplation inside his very own grove of conical hedges. If he were to break his concentration, he might notice that over his right shoulder is the sparkling golden dome that shelters Napoleon’s tomb; and over his left shoulder is the Eiffel Tower—frivolous and airy, in contrast to the serious heaviness of the Thinker. This spot is perhaps the best photo-op in Paris because it has so many trademark elements of the city: high art, iconic landmarks, and harmonious contradictions. You might want to extend your time in the gardens by taking a break at the small cafeteria inside the garden walls, where you can find relatively inexpensive sandwiches, salads, croissants and hot coffee.As enchanting as the gardens are, be sure to also enter the house to see some shockingly beautiful and raw statues. Rodin’s style is very raw—which may be one of the reasons I love it so much. His subjects are often in as state of intensity, where emotions are impossible to restrain—a style most exquisitely exemplified in The Kiss.TIP: The Rodin Museum is between the D’Orsay Museum and Invalides. The best way to find it, though, without getting lose is to head straight to the Invalides, which houses the Military Museum (notice the cannons lining the front of the building’s vast lawn. Go to your left when facing Invalides, to its side street (Blvd des Invalides), as if heading towards the huge golden dome of Eglise du Dome where Napoleon is entombed. Roughly halfway down the street, turn left onto Rue de Varenne.

The kiss. ... And many more other famous powerfull sculptures to enjoy. I saw some of them at Orsey museum but i havent regreted visiting this museum. Museum is located in Rodin' s house and u can walk through the garden, sit on the bench, relax and enjoy the art.

A delight. A great testimony to one of the great french sculptors, with sculptures well set in a garden, and then in the house, with some rare and beautiful paintings from the sculptor's era; also has a nice side-exhibit of a few excellent sculptures by Mestrovic.
We loved this Museum!. This is so hands on, sculpture after sculpture of the most beautiful works of Rodin you'll ever see in one place, lovely gardens, a great experience!
Wow..... Great stop. Who would have thought Rodin would have to petition the Govt. to establish a museum? Great when the weather is pleasant.

An extraordinary Art experience. When about Rodin Museum you can be sure that there is Nothing to dislike. Starting with a vast (almost exhaustive) presentation on audio-guide and continuing with extremely well balanced pieces arrangement, the very intimately settled location in comparison with other touristic objectives and average size Museum is a unique experience for every Art lover.

Great for sculpture fanatics. If you're a fan of sculpture, The Musee Rodin is a great way to see some of the best. The museum has a comprehensive collection of Rodin's works. Don't miss out on the gardens which have some of the most notable work and allow photographs. We went the first Sunday of the month, when the museum is free to all visitors. It was crowded, but not unbearable. It's also included in the museum pass.

The best museum in Paris. Balzac, The age of bronze, Le Penseur and more than a hundred other sculptures, drawings and maquettes and all set in the most beautiful, quiet and revivifying gardens and chateau - it has no equal.

Just Right. I really enjoy this museum for many reasons. It is very well planned, rather accessible, small enough to not be exhausting, and much of it is outside. If you wish to truly get a feel for the genius of Rodin, the labor involved in his work, and an overview of his masterpieces - this is the place for you!
nice collections. must goplace if you have two days there. I like it more than the other museums. Do not go i the rain as some of the great sculptures are out doors.
Beautiful sculptures. Amazing sculptures inside and outside in the garden. A very relaxing experience walking around and a lovely ambiance.

Beautiful sculptures in a great setting. So many of Rodin's works set out in a lovely garden which was great to walk around. Many works also inside the historical building, along with explanations and diagrams etc of how he created his works. Well worth a look.

A once abandoned hotel turned into a renowned museum. We lucked out and caught the Rodin and the Louvre on the first monday of the month where all museums are free in Paris. Some incredible sculptures and paintings that you will certainly recognize, most notably 'Le Pensevr' by Rodin. The main building is an incredible, somewhat deteriorating structure that has been left in tact for the most part, which makes is all feel like an authentic experience. Please go see!

Bronzes are an acquired taste. Whilst superb setting and museum I cannot say that bronzes and the subject matter here cheer one up. Rodin was indeed an accomplished sculptor but with both The Thinker and The Kiss having origins in his "Gates of Hell" the experience can be a little depressing. The unfortunate Burgers of Calais either singly on in a group do not help either. However if you are on a downer look at the marble representations. Here The Kiss in excellent lighting was the highlight of my visit followed closely by The Lovers Hands.

A Marvellous Experience at The Hotel Biron. Though it is the second time for me to visit Rodin's Museum, I would love to go back there again in another season, perhaps in Spring. Both the museum and the garden are remarkable. The actual building was named for one of its owners Marshal de Biron and was built as a private town house in 18th century. Then The Hotel Biron was rented by Auguste Rodin 1908 onwards. The museum has launched an extensive renovation programme till 2014. So they exhibit a temporary collection which still provides a broad outline of some of his works. When you walk around those marvellous statues,figures you just wonder the amount of work and effort this genious, gifted artist must have devoted to his art.
"Think" much of it!. Seeing "The Thinker" was worth the visit! The museum and its garden was simply beautiful and all of Rodin's work - he sure was a very gifted sculptor!
Neat museum. Neat museum. If you're not really into museums, this is a nice short one with lots to see. Interesting art for sure!

Simply spectacular. The setting, the pieces of art, the museum itself. A must attend. We walked the garden after viewing the displays inside. The museum sets up many of the famous pieces in the garden. A cannot miss place.

made me appreciate sculpture. I never thought I like looking at sculptures until I visited Musee Rodin. I enjoyed his sculptures very much and found the information provided by the museum to be very useful in helping me appreciate something I didn't know much about. The brochures were provided in several languages (including English) and told about the sculptor, his style, how he approached different mediums, and what to look for in various pieces. We went through the entire museum (but not the gardens) in about an hour.
Do not miss.. More than a museum, this is where Rodin actually lived. Large sculptures in garden magnificent. Smaller pieces inside also great and show Rodin's utter mastery of this form.

Think Think Think. Highlight wa of course seeing the Thinker - also the Gates of Hell - no because im strange but because of the name. It was a pleasant day so walking in the gardens was ideal. The roses was a nice touch but unfortunately there wasnt much out in bloom.
wonderful garden. The garden was incredible beautiful!!! I love to walk to the end of garden there have a very nice pond. Great atmosphere.

Refreshing to have sculpture spread thru garden. Just about my favorite place, like art I can walk around the best, then walking thru the garden! lunch at their cafe was very good! Pool and archway, would go back again and again...actually couldn't get in until 3rd try, check days they are open and if there are any social movements happening....glad I didn't miss it, nice gift shop!

Small museum, huge grounds. The grounds of the museum are more spectacular than what's inside. The Thinker is outside as are The Gates of Hell. This museum isn't one of the "main" tourist attractions so the good thing is that there are no lines.
Great Museum that you don't hear about. Great museum. The garden, the sculptures, and the house itself were wonderful. Make this a priority on your list, not an afterthought.
A gem. Beautiful gallery and gardens in a charming Left Bank location. Well worth making a special visit for.
Musee Rodin. The garden is the best part! You can spend more to see the inside, the building is quite lovely as well.

small museum. I was amazed at how many Rodin pieces they have here. Not too crowded like at the other bigger Paris museums.
The garden outside is very nice and you can even catch a glimpse of the Eiffle tower.

Fascinating, I never knew there was so much to know about Rodin!. This place was fantastic, it appeared to be under a bit of construction, I wish I could have attended prior to or after the construction rather than during. His sculptures were amazing and the story of his life is fascinating. One morsel I found very interesting was that he sculpted the female anatomy quite a bit although only one piece that I can recall was on display at the museum. I would highly recommend getting the audio guide.

One word - WOW. One of our favorites while in Paris. We loved the Thinking Man and Gates of Hell. All the statues were gorgeous. The grounds were beautiful. Surprising there were not a lot of people around which made for great photos of us with the statues.

suprising. we saw many of Rodins' sculptures in the garden, then went into the former hotel where he stayed... it contained more works by Rodin, also several paintings by Van Gogh, Monet, and other Impressionist artists! On the advice of our Hotel desk person, we bought our Museum Pass here as it was less crowded than everyplace else...

The Thinker!!!. When you think of sculpture, the Thinker immediately comes to mind. Unless you have a Museum Pass (which I strongly recommend) don't go inside the building. The Thinker is outside in the garden and is the big attraction.

Paris As It Was. The Musee Rodin is one-off the usual Paris museums for most tourists. It was a very nice change from the Louvre and D'Orsay. The museum is comprised of a modern, more recent building, and the structure and grounds of Hotel Biron where Rodin lived for many years. Castings of his sculptures are arranged around the grounds (The Thinker, The Kiss, The Gates of Hell, The Burger of Calais...) and the grounds and gardens are a treat in themselves. At the time of his life (and death) the Hotel was on the outskirts of Paris, and it is easy to imagine its semi-rural setting during a visit. Since many of the works are out-of-doors plan your visit with weather in mind.

Pleseant hours with Rodin. To visit Rodin Museum is a great experience in France. Spend some hours in this old style house with a great yard full of sculptures is a great program. And, do not leave without try some meal at the "café".
Don't Miss the Musee Rodin. This museum truly impresses and is a place that doesn't have to take up a whole day if you so choose...on nicer days the garden is the place to visit.
Musee Rodin. Lovely museum and garden. Will only take a couple of hours to look around. We visited in May, it wasn't too busy and the weather was lovely so we could enjoy the garden.
Very great experience. So much fun at Musee Rodin. The sculptures by Rodin were beautiful. Seeing The Thinker piece was the highlight of the visit.

Amazing sculptor, amazing museum!. If you love sculptures, esp. marble, this place is heaven. I am a neophyte in this area, but was grinning like a drunken monkey the entire 8 hrs or so that I spent there. There is construction going on at the moment, but what was there to see was amazing!

Beautiful gardens, impressive sculptures. This is one of the most beautiful museums in Paris. Many of the Rodin sculptures are outdoors in the gardens, which are worth a trip all by themselves. Add Rodin's sculptures and the experience is a delight. There is also an indoor gallery, but I think the displays here change. The exhibition I saw contrasted preliminary models with finished sculptures, which gave interesting insights into the creative process.

Great small museum. If you like Rodin's work this is a MUST SEE!! It is a small museum a couple of blocks from Invalides (Army Museum). The gardens are truly the main attraction. There are sculptures throughout and at the far end a pond and a wooded area with lounge chairs. The garden does close 30 min before the museum so visit it first if it's the end of the day. There is a garden cafe for light snacks. The museum itself in Hotel Biron is very well done. There is an audioguide available. Museum Pass holders stay to the left when entering and go straight to the audioguide desk. There is currently a temporary exhibit in the building on the street which I found quite dull but it is small and doesn't take much time.

Free on the first Sunday..... We arrived in Paris on the first Sunday of November. Many of the museums are free that day and the Rodin Museum is one of them. it is one of those places you see on TV or in books and think you may never see it in person. If you miss it you will regret it, so go if in Paris. It is just across the street from Napoleons Tomb. Of course the "Thinker" is there, but there id much more!
Great collections. Air was nice outside in the garden. if you are sculpture lover you cant miss this one.Museum location is very easy to find

Not to miss. One of the great artists of all times. A wonderful spot. A perfect sunny day. And you will enter a different world. Nothing will be quite the same again. A tour for a whole afternoom. And, extra super, many sculptures by rodin's most famous pupil, Camille Claudel.

Unmissable for Rodin fans. It was about 25 years since my last visit, and the Museum just gets better and better! We visited on a lovely Autumn day, so seeing the large sculpture of the Thinker standing out against a cobalt sky, with the golden dome of Les Invalides just behind it was amazing! The gardens are lovely, so well kept, and full of statues... you just want to live there yourself and go for romantic walks up and down the avenues! The inside of the Hotel (main part of the museum) has fascinating displays with several plaster casts of famous sculptures, showing how Rodin's ideas developed, up to the final product.I have been a Rodin fan since I was a child, and he still grows on me! Interesting to see some works by his mistress, too, clearly inspired by him. Great shop at the end for buying souvenirs or little presents!
A nice place for a few hours. Beautiful gradens and nice collection of Rodin art. make sure its not to cold since a lot of the attraction is out in the open gardens

Beautiful gardens. I loved the quiet gardens with sculpture tucked in the corners and the dome of Napoleon's tomb and the Eiffel Tower visible in the background. The interior exhibits were cluttered and it was overly warm.

Not To Be Missed. To see many of Rodin's masterpieces assembled in one magnificent home is not to be missed. Take the audio tour and stroll in the gardens - and throughout the home. Again, as always, get that Museum Pass.

Enjoy the garden and the house. If you like Rodin, this is the place to explore his work. I personally like the large garden with a mix of manicured and casual areas that have all his greatest hits along with some lesser known pieces.Bu there's nothing wrong with the house that has smaller pieces and prototypes nicely presented on two floors.There's a gift shop (of course) and a cafe for basic snacks.

Rodin Makes You Think!. One of the most underrated and out of the way museums in Paris, is Rodin's Gardens (Musee Rodin) on Rue de Varenne. Like Dali's Museum in Montmartre, this little treasure is dedicated solely to the wonderful art and in particular the sculptures of one man, Auguste Rodin. I have visited Paris on 4 previous occasions and this place was either closed or I couldn't find it. Don't make the same mistake! This museum is among my favourites because it concentrates on the life of one famous artist, his home, his life and his magnificent works. Many of his masterpieces are still there including ''The Thinker'' & ''The Lovers''. There are beautiful sketches and finished artworks plus beautifully manicured gardens to set off his more oversized pieces. Many of his works are also on display at the D'Órsay but there are just enough pieces still here, beautifully displayed without the usual overkill and overcrowding that are the blight of the Louvre and the D'Orsay Museums. Thank goodness for that, as I really enjoyed the relative anonimity of this little attraction. Maybe It was just a quiet day but I really enjoyed the experience. Put it on your list.

The magic of chisels.. The expression of art using a block of marble and chisels to the artist imposes many difuculdades but to Rodin that they never existed. Really he was a magician in his art and left a collection fantastic that everyone should know.

Nature and Statues. A beautiful house where you can see Rodin's and his Camille's sketches and drawings on their original studio. But the greatest attractions rest in the garden, where the statues are framed by nicely trimmed trees and a beautiful pond. Tip: if you are in Paris during the "Nuit Blanche", this museum is a must-see attraction, offering night walkings throught the gardens.

All you ever wanted to know about Rodin. Fantastic collection of sculpture expanding on the collection in Musee D'Orsay.Suggest you invest in an audio guide to get the full experience and to learn that Rodin did not sculpt all these pieces himself but had a small army of others working from his initial designs.

A must-see Museum. Rodin is a small, easy half day museum. A combination of indoors and outdoors, you will see famous sculptures paintings and learn a tremendous amount behind the imagination of Rodin while visiting. In the gardens you have one of the most spectacular views of Paris behind "the thinker" statue you see Les Invalides and beyond that the Eiffel Tower.

Great Museum/Park. A unique museum set in Rodin's studio and the park where he took inspiration. Lots of great bronzes outside in a pleasant park which also has a nice cafe. Indoor exhibits show you how Rodin's style evolved and demonstrate the variety of his work.Crowds aren't too bad, and there are several other sites within walking distance.
hidden paradise. Nine Euros entrance fee is a lot for this small museum but you get gorgeous art, a wonderful old maison and a perfect garden with a nice small restaurant for it.

Wonderful. Loved Rodin's sculptures and the outdoor garden. Didn't go inside the house, so I can't comment on that.. Beautiful and mind-boggling that human hands can create such objects of beauty out of stone and clay!! Get Museum pass and enjoy discounted rates for all museums..
Rodin. Just saw this from the double decker bus tour, get on and off. Was raining so we didn't stop would have like to see more...next time

Awesome Museum!!. Muss Rodin was my husband and I's favorite museum in Paris. The first building that you enter will hold the special exhibits. When we were there in July, it was a showing of all of Rodin's cast models and actual sculptures. The outside garden area is absolutely amazing! We wandered around for about and hour relaxing and taking pictures. A large sculpture of The Thinker is in the center of one of the gardens. There were numerous benches spread throughout the garden that you could sit at, and there was also a little cafe outside. You are also able to go inside Rodin's house, that is now museum. It contains more works by Rodin, as well as works by Rodin's friends. The museum is much smaller that the Louvri and D'Orsay, but it is lovely to walk around and small enough that you don't need to dedicate an entire day.

Highlight of trip!. Must return here - no hyperbole will do it justice. Fe people are aware of the incredible skill of Rodin in creating his sculptures. Anyone who visits the newly revamped modern gallery/museum will be left in any doubt. Sadly no photos are allowed, and the place is small by Parisian attractions standards but it certainly packs a punch. Full of white marble sculptures which are truly alive, far better visit than the Louvre. Incredible visit and certainly highlight of trip.
mandatory!. cute place with Jardin, history of Rodin`s works and great samples of his. a lot are in open air, so better to go in good weather to enjoy the sun:)

Small but worth it. The thing is: There are many many museums like this in Paris. Small. Uncrowded. Relaxing. A lovely garden outside and the statues are phenomenal. We discovered it was also another good place to buy our museum passes - We bought a 6 day and several 2 day passes- not so much to save money but to avoid the lines in other museums-

My Wedding Site.. My wedding planner came up with the brilliant idea to have our wedding ceremony at the Rodin. It was perfect....the grass was perfectly cut and the scenery was stunning. I did not get a chance to go inside the main building but I was fortunate enough to be greeted by the Thinker at my initial visit.

glorious museum. Read up on your history before visiting to make the visit more worthwhile. I had read a couple of Rodin biographies, a short biography of Rose (yes, she was the wife!) and a history of the Hôtel Biron (Isadora Duncan lived here at one stage also, and so did many other well known people). The building itself is undergoing repairs and I visited in the rain, but it was still a brilliant visit because I had so much background knowledge. There are numerous paintings (especially the Van Goghs! very unexpected) that are worth the visit alone, and the gardens are lovely, although Rodin preferred the wildness to the tamed!

Just visited the garden this visit. Construction work in the garden "slightly" diminished teh quality of our visit, but we have been there many times and always enjoy a visit to the garden. I am sure this construction will be completed soon.
relaxing garden. we only visited the gardens, very good value and fascinating sculpture, sunny day and a delightful experiance
walking through. If you are on your way to Bonaparte's tomb, stop here. Its next door. Beautiful gardens, and though Im not terribly into Rodin enjoyed the garden for a bit.

Lovely little museum. There are some beautiful pieces to view, especially "The Kiss" and "The Thinker". Lovely museum which is set out well, with plenty of room to move around the works. Not big crowds like the Louve. Beautiful gardens and when we were there all the roses were in bloom. They even had a box of give away roses. Just sit by the pond and take it all in.

Amazing oasis in the middle of Paris. We returned to the Rodin Museum after 40 years and found it as amazing as before. Unfortunately undergoing restoration so many of our favourites were not on show, but in compensation there was an excellent exhibition of Rodin marbles, well displayed. The gardens are a beautiful calm oasis in the centre of Paris and there is a decent bistro style restaurant with good food at reasonable prices. Entry to gardens and museum at €9 full fee (including the special exhibition) was excellent value.

Best muesum in Paris.... and not because Ms. Sarkozy appeared there in "Midnight in Paris." :-) But there IS a reason Woody chose this place.. and it's because it is the MOST romantic museum (how many times have you had "romantic" describe a museum?) and has the BEST garden in Paris.

what a day in MuseeRodin. we went there in a big raining day so it influence our mood a little bit. But we still with our great mood try to get there. We feel no so good after such wet weather and our wet clothes then we were so tired after the long traffic and effort for it. The total feeling was ok for us.

Beautiful. I love the works of Rodin and the museum offers a large selection of his works, many the originals. The price is decent and the line is nothing compared to the Louvre or Musee D'Orsay. It isn't very large, but I enjoyed it.
very little to see. It is a very small museum privately sponsored it seems but so little to see really. Simply not worth going there.

Rodin Museum is wonderful!. The museum itself is beautiful. You can get lost in the statues both inside and outside in the gardens. The second house shows off more statues and even some of Rodin's incredible paintings.
Beautiful gardens. We love to return to Musee Rodin, just to wander the sculpture garden. It is one of those special small museums that makes a trip to Paris unforgettable.

Beautiful Even on a Rainy Day. Had a great visit even though it was raining. Gardens are so lovely it's still worth the walk around under an umbrella. The Hotel Biron is a place with intricate moldings and details. Rodin's sculptures and paintings are amazing and to think Rodin actually lived in there makes ones visit more intriguing.
intimate, small. a personal, small musuem with a few outstandiing sculptures. Highly unusual setting which makes one imagine Rodin the person at work.
Fantastic. This is a really wonderful museum. The house is lovely and the sculptures and paintings are so well laid out. It is a joy to visit. It also is much less crowded than the other art museums.

Lovely sculpture museum & gardens. For those who love Rodin sculptures, don't miss this lovely museum in a beautiful setting. The museum is housed in a lovely old home with a superb garden. Enjoy Rodin's sculpture inside and outside in the garden, including The Thinker. I will sometimes hang out in the gardens while my husband heads to the Invalides and Army Museum. Lovely place.

Nice park to enjoy art and a break from the city. The art in this mansion in the city is amazing. We loved grabbing an Oranginia and a pastry and wondering the gardens looking at the larger pieces a nice break from the city.

Rodin's best. Full os Rodin's best work, along with some of C. Claudel's best too, a wonderfull experience, can't miss it.
Recommended!

First visit. Have been to Paris several times but never to this gem. There is some renovation going on but that didn't detract from the work on display. Fabulous sculpture and the gardens are perfect for a relaxing lunch with a baguette, some cheese and wine on a sunny day.
Small museum, worth the visit. Enjoyed seeing the thinker, the kiss. The inside exhibits were interesting. The garden was very pleasant too.
not impressed. I was not impressed after all the build up. There were very long lines and limited guides available. The "thinking man" was good though.

Lots of Rodin sculptures, and a great garden. This museum is almost 100% about Rodin, so if that's what you are looking for, you will have a plate full. There are some art from other artists, but majority are Rodin pieces.
Don't forget to visit the garden, it is beautiful.

Possibly my favorite museum in Paris. This museum is serene compared to the Louvre. I love the works of art, the building itself (Rodin actually worked out of it) and the small peaceful gardens all filled the Rodin's powerful work. Don't overlook it.

Beautiful, peaceful. My boyfriend and I visited this museum the last Wednesday of October (on Halloween actually) and the weather was gorgeous. There were lots of flowers still blooming- the roses were sublime. The outdoor sculptures were lovely, but I was really taken with the two indoor areas. The building near the entrance is filled with white marble sculptures that are just beautiful and the building in the garden is a gorgeous old building- beautifully decorated, with big windows looking out over the garden. If you're in Paris and you find yourself in a patch of pretty weather, head to this museum. It's maybe a 15-20 minute walk from the Eiffel Tower. You won't be disappointed.

Enjoy the Outside Gardens. We enjoyed the Rodin Museum, but if we were to make a return trip it would be to just go out in the gardens on a pretty day. It would be a great place to sit and have a little lunch. You can enjoy walking around and admire the sculptures, but also the view of Les Invalades and the Eiffel Tower in the background. If you want to get a taste for Rodin Sculptures, I recommend you just pay the price for the gardens, see his work, enjoy the beautiful setting and return another day if you want to see more works inside.

Go is you like Sculpture by Rodin and a large Garden in the City. If not, it is not essential.... OK Wife lived this but to me it was lovely large garden with lake surrounded by excellent sculptures but how many do you need to see? Especially when Musee de Orsay had Sculptures and more... you need to be a real fan of Rodin to see more.

Besides the thinker, nothing to go mad. It's ok to go once in your lifetime, I've been there several times and that is enough, the gardens are not as beautiful as I remembered, actually there is no garden , just soil and a few sculptures

Quite amazing. Another museum not to miss. In addition to the art, the setting is magnificent. Beautiful gardens to roam around in even in the rain! You can get a picture of The Thinker with the Eiffel Tower in the background. Wow!
Treasure of Rodin's work. This museum is filled with the magnificent work by one of the world's most brilliant and prolific sculptors, Auguste Rodin.

Art for the whole family. The Rodin museum is an excelente programme for a family. There´s a special interactive audioguide for parent and child: the child can guide you through some highlighted sculptures on a map and there are even quizzes in some of them. The visit includes walking around the gardens and inside the museum. My 7 year-old spent two and half hours and had a great time. Now he says he wants to go back there again. Unfortunately the only two languages available were English and French. Really worthwhile!

I fell in love here..... My visit to Paris was a disappointment because my husband couldn't join me. But I'm glad he didn't - I got to fall in love with another man.... The late Monsieur Rodin!The museum compels you to fall in love, actually! It's absolutely stunning - the gardens, the building, the exhibits (the old lady's my favourite with the thinker coming in a close second)After the museum tour, I walked around the lawns - and found it so easy to lose myself in the tranquil environ.Beautiful.....! Ooh la la la.....!

Such a Sordid History!. Inside the grounds they are doing some renovation and it's covered by a huge wrap that actually has the history of how the Musee Rodin came to be, it was very interesting and really made our whole visit that much more memorable. We loved the gardens and the artwork was truly beautiful. We had to come twice, the first time they were closed due to strike which was annoying, but coming back the next day wasn't a big deal and we were glad we didn't miss the opportunity to come while on our honeymoon.

Beautiful Break. This such a nice relief from the other huge museums in Paris. Beautiful grounds and statuary. The house is lovely too and filled with smaller statues. We had lunch at this museum and really enjoyed sitting outside enjoying the garden. Love the quiet and peacefulness that this museum provides in the heart of Paris.
BEAUTIFUL. Great quiet place to enjoy both indoor and outdoor beauty. Don't miss The Thinker in the Rodin garden along with other sculptures, or The Kiss inside.
A great work of Art. Most of the major work is in the phenomenal garden. The Gates of Hell are a must see. Spend time understanding the steps taken in the creation of the master piece.

Tour the grounds and the house. We found that the grounds were more impressive than the house so don't go on a rainy day thinking that it's a nice activity to do inside. But go back on a rainy day and tour the house because it, too, is definitely worth seeing.
Lovely Musee. Rodin's Musee is a lovely museum to visit. The sculptures, garden and his home are wonderful. Seeing the casts that he used to make the full sized sculptures was very interesting.

LOTS TO SEE...INCLUDING THE FAMOUS 'THINKER'. if you're a 'deep-thinker' this is your place. located near another top attraction, 'les invalides' this museum contains many beautiful works by rodin, and even a few paintings, one by van gogh. some of the pieces are located outside, in the lovely gardens, including the famous 'thinker.' if you visit napolean's tomb, in les invalides, you should include 'musee rodin' as well.

Best 1 euro ever!. Just to go into the garden and ogle the thinker! Awesome! Really a treat. If you are "arted out" but need to squeeze one more classic... One euro gets you a tiny garden with Rodins masterpiece and a huge smile!
Just Wonderful. We enjoyed it very much. Try to do it in the morning - less crowded. Do not miss the sculptures garden. .
If you are an art lover this place is fantastic.. Wasn't crowded and outside gardens wonderful. Don't miss The Thinker and The Gates of Hell. The audio tour is very helpful and informative.

The Thinker is the highlight.. This is a nice, simple museum that showcases the work of Rodin. The Thinker is here in a prominent place in the sculpture garden. The rest of the garden is tastefully dispersed with his lesser known works. This makes for a pleasant stroll and lets you forget you're right in the middle of the city.
don't miss. in this lovely old mansion is the beautiful exhibition! amazing garden and loved every piece of museum

We enjoyed the gardens as much as the Thinker. Going to an art gallery with a toddler isn't always the smartest thing to do, but in this case it worked out brilliantly. The gardens outside were perfect for my 1 year old to run around in and burn some energy, while we could enjoy the amazing statues and gardens.Personally I really preferred some of Rodin's other works over "The Thinker" - particularly the one of the 3 duplicate statues, I found that really clever. (As you can tell I'm not an expert art-lover but I did enjoy this gallery).

The Thinker. For a number of reasons we were not able to actually visit the museum but for only one euro, we were able to stroll through the adjacent gardens. This is a great bargain for not only are the gardens beautiful, they feature some of Rodin's sculpture. If you are short of time (or money) and can't see the entire museum, do at least visit the gardens.

Think about this!. Pun on words, but seeing The Thinker was worth going to this museum. Be careful not to miss anything. There is more than one building and outdoor grounds as well. Be sure that you see the original works of art. The Thinker in the gardens is not the original one. You need to see that inside the building.

Amazing! Beautiful and Intriguing!. This is an amazing museum with many of Rodin's fabulous sculptures spread out in the fabulous gardens. Amazing that he completed so many sculptures and they are on dissplay for the public to enjoy. In addition to the gardens the museum building holds many more works of Rodin as well as some others. We did the self tour and thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Another "must see" in Paris.

Lovely grounds, sculptures are magnificent. We have taken the long walk from the 5th to the Musee Rodin many times and each time we try a different route to enjoy the shops and architecture en route. It is a fair hike but worth the visit as the museum has some nice space in behind with gardens and a great view of the house. Inside the museum has undergone some changes over the years but retains the charm of a grand home you can walk through and enjoy the sensual sculptures. Definitely one of my favourite places in Paris and even kids can enjoy the museum.

Lovely gardens. This museum was more than we expected. There was beautiful gardens to walk through and interesting statues throughout. You could see the Eiffel Tower from the rose gardens surrounding Rodin's "The Thinker". Towards the back, there was a duck pond and more statues, providing a nice place to stroll and relax on a beautiful Paris afternoon.

a musee in which to relax. This musee is less known but well worth a visit. We went in September and it is quiet and very beautiful and also very relaxing in the lovely garden surrounds. it is not expensive and you can just as easily buy your entry tickets there as on line as there was no queue. Check opening hours as it closed earlier than most of the others.

Exceptional museum in peaceful garden. NO CROWDS. This is one of the worlds great museums,. It is set in an old chateau in the heart of Paris which suprisingly enough has lovely peaceful gardens which are an oasis. The gardens display some of Rodin's wonderful statues in such a lovely setting. The cafe in the edge of the garden is a good spot to stop for a light meal or drink and is reasonably priced.The old chateau houses many other sculptures and also has a few Renoirs and Van Goghs tucked away amongst other great works.Highly recommend a visit here and note that it is included in the Paris Pass and is very close to l'invallides making it an easy spot to get to.
sculpture. if you like sculpture , this is the place for you . The Thinker is in the garden and his house is worth walking thru

Worth the stroll into St Germain. Lovely little museum in the heart of st Germain - was all a bit high profile getting there as you have to pass a number of govt depts and a fair few gendarmerie with guns! Don't know if there was something going on or was usual. Museum is lovely, used to be a place of nun education until the govt decided these places had to be dismantled; the nuns moved out and Rodin and other artists rented rooms there, and Rodin lobbied to have the mansion house his collection. They finally did in 1919 I think though after the death of Rodin. Nice clean toilets, a change for Paris ! Charming little cafe inside the grounds. And very nice sculpture collection even if you are not a big fan fan of Rodin per se. Wander down to the Luxembourg gardens and the church at St Germain des Près, well worth if you are in the vicinity

Beautiful gardens. We toured both the gardens and the museum (Rodin's home and studio). Both were very nice but the sculpture gardens most enjoyable. The Thinker is here as well as many other of his well-known sculptures. The mansion has a chronological desplay of his earlier works that were also interesting. But if you only do the garden that will be enough.

closed, but.......... when we visited the museum was closed. the garden was free and fabulous and there was an exhibit of rodin's life drawings-an extensive collection of more than 300 drawings. the best closed museum i've ever visited.

Love this museum!. There are pieces here that I have only seen in books. The THINKER was the one I wanted to see and I was amazed! It is somewhat small due to renovations being done. I recommend getting the audio guide, which you will here some really surprising facts about the art work. It was raining when I went, but the garden is amazing. They also have a nice little cafe where you can grab a quick soup, sandwich or salad.
must go. does not take long an hour or 2 the most but well worth it-this is the one small museum to enjoy as it involves his house and grounds

My Favorite!. Of all the museums that Paris has to offer, this is my favorite. Set in Rodin's former home, it is small and intimate. You must enjoy Rodin and sculpture, but if you do, you will be in heaven. Rodin's greatest works are on display and you have a chance to see them in beautiful settings without a crush of people around.
Famous statues in lovely surroundings .... This museum gives you the opportunity to see some of those statues that you only usually get to see in books or on postcards!
Paris Musium pass. This musium was not as big as the Louvre but still a good one to see. The gardens was beautiful, i really like the Gates of Hell and the Thinker at the Rose Garden.

the best museum I have ever visited. if you like Rodin don't miss this one! the building is amazing, the statues fabulous and the garden in "magnifique" . I would advise to find a sunny day to visit it in order to enjoy the garden.

Good to fit in between heady art galleries.. Great museum, even better when sun shining on outdoor sculptures. Nice place for picknic. We planned this smallish gallery to take a mental break from heady massive galleries like Louve etc., well recommend after muse d'art Pray, which is close by.

Class Act. I had been to this museum in 1977. It was delightful to return. There is a guest sculptor who -in his own right- is worth going to the museum. It's fun to see paintings of Rodin and to be among such great art.
Must see. The sculpture garden is increadibly peaceful. Seeing the Thinker is an absolute must. It is juxtaposed by the Eiffel Tower which is nearby.

Charming museum with a beautiful garden. I strongly recommend a visit to Musee Rodin. The art itself is worth a visit but also the beautiful garden with its statues. The building also is very beautiful and the view from the windows is charming.

The Thinker!. It's so cool to see this statue in real life! The way it's situated is really neat because you can see L'Invalides and the Eiffel Tower behind it. The gardens are great and really cheap to visit. They often feature other up and coming scuptors. We did not tour the inside, which cost a few more euros.

Found the Gates of Hell. A number of interesting sculptures, including the Thinker situated in the garden. I was intrigued by the Gates of Hell piece and jokingly posed my husband in front of them for a picture, so he would recognize them in the future if he found himself in front of them.

Lovely house. It was being renovated when we were there. Internally, looked like some of the old flats I've lived in when I was a younger!
