Gardens are beautiful (not like my old flats) and the lost wax process is explained nicely. The Kiss is of course magnificent, and the sculpture dotted around the garden - the Thinker, Gates of Hell, the Burghers of Calais - are all fabulously set. If one was only going to take in a single artist museum, one could do a lot worse

worth going to just stroll in the garden and speak with "the thinker". the museum is in one of Rodin's last residences. the gardens and home are large, yet not overwhelming. sitting in the garden is one of the pleasures of visiting Paris. peace and beauty along with great art from the Rodin collection. and very economic if one does not enter the house. only one Euro. in the garden are several of Rodin's masterpices. i prefer the garden to the house. although both are well worth the visit.

Beautiful place.... I was not too impressed with each museum I saw in Paris,but Musee Rodin was really worth visiting.I am not too much into art,but I like good sculpture.Well,Rodin was great master of his job.Some of the sculptures are really breath taking,and museum garden is beautiful.There were exhibition of Croatian sculptor Ivan Mestrovic during our visit,and it was a bonus to our experience.There is some restaurant in museum garden where you can take a rest,drink or eat something,and I sincerely recommend this museum to everybody.

Who doesn't recognize The Thinker?. This was a return visit for us to see Rodin's beautiful home and art. Great to see clay models and then the bronze statues of the same work. Stroll around garden area. Not overwhelming in size, can easily be combined with another Paris site/museum on one day.

A must for every sculpture lover. Located in an old house where Rodin worked. The house itself and the garden give a good overview of his work and it is informative even for those who do not care about arts. Great location. Not too huge. Intimate and cosy.

Gardens are Beautful. We did not go into the museum just the gardens which gave our children a great overview of this artist. They very much enjoyed the beautiful setting and looking at the sculptures (especially enjoyed using the binoculars for Hells Gate). Would recommend with kids on a pretty day

A Secret Green Haven in the middle of Paris. Located in an old house [mansion] where Rodin worked in his latter life, this is a huge collection of his works. The museum is an easy size to see all without tiring and the garden with its sculptures is a haven.The restaurant food was cafeteria like but of very high quality and great service [with a smile![

If you like sculpture this is the place. All the art/sculpture, the old hotel, the gardens, all donated by Auguste Rodin to France (which they begrudginly accepted!). Wow, very impressive place, and great place to hang out in when it's sunny in one of the garden areas reading a book. Small onsite cafe as well...add this to your list of must see's, 5 minute walk from Invalides and Napoleon tomb, 3 min walk to Varenne metro station.
The Garden of Rodin is excellent!. my favorite part is the display of Rodin's work in the garden. Also a wonderful collection of roses near "The Thinker". A must-see place!

Underrated. I really really enjoy this museum. Honestly it's more like a park since much is outdoors. Also, as I feel it's easy to get bored of museums this is a good one since it's not too huge. But I think the best part of it is that not only are you viewing Rodin's sculptures but it's on a backdrop that includes the gold dome of the Invalides and from many areas the Eiffel Tower. Lots of good picture opportunities.
A TREAT. Pick a sunny day and enjoy the beautiful gardens, and well as the museum. Should be on must do list for Paris

The Thinker. This was recommended by a friend and I also wanted to see The Thinker. When we went, some of the garden area was walled off and it wasn't a very nice day weather wise but you could see what a lovely setting this is.

Museums. Loved Musee Rodin, set on a beautiful estate, with sculptures displayed in the lovely gardens as well as inside the amazing house within the estate, it is definitely worth a visit, and the opportunity to learn a bit more about the amazing artist, Rodin.

Another favorite... it is small but has an amazing collection of his works! The Thinker and the Gates of Hell are incredible and the garden setting is beautiful. It is a great first stop to pick up Musee Passes without lines.

Variety in a small space!. We went to this museum on our first day in Paris. I loved strolling through the gardens (yes,"TheThinker" was proudly displayed ) as well as walking through the quaint rooms in the back building filled with works from a variety of notable artists.This was a great peek into our week in Paris!

Unique. For lovers of Rodin a visit to this lovely little museum and its garden full of his works is a must. There are other museums in France displaying his work, but nothing is as comprehensive as this. We spent a delightful part of an afternoon there.

An other true gem in Paris - a must.. This is the only private financed national museum in France, and the inside of the great Rodin villa could have been more up-to-date... The museum is situated within a fifteen minute walk from the d'Orsay. Rodin's park is beautiful and quiet. Hard to describe, actually. The visit can be over in ten minutes, but we stayed for about an hour. Most people come to see "The Thinker" and "The Kiss", but there are many other things to see - Rodin had a super collection himself. Being Norwegian, we just loved Edvard Munch's painting of "The Thinker". Fantastic.

Exquisite Gardens & Artwork. We were here for a Lana Del Rey concert amid the gardens and various pieces of art outside, on a very rainy night in September. Even in the pouring rain, the museum was enchanting. And when, just at sunset, the clouds parted, and a rainbow appeared, it was even more so.

The Thinker. Very pretty museum which is free for children and teenagers. Adults pay a very minimal cover charge and will worth visiting Rodin's famous sculptures in The Thinker and The Kiss. The gardens are also worth visiting.

Rodin Museum and gardens. The gardens are all one needs to visit here unless you want to see a lot of scultures. It is not worth the extra money for the entry fee. the gardens are only 1 euro and you get to see the thinker. also the cafe is here if you choose to eat here.

Lovely. The gardens around the Rodin museum are full of sculptures and roses, so being there on a beautiful day was that much more enjoyable. I understand renovations are planned, (building is crumbling in some spots), but I hope the essential environment remains unchanged. Highly recommended.

Nice sculpture gardens. We walked to the Rodin Museum from the Orsay before heading off to the Parc Champs du Mars and Eiffel Tower. This museum is small and holds wonderful works. The sculpture gardens with all it's rose bushes was a great refuge during our busy day.

Many reasons to go. We just got the garden tickets as kids were museumed-out for the day. Beautiful walk from Luxembourg Gardens. Formal gardens are serene and well kept. Sculptures are of course wonderful. A small cafe there but they also let me bring in my own latte, which I got a few blocks away at a pain quotidian, in the far back are loungers and a good placeto let kids run a bit. Great views, and photo memories of the Thinker with the Eiffel Tower in the background.
Must see. Fabulous sculptures inside and even more scattered throughout a gorgeous garden. The Thinker is so impressive.
Exquisite. Small, beautiful and intimate. That is what you will experience here.....as well as RODIN!! Need I say anymore?

Walk through the garden, or take the full museum tour; your choice.. A bit overwhelming after a while, unless you a true Rodin afficianado. Unless you want the full multi-hour museum experience, you will be able to see most of the large Rodin sculptures you have heard about by simply taking a walk through the delightful garden.

What happened?. Ten years ago this museum was one of the highlights of our trip! When we revisited this museum two weeks ago, we were very sadly disappointed. All the important works (like The Kiss) were crammed into an annex next to the entry and the bookstore of the museum. Rodin's house itself seemed a little run down. It had lost its charm without the presence of some of the major pieces. The garden was in the midst of a chaotic costruction of what seemed to be a runway for a fashion show. We left quickly.
Excellent!. Everything, epecially the garden, even in a rainy day. And the three Van Gogh paintings! And the sculptures of Camille Claudel.

Go for The Thinker and the Garden. My favorite museum in Paris, both for the superb sculptures of the Thinker and the Kiss, and for the home and garden which house them. More enchanting than the Louvre and the Orsay, this is a place you can spend a relaxing afternoon admiring art.

Garden is nice, museum is dull. Museum needs to work on the presentation of it's pieces - much of the inside comes off like an industrial storage facility for Rodin. The garden is much nicer than the inside, and is quite well kept, but is rather small. I would only recommend seeing this the Paris Pass and if you are also going to the Musee des Invalides located nearby, I don't think it's worth a visit on it's own unless you are an unusually avid fan of Rodin.
Visit on a nice. Great little Museum on great grounds.Bring your camera you are going to want to take a lot of pictures.

Don't miss the nearby Musee Armee. Rodin museum is great to see those famous sculptures. But if you go there, don't miss the musee Armee. It is a fascinating compilation of armaments, weapons, uniforms etc. from the middle ages through World War II and beyond. End up at Napoleon's tomb, a spectacular homage to a great man.
Great bargain. We toured the gardens only which, at 1 euro, was a great bargain. The Thinker and other famous pieces are in the garden, so it's well worth the trip.
Great setting for great art. I didn't know a great deal about Rodin's art until going to this museum. Amazingly presented using the garden as a setting, it is worth visiting for those pieces alone.

A wonderful collection of Rodin sculptures!. A wonderful collection of Rodin sculptures in the studio and on the grounds. Good scenes of the garden area in "Midnight in Paris" - a film worth watching before going to Paris!
Rodin Sculptures. This place is all about Rodin, and it is easy to visit, central to get to, and not too big to wear you out.

More than just Rodin. While there are plenty of great works by Rodin on display, there are Matisse and Van Gogh paintings in Rodin's former home. Also, the gardens are a joy to walk around in and escape some of Paris's hustle and bustle.

Charming Musem with Beautiful Gardens. We visted Musee Rodin on a recent trip to Paris. It is quant and doable in a hour or so and because the pieces are primarily Rodin's, it's a much more focused experience. Several sculputers are outside in the gardens. I would recommend going on a day when you can enjoy the outside exhibits and gardens.
Thought-provoking. A leisurely stroll through the exhibits and gardens on an overcast day with no crowds proved to be a lovely experience!
also under construction. This is my favorite Paris thing but the hotel museum building and much of the gardens are closed for the next year

Perfect tour. I didn't know what to expect and I was pleasently surprised. Rodin was a man of many talents. I really liked the fact that he lived here. His works, both art and sculpture were displayed throughout the house in a continuous way. He was a man of many talents. The famous thinker is outside as is the Gates of Hell in a beautiful garden. A must see.

Even in the rain this was perfect!. It was a downer to start off to the museum and get caught in a downpour, but it worked as there were fewer people. Didn't know much about Rodin beyond the thinker but loved it all. His works featuring Balzac were so intriguing that I had to wiki him while walking back. Couldn't spend too much time in gardens, but roses still beautiful in late September .

Beautiful Sculptures. Oddly this museum is closed on Tuesday when normally Paris museums are closed on Monday. This can be helpful in planning your museum trips. The garden of sculptures is beautiful and very relaxing. The leaves were changing colour in some areas of the garden and it great for pictures. If you have a museum pass you can by pass the line!

Lovely spot. The museum includes the Hotel Brion where Rodin lived and worked. The building was stolen from the church by the state and rented cheaply to various artists. Rodin negotiated with the government, giving them his collection (his works and works by others), insisting that they be shown here. There is a lovely garden, the perfect place to show his large sculptures. The Thinker and the Burgers of Calais are here. It's worth a visit.

do this on a pretty day. Be sure to see this museum on a day when you can be outdoors. Don't miss any of the outdoor bronzes. They are all placed throughout the grounds. Also, be sure to take a rest in the lovely gardens in the back of the property. There is a take away snack bar if you want to have a snack while enjoying the gardens.
Fascinating Sculpture. Hell's Gate, the Thinker, Job, the Kiss were just a few of the wonderful pieces on display. Many are ina beautiful garde setting. Definitely worth an afternoon.
A Classic. It is on the list of the top ten things to do in Paris for the lovers of the arts. Beautiful displays, garden and exhibitions.
Blown away. Didnt realize how impressive this museum is. Went on a nice day. Gorgeous property nice outdoor restaurant and caught a few rays. Spent more time here than we were expecting. Fascinating!

Great museum!. The garden really takes your breath away. We loved the small, intimate feeling of the place, and being able to enjoy such masterpieces in such lovely surroundings. A highlight of our trip.

One of the best.. This is a beautiful museum. It was renovated from an old hotel, the place it awesome on its own.
The gardens are one price, and inside is another. Honestly, just gardens had most of the great sculptures including The Thinker. So if you're wanting a few buck just do the gardens.
Great Gardens. This was a favorite. I was especially impressed with The Gates of Hell. The Cafe is expensive. Eat elsewhere. Do not miss the tour of Rodin's residence.
Awesome. This is a wonderful place. It takes a little while to get here but it is well worth the trouble. The gardens are beautiful and it is a treat to see Rodin's work.

If you like sculpture. Fantastic range of exhibits and well presented in a beautiful setting. Part of the building is under renovation so there was some work going on but it was a great morning visit. Well worth it.

Wonderful Place. Most works are outdoors so go on a good weather day. The funding is all or mostly private so the former house still needs a lot of repair inside but is used to display many works. The outdoor settings/gardesn are delightful. Not overwhelming and very enjoyable. Nice little cafe. Just pleasant.

Rodin Garden. We only toured the garden. What a value! Only 1 euro for admission. The sculpture garden is magnificent, and includes such famous works as The Thinker and Hell's Gate. A wonderful afternoon!
Lovely setting. An interesting museum in a beautiful setting. It was all fascinating, but on a hot day we found the best part to be walking in the gardens set with Rodin sculptures.

Beautiful. We visted the garden which was only a euro each. The sculptures are amazing and worth visiting on a sunny morning in Paris. We arrived before 12pm and there was no line, when we left a bit before 12pm a line was building so I suggest a morning visit.

Wonderful Statues. Besides the Thinker, there are numerous statues (and a few paintings) by Rodin at this museum. They are not only in the museum but also in the garden. If you like statues and sculptures, this is the place for you.

Beautiful Sculptures. The museum is a little enclave of peace on the Rue Varenne and it's hard to believe you are in the middle of Paris. Close by is the impressive Invalides, when you have tired of the chestnut dappled light on the sculptures in the garden

No better way to see sculpture.. This is a true gem amongst museums. Remember, it is a French garden (as opposed to an English garden). The emphasis is on shape, not colour. The sculptures are positioned exquisitely so that you interact with them and they interact with the buildings surrounding the grounds. Amazing.

Love this Museum. I have been a few times to Paris and the Musee Rodin is always a must go. The Museum has a very tranquil feeling to it. You can pay for the Museum and the Gardens or separate, but I reccomend both. Also, audio tours are completely worth it in all the Paris Museums. My favorite sculpture "the kiss". I would have bought a smaller version in the gift shop, but I found them to be on the pricy side. So, if you are into sculptures; this is your Museum!

The Gardens are the most impressive part. While Musee Rodin does boast a great selection of the artist's works, not to mention paintings by Munch, Van Gogh, Singer Sargent and others, the gardens are by far the star attraction. For only €1 you can wander about and see his most famous works - The Gates of Hell and The Thinker - set amongst rose buses and manicured lawns. The Museum is also fantastic, but with so many other Museums in Paris the garden makes for a welcome break. It has great views of the Eiffel Tower also!

We loved it!. This is a fantastic little museum. The size and scope was perfect. The grounds and gallery were beautiful. Can easily be visited and appreciated thoroughly in a few hours. I would recommend to all that visit Paris.
Well worth the visit.. Beautiful gardens with Rodin's famous sculptures, The Thinker etc. We only enjoyed the garden tour this time. Sure to be back.

Beautiful, gardens are the best bit. You can pay to get in the museum or just the gardens. Even as a Rodin fan I thought the gardens were much better then the rather small museum. The gardens also have a lovely cafe, which I didn't see mentioned on the website, which serves beautiful French cuisine in a beautiful setting, well worth the1euro entrance fee

See the sculptures of the great master in his own home. If you are not keen on sculpture (marble, bronze, stone) avoid the Rodin Collection. But anyone interested in French art of the 19th and early 20th centuries should plan on spending a couple of hours here. Take in the house first then wander the large "garden' where several masterpieces are scattered around. Costs 9 Euros.

Great change of pace.. My wife really enjoyed the serenity at Musee Rodin. This is because the majority of the sculptures are outside in the rose gardens with no bumping and shoving like at the Louvre. I feel it is a stop to plan on good weather only otherwise you're missing out on many great photo opps outside with the Eiffle Tower and Napoleon's Duomo in your background.

One of the best museums to visit. Okay, the museum is a little run down. Floors creak. There are cracks in the wall. But you know what, I love it here. The collection is amazing. The garden is so spectacular. They even have a little cafe out there so you can get a croissant. Just a really relaxing place to visit.

See 'The Thinker' and other works in the garden for 1€.. If seeing a handful of Rodin's work is enough for you, just enter the garden for 1€--probably one of the best values in Paris! I took a baguette sandwich with me that I bought off the street and went into the garden and splurged on a pastry dessert from their cafe--good times!

This is visit to treasure. My knowledge of Rodin was limited, for sure. The Thinker and Gates of Hell come to mind. But he was so much more of an Artist. We chose the musee and garden ticket. Well worth it. The art done by his muse and mistress, are also on display. The Wave depicting 3 women under a overwhelming green marble wave will always be in my memory. No rushing, no pictures inside allowed, but the garden is ok. The Roses were in bloom and we took the time to smell them.What a wonderful day.Merci

BEST museum. I love, love, love this museum! I go every time I'm in Paris. The garden is beautiful when in bloom. The house is in need of some renovation. Small, manageable, and tranquil museum - don't miss it.

Hard to believe these works are outside... The Rodin gardens and walkabout is interesting and thought provoking. To see Rodins works in this setting was perfect - exactly as a sculpture garden should be. Winnipeg's Leo Mol Garden is the only one I have seen that can compare. The museum and gardens are great for a one to two hour walkabout on a sunny day. The location is within a short walk of a number of other great sites, museums and attractions.

see the "Thinker" in the garden. We only strolled the garden area for one euro. This was enough for us, since we were already tired from the day's activities. But it was so much fun seeing "The Thinker" and the other sculptures. The outside eating area is cute and the garden walk is quite wonderful. It is interesting to note that some of the smaller sculptures are also in the larger sculptures. See if you can spot these.

A tranquil place full of exquisite objects. The garden is one of the best places I know to just sit and soak up the tranquillity. Rodin did a great variety of different sculptures and I found that I wanted to linger over many of them. His ability to show expression and emotion in a face is quite extraordinary. The high point, as one might expect, was The Kiss, a piece so beautiful and affecting that it brought tears to my eyes.

Exquisite. To be able to closely examine Rodin's exquisite works was a real treat. His ability to capture people's personalities via their facial expressions was impressive. I hadn't realised how many famous people had posed for him. The gardens were a relaxing place to be, and gave us time to reflect on his work before entering the building where the number of works presented was almost overwhelming. The building itself, a former girls' home, had apparently been marked for destruction before Rodin moved in.

Beautiful!. This beautiful museum is special with both the museum (Hotel Biron) that contains a rich Rodin’s collection and the garden that hosts some famous Rodin's sculptures including 'The Thinker' and 'The Gates of Hell'. Upstairs in the museum among the sculptures there are 3 paintings by Van Gough and one by Renoir, Rodin’s favourite.Entrance fee (both museum and garden) is 9 Euros. Museum is closed on Mondays. When you reach the end of the garden and walk through the arch opposite the pond, there is a tranquil place with wooden loungers, benches where you can spot locals reading and resting (you can enter just the garden only for a symbolic fee of 1 Euro). It is a lovely place to get some rest and enjoy nature in the heart of the city. At the moment the part of the garden behing the museum is closed for refurbishment until 2014. Apart from this we enjoyed the visit and plan to come back again when the works on the garden are finished. There is a very nice cafe where we had lunch. Come around 2pm, it is less busy, it gets busier later again. They offer nice salads, hot dishes (pasta, quiches) and delicious pastries. Food is very tasty and reasonably priced.

Beautiful on so many levels. My first visit to the Rodin was more than 10 years ago, and the layout of the museum with sculptures placed not only in the house but amongst the garden and landscape really gave me a new appreciation for this type of art. My return last May exceeded all expectations. The roses were in full bloom and amazing. The house now features two floors of artwork. The interweaving of the house and gardens and scultpures is still the most grand museum experience for all the sensory levels, from smelling the flowers, seeing the beauty, hearing the outdoors ... Displayed in this manner, the artwork is very accessible and "real" even to those who are not necessarily museum devotees. The Rodin is a "must visit" on a trip to Paris.
Best Paris Museum. Beautiful sculpture in a beautiful garden and chateau setting. Pleasantly tranquil. Skip the crowded Louvre and d'Orsay and enjoy some time in the gardens.

Lovely museum. Nice little museum tucked away on a side street near Les Invalides and Eiffel Tower - the gardens are beautiful and if you have the patience to wait for others standing right in front of the famous "Thinker" statue, you can get some great shots!£9 per adult and it won't take you much more than an hour to go through the entire exhibit..A definite must in Paris!

Interesting to see and not overwhelming. The current exhibit "Rodin, Flesh and Marble" was interesting to see and didn't take all afternoon to do it. We went on a warm day and it was quite warm inside but afterwards it was wonderful to sit in the garden and admire the surroundings and the beautiful building while feeling like you were away from the busy streets.

beautiful museum, beautiful gardens. This museum hosts many famous sculptures, including "The Thinker". Even if you're not in to sculpture art, I highly recommend going to appreciate the architecture of the museum itself, and taking a stroll around the garden that lies just behind the museum. Very beautiful and included in the museum pass.

Beautiful museum. I really enjoyed the museum and wandering through both the museum as well as the grounds outside. We went on an early morning and it wasn't too crowded. Great spot to go and visit some amazing sculptures!

Great Museum. If you are a sculpture fan or simply appreciate art in general, you will greatly appreciate this museum.It is unpretentious and has many of the masterpieces of the master. I try to go every 5 years not to forget.

The cathedral. This is worth taking time away from Napoleon's tomb and spending more time here. Highlights - the gardens where you come across masterpiece after masterpiece. And the second floor, there is the sculpture of two hands intertwined, titled The Cathedral, that is set in front of a window overlooking the gardens. Perfect.
Rodin garden is only 1 euro. Nice place to picnicIce cream snack barUnfortunately some construction which requires some extra walking aroundThe thinker is outside as are the Gates of Hell

Wonderful museum. See the garden if you don't have time for anything else. It's only 1 euro for the garden and this may be the best part anyway. Imagine The Thinker in the middle of a rose garden? You get the picture.

If you like sculpture, this is the place for you.. Well worth a visit. Dozens of Rodins scuptures and paintings displayed in his spacious house and gardens. Plenty of room to see it all in comfort. Not too busy when I visited.

Lovely setting. I'm not an expert in Rodin's work, but it was worth it just to see the Thinker, and it's great that so many of Rodin's statues rest outside in the gardens. There were also a few clay sculptures I thought were really beautiful. I didn't need a ton of time here but I'm glad I went.

The Thinker is amasing!. An amasing collection of Rodin's work will definitelly leave you spechless. Stunning pieces of work are incorporated in an extraordinary setting- a beautiful park and an old building. I sipmly loved it.

Sculptural Splendor. I didn't visit the museum, because it was too near closing time when I arrived. Opted for the sculpture garden instead and was I glad. In May, the roses were in full bloom, their beauty and fragrance enhancing Rodin's magnificent pieces. His "Gates of Hell" is worth the admission price, as well as some other gems. This is a fantastic place to meditate and reflect, surrounded by the vision of a productive artist and intellect

Welcome respite. Our family of four visited on a very hot day so did not spend alot of time inside, however we all enjoyed the gardens and outdoor exhibits. Lazed under trees and devoured icecreams at the cafe. Would recommend this museum for families.
Beautiful garden. The Rodin Museum is near the Effiel Tower. The garden has many of Rodin's larger pieces. It's a lovely place to stroll around.
disappointed. last time i visited i sat in the lovely garden and had lunch. this time the garden was a bit shabby and the collection display was in transition (under renovation).
Relax and enjoy the art. There is no line and the garden is quite nice with sculptures spreading around. Have a quick lunch in the garden and enjoy the view.

Quiet museum. A very spare museum and really quiet. Rodin's work is, of course, stunning. The "Thinker" is in the lovely rose garden. Going through does not take much time so plan on other things to complete your day! By all means, then, go to Napoleon's Tomb which is just a short walk away from Musee Rodin at the Hotel des Invalides.

Wonderful sculpture. This museum was a spectacular property as a home. The sculptures are displayed in a wonderful garden with cleverly designed bushes. The garden was being prepared for a wedding on the day we visited. The sculptures inside were impressive. Don't miss this one.
A great place to see Rodin Sculptures. It is such a great place to see Rodin's sculptures. There was a great inside exhibit then also a great garden with lots more sculptures.
just 1 euro. Pay just one euro and see the most interesting part of the museum, which is in the palace yards. There are several of Rodin sculptures, including the famous "the thinker".

Peaceful and lovely. This was probably my favorite museum visit of Paris. It is a manageable size and not overly crowded like some of the other art museums. I loved the captivating sculptures and there's a nice garden in back where you can take a quiet lunch break and relax.

Walk the gardens. Wonderful afternoon walk in the gardens. Unfortunately there was construction so some areas blocked off and made strolling from start to finish a little difficult. We were short on time so did not go through museum but saw his major works in garden. Shortcut for museum pass holders

Gardens Beautiful. Wonderful gardens with beautiful sculptures unfortunately at the time of our visit there was a large modern white marquee in the garden for an event this took away from the ambience, Also the Hotel was partially closed for renos just bad timing, however staff very helpful and the Art the main attration speaks for itself
Included with your Museum Pass. A quick trip and worth it if you have a Pass. My husband and I enjoyed the displays and I loved the bronzes.

Musee Rodin. Loved it! Incredible statues! It was the first thing we saw in Paris after checking into our hotel after the overnight flight and we thought that there were not enough signs to direct tourists there! But maybe we were just not oriented to Paris yet!!

Nicely done!. I am not typically a museum person but I thoroughly enjoyed the Musee Rodin. The combination of the gardens, the sculptures, and the works of art create a nice experience while winding down from the busy feeling of Paris.

If you have an ounce of romance in you, visit this. Many people know the famous statue "The Kiss" by Rodin. This museum, which is full of wonderful things to see, will expand your Rodin horizons. It contains many beautiful examples of his work, my favourites are the Ballet Dancers. It is on the edge of the beautiful Jardin de Luxemboug gardens, so you can enjoy a romantic stroll after you have seen all of the sights in the museum.

Sublime. The strength of Rodin's work hits you like a ton of bricks and you feel like you are in his workshop,the way his work is displayed.It takes some considerable time to go through both buildings but then there are the fabulous gardens and outdoor sculptures to stroll around.Go in the morning around 10 am then walk down Rue de Varenne to the Quartier Latin for lunch at Lipp(war trousers) and spend the afternoon cruising the 'Boulmiche' and St Germain.

Walk the gardins. This is a very nice small museum. The best part is so much of what you want to see is outdoors in some lovely gardens. So many of the museums in Paris are overwhelming with quantity of stuff. This one is just right. The way it shows the progression of Rodin's work is very interesting.

My expectations may have been too high. Expensive, no student discount and not many exhibits. The toilets were clean and welcome. The audio commentary was rather dull and I was disappointed with the one room of exhibits. The garden was a little better.

Restful and relaxing. After spending several days seeing sites with crowds and hectic traffic, this was a much more relaxed and peaceful Museum. Not only were the sculptures beautiful but the surroundings and rose filled gardens filled the senses and calmed the soul.
A Mus - See. Very beautiful place! The building itself is almost as interesting, as the exhibition. Explore the gardens completely, that's a special place!

A wonderful place to spend some time. The Rodin Museum was one of the highlights of our trip to Paris. We got there in the morning just after opening and the crowds were minimal. The sculptures on the grounds were incredible and as we walked around, we could enjoy them with nobody else nearby. You'll see one of the most well known sculptures here - The Thinker. Chances are you can get a photo with no one else in it. Inside, there was a certain calmness that is not present in the bigger, more crowed museums - creaking floors, no tour groups. All this plus some of the most awe inspiring art you'll ever see.
Attractive museum. I loved this museum which had the exhibitions both inside and outside. There are a lot of famous statues in the museum.It is not a big museum but, very attractive.
quiet garden and nice museum. Le penseur de Rodin is my favorite but all the sculptures are beautiful and the garden is very pleasant an quiet

Love the Smaller Museums !. If you love Rodin - you will adore this museum. Unlike many others reviewers, I have never suffered the long lines to get in - perhaps luck ?! Have visited here multiple times as the lovely garden setting for these amazing sculpures is uniquely charming (great photo opportunities!!) - allowing you to look at the works from every angle imaginable. Also the comprehensive collection of his work inside the house is excellent.I personally enjoy going back to these 'smaller' museums -- you can get much more 'up close' for longer....and able to see 'everything' (foregoing the 'frustration' of 'missing out')!Great for all age groups!

A Gem!. During the heat of August it was a treat to go visit Musee Rodin. I hadn't visited it in many years but since it was my kids first trip to Paris I really wanted them to see it since whenever we visit the Metropolitan Museum in NYC we always see the Rodins. It was very interesting to see how they worked the various materials. Also, liked to see the artwork that was not Rodin's.

Just OK. We found the audio tour less than informative and didn't feel the park lived up to the scene we had read and heard about. Wouldn't go back or recommend with so many other amazing spots to visit in Paris.

Best attraction for young family in Paris. Although I have been to Paris on a number of occasions, I had never been here before. And what a treat was in store!Having done the "cultural thing" in Versailles, Monte Martre and a cycle through much of central Paris, this museum was definitely the highlight. Three kids (11,8 and 4) loved the statues, racing around the gardens, posing as the Thinker, etc. and then having a cold drink in the wonderfully appointed cafe.Also, although we went in the middle of August, there was no queue and the indoor activities were equally fun.

im such a massive fan.. this is the place to go, i have always loved Rodin so this was a real treat, so much of his work and you really get a feel of what the artist intentions were when he made his home into a museum. the gardens are stunning, my favorite was the gates of hell in bronze, its so impressive.

Sunday afternoon in August with Rodin; who could ask for more?. The Musee Rodin hasn't changed much over the past years except for the construction of a new (new to us) visitors center and entrance to the hotel housing Rodin's sculptures and collection. It used to be that one walked through the large gates into the courtyard where you began to immediately enjoy the grounds and sculpture gardens. Now, there is security for this national treasure. A must for the times. But, nevertheless, an unfortunate way to begin one's visit.This is one of our favorite museums in Paris, and we were fortunate to spend a warm, summer afternoon in the collections and gardens. The sculpture garden hasn't changed over the years, but the display of marble statues and collections have undergone reorganization. The hotel soon will begin a renovation, and it is expected to last only a year before it reopens in 2013. We'll be interested to see how they reorganize the hotel displays.If you plan to spend several days in Paris and visit both Parisian monuments and museums, purchasing the Paris Musee card is the only way to go. Coupled with the Paris Visite card for Metro, Bus, RER, and SNCF travel in zones 1-3, it saves time and Euros. Sometimes, a package deal is available at the Information booths at airports and Gares.

A lovely way to spend a sunny afternoon. Not many museums allow you to see where an artist worked. A nice little cafe to sit with a coffee in the grounds and admire the sculptures. Displays show not only the finished pieces but also the clay casts and drawings.

Rodin Museum. This museum located near the Place Des Invalids was recommended by our hotel. It was a great was to spend a couple of hours to see some incredible sculptures both inside and out of doors. The museum building is looking a little run down, but currently under renovation. The audio tour is also worth the extra fee for increased enjoyment.

Not a family favorite. We took our children, age 11 and 13, and the Thinker was the highlight. They found it extremely boring. If you are a fan of Rodin , then you will enjoy it, but we were uninspired.

More than I expected. All of Rodin sculptures are great but they are especially good in the garden setting and in the old hotel which will be lovely when restored I had thought if was just the room that you see when you first walk in. The cafe in the garden had nice food.

Quick visit with our Paris Museum Pass. We're not huge sculpture fans but this museum was close to our hotel and entry was free with our Museum Pass so we paid a quick visit. Enjoyed seeing Rodin's most famous pieces and I'm sure more cultured people than us would love it! PS: Paris Museum Pass is well worth buying in advance - 2/4/6 days available.

Don't miss this gem!. This is a lovely stop while outing Paris. We Started with a relaxing lunch in the garden cafe then proceeded to stroll through the grounds and admire the gardens and sculpture. This is the house where Rodin lived and it too was very interesting. With a Museum Pass you do not have to wait in line!
A Must Sculpture Museum in Paris. Every Paris visit I make includes a visit to at least the gardens of the Rodin. For my money this is a wonderful relaxing interval from the Louvre or d'Orsay.

The Musee Gardens were lovely. Running short of time, we decided to pay 1E to visit the Rodin Gardens. What a treat! Beautiful sculptures, exquisitely manicured trees and hedges and flowering rose bushes....We ate lunch at the little cafe in the gardens and we felt as though we were in the countryside instead of in the middle of a bustling city.

A Secret Garden in the City. We were able to just wonder the gardens and admire the flowers and sculptures at our leisure. We could and did lounge on the lawns, sit for a while at the pond, take our time in the house, and, generally, really enjoy the experience. The Gates of Hell are here as well as The Burghers of Calais. Rodin's personal collection of artwork done by his friends is upstairs in the house and well worth visiting. It's a cool oasis in the city on a boiling day. We loved it!

a quite aftrenoon. Rodin's work is a product of his time, although ahead of style when he worked there are many great sculpters since. his work though still rates at the top. most of the works are outside where you can contemplate them quietly.

My favorite museum in Paris. I love the art - the sculptures are just so amazing - so fluid and emotive and all carved in marble! I love the intimacy of the museum in how it is all presented. Lastly, the gardens are lovely.

The most wonderful museum and gardens!. I was there when it opened at 10:00 am, so it was as though I had it all to myself. It was beautiful and the sculptures were awesome. It's hard to put into words the feelings that I had while strolling through the gardens and Rodin's sculptures. Everyone who goes to Paris should make this a part of their visit! (But then, it would be crowded and I couldn't have it alone!)

My favorite museum. Incrtedible sculptures by Rodin and some of his students. Take a picture under the "The Thinker". Also has some of Rodin's paintings as well as Renois, Picasso, Munch that he owned. Visit the cafe in the garden in the back.

Rodin Fans will love it. We spent a rainy Sunday afternoon at the Rodin. The lines were long and the galleries crowded but we did not expect it to be any different because we went on a free Sunday. Don't miss the outside gardens...not crowded especially in the rain! It is covered by the Musse pass also.

I love this museum!. The museum, there is in the park.It's not grand but not small.We must walk on foot but it's not problem as there are many benches.If it is sunny, you can eat lunch dans the park. There are many sculptures and pictures.
Awesome. Amazing place. The house is good, but the gardens are the best. Try to go on a sunny day. You'll enjoy walking around the gardens and coming across the various sculptures.

Beautiful setting. This proved to be a really neat museum that highlights Rodin's The Thinker. The gardens are manicured and really pretty. We thought it was unique setting and a nice place to sit for a bit. There are many collections in the mansion house.

Amazing Neighborhood, Extraordinary Garden and Life. Masterpieces at his home...how often do we get to see that. While some rooms could use a dusting, this is a must visit in an extraordinary location steps away from the Paris residences of Mick Jagger, Johnny Depp and Bernard Arnaud, diagonally across from one of Paris's finest restaurants (the Michelin 3 star Arpege) and a few blocks off the Seine. The garden is extraordinary and likely will draw more of your time on subsequent visits to the Musee.

Gardens provide artistic escape. I am so glad I found time to visit!. I only visited the gardens so I cannot speak for the museum. The gardens are beautiful with many nooks and crannies where one can sit and while away the time. There are also many sculptures to view including "Le Penseur." It is the perfect place to step away from the hustle and bustle of Paris and relax in peace and quiet. It is well worth the small price you pay.

even just seeing the gardens for 1 € is worth it. We didn't have time to do the whole museum (house) so just took the garden tour, but that is where "Le Penseur" sculpture is anyway along with other interesting works. Beautifully manicured trees and rose bushes, too.

Great museum experience with kids in tow. Our 10 year old visited the Detroit institute of Arts on a school trip and saw their copy of The Thinker in front of the building. So it was a no brainier that during our stay in Paris we would have to visit Musee Rodin. The line to get in was longish, but definitely doable. We bought the 10 Euro family pass that gave us access to the gardens and the museum itself. We had to check our small backpack in the building, but there really were no other strict rules, so no one said a word when visitors were touching the artifacts. There were great photo ops in the beautiful gardens with Rodin' s famous statues and the golden dome of Les Invalides in the background.

Beautiful art. Lovely sculptures of Rodin but they would not allow pictures (which is odd because they are sculptures and the Louvre allows photos of the artwork). However, it is still a lovely museum with fantastic arts of work!

one of the best museums. a real find in Paris. Beautiful grounds that you could spend your entire visit in because of the numbers of sculptures displayed. Very interesting panels in multiple languages giving the history of the house and how it came to be the property of the state.

Ok, unless you are a huge sculpture fan. We went to the Army Musem at Invalides and thanks to the fact that we had the Paris Museum Pass we went here. They had a nice temporary exhibit of Rodin's work on in marble which I have to say was the best thing we saw. The Thinker and Gates of Hell are impressive but we've seen replicas so many times it was not all that for us. If we hadn't purchased the museum pass we likely would have skipped it.
Hidden treasure. I think the garden is my favorite place in Paris. Give yourself a little time to sit on a bench and take in its charms.
i love. I visited there for a second time! Always worth seeing the perfection of the works of Rodin! and the sculptures throughout the garden are wonderful.
The Kiss. Far more to see than just the kiss. The house and gardens alone are worth seeing. Be sure to beat the queues though...book ahead

No matter how often we have gone I still need to visit whenever we are in Paris. I love Rodin's work but I think anyone would enjoy this park/museum. The display of his work is both on the grounds and in the Museum, especially nice on a beautiful day on your way to Invalides.

everything about Rodin. If you know a bit of Rodin (watched the movie or read Camille Claudel's life story), the museum puts eveything within context. This was the first time I have seen his infamous Balzac and a constructed version of his 'Gates of Hell'. In the main house, you can also see a couple of Claudel works.I would recommend to have a look at the main house first, have a look at the works in the garden, have a coffee at the beautiful garden cafe and explore the marble works less. Also, it is a good investment to get the audio guide (they do not give you headphones for some interesting reason, so take a pair with you). They only accept cash though.

Fantastic. I really liked this museaum. It has just the right amount of pieces on display, they are so beautiful and there was plenty of room to view them. I went around twice to revisit the statues I liked the most. The gardens are lovely. I thoroughly recommend it.

My favorite museum in Paris. Lovely museum in the artist's former home houses an impressive collection. The garden contains many examples of Rodin's genius. The Gates of Hell are scary and beautiful. Well Worth your time.

Fantastic museum. The great door sculpture and The Thinker will amaze you, but there's so much more here. The gardens are lovely and you should also take a look at the works of Camille Claudel, Rodin's lover. She was an exceptionally talented artist who was treated badly by Rodin, but her works are so inspiring and heartfelt that I dare you not to be moved.

A delightful visit - a museum not to be missed.. Many of Rodin's works are here set in delightful gardens. His complex life history is explained in clear english and I came away with a much better and kinder understanding of his life. The day of our visit the weather was wonderful and we spent much time relaxing in the gardens enjoying a drink. We want to visit again.My wife is disabled. The French authorities kindly allow us free access.

Beautiful museum and garden. We loved this museum. Originally chosen to see 'Le Penser' (the thinker) but ended up being so much more. The gardens are beautiful, and the sculptures throughout the museum and gardens are breathtaking. A very relaxing tour. While the Paris pass gets you into this museum, you do still have to wait in line. Go on a sunny day to really be able to appreciate the gardens.
Not to be missed. Kind of forgotten considering all of the treasures in Paris. Some of Rodin's most memorable pieces on display!

Beautiful museum - dont miss it. What a beautiful peaceful place - incredible work, beautifully displayed and stunning garden. We had a museum pass which once again assisted us in walking straight in without queuing. There isn't a seperate queue so make a point of showing security your card.

the garden is excellent value at just 1 euro. we only did the garden at 1 euro each and it was money well spent. you walk out of the enrance to the museum and turn left and the thinker is there. amazing. the setting is so tranquil with so many statues in amongst the trees. the "gate of hell" are a must see (the plaster version in the orsay are such a disappointment afterwards).it also was so quiet compared to the louvre and the orsay which is what i loved about the place. this was my second visit and i was transfixed again.

Favorite museum - though small it is beautiful. This museum is a little hard to find but worth it! We loved it. The sculpture was incredible and the gardens were beautiful. The pieces were impressive and the setting was amazing.
Loved it!. I went to this museum based on a friend's suggestion and loved it. This museum is at Rodin's house and it was really an educational and lovely experience.

Worth the trip. This is a lovely museum with sculptures inside and out. The gardens are beautiful and the pieces are equally captivating. Afterwards we enjoyed beer in the garden. A great spot to spend an afternoon.

Got the time, gots to go. If you don't go to the Rodin, don't blame me. It's worth going if for no other reason to see the Burgers (sic?) of Calais. It's hot, it's crowded, it's relatively small, it's a must.

The garden and the thinker -what more could you ask for. An absolutely beautiful garden. Roses everywhere. Very peaceful and welcoming. The statue of the thinker amongst the roses and hedges is impressive

The Garden. If you are short on time but want to experience Rodin, buy a ticket for just the Garden. There you can enjoy The Thinker, among other important works. There is a nice little cafe, and teh flower beds and lawns are lovely.
A Thinker. IF you are a Rodin lover then you will adore this well put together collection of Rodin's work. If you are just an art lover you will discover how many of Rodin's pieces you already know.
Absolutely amazing. Would love to go back to this place. Never before I have been to such a place that leaves you breath taking.

Up close to the works of a master. Awesome opportunity to get up close to the works of a true master in sculpture. Beautiful gardens as well. Not too crowded since it is off the beaten path. Near the metro and the Invalides. There is a wonderful cafe nearby - I believe it is called the Cafe de Duex Musee or something of that sort. Get the chocolate cafe viennois and an omelette - to die for!
Always wonderful. The gardens are just great. The special marble works exhibit was exquisite? I am partial to small museums where you can take your time and admire he works

One of my favorite Paris museums. An intimate glimpse inside a stately Paris home and gardens. I've visited it a couple of times and there is just a special feeling there. The gardens are beautiful and beg you to stay awhile and soak in its beauty.
A gem!. Don't miss the Musee Rodin, in Rondin's home and gardens. A lovely setting and beautiful museum with wonderful representations of Rodin's sculptures, process and his personal art collection.

Beautiful display. This museum is located in Rodin's house and gardens. His sculptures are beautifully laid out in his yard and easily visible even when there are many visitors. The house has additional sculptures as well as paintings done by Rodin's friends and students.
Good place to visit. Except for a few pieces, I am not really a Rodin person. That being said, I would definitely return. Beautiful grounds, complete with statuary. Main building is full of statuary.

An unexpected find. Weren't we lucky when wandering around streets near Les Invalides, to come across this gem. The special exhibition on Rodin's work with marble was very educational and the gardens with so many works exhibited in appropriate settings were great. The permanent exhibition in the large house was good in parts but it needs more curating effort to guide the visitor around.

Worth it. I have to admit- after visiting the museum I'm not really a big fan of Rodin's work- but I have always had a fascination with The Thinker statue and it didn't disappoint. I was very glad we took the time to go over there and see it- I'm not sure why but the gift shop only sells a really crummy rubber eraser copy of it- I was ready to purchase a decent one too- but the one I found at a garage sale years ago continues to be the best I've ever seen (other than the original)

Great if you like Rodin, otherwise not. Visited with a group. I'm not really interested in Robin, although his sculptures were nice. Long wait to get in, only to discover that we could have gone in a different way as a group (different employees gave different stories). The gardens are pretty. The indoor exhibition is nice but there is no air conditioning and it's very hot.The best part of the museum was the small cafeteria, which had moderately good food, although there was a long wait at the counter and register.

for Rodin lovers or a garden stroll. Museum was excellent but could have been more English-friendly explanations, garden outside was FREE and gorgeous. Make sure to go around corners, through the outdoor cafe, etc. or you might miss a good portion of the garden, which is definitey the highlight of the property

Beautiful Garden. I visited the Musee Rodin with my 13 year old son on a gorgeous sunny day in July. The beautifully maintained garden was the perfect setting for Rodin's magnificent sculptures. At first, I was a little surprised that there weren't more sculptures outside, but after walking around and really taking it all in, I realized that if there were more, the photo- snapping crowds (me included) would make this experience so much less enjoyable. The spacing between the artwork outside really gives you room to enjoy and appreciate each piece, without them all blending together. I enjoyed the mansion too, but the garden was really something special. With the Museum Pass, we didn't have to wait in the line that had formed along the sidewalk outside.

Beautiful Garden with amazing Statues. I have ben wanting to visit this Museum each time I have been to Paris and at last made it this July - I was not disappointed - take yourself, have lots of time, and wander around these beautiful gardens and marvell at Rodin's Sculptures . brilliant - don't forget your camera too - and hope it is sunnyish but not raining

Combination of indoor and outdoor experiences.. Sculptures are sprinkled throughout large formal gardens with roses and a fountain and places to lounge. Inside the beautiful mansion are maquettes and versions of his sculptures. A special exhibit points out his philosophy through examples of his work.

Rodin the master and his mistress Camille. Along with Rodin's work is that of his pupil and mistress, Camille Claudel. His work, rivaling that of Michelangelo is magnificent, lifelike and simple. That of Camille is complex and seems tortured.

for Rodin lovers and not only. If you like Rodin than you must see this museum when you are in Paris. It's the house where he really lived and worked and the park surrounding it is great. The only thing that is not so good is the fact that the museum (the rooms) need to be renovated. There are cracks in the walls, the painting of the walls needs at least to be cleaned. Other wise you will see also some statues by Camille Claudel that are indeed impressive.
Excellent display.. Displays in the museum & the gardens arranged very well. Lovely rose gardens. Amazing range of his work.
Rodin garden. We didn't go into the museum itself.we only bought a ticket for one euro to the gardens. They were wonderful,very relaxing and certainly worth the price. I would definitely go again

Never cease to inspire!. This is the third time that I came here and enjoyed it as if it was the first time. The sculptures are almost alive, the garden is very nice and we got a special bonus of the temporary exhibition of marble statuettes! A must when you are in Paris
lovely gardens.. I think the garden is worth the visit, the gallery is ok but if one were on a budget a sense of Rodin's work can be gained by a quite sit in the garden.
Rodin+Museum's Staff= Good experience. Rodin is amazing, but the museum's staff hinder the quality of experience...The staff are rude and unprepared for an international environment
Lovely gardens. A little too much of the artists unfinished and unedited work, but a tour around the garden for a euro is a steal.

Beautiful museum -- washrooms a disgrace. Beautiful museum, but the washroom was a disgrace. With the volume of tourists / fees, you think they would have someone maintain the washrooms (both cleanliness, and infrastructure) better.

The house is badly in need of renovation. Well worth a visit if sculptures is what you like. We actually liked the paintings of Rodin more than his sculptures. The house in which the exhibition is displayed is very badly in need of renovation. Good to combine this with a visit to Les Invalides as both are next to each other - walking distance.

Personal and inspiring. I went here many years ago but I can still remember clearly the wonderful impression this former home of Rodin left on me. There are wonderful examples of his famous pieces (Gates of Hell, the Thinker, Burghers of Calais) and plenty of masterpieces to discover. His study of hands were a standout for me. A fantasy world and an escapist dream for those artistically minded .
2 for 1. The museum includes his artwork but also his home and gardens. The gardens in the summer were beautiful and peaceful

Don't "Thinker" about it!. When in Paris, one must see the "Thinker". This was a museum that is small and you just want to go in and see the Thinker and walk around a little. Again, we were glad to have the Paris Museum Pass as this museum was included.

Great views of the Eiffel Tower. This museum really feels more like a park, particularly when the roses are in full bloom. It also offers some of the best views of the Eiffel Tower and the dome of the Invalides in all of Paris - to say nothing of the beautiful sculptures inside. A definite must.
One man, many styles. Fantastic setting for the works of Rodin (he did live and work here). Exhibits well laid out especially in the garden. Explanations in English throughout and a good cafe.

inspirational. This museum is gorgeous and inspirational for artists, creatives, poets, writers and more... It extremely well kept. It is full of Rodin's famous sculptures and pieces, from the thinker to the embrace. It's worth spending a few hours here, wandering inside and out. Take a sketch or notebook.

Not just a museum: park and relaxation. One of my favourite museum in town (the other one is L'Orangerie). I went a few times. The sculptures, drawings, sketches, all is SO incredible. Take your time to go for a wonder in the garden...during a sunny day you can lounge and read a book in a superb spot.

i love this place. i've been here a few times - it's often bypassed by tourists, but it's a wonderful museum, so worth visiting. maybe it's a little out of the way, but if you are a fan of rodin, this museum should not be missed. the museum also includes works by monet, renoir, van gogh, munch, etc. the gardens are lovely - what a peaceful place to sit or wander. and you can get ice cream - what more could you want!
Can't beat strolling by the Seine!. On the Seine, along the Seine, around the Seine... all good options! We chose a stroll along the Seine, taking in the bridges and the many attractions near-by.

Back here after 31 years. Still as fascinating and inspiring as ever, still as awestruck as 31 years ago... However, come armed with some pre-existing knowledge of the history behind the sculptures, as there are no explanations anywhere. The gardens are beautiful, the sun throwing a dappled light onto the bronze sculptures under the trees. This museum is well worth a visit.

Enjoyable and the right size. The museaum was not overwhelming but well laid out and accessible. The only thing missing was a multilingual guidemap brochure for those who want to browse without an audioguide.

A House, a Garden, and a Home for the sensual. I walked spellbound through this "outdoor" museum. Tree colonnades salute lifelike replica's, and echo the indoor treasures, of what Rodin exposed in sculpture after sculpture: the roughness or the smoothness, the age or the youth, the hand or the head, of what the sensual pulsates and gives to life! Adolescents were filling in questionnaires and saw themselves reflected in art: striving to enter life with a purpose and an aim. Children ran around aghast. Adults feasted. And the post-75 yr olds nodded in confirming the truth of the reality depicted in the art. A definite visit when in Paris!

Lovely if the weather is good. Fortunately the weather was fantastic for us so this was a lovely museum as it is set in some lovely gardens and has some great pieces outside.With the Museum Pass you skip the queue too!
Awesome.... Amazing to look at this exhibition of Rodins works. Beautiful gardens with something interesting around every corner. Grumpy stewards!

Thanks to "The Thinker". Just loved the exhibitions and seeing Rodin's work. Was a little disappointed that part of the gardens were closed off due to construction works for some type of outdoor buildings.

A very special place. This would have to be our favourite place in Paris. We used our museum pass to enter but the lines are rarely long. Behind the entry wall, lies a hidden and peaceful oasis consisting of a chateau and beautiful gardens, littered with Rodin masterpieces. "The Thinker" seems to pop up from behind a hedge, while "The Burghers of Calais" appear to be huddled together in conversation in another part of the garden. There is a lovely cafe in the gardens or you can simple sit and take in the beauty (not sure if you can bring your own food in - perhaps?). It is rarely overcrowded and is always a place we try to re-visit.

Amazing garden. The museum is nice, Rodin was a great artist. But what is really amazing is the garden. Visit in spring or in summer!It is also possible to visit only the garden. This costs €1. There is a café in the garden with tables out in the garden where you can eat or drink. The food and drinks are quite expensive but the surroundings make up for it.

Impressive garden.. nice sculptures in garden, only 1E if you are short of funds.Many signs missing, so it's impossible to know what is that you are seeing. That is, if you are not familiar with than particular sculpture. We couldn't find anyone that could inform us abouta particular one we liked very much.
Thinker. It was so beautiful , the thinker and the sculptures inside the Musee, it was an incredible place. Small Musee but worth it, little cafe right outside was heavenly.

A pleasant surprise. Friends wanted to visit the Musee Rodin so we all went together. I had not expected the collection to be so large and varied. We thought we might spend an hour or so visiting the museum, but stayed a lot longer than that. We loved the garden even though it was in the midst of renovations.

Not planned but thoroughly enjoyed. This was a back up site after a mini-strike closed d'Orsay. Disappointed Rodin in context of his workshop. Inside and out there was so much to see in such a compact area. Well worth it and completely unintended

Beautiful grounds and sculptures. We just paid 1 euro each to see the Thinker, and enjoyed so much more at this lovely museum. We stopped for some wine in and snack in the cafe and wandered the grounds, enjoying the many sculptures and gardens for several hours,

Musee Rodin. While the museum is undergoing a rearrangement, it is still worth visiting. We especially enjoyed the temporary exhibition "Rodin, flesh and marble". The audio guide provided lots of interesting info.

Relaxed Atmosphere. On my list of must see in Paris, the garden is quiet for comtemplations. Just sit at the bench in front of The Thinker and you'll see. It's such a contrast to just visiting the Louvre. Less crowded than Musee d'Orsay, where you can check out the duplicate The Gates of Hell at your own pace.
Lovely. 9 Euro to see the exhibition and old Hotel or 1 Euro to visit the gardens. Beautiful garden to walk around and discover Rodin's wonderful sculptures in a peaceful setting. Not to be missed!
Rodin. Excellent visit, enjoyed this visit. Lots of walking but the gardens are wonderful. For some reason, I had difficulty locating this museum but it was worth the wait.

Pity we could not see the whole thing. The primary museum is closed, there is a representative collection in a small, very hot room. It was great to see the work, we would have enjoyed it more in a better atmosphere.
Sculptor´s home.. On of the greatest sculptors of all times home, with a great collection inside the mansion and in the gardens. Very pleasant.

A secret in Paris. Not much known by tourists, the Rodin Museum in Paris is an unforgettable program, both the local and the works of Rodin. The tour requires about two hours to contemplate the work of the sculptor and to visit the gardens of the house. A wonder!

Just go in the garden. All the famous statues that you came to see (The Lovers, the Thinker, The Burghers of calais) are all in the garden, which you do not have to pay to get in to. The museum itself was over-priced and as I write this review I'm struggling to remember what was actually in it. There is an equally over-priced restaurant on site, full of jostling tour parties.

Go for the garden. This is one of Paris' treasures and is rarely crowded. There's now an outdoor cafe in the back garden area along with a lot of wonderful Rodin sculpture pieces. Great place to spend several hours snoozing in the sun.

A hidden gem!. So much to see, all the statues in the grounds are wonderful. We walked from the Eifel tower to the musee Rodin and then to the musee de or say. If you enjoy walking it was a great way to see the city.

A Must -- Rodin's "The Thinker" Reminds Me of The Many Lives Of Dobie Gillis". This is a Must in Paris, even for people athat are not Art and Sculpture Lovers.
This Thinker Statue is featured in many TV Shows and Movies like Midnight in Paris.
The setting is surprising, yet Peaceful, since it is next to Napoleon's Tomb.

Hidden Gem. There is something amazing about this museum and its gardens. The former residence of Rodin, it feels like we have stepped back in time. Le Penseur is here (the thinker). The gardens are truly amazing.

Good thing in a small package. When we purchased the Paris Museum pass, we tried to spread everywhere (A LOT OF PLACES!) over the course of the duration of the pass. To effectively do this, we got the map, sat down and planned it. Musee Rodin is not far from Musee De L'Armee and though we weren't planning to go there we thought we might as well. It definately was not a disapointment, the interior areas of the museum was quite crowded but the grounds themselves were far less and more spacious. I prefer the outdoors anyway so this was perfect for us, there is a nice little cafe that is expensive but on par for Paris and we ate lunch on the lawn, it was really laidback and relaxing. The sculptures were really interesting and there is a lot to look at, I especially enjoyed the park like environment and the outdoor sculptures. I especially liked the fact that we were in and out in under 2 hours, yeah we raced around because we are on a tight schedule but we still managed to eat lunch in this time! Like a lot of things in Paris, if I didn't have the museum pass I probably would not have gone, there are just other places to me that take precedence. However, I do not regret going and if I got another museum pass would go again especially if I was in the neighbourhood. All in all it was a pleasant and good experiance and I am happy we went to Musee Rodin.
Must see In Paris. Nice small museum. Garden is great place to relax after walking in Paris.
Fantastic Gem of a Museum. It is just a lovely place on a nice day. The sculpture is all familiar, so you feel a bit overwhelmed. One of my favorites

Great bonze. If interested in sculpture this is a must in Paris. Some of Rodin's most famous bronze works in their natural setting, outdoors, and models for his works inside. Nicely presented and easy to do in see everything.
A great surprise. We werent even going to go here at first but did because we had the Paris Museum pass and thought why not. It was amazing and we really enjoyed the sculptures.

Must visit. This small museum is a must-see. Though there were many people there, it was far less crowded than the Louvre and other tourist spots. You can get right up close to the sculptures and the gardens are beautiful, contemplative and relaxing.

Why I came to Paris... Wow. incredible sculptures with incredible stories. Gates of Hell were definitely a highlight. I would strongly suggest purchasing an audio guide- the stories that these sculptures are based on are fascinating!

Beautiful sculptures, but awful museum staff. The actual artworks are truly amazing, as are the gardens, but the museum staff were SO RUDE, that we actually cut our visit short. We were sitting in the garden eating a sandwich and were hurried inside, as they said that we couldn't sit outside??????Then there was a fire alarm ( I think thats what it was, as no one explained to us tourists what was going on)and we were all rushed out of the museum into the garden...then the garden staff members got all cross with US for coming into the garden....AND the restuarant staff were disdainful and patronising. This musuem should REALLY improve on its people skills!

A Beautiful Place. Small but lovely, this is definitely one to add to your itinerary. Alongside several others (The Burghers of Calais and The Gates of Hell) The Thinker is situated in the middle of a beautiful garden and even thronged by other visitors, it's still spectacular.
What power. these sculptures will bring tears to your eyes they are so moving
Artistic reflection. Auguste Rodin lived and worked in this mansion. The gardens are filled with his raw, massive sculptures. They seem to have a life force with continual movement.

My favourite place. We visited so many places while in Paris, but the Musee Rodin was probably my favourite of them all! I initially went just wanting to see The Thinker, but there's so much more. The gardens are absolutely beautiful and there are numerous sculptures outside. There are more sculptures inside, including The Thinker in its original size, as well as Monet and Van Gogh paintings. Definitely worth a visit.

One of the many small museums of Paris you shouldn't miss. Yes, we all flock to the Louvre and d'Orsay, but Paris is full of smaller museums (Nissim Camondo, Jacquemart Andre and this one) which are full of treasures. Shame Camille Claudel, Rodin's muse and a great sculptor in her own right, isn't featured more...
A CULTURE SHOT. Interesting even for a philistine engineer who is more used to concrete than marble. The gardens are a nice touch.

culture culture. A breathtaking collection of art/sculpture... a true feast for the senses ...a must for any aspiring culture vulture on the downside prepare to be crowded... hot and stuffy... I guess only to be expected.

If you love sculpture. Rodin was amazing, fun to tour as well. Liked the gift shop here best of any musem. Had the best postcards. Lots of info about the artist and tons and tons of his work on display

Unexpectedly exciting. I loved the territory, some of the sculptures touched my soul deeply. I went there early in the morning, just before the opening, so that I would't have to stand in a line. 20 minutes before the opening there were already a lot of people there, so it was a right decision.
The doors to hell!!. This is a great museum with some fascinating Rodin sculpture including The Thinker and (my personal favourite) The Doors to Hell.
Small but great. I always like this little museum. Rodin's sculptures always seem to be filled with movement and emotion. His garden is quite lovely as well.
To see so much of Rodin in one place is a privilege. I wander round here most times I come to Paris and never fail to enjoy it.
The wonderful place. It is a quiet and beautiful place, where you can rest surrounded by many amazing sculptures.

A lovely mix of art and gardens. The Rodin Museum was one of my most anticipated visits during our recent stay in Paris. And even though they were in the middle of a pretty extensive renovation project and the drizzling rain never let up, it was still an incredible experience.You entire into the first building where you can buy your tickets (or present you Paris Museum Pass). There's also a pretty nice gift shop with an assortment of books, t-shirts, and standard souvenir stuff. From there you move in to the first room with a number of great Rodin sculptures highlighted by "The Kiss". After that you make your way outside and to your right "The Thinker", Rodin's most popular works, sits surrounded by some beautiful hedges. From there the path takes you through the gardens where some of the artist's bronze casts are strategically placed. There's also a nice little cafe on the grounds. You weave around and come out at the gorgeous pool with a lovely garden facing the Hotel Biron. This was one of the prettiest places in Paris even with the overcast skies. I can only imagine how beautiful it would be under a bright sun. From there you can enter into the garden area that features Rodin's "The Three Shades" and "The Gates of Hell".You can also go into the Hotel Biron for two floors of more Rodin sculptures. The beautiful staircase and the creaking wooden floors also add to the experience. As I mentioned, the museum is undergoing a big renovation so a lot of the sculptures aren't where they will be once the work is done. But there is still some amazing artwork to see and some glorious and relaxing gardens just waiting to be enjoyed.

fun and unexpectedly hilarious. I visited this museum on a Saturday with a local friend. We got the giggles looking at the Apotheosis of Victor Hugo maquette. (19th century kitsch that has to be seen to be believed). The space includes multiple indoor exhibits and a garden with The Gates of Hell. A nice way to spend an autumn morning in Paris. Well-stocked gift shop, too, and an interesting neighborhood.
The gardens are worth the visit. Take a picnic lunch and sit in the gardens. A good place to take the kids, they can run around...

Not as popular as Orsay or the Louvre but worth the visit. If you like sculptures and Bronze you should like this museum. A number of sculptures are located oustside in a cute garden in the middle of Paris close to the INVALIDES. Rodin's sculptures are very powerful, most people would know LE PENSEUR ( the thinker) , I personally like a lot the " bourgeois de Calais" , turn around the sculpture and appreciate how harmonious he sculpture is from any angle. The house hosts more sculptures including famous marble sculptures. I love this museum, not only because of my interest in sculpture but also because it is he right size of museum. You can visit it in about one hour or so without being tired nor bored. Highly recommended!
Lovely!. Not just Rodin, but also other great artists. The grounds are fabulous, so worth it!

First rate...if you like Rodin. I've been to this museum three times now, and each time I go I like his stuff less. I don't think that's because I truly like his work less, but rather that I like other art more and more, thus relegating Rodin to a lower position on my personal "like" list. But if you like his work, this place will be heaven for you. Lots of first-rate art in a memorable setting.

quiet gardens. We enjoyed the Rodin Museum on the first Sunday of the month when it was free to enter. Even though the line was long when we arrived just before the opening time, it only took about 10 minutes to get into the grounds and then we were unhurried and uncrowded. What a treat to see the Thinker and the beautiful gardens that surrounded it.

My favorite museum in Paris. Not to be missed... the Thinker is spectacular... the kiss... sensual.... The building in the garden must be visited as they have some fantastic Rodin pieces not to be missed!

Good way to spend an hour or two. This is a great spot to relax and stroll through a park-like setting for a short break from the streets of Paris. It's a good deal (persons under 18 are free), and Rodin's work is well worth a look.

Very impressive museum and gardens. The Rodin museum is one of the smaller museums you'll likely get to on your trip to Paris, but is still well worth the visit. The museum is a converted house with two floors of galleries, surrounded by a beautiful large garden which contains more of his larger work. All of his great works are here and it will certainly be one of the high points on your trip. There's a small gift-shop which you enter the grounds through which provides a last-minute opportunity for some mementos.
great museum, good exposition. just a great visit you shound not miss. Relax in the beautiful garden, enjoy the sculputres of Rodin.

great for sculpture-lovers. The neat thing about this museum is seeing the artistic process: there are models, and original size sculptures of some of the larger pieces, and lots of studies for the Gates of Hell, which you can see in the garden. The history of how the museum came to be is very interesting, and it can be amusing to stroll through the garden and see international tourists posing like the sculptures. We also saw a temporary exhibition of marble sculpture which was breathtaking. I'm not sure how much longer it is there in the same form, but it is very much worth seeing if you can.
Best Museum Experience!. The majority of Rodin's sculptures are in the Garden (simply beautiful)...and the trail and history are simply an experience you will not want to miss.

One of the greatest sculpture. "The thinker", artist Rodin. One of the greatest French sculptures just like his mistress Camille Claudel. The technique, artistry and creativity are amazing just like Michelangelo. The garden, very peaceful and a nice place just to relax. It's worth the trip even you do not anything about art.

the thinker makes u think. what a talent....incredible grounds and gardens...the thinker alone makes it worth the trip... then the kiss...then dantes inferno...saying it was a moving experience doesnt do it justice

A Must See in Paris. We enjoyed this museum much more than The Louvre or Museo d'Orsay because of the intimacy and the surprisal factor. We have visited lots of museums in many cities so it is hard to be wowed by another museum, even one as famous as The Louvre but we were wowed by the exquisite Rodin sculptures and took a ton of pictures, many from just a few feet away
