Always visit the Musee Rodin when in Paris!. I can't visit Paris without going to the Musee Rodin. I never thought I was that interested in sculpture, but was won over after my first visit to this lovely spot! The gardens are beautiful and the Rodin masterpieces are just scattered around. They have completed the new entrance, auditorium and gift shop since my last visit which unfortunately takes away a little from the idea that you just happened upon someone's home, but it is well done and not attached to the original home (and gift shops are needed for revenue). It is a great place for a quiet afternoon.

My favorite little museum. This remains my favorite little museum in Paris. In the summer, I would recommend just hanging out in the garden, a separate and lower fee, and enjoy an hour or two sitting in the shade to get out of the heat and also taking in the best of Rodin's works on the premises.
Worth the visit. Just a great place to visit, with the grounds in the middle of the city you still feel as though you are in the country.
beautiful. perfect combination of beautiful gardens & art. sculptures are amazing

Five star for its content but, really!. Dear Musee Roin.The works of the master do, of course, speak for themselves, but please can I ask for a little more consideration of the art and less attention to the needs of 10 minute trippers or passing coach tours!Yes, the thinker was intended to be looked up to, but does it have to be placed in such a place where the best view is from the lines of passing bus tours.And the garden, yes is is lovely and peaceful, but does "The Fallen Caryatid" have to be obscured in an out of the way position to facilitate foot-fall?I am not looking for academic silence and gallery quiet. Rodin was about real life and the garden concept in particular is excellent. By all means introduce this work to as wide an audience as possible, but I do not think that I am alone in visiting this for more than a photo operability and a tick on my tour book!Thank you..
Glorious. If one wishes to learn about the impossible art of turning stone to lush, sensual, human beings go to this museum. You will learn what a master sculptor and artist is.

A Must For Fans of Sculpture. Spent an entire day at the Musee Rodin in Paris with family including young child. We enjoyed walking the garden as well as was much impressed with the painting collection in the villa.

Beautiful oasis of calm. For one euro you can explore the 3 hectares of gardens and sculptures in this lovely garden. There is also a lovely cafe in the garden and beautiful rose gardens. A beautiful serene spot in Paris to spend a couple of hours.

Charming, beautiful and lovely. This small museum has a beautiful garden perfect for wandering, dreaming and appreciating Rodin's fascinating sculptures. Sitting in this garden appreciating the trees, sculptures and birds was one of the highlights of my trip to Paris!It's well worth getting the audioguide which is available in several languages and has great commentary on the artistic, personal and anecdotal aspects of the sculptures and artworks presented in the lovely gardens, and the grand old house which forms the museum. Extra tips: The staircase inside is slippery so hold on to the hand rails! Visit during the middle of the day to avoid congestion in the museum; it seems to be more crowded in the mornings and early afternoons when school groups come to visit.

Evocative. Landmark museum containing so many of Rodin's major works including the Age of Bronze, the Gates of Hell, the Thinker and the Burghers of Calais. A must see for someone visiting Paris for a second or third time.
Beautiful grounds. Loved this smaller musee devoted to Rodin. The museum is smaller and less daunting than the other, larger museums in Paris. The grounds are beautiful as well as the art.
Lovely. This is a nice museum where you can see Rodin's sculptures in the middle of lovely gardens.

Beautiful art and magnificent grounds!. We lucked out and visited Musee Rodin on a bright sunny day. Walking around the grounds was lovely. The gallery isn't as organized or well curated as some, but knowing Rodin had selected it made it special and well preserved with his collection.
Both Museum and Gardens worth a visit. I really enjoyed my time there, so much to see both inside and outside. It was a thrill to get so close to the sculptures.
quiet and beautiful. not so well visited, but that makes this a great sanctuary to observe Rodin's sculptures in a beautiful setting, nice tea house in the gardens

For art lovers and lovers. Bon musee!
I enjoyed this museum very much - easy to locate, friendly welcome and good information in several languages.
I love Rodin and there was an excellent piece on his own lovers that was fascinating.

Lovely musee. To actually see, up close, the Rodin sculptures I've only seen in books, was a thrill for me. The masterpieces are displayed beautifully and with great care and thought as to their surroundings and settings. The "gates of hell" was fascinating to examine close up, as was 'The Thinker' and many other pieces. It's not a big place, but well-designed, such that it didn't feel crowded or over-run even though there was quite a crowd out that day. And with the outdoor venue, it feels more relaxed, almost peaceful, where you can take your time and not have to rush to see the next piece.We were there around lunchtime, so took a very pleasant break at the cafe at one of the outdoor tables and enjoyed a lovely lunch and some sun, as well.

Loved this museum. To be able to walk around these sculptures I'd seen and read about in books was amazing. Walking through the house and seeing not only Rodin's work but art/objects that he owned and influenced was wonderful. Also, going through a museum this small made the experience very intimate and special--even though there were other people walking thorough the house and the beautiful gardens, it was easy to be lost in the surroundings.
A garden treasure. What a respite from the hectic Parisian scene. A sculpture garden from paradise. Relax and enjoy.
see the garden. Small museum, with famous art works both inside an old townhouse and displayed in a large, quiet, beautiful garden.
think about it. loved the gardens and sculptures in it. The house mainly helped in understanding the process of making the art. A good value and an enjoyable stroll
One of my favorite museums. If you like sculptures, this is the place to be. Rodin's major pieces. Camille's sculptures are as beautiful as Rodin's. The parc is beautiful.

Gorgeous garden and easy museum visit. This is one of my favorite museums, on a sunny day it is relaxing to meander around the beautiful garden and admire the sculptures. The indoor museum is an easy walk, not overwhelming. If you have time, definitely make a stop there. As with most museums in Paris, the first Sunday of the month entry is free.

Don't Miss This Little Gem!. Paris is fabulous, but sometimes it can be visually overwhelming. We found the Musee Rodin (http://www.musee-rodin.fr/en/) a perfect antidote for that sensation. Opened in 1919 and housed in a exquisite private townhouse, it sits in an enclosed garden that provides a quiet oasis in the midst of the city. The cafe in the garden offers very good food at reasonable rates -- far better on both counts than we experienced at the Musee d'Orsay cafe.I was amazed at how close we could get to the diverse works of Rodin and those of Camille Claudel, his pupil, collaborator, and mistress. My husband and I wanted to document as much of our time in Paris as we could in photos, and were delighted to find that we could use our cameras (no flash) freely in this museum. I look more closely at things when I am working out the best angle and distance from which to photograph them, and enjoyed working within the confines of the space and other visitors.The interior of the building was as fascinating as the artworks -- amazing chandeliers, ornate mirrors, delicately carved trim on door frames, and much more. We spent about three hours here, and left feeling refreshed and inspired. I highly recommend it as a Paris attraction!
Small but beauty. Love it! If you can spend sometime in the gardens without any pressure to go somewhere else, do it. It is a great place to take a break and relax.

Beautiful grounds and museum. If you love Rodin sculptures, you will love this museum. Many of his most famous pieces are outside. The Burghers of Calais is magnificent up close. The Thinker is poised above the viewer. You can walk right up to the Gates of Hell. Inside, you can see photos from his studio, his famous hands and The Kiss, as well as sculpted "sketches" he did for many of his famous pieces.
My Favorite. Musee Rodin I revisit again and again. His work is astounding, sensual, and powerful. This is where to learn what sculpture is all about. An education, a joy.
on a sunny day. nice lay out, sculptures in the garden, wasn't too busy, worth a visit
Rodin was the BEST!. The museum itself (old Hotel Bristol, where he lived) is in decay but the grounds are impeccable (the larger statues are there, including Gates of Hell, the Penseur, etc).

Rodin is great, but Claudel is even better. This is Musee is small, but impressive; not only because of the lovely garden with all the sculptures from Rodin, but also as there are a few from Camille Claudel, which are - from my point of view - even more spectacular. You must also visit the Hotel Biron, which shows some smaller sculptures, but very amazing ones.

Nice museum. Be sure to go into the building in centre. There is more stuff to see in there. All the large pieces are in the garden outside. The price for garden is 1 euro. More for the museum in the center. We were able to enter the museum building with the 1 euro ticket, I think the person checking the tickets did not know the difference.Pro Tip: (We did not do it since Orsay had a strike that day). If yougo to Rodin before 1 then you can buy a combined ticket. You can see Rodin and then go to Orsay and enter through the ticket holders line. The line (C) is sometimes smaller than the one for ticket buying at Orsay.

Beautiful gardens and sculptures. This is a very small museum on beautiful grounds with exquisite gardens and sculptures. We had a lovely little lunch at the cafe in the garden and enjoyed eating outside on the beautiful sunny day. I recommend seeing this museum on a beautiful day so you can take advantage of the gardens. The museum displays the works of the French sculptor Auguste Rodin.

An Unexpected Treasure. We went only because it was so close to Napolean's Tomb. What and unexpected treasure. The sculpture garden is lovely. It's serene and quiet, even with many visitors. The sculptures are dramatic, well-placed, and most larger the life-size scale. The chateau, with its smaller pieces, it a step back in time and a glimpse into another era. Take the time, it's worth it.
Lines too long. Waited in line 1.5 hrs to get in. Get the Paris Pass, you get to walk right in. The gardens were okay, the inside not worth my time.

Thought I would get bored but boy I was wrong!. When my friend insisted I go to visit the Rodin's museum in Paris, I thought I would get very bored just looking at sculptures from one same guy. Boy I was wrong! What a beautiful place this was, not only the grounds were gorgeous and well kept but the sculptures were really great. This museum can be seen in the film "Midnight in Paris". Try and not miss it if you are in Paris, it's worth it and included in the Museum Pass.

A calm retreat in the middle of the city!. We bought a couple jambon beurre sandwiches at a nearby boulangerie, stuffed them into our bags and headed to the museum. After marveling at the amazing statues we headed outside behind the house to the beautiful garden. We grabbed a shady spot among the greenery and had a relaxing picnic and rest. It was a very nice and calming treat in the middle of the busy city!

In my book the best Museum in Paris is the Musee Rodin. We visited the museum the first thing in the morning and it was not crowded at all. I had been there before and wanted to take my two grown daughters there as it has always been my favorite. We loved the gardens with all the topiaries, and the wonderful sculptures, such as "the Thinker" and the "Gates of Hell" - and many other beautiful works by Rodin. The old hotel which houses his sketches and many other paintings and sculptures, is organized in a beautiful fashion. You can spend an hour or two there, or much more time if it is available.
A Gem .... quiet and less crowded. This museum was exceptional, quite, and you can sit and relax at the cafe.

A Beautiful Calm Place in the Heart of a Great City. We had spent quite a bit of time in the Musee D'Orsay in the morning and grabbed a bite of lunch. Then we walked over to this museum. It is a beautiful park and such a nice place just to sit enjoy the gardens and sculpture and recharge. A wonderful oasis
fabulous sculpture. A good small museum. If you are short of time go through the outside first. The sculptures are amazing.

What Do You Think?. The dominance of Rodin's "Thinker" in the garden lures you through the doors, but it is the scope of his talent displayed in so many other forms that overwhelms you. No matter the media, Rodin and his friends (including Van Gogh) have masterpieces on display throughout the buildings housing the museum. It is interesting to see some of the same pieces done in bronze, marble and plaster.
Art + food = great deal!. No hurry to enjoy this museum. Lots of Rodin´s works, plus the extra of a good restaurant with great food at affordable prices.

Must See in Paris for 1 Euro. This is a must see when in Paris. Located near Napoleons tomb and not far from the Eiffel Tower, this museum is a wonderful place. There are two options to consider when visiting. for 1 Euro (seriously) you can visit the garden of the museum. All of the larger, major works of art are available to see here like the Thinker and The Gate of Hell. For an additional 10 Euro or so, you can visit the home which contains the smaller works of art. I did both but when I return, I'll just visit the garden area. Having visited in the Fall, most of the flowers etc had gone away. I'm sure it's stunning in the spring and summer. Enjoy

Could sit here for hours. There's something so breathtakingly beautiful about Rodin's sculptures. Just like his most famous sculpture, "Le Penseur" (The Thinker, I could sit in the garden for hours in the garden amidst his work, thinking and watching the light hit on the sculptures in different ways.
Very interestingly laid out. Really nice to see most of the sculptures in the open air. Not busy at all either.
Lovely garden. Garden is very cheap and has lots of great Rodin sculptures

Add this to your list of must see attractions in Paris. We loved the Rodin museum. It is a quiet respite in the heart of Paris and we loved strolling through the gardens of Rodin's home seeing his sculptures outside. This was a welcome change from the scores of other museums we visited while in Paris. We enjoyed a beverage and snack in the cafe on the grounds. Our musueum pass allowed us to walk right in without a wait.

Variety. Some works are inside and others are in a beautiful garden setting. The works in the Hotel are displayed nicely with the architectural highlights of the building. Stay however long you have and if short you won't feel like you missed too much (as with the Louvre); nor will you get bored if you stay a long time. You have options for the audio head-set explanations or just read the printed cards (inside exhibits).

Magnificent Sculpture in a lovely setting, Plus a bonus meal. We visited the museum twice in our stay in Paris. I love Rodin, and saw the Gates at the Metropolitan Museum or Art as a young man (I think it was the plaster from the Orsay). Thirty years later the bronze works really felt different. Faces I saw as ugly in my youth are now filled with lifes experience. Rodin brings raw emotion to life like few others... Now to the surprise part of the visit. I went to the cafeteria and ordered the Plate De Jour. What a pleasant surprise. I had Chicken in white wine and pickle sauce (excellent), fresh mashed potatos, and a bowl of potato-carrot soup. All were excellent. My wife'ssalad was also delicious, and cold beer is bargain priced. Don't be afraid to visit the Rodin for an excellent lunch.
LOVE LOVE this place. I love the garden in the back to relax after a day of walking.
master pieces. Always impressive to see the sculptures of Rodin.
Finest of Paris museums. The house of Auguste Rodin and the carden full of his statues is exquisite

Beautifully intimate. This gallery/museum was a surprise. I had always intended to go, but not realised just how beautifully it was put together. I especially loved the marble gallery of Rodin's works. Well worth the price of admission.We bought audioguides and found them helpful as there was little in the way of info next to the pieces. Recommend if you're into that sort of thing.

Spectacular. Do not miss this....it is such a treat. I learned much about Rodin while here and the location is easy to get too. I spent a couple hours here and it was delightful. Have a coffee in the garden surrounded by Rodin's wonderful sculptures!

A quick trip. A fairly small garden and house. Was worth seeing the 'Thinker' and included in the Paris Museum Pass, so we didn't feel bad about spending extra to pop in there. The line can get long, and there's not much skip for the Pass holders, but still not too long of a wait.
A must see. stroll thru gardens and view amazing scuptures,. Pick up a pushbike and ride to here, plenty of parking on side street. Cute park opposite Musee.
COOOL. If you like Rodin, you will love this place--plain and simple. Nice location.
Worth a Visit. a nice 30-45 investment of time in the vicinity of Les Invalides.

Great lunch as well!. The museum is actually a former residence ,with a collection of Rodin's works thru out the building,as well as the gardens. They also offer admittance to the garden only for a small fee, and many locals take thier lunch break here. The cafe located here is excellent as well!

Definitely visit and enjoy but don't expect to be overwhelmed. The Musee Rodin is a nice place for a leisurely stroll through the main house and adjoining gardens. One must appreciate Rodin or twentieth century sculpture to fully appreciate the Musee. I visited once before roses were in bloom and once in the autumn. I was not overwhelmed by either visit.

One of my favorite spots in Paris. I visit the Musee Rodin every time I visit Paris because I admire Rodin's sculptures and because the gardens here are so lovely. Over the years, this museum has become more popular but because the gardens are so large, I never feel crushed by a crowd. On a beautiful day, there is nothing more pleasant than a walk in the garden among the sculptures. There's also a nice little cafe in a shaded area where you can get something simple to eat, write some notes, look through your guidebook or just watch people.
Wonderful. I love this place - the way Rodin could get such emotion into sculptures - amazing!
Beautiful sculptures. This was not too crowded when we visited. The garden area is pretty and there is a nice little cafe there too.

Excellent value for money.. We paid 6 euros for the house and gardens. The house was good because it had cards in English telling the story of his life.
The best sculptures are in the gardens and this only costs 1 euro.

Beautiful museum. Don't miss this museum the sculptures are incredible, Rodin is a genius at sculpting you must see the amazing details in his work. The grounds are really pretty too this is where you will find the famous Thinker scuplture.

Amazing sculptures in a tranquil setting. This museum is set in Rodin´s house and garden, with some of the larger works dotted around the garden, and smaller pieces inside the house. It´s not a very large museum, so is not overwhelming, but was a wonderful way to pass a couple of hours, admiring the various works. The Thinker and The Gates of Hell are naturally the most sought-out pieces, but there are so many other works to take in and admire. I´d definitely go back.There´s also a nice café inside the garden´s grounds, with good sandwiches and salads and without over-the-top prices, so on a sunny day, it´s a great setting in which to relax for a while.

To the Gates of Hell into Paradise. This museum was so easy to visit it should top everyones list as a Paris attraction. No lines, hardly a fee (1 Euro to visit the grounds), and a beautiful sculpture garden. If you've got a free afternoon, or an hour take the time to walk among the sculptures and garden. Then take a peak at The Gates of Hell and ponder the Thinker. See some fun video here: http://savvynomad.com/2011/10/the-gates-of-hell/.

Love this place. I have always loved Rodin's work, so was keen to visit this museum. It did not let us down. Not only does this museum house his wonderful work, the museum itself is a wonderful example of Parisian architecture. To cap off an all round wonderful experience, the gardens provide a little piece of peace in this busy, noisy city. We will certainly be back.
Beautiful sculpture garden. The Musee Rodin has beautiful flowers in August. The sculpture are placed along a walk as well as inside. On August 22 my husband and I enjoyed the outside garden.

Perfect setting.. This was my 2nd visit to Musee Rodin. What a great experience, both times.Wonderful works of art inside and out. The gardens are an incredibly wonderful way to tour Rodin's work. Visitors will find this a far more relaxed and, in my opinion, fulfilling tour than the Louvre.There is no question that the Louvre contains some of the most famous works of art in the world but Musee Rodin gives it's patrons the ideal atmosphere in which to view the exhibits.
Let me tell you this: The Gates of Hell are here. And you will get close!. A 1 Euro admission to the Gardens was the best spent Euro of the trip. Sculptures are gorgeous. Take a sunny day, please.

Beautiful inside and out. What a beautiful and wonderful way to spend our first morning in Paris. Because many of the works are located outside, you definitely want to go on a nice day. We had a picture perfect day and it made the visit that much more spectacular. Wandering through rose gardens that were in full bloom only added to the experience. The layout inside is quite lovely with several rooms in which to wander. After viewing every piece of art, we found a great spot outside to enjoy the gardens. Perfect morning.As it turned out, on Sunday's there is free admission so you do need to get there early in order to avoid the long lines.
Had to See the "Thinker". Really not planned to see this, but thoroughly enjoyed it. Also ate in their outdoor cafe! Enjoyed!

Small but amazing museum. It´s not a very big museum, but they have some Van Gogh painting and as the name says a lot of Rodin's sculputures. They have a very nice garden where you can sit and enjoy looking at the sculputures

Best Museum Experience By Far. We've seen parts of the Louvre -- fantastic collection of art but too big to see it all. We've seen the Musee D'Orsay -- more reasonable size but too crowded. Now we've seen the Rodin Museum -- just the right size! First of all, this museum is really accessible as its right off a Metro stop and blocks from Les Invalides. They monitor how many people are inside so it doesn't get too crowded. They also let you take pictures which is rare in good museums. The sheer size of some other museums make them overwhelming to people, but Musee Rodin is the perfect size to browse.Some of Rodin's most famous pieces are in the gardens and some are in what used to be Hotel Biron. It was so refreshing to see art on a grand scale in an outdoor setting. You can sit on the steps of "The Thinker" for a picture in the garden. Stand back and gaze at "The Gates of Hell." Take time to marvel at Paolo and Francesca embracing in "The Kiss" inside the mansion. Learn how Rodin and Monet were friends. Really interesting stuff.

A very special and pleasant place in Paris. I have been to Paris some times but never had gone to Musee Rodin. This last time, as I was trying to see something different, I decided to go there. The museum is located in the former residence of Rodin. The most important masterpieces are located in the garden. So, as soon as I entered, I almost bumped into "The Thinker". The garden is a really pleasant place. Inside the house, there are more masterpieces and a special room dedicated to Camille Claudel - which I think was the most special room inside the house. Definetely, a place to spent a couple of pleasant hours in Paris.

Raw, potent, made me fall in love with Rodin. I'm not a huge sculpture fan but seeing the works of Rodin blissed me out. The Three Shades is now my personal favorite, after seeing it displayed amongst the beautiful gardens. Seeing his sculptures outside of the usual four walls of a museum also allowed me to appreciate the intense presence his figures emanate. There is also much to see inside of the mansion so do go inside. It is covered by the museum pass.This treasure of a museum also introduced me to The Age of Maturity, sculpted by his former lover, Camille Claudel. It actually moved me to tears, mostly due to the fact that she became increasingly paranoid after their breakup, her glorious career ended and she died in an insane asylum, but also because I am getting older and saying goodbye to youth as well!There is a metro (Varenne stop) and bus stop right in front of the museum on Blvd des Invalides so it's incredibly easy to find. We walked from the Eiffel Tower to the Military Museum (Napoleon's tomb and a cool assortment of armour, weapons, et al) then on to the Rodin, then took the bus back to our apartment near Luxembourg Gardens without getting too tired.

Wonderful Museum. I used to live in San Jose, California, and I would often visit the Stanford Museum in Palo Alto and the Legion of Honor Museum in San Francisco to see their Rodin collections. I am a fan of Rodin and like most of his work. So I felt very good to go to the Hotel Biron and see the Musee Rodin. My favorite sculptures were the Age of Bronze, The Kiss, and The Thinker. The Burgers of Calais is terrific as a work of art, and so is the Gates of Hell. Balzac is not much to my liking. The work of Camille Claudel is very good. I saw the movie about her many years ago and she was a feminist ahead of her time. I enjoyed the beautiful garden at the back of the museum. The sculptures there were perfect for the place. What was interesting is that I found out that you can still order a Rodin sculpture. They still have the forms.

Want to see World famous Sculpture, then come here..!!. I'm not particularly artistic, but to see such world famous sculptures at such a closeness is fascinating. We went here on our "Culture Day" whilst we had the use of a "Paris Pass" and had the admission price included in the ticket, which was well worth doing.The surroundings are quiet and secluded and it was not over popular, unlike the D'Orsey and Louvre.

A must go. I've had been in Paris before, but I had never given so much attention to this museum (because of the great number of things to see and museums to visit). I think that was because we are used to see Rodin masterpiece works in many other museums even in other countries. But here the classics are all together and in an amazing garden! Don't forget to visit the main house interiors with some of the Camille Claudel works and some surprises as two incredible beautiful Van Gogh's and one Monet specially made for his friend Rodin. It was worthwhile visiting.

Intimate times with Rodin's works. For anybody interested in the work of Rodin, this is a must see. The Hotel Biron, which is itself a beautiful and elegant building, is the basis of the museum with the hotel and its gardens both used as a setting for Rodin's famous works, including The Thinker, The Kiss and the Gates of Hell. Being able to see his works in place also allows the sheer mastery and majesty of his sculptural technique to be fully appreciated. Rodin actually used the Hotel Biron as his workshop and so it is a total Rodin environment.Make sure you go on a fine day as this allows you to see the sculptures outside at their very best. The garden itself and the lake are a beautiful setting as well. The other general advantage here is that there is not the usual huge crowd one encounters at the Louvre, for example.Les invalides and the Military Museum are also close by.

An absolute must. It's a smaller museum with a lovely garden, not too difficult to get into but you would still do well to have pre-bought your tickets. We have visited before and I am often reluctant to revisit on the basis that it's never quite so good the second time around. I was wrong, once again it took my breath away. I'm not into Rodin's paintings but the scuptures are superb. The two most famous are The Kiss and The Thinker. Not to downgrade either but my personal favourites are The Burghers of Calais and the Gates of Hell.You really shouldn't miss this little gem of a museum. The garden is lovely and peaceful and the artwork stunning.

Don't miss the Rodin Museum. It's not as crowded or hectic as other museums in Paris so it's easier to visit with children than the Louvre. Located in the Hôtel Biron, it features mainly sculptures Auguste Rodin. The most famous is probably The Thinker but there are many other notable works and the museum's garden is lovely. The museum is located near a Metro stop, Varenne. Behind the museum building is a small lake and casual restaurant.
do not miss this museum!. interesting museum, beautiful garden and park, great place to relax after museum tour

Not to be missed - great art and gardens. I have been a big fan of Rodin and his artwork, but I wasn't ready for the collection here amazing. The gardens actually were very nice and they have food stands so you can walk around and enjoy the sculptures in a garden setting.

lovely grounds, nice and small, not too crowded. nice and easy to find, well located, set amongst beautiful grounds, and well spaced apart to save from crowding.Part of the Museum Pass - quick and easy entry. The statues of 'the thinker' and 'the kiss' are a must see, but overall it is a lovely experience wondering around seeing the different pieces of sculpture and art.

Pleasantly Surprised. I was pleasantly surprised. I visited the museum because I had the Paris Museum pass. Upon approaching there was a very long line to get in, but since I had the pass, I just showed at the door, and able to get in without wait. The garden and museum was more than I expected and quite relaxing.

Lovely museum and garden. The gardens of the house are wide enough not to feel too crowded. We had lunch at the museum's cafeteria (a good bowl of salad for 11 euro), pleasantly seated in the shade. The evolution of Rodin's artistic career could be illustrated in a more organic way. Not worth getting the 4 euro audioguide: the same information can be read for free in the sheets available in each of the rooms. Probably the best option would be to buy the Guidebook to the museum for 10 euro.

ONE NOT TO BE MISSED!. I can't rate this museum highly enough - the museum itself is very interesting but walking in the gardens amongst Rodin's wonderful sculptures is an experience I'll never forget. There is a nice cafe too, entrance fee is just 10 euros for a family and amazingly, even my two young boys loved it!

best in Paris. Rodin Museum: magnificent! The best museum in Paris!Yes, the Louvre is a must, but don't miss this precious gem in Paris! The architecture is awesome, gardens are fantastically neat and the scupltures of Rodin are simply gorgeous. Every statue in the gardens seems to be alive and all the collection is surprisingly stunning.A must see!

Don't forget the gardens!. I can't add too much as I think the Musee Rodin is one of those museums that most people are either going to go to or not go to, and they probably know this from the beginning. I just wanted to pipe up in favor of the gardens. When I went with my partner, who is an artist, I whiled away some lovely time in the gorgeous gardens while he intensely studied the sculpture. The gardens are manicured and well-maintained, and there are great areas to rest and contemplate from benches by the Gates of Hell to chaise lounges with a wonderful view of the estate. That's not to say that the museum itself isn't worthwhile, especially as the building is so unique and lovely and you can really get a feel for life as an artist in Rodin's time. But if you're traveling in a group and on the fence about going, remember that the museum is much more than the sculptures - and if you're still not convinced, you can purchase a less expensive garden-only ticket which still lets you see some of the most famous pieces such as The Kiss and The Gates of Hell. Musee Rodin wasn't on my list of must-dos, but the wonderful garden made it definitely worth it.
Extraordinary collection. A must if you like sculpture. All the best of Rodin's and Claudel's work, lovely gardens. Pity the building's interior is in such poor condition.

Simply amazing!. Amazing attraction concentrating on one the the greatest sculptors the World has ever seen. Great outdoor gardens with some of Rodin's most famous pieces such as Le Penseur, and incredible indoor exposition, including pieces from Rodin's muse Camille Claudel. As for other Paris attractions, we bought our tickets online ahead of time and were able to print the PDF file from home. However, we went a Friday morning, and there were lineups whatsoever to get in.

A small and accessible gem. DISCLOSURE: I am not the FrankMcB who wrote the other review but we are closely related. Very closely related.This museum does not seem to appear on "Top Ten" lists of Paris attractions but, if such lists ever expanded to 15, I think many would add it.Musee Rodin has a lot to offer but the thing I liked about it the most is it is not overwhelming like the better known and larger musuems of Paris. It does not have the huge crowds filling our their "checklist" of museums and monuments and, with a 1.5 or two hour visit, you can feel that you got a fairly thorough look at Rodin. The museum includes Rodin's greatest works and also gives you insight into his evolution as a sculptor, his place in the Impressionist movement, and an understanding of the technical aspects of his work.In addition to the buildings, the gardens, which hold his principal works, are a pleasant place to relax and take a break.NOTES FOR VISITORS:1. Near Napoleans Tomb/Invalides so this can be combined with those attractions. The Musee Rodin, the Musee de l'Armee, and the Eiffel Tower would be a full day.2. Some maps are terrible but the closest metro stop to the entrance is VARENNE.3. Covered by Museum Pass. 4. I have heard you can visit the gardens alone for a Euro or two. While you cannot enter the buildings, this would give you access to "The Thinker", "Burghers of Calais", "Victor Hugo", "Gates of Hell", several full sized studies for "Burghers of Calais" and other works.5. There is a cafe in the garden.6. If you really want to relax, there are chaises at the southernmost end of the gardens.

One of Paris' greatest (and most overlooked) art museums.. An excellent exhibition of the work of Auguste Rodin. The museum in comprised of a house where Rodin lived and the surrounding garden, both filled with his work. The garden and house are quite calm, without the hustle and bustle of the more popular Paris art museums, such as the Louvre.Not only does the garden house some of Rodin's most famous works, such as "The Thinker"; it also displays much of the work that went into them. For example, there garden has six full-sized nude studies from "The Burghers of Calais". The house contains a massive volume of his sculptures, much of it little-known, that allows one to view both the evolution and scope of the sculptor's work. It also displays a smattering of the work of his students and contemporaries- the museum has several works by Van Gogh and Monet, the latter a close friend of Rodin.One sad fact is of the museum is that, in an attempt to incorporate modern art, the courtyard contains three recent abstract pieces, each resembling a four meter tall chrome plated aluminum turd. Fortunately, this is the entire extent to which such art has permeated the museum- the rest is all that of Rodin and his contemporaries.Overall, the Museum was an unexpected treat, and wonderful experience, and almost as much as an art must-see as the Musee d'Orsay.

Nice Museum. We only spent 1 hour here in the gardens and in the house.Artwork and sculptures were nice. Not our favorite museum in paris, but it still manages to hold on to its intimacy in its space which is a nice change from all the tourist crowds.Walk afterwards to nearby napoleon's tomb. Have lunch on Rue Cler (cheap and good).It's a nice museum.

Wonderful Oasis in the City. I loved this museum and garden. It is a "must-see". Would suggest visiting the garden in the early morning or late in the day if you are a photography buff like myself. The THINKER is in an open area and I found it very tough capture it's amazing details in the mid day sun. The rose garden is beautiful in full bloom. Other impressive works by Rodin are scattterd through the garden. The Museum itself is small but also very interesting.

lovely sculpture garden. I love sculpture gardens and this is a good one. It isn't very big but "The Thinker" alone is worth seeing. I also went indoors which was very good but not all Rodin. I agree with others that the shop is a bit expensive.

Absolutely Love Musee Rodin!!!. Musee Rodin is one of my favorite stops while in Paris!! Art lovers will enjoy the rich collection of displays, including the Thinker, the Burghers of Calais, the Gates of Hell, and The Kiss. The souvenir shop, on the other hand, is rather small and the items are a bit too expensive. If you are looking for Rodin trinkets, you can find them all over the city for a lot less. An added bonus for the Clark W. Griswald-type travellers: Les Invalides, the Musee of the Armee, and Napoleon's tomb are just a few steps away. You can see all this and Rodin in about half a day.

A cool respite on a hot day. The Rodin Museum provides the perfect antidote to a hot spring day on the crowded streets of Paris. The gardens are well tended with sculptures peeking out from among the plantings. There is a wonderful outside cafe (with seating) for a snack, coffee, hot chocolate or ice cream. It was a tad pricey but having a pain au chocolat and coffee while staring at a few Rodin sculptures makes up for the temporary lightening of the wallet (when the belly is filled and the mind and eyes are enriched than what is money anyway).The house provides a look into the sculptural life of Rodin including his relationship with the (much) younger sculptor, Camille Claudel. There are a few of her works on display; I recommend taking time to look at her work as she was also a skilled sculptor.We used the Museum Pass so were able to bypass the relatively short line.Well worth an artistic and calming break in Paris.

An oasis of calm and beauty. Rodin is one of my favourite sculptors so to see his work in one place was wonderful.There are two parts to the musuem: indoor and outdoor. The outdoor area, the garden, is either free for EU students or a nominal cost (1 euro) and you get to see The Thinker, the Gates of Hell and other famous works, as well as the cafe (more on that later).The indoor part of the musuem costs a bit more but is worth it. The house is in need of repair and restoration but is still beautiful when you look at its bones and features. It is easy to see how wonderful it must have been.The cafe is busy and although a bit pricey, yummy. If you can score seating outside on a beautiful day, you are indeed fortunate. Many people brought a picnic lunch and ate al fresco on one of the many benches available throughout the garden grounds. Unlike the frenzied, camera-flashing, tourist gawking musuems you find yourself in when touring Paris, this musuem is delightfully under-stated. Well worth visiting.

Skip it.. Gardens in flux. Numerous statues with no explanations. Why spend the time when so much other fine art In Paris. Spend your time with the Louvre sculptures. Gardens OK but see the Jardin de Luxembourg instead.

Beautiful and relaxing. Musee Rodin is a perfect spot if you need a little break from tourist crowds. There are no lines at the entrance, no hordes of shorts-wearing backpack-carrying tourist zombies inside. Museum itself is a charming two-story house where you can find all the smaller-scale Rodin work, including the beautiful Danaid. The most enjoyable part are probably the gardens where you can see the Gates of Hell, the Thinker, etc, etc. The entrance to the gardens is only €1! Perfect choice on a nice sunny day, and a must for all art lovers!

A true appreciation of art. The Musee Rodin is a museum dedicated to French sculptor Auguste Rodin. If you only have a few days in Paris I suggest going to see the Musee du Louvre and the Musee d'Orsay, however if time permits Musee Rodin is a sight not to be missed. Situated on picturesque grounds the museum itself is a work of art. The building is a hotel converted to display all the Rodin's sculptors. The Thinker, The Kiss and the epic Gates of Hell are all beautifully dark and thought provoking. I highly recommend this museum if you have the time, and the appreciation for this type of art.

Lovely. I went here on my own, and it was lovely. The museum had many of Rodin's fantastic works to look at and admire, but there were alot of people to compete with. Gardens are beautiful to walk around. Definitely would recommend going here.
Love this museum. I love The Thinker! You can see the Eiffel Tower in the background. Inside and outside museum.

Great place for a relaxing afternoon. Full price admission was 6E, but admission to only the gardens was 1E.  In the back of the gardens are some great wooden loungers to relax in away from the crowds of the city (but get there early to claim one).The gardens are well worth the stroll, but the museum itself is in fair condition. The collection is in good condition, but the building has several dozen patches over the parquet floor that can be trip hazards.

peaceful and relaxing. İndeed one of the best museum in Paris , it has a great relaxing garden and statues Also there is a musuem store inside that u may buy books,pens,tshirts etc.. Have a nice day in Paris :)

The Best. A must see for anyone going to Paris. Musee Rodin is a wonderful place to spend a sunny afternoon strolling the grounds and seeing the beautiful sculptures. Even with large crowds there is plently of space and you never feel rushed. Take the time to sit and admire the beauty that surrounds you and enjoy a glass of wine or lunch in the garden cafe. It is like being in a world of your own!We will most certainly return here on our next trip to Paris.
Worth dropping by. I tell everyone that if you're in Paris just stop by the Rodin Museum's garden it only costs 1 euro and you get to see arguably the most famous statue in the world

A must see! My favorite museum in Paris.. I loved the Musee Rodin! We spent hours touring the grounds and museum. We were able to spend as much time as we wanted looking at different pieces without being in large crowds like at the Louvre. As a bonus surprise, the Musee Rodin was free the day we went (New Year's Eve). If you do not have time to go inside the museum, pay the 1 Euro fee to tour the gardens and see the works out there. Definitely worth the admission fees.
Well worth the visit. A great museum, both the inside exhibitions and the beautiful gardens. Wish I had more time to wander. Would highly recommend to anyone.

Our favorite museum in Paris. My wife and I found this to be the most enjoyable museum in Paris. We preferred this to the Musee D'orsay and L'Orangerie. The were many sculptures outside in the garden to admire while relaxing, as well as inside the house.

Simply Tastefully Well Done. The venue is unmatched. It's always a rare treat to see an artist's work so lovingly presented in his/her home and garden.
We loved the comfortable surroundings and the generous garden in which to stroll and admire Rodin's work.
Great Museuem. My Favorite: the Burgher of Calais.....wish they had the small bronze reproductions to place in my home.

A relaxing beautiful place.. The gardens at the Musee Rodin are wonderful. On the day we visited it was not crowed, which added to the peaceful ambience. Really enjoyed strolling around, seeing famous sculptures in a fantastic setting. There is a small cafe in the gardens which is tastefully decorated.

Excellent museum, indispensable audio guide.. The Rodin Museum was probably the most satisfying museum experience I had while in Paris. It's certainly smaller than The Louvre or Musee d'Orsay and therefore easier to wrap your mind around in a single visit. I knew next to nothing about Rodin before my stop and left with a whole new appreciation of him and sculpture art in general.Easily found just to the east of Hotel des Invalides, the museum is partly inside an old 18th century mansion and partly spread throughout the surrounding gardens. The museum is laid out in chronological order, starting inside with his early works and moving through the Belgian period, portraits of women, and public monuments to name a few. Larger works (The Kiss, Eve, the Gates of Hell) are given their own room and thorough explanations. The outdoor gardens include many of these figures set against a more natural background. I found the audio guide a great help and thought it added to the experience tremendously. Overall time for the visit was about 3 hours.Highly recommended and one of my top five experiences while in the city.

Fantastic Garden!. Can't speak for the actual Museum because we didn't go in but the garden alone was well worth the trip. The best part is that access to the garden is only one euro and if you are going to be in Paris for a while, you can get a yearly pass for 15 euro! Good variety of sculptures but not so many that they overwhelm the space.

Idyllic. Involves a taxi or a little walk. Not part of the main tourist drag but not to be missed. the best is the sculpture perfectly placed by the artist himself who lived and worked here for many years on a government pension and rent free in the grand period house perfectly set in the extensive and varied walled garden. The house is worth walking round but if money or time is tight then prefer the outdoor wonders and take tea in the pavilion. I came to paris for many years before I was recommended to this place and now love to go back and back.

Lovely museum !!!!. This is one of these small and charmy museum that everybody, even people who are not very much into arts, will find pleasant and interesting.Museum is very combact, 2 floors with Augiste Rodin's artwork, and some art work of his mistress Camille Claudel. There are a couple of paintings etc from Rodin's personal collections, or item dedicated to him, but the place make visitor not to feel overloaded with exibits and information. Rodin's style helps a lot to that! I visited end of November, and I noticed there were many French visitors,as well as foreigners. This place was busy, but not too crowded. It houses some temporary collections time to time so it becomes quite popular to Paris art lovers, and it's mentioned in guidebooks, so its fame will keep growning I guess.Now, as other people mentioned, high-light of the museum is its lovely garden, with nice plantation, many statues,a small pont, and many benches to seat down and enjoy. I visited on a not-so-sunny day, and I still spend about 1 h and a half in the garden. There is a cafe/restaurant where hot drinks are served on very low prices. There is a decent collection of food items, but I noticed that these are a bit pricey...Full entrance fee for the museum is 6 euros, a very reasonable fee, especially taking into concideration that most Paris attractions are rediculously expensive. You can buy a 12 euro pass to save a couple of euros if you plan to visit Musee d'Orsay on the same day. Musee Rodin is included in the Paris Museum Pass too. Very good value for money.For people who like to visit many attraction on the same day, please note that Invalides are located close by too.

The gardens at the Musee Rodin are not to be missed!. I did love the museum but the gardens captured my heart. The next time I go to Paris, if the weather is good, I plan to go there to read, write or contemplate. The best part is it was only 1 euro for the gardens which I think is a fantastic deal, especially since there are several sculptures in the gardens.

weather permitting ,the most perfect picnic spot you could find. 1 euro into the garden to relax and take in the most amazing statues,gardens and ambience.The indoor collection is well worth a visit and a couple of hours will do both if your not up to the gruelling hike through the Louvre.

Beautiful grounds. We probably didn't see this in its best light. It was a very hot day at a very tourist-y time of year. We paid to tour the actual museum but I don't htink that was necessary. The grounds were the most stunning and I think are available to tour at a reduced. In that respect, it's a steal.

an intimate visit with Rodin. This is my favourite museum in Paris and in the 10 days I stayed in Paris I returned twice. Each time I rented the audio and slowly wound my way through the gallery and into the garden enjoying the descriptions of his unique sculptures. The quiet "Meditation Garden" was a serene oasis where I spent a half hour writing in my travel journal. Luck would have it and the sun shone each day so I was able to enjoy the outdoor cafe sipping a cup of hot chocolate and a beautifully flaky chocolate croissant while enjoying the company of half a dozen small, hungry birds. The friendly staff, beautiful grounds, wonderfully clear audio narration and a wonderful collection of the best of Rodin makes this one of Paris' best museums ! maryshepherdpottery@yahoo.com

Great sculptures, not so great museum. The Rodin museum was one that I thought was average. There are 2 floors in the main building with special exhibits then housed in the building where you get tickets and have a bookstore. Obviously the pieces displayed are magnificant but for the museum itself, I wasn't that impressed. We went on an August afternoon and while not an really hot day, the museum was stifling. No air conditioning or even ventilation in the rooms and with the crowds everywhere , we had less then desirable viewing experience. The gardens are ok but I feel it doesn't deserve the raves of the other reviews. However, my standards may now be skewed by recently visiting the gardens of Versaille and Vaux-le-Vicomte. There are perhaps two dozen statues scattered around with minimal documentation and then only in French. I did like the area at the back of the garden where one can actually sit on the grass - there were even some lounges to use. We did have a great cup of tea and cappuccino in the small cafe located on the grounds.Overall, a fan of Rodin would love this museum but for the average person, I think an average experience.

Subdued but magnificent !. If you like the gardens of Paris and are looking for new places to go, try these gardens at the Rodin Museum. I think one thing that makes this one good is the way it works with the mansion as an urban garden, although it was originally the private residential garden for Rodin. There are many sculptures throughout the garden - you can see quite a bit of work without entering the museum. This is one of those places where you feel like you've discovered something off the beaten path. A bit low-key compared to the other big gadens & parks, but really well done.It's worth noting that the gardens have a small cafe. You can see a menu on the French version of the museum website : http://www.musee-rodin.fr/accueil.htm > Jardins > Information Practiques > La cafétéria > menu. Even though you have to go through the French side of the website the menu is in both French & English ! And if you don't go to the cafe you could probably slip in a light lunch & a drink and have a discrete bench picnic - just a suggestion -
Refuge in Paris. Very tranquil and fascinating museum, right next door to Invalides.Lovely Salon de The under the trees in the gardens.

Visit the gardens, skip the museum.... ...unless you're a hardcore Rodin fan. The gardens really are wonderful--"The Thinker" is here, as well as "The Burghers of Calais" (along with individual studies from that piece). However, the building is pretty shopworn--a bit dingy, a bit cluttered. The displays inside are in desperate need of real curation; one gets the sense that nothing has really been done to contextualize the work or the artist since the original setup.

Fabulous!. I recommend this museum to all travelers, the sculptures are magnificent, the museum is wonderful. I visited today, it was a very hot day, I had the opportunity to enjoy the shade that the garden offered and then enjoy the coolness of the museum. Even non Rodin fans would have difficulty criticizing any part of the Musee Rodin, exquisite art, fabulous gardens and helpful and attentive staff, I believe that in the hustle and bustle of Paris this offers a welcome break whilst still absorbing amazing art and atmosphere. The location if perfect, right next to an underground station, with a wonderful restaurant on the corner to enjoy a refreshment before or after visiting.

Nice enough. This museum was pleasant and the grounds lovely. It was nice to see the “Thinker” in the garden. Unless you are a huge Rodin fan or have extra time, I don’t believe you should go out your way to see this museum. The Louvre, Orsay, and L'Orangerie should be on your list first. I thought it was pleasant enough.

Beautiful art in a beautiful museum.. The Thinker. The Gates of Hell. Both outside in the front lawn! You would think they would be tucked back and behind glass. This was a beautiful exhibit in a beautiful setting. Skip the headphones put pay the extra euro for access to the gardens. Wander around, find sculptures, and enjoy a great artist's work.

The most relaxing and enjoyable museum. We went to the Rodin the day after walking through most of Le Louvre. It was one of five museums we visited, including the d'Orsay and the Centre Pompidou. We were so relieved when we got to the gardens and could move about without crowds, enjoying each sculpture at our leisure. It was lovely and peaceful. We were both fans of Rodin, so we sprang the extra five euros to go inside the museum. But for those who just want to see his larger-than-life sculptures, including The Thinker, I would just spend one euro to see the gardens. They were certainly the highlight for us.

1 Euro for the Garden is a steal!. I went to Musee Rodin on my last day in Paris. I read that just going in the garden was cheap. 1 euro to do this is such a steal (the thinker statue with the eiffel tower in the back is a perfect picture). I had a museum pass the first day I was there, but didn't pay to go through the whole museum. If you have the pass, then you should definitely go hit this museum. If you are trying to be cheap, then you could probably spend a half day to whole day in the garden. There are chairs in the very back to lounge in.

Nice break from the crowds. This was a nice change of pace from the busy museums and churches. Calm, quiet, relaxing with beautiful art and gardens. Covered by the museum pass. I would go if you have time. Not a must see but interesting.
The Garden is awesome!. Ok- we went after opening times and the museum wasn't open but I definitely recommend a sunbathe in their sculpture garden.What a chill out:)

Museum gardens are amazing!. I visited the Rodin based on reviews from TA and was not disappointed. Metro stop is Varenne and directional signage is excellent. I was able to skip the queue with the Museum Pass, but the line wasn't terribly long at 1pm on Tuesday anyway. I opted not to purchase the audio tour (4 Euros) as I preferred to take in the serenity of the gardens. Pick up a complimentary map and guide and stroll outside.Of course "The Thinker" is high on everyone's list and it's immediately to your right after exiting the interior. The gardens also offer beautiful views of the Invalides Dome Church and Eiffel Tower. Many of Rodin's works are on display here to be taken in at your own pace. I noted some people on the array of benches that were enjoying the sunshine and sketching, so I took their lead, read for a while, and took a 30 minute snooze to recharge for the rest of the day and evening.Don't miss the "Gates of Hell." either. It's an amazing sculpture!

good museum. Was recommend by my boss to visit this museum – I only knew about The Thinker and was pleasantly surprised about his other works! He has so many sculptures I wondered if he actually had time to sleep! This is a museum well worth visiting – just a 15 minute queue to get in but they do sell a combined Rodin and D’orsay museum pass which makes it cheaper but mind you go in with plenty of time – we went in a Friday but both musems close around 5 ish whereas the Louvre closes late on a Friday so can be confusing!

Do not miss this!. So pleased that we took Tripadvisor's advice to visit this gem! Counting the pennies, we decided to just visit the gardens - superb value for only one euro! We spent a couple of hours here (including time at the cafe) and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. Lots of statues, lovely views towards Les Invalides and the Eiffel Tower and beautifully laid out gardens... what more can I say? Just go - you will love it!

Amazing Rodin. I would recommend the Musee Rodin. It was very impressive for seeing Rodin's work. Go early in the morning to avoid lines. Do not get the audio as it is confusing and not all that helpful. The museum is the outside garden and then the house. There is also a permanent collection inside by the ticket counter. Do not do this part unless you are totally a Rodin enthusiast. It is not worth the extra money or time. The museum pass can be used here.

peaceful relaxing and beautiful. Even though we're not really art lovers this museum was well worth the stop and we ended up staying here longer than some other larger museum (such as Orsay).  The gardens spread out the statues nicely so that you can see them easily without ever being crowded, there are numerous benches to sit on, a nice cafeteria with tables (and rest rooms) to the side of the garden. Inside of course it's a little tighter but still plenty of space given to each of the works, the Kiss being an obvious favorite inside, Gates of Hell, and the Thinker ouside. it's included in the museum pass, even if it weren't it's worth the admission and just a nice break from some of the more hectic spots you're likely to visit.

so peaceful. I love this museum! It’s so different from all the other museums in Paris. Some of the sculptures are kept inside a mansion on the grounds and some are kept outside in the rose gardens. The gardens are the best part, I even laid down for awhile to read a book. The roses are gorgeous and Rodin’s work is truly impressive. Go later in the day and you won’t have to wait in line.

Nice change from stuffy museums. Went to the Rodin Museum in late June. It is a wonderful change from stuffy museums. As soon as you pay, you go straight to the garden. This has a beautiful garden with The Thinker and The Gates of Hell, with a house with more sculptures inside. Anyone under 18 is free. It was a somewhat hot day when we went, so a few extra benches in the shade would have been nice. At least with a smaller and beautiful museum you wouldn't get lost as you do in the Louvre. The sculptures are amazing.

Musee Rodin. I agree with the reviewer who recommended the Rodin Museum for an arrival day destination...The Musee d'Orsay is too much in my opinion for jetlagged eyes and feet to cover upon arrival..It demands a rested approach...In addition to the photographic opportunities the Rodin affords, it's simply a nice place to sit in the garden and enjoy the incredible beauty of the garden and sculptures all about...I've had delicious lunches at the cafe in the garden...Ham from the Savoie, gruyere cheese, and bread from Poilane...You can buy a museum pass at the entrance ticket kiosk and that line is not that long in my recollection....Then you'll have it for the rest of your Paris visit to use in other museums and attractions..It will save you lots of time at other museums like the d'Orsay where the lines are also long and you'll probably visit more attractions simply because you have the pass and more time to use it...It comes in varying lengths...like 1-day, 3-day, and maybe a 5-day...I always take the 3-day....You must enter the date of first use but don't do it til you're actually entering the first museum...Then the meter is running...So you'll be busy going to places for a day or three...

One of our favorites!. My husband and I visited Paris in May and the Musee Rodin was one of our favorites. On the morning of our first full day after arriving from Boston, we attempted the Musee D'Orsay. The crowds and jet lag hit us about 30 minutes into our visit there so, feeling quite overwhelmed, we quickly finished our self-guided tour and headed to the Musee Rodin gardens. Wow! In our fatigue, this was just what we needed! We grabbed a drink at the snack stand in the gardens and had the most delightful time sitting in the shade and strolling through the gardens. They are so beautiful and such a fun way to see such amazing works of art! Some of my favorite pictures from our trip to Paris were taken in the front of The Thinker with the Eiffel Tower in the background. After an hour or so of enjoying the gardens, we toured the inside of the museum. It was also a treat! The Musee Rodin gardens are a "must see" - they are an oasis! As a side note, however, we were quite glad to have the Museum Pass as the line for non pass holders was all the way down the street.

A Gem!. First - get the Paris Museum Pass before you go. We bought ours in London at the Eurostar Terminal. The pass will get you by all the lines. They are also available at tourist information booths and museums throughout paris.When we were there at the end of April, the line went around the corner, we bypassed it and walked in the door to the left of the entrance. No waiting!Don't let my description of the line deter you from going. It was not at all crowded inside. In fact, we speculated that they intentionally controlled the number of people inside and thus the lines for non-pass holders.It is very peaceful inside and beautiful. The gardens are lovely, there's a little cafe in the back of the property and the sculpture is fantastic. We walked from our Rue Cler hotel. This place truly is a gem!

An outstanding Museum Experience. On recent trip to Paris, my husband and visited the Rodin Museum and we were both very pleased with the whole experience. The museum is very close to Les Invalides and is easily accessed by Metro. Hotel Biron is a rococo mansion with about sixteen exhibit rooms. Each room has only two or three sculptures so you can enjoy each piece without feeling overwhelmed or over-stimulated. All the larger than life sculptures are carefully situated throughout the beautiful gardens, so you can stroll at your leisure through the grounds as you view Rodin's magnificent works. We rented the audio devices available and found them an excellent way to fill in the blanks of our knowledge of Rodin and his works. Learning the background of each work made the experience that much richer. But best of all, the grounds are so peaceful and idllyic. We were there in early December and the gardens were still lovely, not as beautiful as they would be in spring or summer but still colourful and lovely. I would highly recommend a visit to this museum. Visit the web site and then visit the real thing...you are in for a treat!!!

Excellent!!!. What is so weird is that we arrive and are like, "oh he's the one that did this sculpture"! I love the famous ones such as the Thinker and Gates of Hell. Absolutely spectacular. There is also some rooms when you first enter museum of a Japanese artist. I'm really bad at remembering names though so I can't remember who but he had some quite interesting sketches. Rodin sculptures are not to be missed though. They are remarkable.

Not to be missed. Although I'm not a huge sculpture fan, it was difficult not to appreciate the beautiful, famous and familiar pieces throughout this museum and its grounds. The building itself is a little worn, with some creaky floors, but the art within is clearly world-class and not to be missed. The location is an easy walk from the Rue Cler area and Napoleon's Tomb.

A Hidden Gem. Of all the museums in Paris, this is perhaps the most underrated. The museum is actually housed in Rodin's former house! "The Thinker" sits right outside in his sculpture garden! Because most of the pieces are displayed as they were during Rodin's lifetime, this museum offers a much more personal experience than other museums. I can't recommend it enough.

The best!. The Rodin museum is absolutely, without a doubt, my favorite museum in the world! (Granted I am a huge fan of Rodin and, more particularly, Camille Claudel.) I block out a day to spend there every time I'm in Paris. (This would probably be too much for most people. I'm a little obsessive.) The location is convenient to other "things to see", while the gardens are beautiful and serene. You will never know you're in the city once inside the walls. The collection of Rodin's work is amazing and it also houses the majority of the remaining works of Camille Claudel, who was Rodin's apprentice and lover. If you are a fan of sculpture, this is a MUST SEE!

BRILLIANT!!!!. I am an art student in Northampton and i LOVE Rodins work. Even if your not an art fan i know you'll love it. His work is incredible and to see the amount they have on show is breath taking. I am going again next week as i loved it so much. I recommend it to ANYONE.

"Think" with the dome of Les Invalides in the background. The statue of "The Thinker" is in the garden, so you can do the same pose and get the glorious dome of Les Invalides in the background. The gardens are lovely, and there is an outdoor cafe under dense shade. The gift shop has nice items at good prices, especially lovely postcards of Rodin's sculptures. Don't miss the chandeliers on the second floor, stunning!!!

Great Museum and the Grounds are Terrific!. If you enjoy Rodin's work then you will find this museum great. I went on a sunny morning and ate lunch in the garden. Marvelous and the food was very, very good.
Rodin Museum - A Must!!!. The Rodin museum is a must see! The grounds are beautiful and the collection is magnificent. If you appreciate Monsieur Rodin, then you simply must visit if ever in Paris!

One of my Favorite Places. The Rodin Museum and Sculpture Garden is one of my favorite secret places in Paris. It is charming and relaxing and a wonderful way to spend an hour or two. Even if you are not well-versed in Rodin's work, you are bound to recognize some pieces (the thinker, the kiss) and enjoy some others. Definitely a worthwhile stop for anyone who is going to spend more than a day or 2 in Paris!

A different sort of museum. Visited the Rodin museum with my wife April 2003. I'm not much of a museum buff but this was a very pleasant visit (not least because it's next to the army museum at Les Invalides). The formal gardens (where you will find the thinker) are tranquil. Inside the lovely house you will find the kiss. A nice suprise was the Van Gogh, Monet and Renoir paintings upstairs. Reasonably priced at 5 euros per adult. Under 25's are 3 euros and under 18's are free!
